('60', 0, 1, 2, 42) 1. LETTER TO K. S. RAMABHADRA AYYAR March 10, 1933
('60', 0, 2, 3, 93) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter of 22nd ultimo.
('60', 0, 2, 4, 141) I do not encourage your advances because your letters create no favourable impression on me.
('60', 0, 2, 5, 234) They seem to be unbalanced and if what you write creates a bad impression on me your visit is not likely to improve matters, hence I do not like the idea of your wasting your money in travelling here and then wasting your time and mine.
('60', 0, 2, 6, 471) I assure you that I have not a single minute to spare.
('60', 0, 3, 7, 526) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('60', 0, 3, 8, 548) K. S. RAMABHADRA AYYAR ADVOCATE, HIGH COURT LUZ MYLAPURE, MADRAS

('60', 0, 5, 10, 642) 2. LETTER TO SURENDRA MOHAN BHATTACHARYA March 10, 1933
('60', 0, 6, 11, 698) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter for which I thank you.
('60', 0, 6, 12, 753) You remind me of slave owners of old who used to recount their services to their slaves in that they gave them food and shelter some what after the style in which they gave both to their cattle, only the treatment of the slaves was in many respects worse than that of their cattle and in no respect better, and it is quite evident to me that you do not even take the trouble of knowing what educated and religiously minded Hindus have done and are doing for Harijans whom they do not consider in any shape or form lower than themselves but regard them as their own kith and kin.
('60', 0, 7, 13, 1332) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('60', 0, 7, 14, 1354) SURENDRA MOHAN BHATTACHARYA VEDANTA SHASTRI VILLAGE ALGI P.O. MADHABOLI DT.

('60', 1, 7, 10, 1966) March 10, 1933
('60', 1, 8, 11, 1981) DEAR FRIEND, I have not been able to deal with your letter of 23rd February earlier.
('60', 1, 8, 12, 2066) Please excuse me.
('60', 1, 8, 13, 2084) 1 think that you are quite right in your contention that if the Untouchability Abolition Bill is passed, Temple entry Bill is unneces sary.
('60', 1, 8, 14, 2224) If you can therefore get the Abolition Bill passed in the Mysore Asse mbly, it would be unnecessary to press for the passage of the Temple entry Bill so far as Mysore is concerned.
('60', 1, 8, 15, 2405) But you will see to it that the interpretation of the Abolition Bill is accepted by the sanatanists.
('60', 1, 8, 16, 2506) If that is achieved the rest may be left to the ripening of public opinion.
('60', 1, 9, 17, 2582) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('60', 2, 1, 2, 2725) 5. LETTER TO E. LINDSAY
('60', 2, 2, 3, 2749) March 10, 1933
('60', 2, 3, 4, 2764) DEAR SISTER, I was delighted to have your letter and to have the beautiful anecdote about the social worker.
('60', 2, 3, 5, 2873) I have just glanced through the lines you have sent me.
('60', 2, 3, 6, 2929) Did I never tell you that I was very stupid at judging poetry?
('60', 2, 3, 7, 2992) I shall therefore need to read your lines half a dozen times before their beauty and message will dawn upon me.
('60', 2, 3, 8, 3104) Mahadev is a poet and he has no difficulty about making up his mind when he sees a piece of beautiful poetry.
('60', 2, 3, 9, 3214) I shall therefore seek his assistance.
('60', 2, 3, 10, 3253) He is doing his work only within a few feet of me, but we are so immersed in our tasks that we have hardly time to talk about so many common things and interests apart from the task in front of us.
('60', 2, 4, 11, 3451) Yours sincerely, MADAM E. LINDSAY BALLIOL COLLEGE OXFORD

('60', 3, 6, 8, 4490) 8. LETTER TO USHAKANTA MUKHOPADHYA
('60', 3, 7, 9, 4525) March 10, 1933
('60', 3, 8, 10, 4540) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your interesting letter which I have read care fully.
('60', 3, 8, 11, 4623) There is no difficulty about understanding your letter.
('60', 3, 8, 12, 4679) The prescription that you have suggested is being followed in all the parts of the country.
('60', 3, 8, 13, 4771) Sanskrit literature has been translated in the vernacu lars and is accessible to even the illiterate masses.
('60', 3, 8, 14, 4880) As far as the law is concerned, there is no question of compel ling anybody to regard any other as untouchable.
('60', 3, 8, 15, 4992) The object of the Bill is to withdraw the sanction of the law to a custom which cannot be defended by any ordinary rule of morality.
('60', 3, 8, 16, 5125) The law is simply meant to give the reformer the scope of bringing the message to those who will listen to it.
('60', 3, 9, 17, 5236) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('60', 3, 9, 18, 5258) USHAKANTA MUKHOPADHYA 12 MUKHERJIPARA LANE KALIGHAT, CALCUTTA

('60', 7, 6, 8, 10532) 16. LETTER TO NRISINHPRASAD K. BHATT
('60', 7, 7, 9, 10569) March 10, 1933 If the Hindus of Bhavnagar pass a resolution by an overwhelming majority asserting that there are no classes among Hindus who are descendants of the original Shudras or who should be regarded as untouchable, I would see no moral objection to the admission of Antyajas despite the particular clause in the agreement being against their being admitted.
('60', 7, 7, 10, 10935) For, if such a resolution were passed, there would be no community which could be described as Antyajas.
('60', 7, 7, 11, 11040) We often find contradictory rules being followed in the diffe rent branches of the same institution.
('60', 7, 7, 12, 11141) Since the prohibition applies to residence, I see no moral objection to the admission of Antyajas to the school.
('60', 7, 7, 13, 11254) On the contrary, it would show disregard for dharma to deny admission to them.
('60', 7, 8, 14, 11333) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: S.N. 20533
('60', 8, 0, 1, 11378) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 9
('60', 8, 1, 2, 11420) 17. LETTER TO NARAHARI PARIKH March 10, 1933
('60', 8, 2, 3, 11465) NARAHARI, I could read your letter of the 4th only today.
('60', 8, 2, 4, 11523) Your question is good.
('60', 8, 2, 5, 11546) One who is convinced that there is no other way but brahmacharya should know that the right thing for him is to strive exclusively to discover the means of perfecting it and should continue his experiments to that end in the faith that large numbers of people will adopt it one day.
('60', 8, 2, 6, 11829) He should also be convinced at the same time that artificial means of birth control are dangerous from every point of view and are bound to loosen morals.
('60', 8, 2, 7, 11984) Even if we assume that people will have to suffer during the interval before brahmacharya comes to be widely accepted, I see nothing wrong in that.
('60', 8, 2, 8, 12132) Like an individual, a society also will reap as it sows.
('60', 8, 2, 9, 12189) But God is merciful.
('60', 8, 2, 10, 12210) There is mercy even in those of His acts which we regard as punishment.
('60', 8, 2, 11, 12282) When the birth rate is high, the death rate also will be proportionately high.
('60', 8, 2, 12, 12361) Mankind, therefore, will live on.
('60', 8, 2, 13, 12395) It is true that such life will not be happy, and it is best that it should be so.
('60', 8, 2, 14, 12477) This knowledge also will persuade people to adopt brahmacharya, for even a little experience of it will show that, when it has become habitual, it is a source of much greater happiness than indulgence can give.
('60', 8, 2, 15, 12688) In order that the world may go on satisfactorily, isn’t it also necessary to obey the other laws of God?
('60', 8, 2, 16, 12793) One such law is that nobody has a right to take more than the minimum he needs for his physical maintenance.
('60', 8, 2, 17, 12902) If everyone obeyed this law, there would be no starvation even if brahmacharya was not observed by large numbers.
('60', 8, 2, 18, 13016) Physical labour is not confined to work in the fields.
('60', 8, 2, 19, 13071) Every farmer ought to use his hands and feet fully, especially the hands.
('60', 8, 2, 20, 13145) In a country where the farmers have no subsidiary industry, they become almost like animals.
('60', 8, 2, 21, 13238) If the company of animals is necessary, the experience of using tools is equally necessary.
('60', 8, 2, 22, 13330) If all men cultivated manual skill, then even if the population went on increasing, within limits, everybody would have enough food to eat, cloth to cover his or her body with and protection against heat and cold in a home.
('60', 8, 2, 23, 13554) Remember the meaning of varnadharma which I have been explaining these days.
('60', 8, 2, 24, 13631) I think I have answered all your questions, but write to me again if I have not.
('60', 8, 3, 25, 13712) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 9056

('60', 9, 2, 3, 13847) March 10, 1933
('60', 9, 3, 4, 13862) NARANDAS, I enclose with this letters for Narahari, Moolchand and Champa.

('60', 9, 3, 9, 14144) Preserve it there.
('60', 9, 3, 10, 14163) I have, however, informed him that, if you consent he must go to the Ashram but that he should see his wife, and if she and the children are fit and are willing to stay in the Ashram, all of them should go.
('60', 9, 3, 11, 14370) I will now let you know what he decides as soon as he informs me.
('60', 9, 3, 12, 14436) Parachure Shastri also will keep you informed.
('60', 9, 3, 13, 14483) The final decision will be based wholly on considerations of dharma.
('60', 9, 3, 14, 14552) All of us, therefore, may rest assured that it will be for our good.
('60', 9, 3, 15, 14621) I hope you got my previous letters in which I wrote to you about Lakshmi.
('60', 9, 3, 16, 14695) I wrote one yesterday and one the day before.

('60', 10, 1, 2, 15316) 20. LETTER TO MOOLCHAND AGRAWAL March 10, 1933
('60', 10, 2, 3, 15363) BHAI MOOLCHAND, Your query has already been answered in Harijan.
('60', 10, 3, 4, 15428) The exercise of the tongue and the pen cannot be regarded physical activity.
('60', 10, 3, 5, 15505) In this context it means only labour by hands and feet.
('60', 10, 3, 6, 15561) If people do not labour on the land and then starve, what can the brain do?
('60', 10, 3, 7, 15637) At that time whosoever cultivates even a little will be the saviour.
('60', 10, 3, 8, 15706) What is the use of a speech when the house is on fire?
('60', 10, 3, 9, 15761) You will need water to fight the fire, and so on.
('60', 10, 3, 10, 15811) It does not mean that brain work has no utility.
('60', 10, 3, 11, 15860) It only means that ideas of those alone will bear fruit who appreciate the significance of manual labour and themselves undertake it.
('60', 10, 3, 12, 15994) Both types of work should proceed side by side and the best principle is to earn one’s bread from manual labour and to employ the intellect for service only.
('60', 10, 3, 13, 16152) That will secure a perfect balance.
('60', 10, 3, 14, 16188) You may take it that the Ashram was founded with the same objective.
('60', 10, 3, 15, 16257) You have to grasp this fact if you wish to benefit from a stay in the Ashram.
('60', 10, 4, 16, 16335) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 770
('60', 10, 5, 17, 16375) 21. NOTES
('60', 10, 6, 18, 16385) WHAT THEY TEACH
('60', 10, 7, 19, 16401) The reader should study the tell tale figures, collected by the Editor and published in another column, of the ‘depressed classes’, otherwise called the ‘exterior castes’ of the Madras Presidency.
('60', 10, 7, 20, 16598) They have eighty six sub divisions among them.
('60', 10, 7, 21, 16645) The sanatanists would claim that they are all untouchables by birth!!!
('60', 10, 7, 22, 16716) What were they before they were so classified in the census?
('60', 10, 7, 23, 16777) It is interesting, too, to note that the criterion of untouchability has not been the same for all the Provinces, nor the same in every part of the same Province, nor is the untouchable of Madras necessarily untouchable in Bombay or Bengal.
('60', 10, 7, 24, 17018) The more one studies these figures, the stronger will grow the conviction that this untouchability is purely man made.
('60', 10, 7, 25, 17137) The census superintendents have been the sole judges.
('60', 10, 7, 26, 17191) The reader will note also that the various Governments have differed in their views as to the
('60', 10, 8, 27, 17285) 1 Perhaps Gandhiji meant Harijan Sevak as no answer is identified in Harijan.
('60', 11, 0, 1, 17363) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 11, 1, 2, 17404) classification.
('60', 11, 1, 3, 17420) If the untouchables are God made, why all these differences?
('60', 11, 1, 4, 17481) The time is coming when there will be a bid on the part of caste Hindus for being classified as ‘untouchables’.
('60', 11, 1, 5, 17593) Signs have already begun to appear on the horizon.
('60', 11, 1, 6, 17644) If untouchables were God made, we should be able unfailingly to distinguish them without effort from the rest, as we distinguish one species from another.
('60', 11, 1, 7, 17799) And who will answer for these sub divisions if not caste Hindus?
('60', 11, 1, 8, 17864) If they will give up untouchability, there is every hope of untouchables giving up the sub untouchability among themselves.
('60', 11, 1, 9, 17988) A GRADUATE’S DIFFICULTY A graduate correspondent wants to know why I say that the practice of untouchability is common to all mankind and religions and that it is a necessary institution.
('60', 11, 1, 10, 18176) When we perform natural functions involving uncleanness or have unclean diseases, we are untouchable till we have become clean.
('60', 11, 1, 11, 18304) The extent of untouchability and the methods of becoming clean no doubt vary among the nations, but the practice of such untouchability, be its extent ever so small, is common to all, including the so called savage nations.
('60', 11, 1, 12, 18528) It is a sound hygienic rule when it is intelligently observed.
('60', 11, 1, 13, 18591) But it was reserved to modern Hinduism to brand a person asuntouchable by birth and call him an offspring of sin.
('60', 11, 1, 14, 18705) It is a most tragic spectacle that a religion which boasts that ahimsa is the highest thing in life should carry vindictiveness into the other world.
('60', 11, 1, 15, 18855) It is against this insane untouchability that I have invited all Hindus who are proud of their faith and jealous of its purity to wage relentless war.
('60', 11, 1, 16, 19006) The same correspondent further asks, “Does not your varnadh arma deprive people of all chances of rise in the social scale?
('60', 11, 1, 17, 19130) Should not everyone have the permission to follow what occupation he likes?” According to my conception of varna, all inequality is ruled out of life.
('60', 11, 1, 18, 19281) Inequality of intellect or in material possessions ought not to mean inequality of social status.
('60', 11, 1, 19, 19379) I do most emphatically maintain that man is not made to choose his occupation for ‘rising in the social scale’.
('60', 11, 1, 20, 19491) He is made to serve his fellow men and earn his bread by the sweat of his brow.
('60', 11, 1, 21, 19571) And since the primary wants of all are the same, all labour should carry the same value.
('60', 11, 1, 22, 19660) This law Hinduism discovered and called the law of varna, and carried it out in practice more or less perfectly with amazing success.
('60', 11, 1, 23, 19794) What we see today in Hinduism is its caricature.
('60', 11, 1, 24, 19843) It is my certain conviction that obedience to that law alone can save the perishing world.
('60', 11, 1, 25, 19934) Its conscious recognition means contentment and consequent freeing Of human energy for the moral uplift.
('60', 11, 1, 26, 20039) Its disregard spells
('60', 12, 0, 1, 20060) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 13
('60', 12, 1, 2, 20103) unhealthy discontent, greed, cut throat competition and moral stagna tion ending in spiritual suicide.
('60', 12, 1, 3, 20206) This law, as I understand it, is not and never has been a mere ceremonial rule regulating the restrictions on eating and marrying.
('60', 12, 1, 4, 20337) WHAT IS SPIRITUAL PROGRESS?
('60', 12, 1, 5, 20365) “When you write about the spirit, the spiritual progress of Harijans, what do you mean?
('60', 12, 1, 6, 20453) And why is such progress of the world retarded because that of Harijans is?
('60', 12, 1, 7, 20529) Why is the spiritual progress of Harijans retarded if they are not admitted to temples?
('60', 12, 1, 8, 20617) “ —asks a persistent correspondent who has many other questions which need not engage us just now.
('60', 12, 1, 9, 20716) Spirit is that moral being which informs the human body and which is imperishable.
('60', 12, 1, 10, 20799) Spiritual progress is that which promotes the realization of that imperishable essence.
('60', 12, 1, 11, 20887) What retards the progress of my neighbour must retard mine.
('60', 12, 1, 12, 20947) India is a big neighbour of other parts of the world.
('60', 12, 1, 13, 21001) India’s spiritual progress cannot but be retarded if that of forty million Harijans and, therefore, of the two hundred and thirty million Hindus is.
('60', 12, 1, 14, 21150) As to temples, I have discussed elsewhere 1 in this issue what a large part they play in the life of mankind.
('60', 12, 1, 15, 21260) Spirit itself is capable of intellectual dissection only up to a point.
('60', 12, 1, 16, 21332) It transcends reason, hence it is a matter of faith.
('60', 12, 1, 17, 21385) Even so are places of worship matters of faith in the last resort.
('60', 12, 1, 18, 21452) THE BENGALI “HARIJAN” Two issues of the Bengali Harijan are already out.
('60', 12, 1, 19, 21525) It is publis hed in the form of a magazine with an attractive cover with a Harijan woman carrying a basket of refuse on her head.
('60', 12, 1, 20, 21655) It is published under the auspices of the Khadi Pratishthan, College Square, Calcutta, and the annual subscription is Rs. 4 including postage, and Rs. 3 without.
('60', 12, 1, 21, 21817) The first and second issues contain either full translations or substance of all the articles that have hitherto appeared in the English edition.
('60', 12, 1, 22, 21963) It contains also translations of some of my previous writings on Hindu religion and editorials or editorial notes from Satisbabu’s pen, such as, “Result of Neglect”, “Solution of Some Problems of Untouchability”, “The Sanatanists’ Prayer”, “Responsibility of Municipality”, “Depressed Classes and Untouchability”.
('60', 12, 1, 23, 22277) It came out with 2,000 copies the first week, all of which were sold out.
('60', 12, 1, 24, 22351) It came out with 3,000 the second week.

('60', 13, 1, 2, 22565) 22. A TRUE SERVANT
('60', 13, 2, 3, 22584) Experience that is being daily gained shows that the service of Harijans is perhaps the hardest of all services.
('60', 13, 2, 4, 22697) There are to my know ledge many girls and grown up women performing daily personal service.
('60', 13, 2, 5, 22789) One of them gives a graphic account of her experience in scavengers’ quarters.
('60', 13, 2, 6, 22868) It was with the greatest difficulty that she could restrain herself from vomiting when she first went to these quarters.
('60', 13, 2, 7, 22989) I am glad women are taking their due share in the movement.
('60', 13, 2, 8, 23049) How are the Harijans living in hideous filth to be served?
('60', 13, 2, 9, 23108) They have no will to be served.
('60', 13, 2, 10, 23140) They curse those who go to their quarters.
('60', 13, 2, 11, 23183) Some even stone workers out of their streets.
('60', 13, 2, 12, 23229) Still they must be served, if we will serve ourselves.
('60', 13, 2, 13, 23284) They must be raised out of this state, if we will raise ourselves.
('60', 13, 2, 14, 23351) We have pressed them down and in so doing wehave gone down ourselves.
('60', 13, 2, 15, 23421) Not everyone can perform this high service.
('60', 13, 2, 16, 23465) Let me sum up the qualities that I have found to be indispen sable in a Harijan servant: He must have true love for Harijans as if they were members of his own family.
('60', 13, 2, 17, 23633) He must have great patience and courage to bear physical injury and insults.
('60', 13, 2, 18, 23710) He must have a character above suspicion and reproach.
('60', 13, 2, 19, 23765) He must be prepared to live on the barest possible sustenance.
('60', 13, 2, 20, 23828) To go through all my correspondence and to have interviews with Harijans, sanatanists and workers is to pass through a raging fire.
('60', 13, 2, 21, 23960) Harijans who have at all become vocal are naturally suspicious and often exacting.
('60', 13, 2, 22, 24043) They are impatient.
('60', 13, 2, 23, 24063) The sanatanists think that the Hinduism of their belief is in danger.
('60', 13, 2, 24, 24133) They have money which they are using freely.
('60', 13, 2, 25, 24178) New organs are daily coming into being.
('60', 13, 2, 26, 24218) They impute motives, make the wildest statements about the reformers and distort the whole movement.
('60', 13, 2, 27, 24319) The workers are not all an ideal team.
('60', 13, 2, 28, 24358) I have seen how one worker can poison the whole atmosphere around him unless he is thoroughly trustworthy and is pure in mind and body.
('60', 13, 2, 29, 24494) If the worker is to satisfy both the Harijans and the sanatanists, he will do so only by showing the highest character, deep humility and great charity.
('60', 13, 2, 30, 24647) In other words, he will have to be a man of religion.
('60', 13, 2, 31, 24701) This is a movement for the purification of religion.
('60', 13, 2, 32, 24754) No religion has ever been purified by brag and bluster or by men with a loose character.
('60', 13, 2, 33, 24843) Workers will have to be most circumspect.
('60', 13, 2, 34, 24885) Sanatanists are
('60', 14, 0, 1, 24901) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 15
('60', 14, 1, 2, 24944) reported to be resorting to goondaism and not to hesitate to resort to force to break up meetings.
('60', 14, 1, 3, 25043) This is no wonder.
('60', 14, 1, 4, 25062) Evil has its own vested interests.
('60', 14, 1, 5, 25097) These are undoubtedly in danger.
('60', 14, 1, 6, 25130) And they will put up a fight for existence.
('60', 14, 1, 7, 25174) Where, therefore, there is any danger of disturbance, the workers must avoid it, even if they have to give up public meetings and the like.
('60', 14, 1, 8, 25314) In such cases they must take the message of deliverance from house to house.
('60', 14, 1, 9, 25391) They must not engage in vain disputations or interpretation of Shastras.
('60', 14, 1, 10, 25464) They must rely upon the unfailing ability of Truth to protect itself.
('60', 14, 1, 11, 25534) Truth is life and it propagates itself the moment it has got a habitation in some human personality.
('60', 14, 1, 12, 25635) Mute conduct is often the most effective speech.
('60', 14, 1, 13, 25684) Workers, therefore, need to have a living faith in themselves and the cause.
('60', 14, 1, 14, 25761) But they know that by themselves they are nothing.
('60', 14, 1, 15, 25812) Therefore, faith in themselves means faith in God.
('60', 14, 1, 16, 25863) Those who empty themselves of all pride and all egotism have the greatest help from God.
('60', 14, 1, 17, 25952) Hinduism will be purified of the evil of untouchability only by the willing sacrifice of thousands of such true servants.
('60', 14, 1, 18, 26074) Harijan, 11 3 1933
('60', 14, 2, 19, 26093) 23. ARE TEMPLES NECESSARY?
('60', 14, 3, 20, 26120) An American correspondent 1 writes: 2
('60', 14, 4, 21, 26158) The great religious truths which the prophets of religion have apprehended and proclaimed have always been lost when their disciples have tried to localize them in priestcraft and temples.
('60', 14, 4, 22, 26347) Truth is too universal to be confined and made sectarian.
('60', 14, 4, 23, 26405) Therefore, I consider temples, mosques and churches to be a prostitution of religion.
('60', 14, 4, 24, 26491) When religion is made a monopoly by the priesthood and temples become vested interests, the great mass of mankind becomes isolated from truth.
('60', 14, 5, 25, 26634) Therefore, I can see no advantage in gaining permission for the Harijans to enter the temples.
('60', 14, 5, 26, 26729) I know that justice demands that they shall have the liberty even to do wrong.
('60', 14, 5, 27, 26808) But if they are to learn the lessons of self respect which will enable them to take an equal place with caste people in the development of the future of our civilization, I think they must learn an independence of all priests and temples.
('60', 14, 5, 28, 27047) When you spoke in Europe that you “formerly considered that God is Truth but now you realized that Truth is God”, you struck a responsive chord in the hearts of all of us, whatever our traditions may have been.
('60', 14, 5, 29, 27258) But when you become a defender of the faith of temple Hinduism, even though it be a purified type, we feel that you have lost
('60', 14, 6, 30, 27384) 1 Presumably Boyd Tucker; vide “Letter to Boyd Tucker”, 23 3 1933. 2 Only extracts from the letter are reproduced here.
('60', 15, 0, 1, 27504) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 15, 1, 2, 27545) your universal appeal, an appeal which I consider you to have made not as a Hindu, but as one of that large body of spiritual minded Hindus who do not look to the temples for the spiritual sustenance of their lives.
('60', 15, 1, 3, 27761) I do not believe that such men are outside the best traditions of Hinduism but are rather in the line of the creators of the religious spirit which has made the spirituality of India her greatest contribution to humanity.
('60', 15, 2, 4, 27983) Nor do I believe that this higher Hinduism is too high for the Harijans, whose spiritual intuitions have never been dulled by our modern type of education.
('60', 15, 2, 5, 28139) Buddha, Chaitanya and Kabir all made a large appeal to this class, and the teachings of Jesus were most appreciated, not by the high and mighty, but by publicans and fishermen, who were outside the pale of respectable society.
('60', 15, 2, 6, 28366) This considered opinion representing a large body of people throughout the world deserves respectful consideration.
('60', 15, 2, 7, 28482) Such an opinion, however, does not appear before me for the first time.
('60', 15, 2, 8, 28554) I have had the privilege and opportunity of discussing this subject with many friends in the light it is presented.
('60', 15, 2, 9, 28670) I can appreciate much of the argument, but I venture to think that it is inconclusive, because it has omitted material facts.
('60', 15, 2, 10, 28796) Some priests are bad.
('60', 15, 2, 11, 28818) Temples, churches and mosques very often show corruption, more often deterioration.
('60', 15, 2, 12, 28902) Nevertheless, it would be impossible to prove that all priests are bad or have been bad and that all churches, temples and mosques are hotbeds of corruption and superstition.
('60', 15, 2, 13, 29077) Nor does the argument take note of this fundamental fact that no faith has done without a habitation; and I go further that in the very nature of things it cannot exist, so long as man remains as he is constituted.
('60', 15, 2, 14, 29292) His very body has been rightly called the temple of the Holy Ghost, though innumerable such temples belie the fact and are hotbeds of corruption, used for dissoluteness.
('60', 15, 2, 15, 29462) And I presume that it will be accepted as a conclusive answer to a sweeping suggestion that all bodies should be destroyed for the corruption of many, if it can be shown, as it can be, that there are some bodies which are proper temples of the Holy Ghost.
('60', 15, 2, 16, 29718) The cause for the corruption of many bodies will have to be sought elsewhere.
('60', 15, 2, 17, 29796) Temples of stone and mortar are nothing else than a natural extension of these human temples and though they were in their conception undoubtedly habitations of God like human temples, they have been subject to the same law of decay as the latter.
('60', 15, 2, 18, 30044) I know of no religion or sect that has done or is doing without its house of God, variously described as a temple, mosque, church, synagogue or agiari 1. Nor is it certain that any of the great reformers including Jesus destroyed or discarded temples altogether.
('60', 15, 2, 19, 30307) All of them
('60', 15, 3, 20, 30319) 1 Parsi fire temple
('60', 16, 0, 1, 30339) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 17
('60', 16, 1, 2, 30382) sought to banish corruption from temples as well as from society.
('60', 16, 1, 3, 30448) Some of them, if not all, appear to have preached from temples.
('60', 16, 1, 4, 30512) I have ceased to visit temples for years, but I do not regard myself on that account as a better person than before.
('60', 16, 1, 5, 30629) My mother never missed going to the temple when she was in a fit state to go there.
('60', 16, 1, 6, 30713) Probably her faith was far greater than mine, though I do not visit temples.
('60', 16, 1, 7, 30790) There are millions whose faith is sustained through these temples, churches and mosques.
('60', 16, 1, 8, 30879) They are not all blind followers of a superstition, nor are they fanatics.
('60', 16, 1, 9, 30954) Superstition and fanaticism are not their monopoly.
('60', 16, 1, 10, 31006) These vices have their root in our hearts and minds.
('60', 16, 1, 11, 31059) My advocacy of temple entry I hold to be perfectly consistent with the declaration which I often made in Europe that Truth is God.
('60', 16, 1, 12, 31190) It is that belief which makes it possible, at the risk of losing friendships, popularity and prestige, to advocate temple entry for Harijans.
('60', 16, 1, 13, 31332) The Truth that I know or I feel I know demands that advocacy from me.

('60', 16, 1, 16, 31576) But all reform without temple entry will be to tamper with the disease.
('60', 16, 1, 17, 31648) I am aware that the American friend’s objection is not based upon the corruption or impurity of the temples.
('60', 16, 1, 18, 31757) His objection is much more radical.
('60', 16, 1, 19, 31793) He does not believe in them at all.
('60', 16, 1, 20, 31829) I have endeavoured to show that his position is untenable in the light of facts which can be verified from everyday experience.
('60', 16, 1, 21, 31957) To reject the necessity of temples is to reject the necessity of God, religion and earthly existence.

('60', 16, 3, 23, 32078) 24. WHY N0T SIMPLE ‘HINDU’?
('60', 16, 4, 24, 32106) In the course of a letter, a caste Hindu correspondent writes:
('60', 16, 5, 25, 32169) If these depressed classes are finally to be merged in the Hindus, was it not better that instead of ‘Harijans’ they should have been given the name ‘Hindus’ which would have applied to both the caste Hindus and the depressed classes?
('60', 16, 5, 26, 32404) It is still time that the word ‘Harijan’ is given up in favour of the ‘Hindu’, so that the caste Hindus and the Hindu depressed classes are known in common parley as well as in Government papers as only Hindus.
('60', 16, 5, 27, 32615) The correspondent is too late with his suggestion.
('60', 16, 5, 28, 32666) If a separate register of untouchable classes had not come to stay, at least for the time being, the common name might have answered the purpose.
('60', 16, 5, 29, 32812) But the separate register makes it absolutely necessary to know the untouchable classes by some name, and if such is the case, why not
('60', 17, 0, 1, 32947) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 17, 1, 2, 32988) give them a name that truly befits them and has no ill flavour about it.
('60', 17, 1, 3, 33061) I regard ‘Harijan’ as a fitting name, because the caste Hindus cannot be properly considered God’s children, but the untouchables certainly can.
('60', 17, 1, 4, 33206) I have suggested the real method of abolishing the distinction between caste Hindus and Harijans, namely, by caste Hindus perform ing the purification ceremony of ridding themselves of untouchability and becoming Harijans themselves.
('60', 17, 1, 5, 33440) And if it was open to anyone to be classified as untouchables in the register for untouchables, I should most decidedly advise caste Hindus to declare themselves as such and to live also as such.
('60', 17, 1, 6, 33636) That will be a substantial and organic method of amalgamating the two into one body.
('60', 17, 1, 7, 33721) This is the proper place for referring to the same suggestion made by a Harijan friend but from a different standpoint.
('60', 17, 1, 8, 33841) He says that the best way of getting rid of untouchability is to advise Harijans to adopt names that will never signify an untouchable and to declare themselves also as mere Hindus or as Brahmins, Kshatriyas or Vaishyas.
('60', 17, 1, 9, 34062) This suggestion was made to me even as early as 1915 when I began the crusade against untouchability.
('60', 17, 1, 10, 34164) This Harijan had his own experiences and told me that he had travelled from one end of India to the other, that he had freely entered all the principal places of pilgrimage without let or hindrance and that he had taken with him a party.
('60', 17, 1, 11, 34402) When he was introduced to me, I saw no mark about him of being a Harijan.
('60', 17, 1, 12, 34476) He was dressed like a Brahmin, had a tilak on his forehead, a mala of tulsi or rudraksh—I forget which—and his speech was that of an ordinary Gujarati.
('60', 17, 1, 13, 34628) He and his party took up their abode in dharmsalas and never had the slightest difficulty, having unhesi tatingly proclaimed themselves as belonging to one varna or the other.
('60', 17, 1, 14, 34804) My visitor told me that this practice of untouchables hiding their identity was quite a common thing amongst them and that it was growing.
('60', 17, 1, 15, 34943) He unfortunately received no encouragement from me.
('60', 17, 1, 16, 34995) I told him that that practice might be convenient for him and the few who could afford the means and had sufficient training to be able to shed some of the habits which marked out an untouchable from the rest, but that the practice of a few, apart from its being dishonest and, therefore, tending to deterioration of manhood, would make no impression upon the tens of thousands of untouchables who could not even stir out of their villages.
('60', 17, 1, 17, 35436) The reply that I then gave applies with equal force even today.
('60', 17, 1, 18, 35500) The straightest and the quickest method, therefore, is to conduct the movement openly, to know the untouchables as such and yet for caste
('60', 18, 0, 1, 35638) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 19
('60', 18, 1, 2, 35681) Hindus to treat them on terms of absolute equality with themselves; and as the movement has begun on a very large scale and the declara tion was made on behalf of caste Hindus in September last that untou chability was gone, it surely became necessary to know untouchables by an inoffensive name whilst the process of amalgamation was going on.
('60', 18, 1, 3, 36026) ‘Harijan’ in my opinion was the best name to know them by.
('60', 18, 1, 4, 36085) Harijan, 11 3 1933
('60', 18, 2, 5, 36104) 25. A GROUNDLESS FEAR
('60', 18, 3, 6, 36126) A sanatanist correspondent writes:
('60', 18, 4, 7, 36161) Suppose a sanatanist builds a new temple and appoints trustees for its management; suppose he throws it open to all Hindus of the four castes, but not to untouchables.
('60', 18, 4, 8, 36329) According to the Anti untouchability Bill, the disqualification of the untouchables will be inoperative.
('60', 18, 4, 9, 36434) According to the Temple entry Bill, if the reformers are in the majority, they will be able to secure the admission of untouchables.
('60', 18, 4, 10, 36567) Thus, although the person who dedicates the temple may be of opinion that the temple will be polluted by the admission of untouchables, although he may be of opinion that he, and persons who are of his way of thinking, cannot worship properly if untouchables are admitted, yet untouchables will be allowed inside the temple and his express desire will be violated.
('60', 18, 5, 11, 36932) If, however, a sanatanist builds such a temple in, say, Tibet or China or Afghanistan, his desire will no doubt be respected, as there is no Anti untouchability Law or Temple entry Law in any of those countries.
('60', 18, 5, 12, 37144) Thus a sanatanist cannot worship as he likes in a temple built by him in India if he desires that his brother sanatanists of the higher castes should have the right of entry into that temple.
('60', 18, 5, 13, 37336) But he will enjoy this privilege if he builds the temple in any other country except India.
('60', 18, 6, 14, 37428) Do you think that this position is satisfactory?
('60', 18, 6, 15, 37477) If I was a believer in untouchability, I should not dread the Bills as my correspondent does.
('60', 18, 6, 16, 37571) So far as the supposed greater freedom in Tibet, China or Afghanistan is concerned, the correspondent forgets that there is no such thing as untouchability in these three countries, so far as I am aware, and he certainly will not be able there, as he is in this country, to prevent the entry of a single person merely on the ground of untouchability.
('60', 18, 6, 17, 37922) But even when untouchability ceases to be recog nized by the law, that fact will not necessarily entitle the untouchables to enter any temple they choose.
('60', 18, 6, 18, 38077) Thus, a sanatanist who builds a temple for certain persons exclusively builds a private temple and he will have the perfect right to exclude any person he likes, whether untouchable or touchable.
('60', 18, 6, 19, 38273) All he will not be able to do is to
('60', 19, 0, 1, 38309) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 19, 1, 2, 38350) exclude a person purely on the ground of untouchability and secure the assis tance of the law in order to compass his purpose.
('60', 19, 1, 3, 38477) And even public temples will successfully prevent the entry of untouchables if public opinion is against their entry.
('60', 19, 1, 4, 38595) All that the first Bill does is to refuse legal sanction to the cult of untouchability.
('60', 19, 1, 5, 38683) No Hindu temple will, however, be opened to the Harijans till caste Hindus have been converted.
('60', 19, 1, 6, 38779) Under the second Bill, private temples are uninterfered with and public temples can only be regulated according to public usage, which is always subject to change from time to time.
('60', 19, 1, 7, 38961) And when a sanatanist builds a public temple for the four varnas, it is only by implication that untouchables are excluded; but if untouchables are merged in the four varnas, surely there is no violence to the sanatanist’s will, because he could not regulate the religious belief of posterity nor stop its growth.
('60', 19, 1, 8, 39275) The only objection of the correspondent, therefore, that needs consideration is the right of the minority under the second Bill.
('60', 19, 1, 9, 39404) I have ventured to suggest a compromise which jealously guards the rights of a minority even of one.
('60', 19, 1, 10, 39505) For, I have no desire personally to interfere with the religious right of a single individual.
('60', 19, 1, 11, 39600) But what the correspondent hopelessly fails to do is to recognize the right of the reformers which he insists upon their recognizing in respect of himself and his co sanatanists.
('60', 19, 1, 12, 39779) Harijan, 11 3 1933

('60', 20, 1, 2, 40252) 27. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('60', 20, 2, 3, 40275) March 11, 1933
('60', 20, 3, 4, 40290) MIRA, It is 3.15 a.m., 11th, Saturday now.
('60', 20, 3, 5, 40333) The day of my writing to you has become upset owing to the uncertainty of the arrival of your weekly letter.
('60', 20, 3, 6, 40442) This week I had two from you.
('60', 20, 3, 7, 40472) Last week’s was received only on Tuesday and this week’s on Wednesday.
('60', 20, 3, 8, 40543) But yesterday morn ing I thought I had still to hear from you and I devoted the morning to writing other important letters.
('60', 20, 3, 9, 40667) And then when it dawned upon me that there was nothing more to come from you, I would not write to you during what you may call office hours.
('60', 20, 3, 10, 40809) I love to write this letter and such others in the early morning.
('60', 20, 3, 11, 40875) I see that you are once more enjoying the company of birds and animals.
('60', 20, 3, 12, 40947) Frogs have somehow or other appeared to me helpless creatures.

('60', 29, 1, 2, 59878) 37. DISPOSAL OF CARCASSES 1
('60', 29, 2, 3, 59906) [March 12, 1933] There are several sections among Harijans, e.g., the Chakkiliyans and Madigas in South India and Chamars in Gujarat, who remove and dispose of dead cattle and eat their flesh.
('60', 29, 2, 4, 60099) Disposal of dead cattle is a sacred obligation and occupation.
('60', 29, 2, 5, 60162) But the eating of carrion is a most filthy habit, regarded as one of the heinous sins in Hindu scriptures, and it is essential that at this hour of self purification our Harijanbrethren should be helped to get rid of this habit.
('60', 29, 2, 6, 60391) But they plead their inability to do so for various reasons.
('60', 29, 2, 7, 60452) “It is a habit to which we have been accustomed for ages”, they say, “and now it is a positive delicacy which we cannot forgo any more than you can do without your finest delicacies.
('60', 29, 2, 8, 60635) You should also know that removal of dead cattle is an obligation imposed upon us and we may not shirk it without risking the wrath of the Mahajans; you know, perhaps, that carrion is part of the remuneration for the removal.
('60', 29, 2, 9, 60861) We are thus tied down to carrioneating for three reasons.” The argument deserves consideration.
('60', 29, 2, 10, 60957) Written and spoken appeals will be of no avail; we must show them the way out.
('60', 29, 2, 11, 61036) We should first acquaint ourselves with the conditions obtaining in various parts of the country regarding the removal of dead cattle, and have them altered as circumstances may require; we should supervise the actual skinning and other attendant processes and see to the proper disposal of the remains.
('60', 29, 2, 12, 61340) The removal must be made conditional on a promise not to eat the carrion, and no one should be compelled to remove dead cattle.
('60', 29, 2, 13, 61468) This work demands a fair number of volunteers.
('60', 29, 2, 14, 61515) They must learn the art of skinning dead cattle in a clean manner and teach it to the Harijans who are doing it today in the old fashion.
('60', 29, 2, 15, 61653) The carcasses should not be dragged as at present, as it damages the hide and decreases its value.
('60', 29, 2, 16, 61752) They should be lifted and removed in an expeditious and efficient manner.
('60', 29, 2, 17, 61826) The hide curers will willingly adopt the new method, but not until the so called high caste people have mastered it.
('60', 29, 2, 18, 61943) The way in which dead cattle are disposed of today is most uneconomical and entails a loss of crores of rupees to the country.
('60', 29, 2, 19, 62070) Every bit of the carcass must be made proper use of.
('60', 29, 2, 20, 62123) Much of it is
('60', 29, 3, 21, 62137) 1 This is a translation of a Gujarati item which was published in Harijan bandhu, 12 3 1933 .
('60', 30, 0, 1, 62231) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 31
('60', 30, 1, 2, 62274) wasted today.
('60', 30, 1, 3, 62288) The hide, the bones, the entrails and the flesh are all useful and ought to be properly utilized.
('60', 30, 1, 4, 62386) The hide is being put to use of a sort.
('60', 30, 1, 5, 62426) The bones are mostly wasted.
('60', 30, 1, 6, 62455) They should be carefully collected and turned scientifically into manure.
('60', 30, 1, 7, 62529) The entrails are utilized for gut, etc., but there is room enough for improvement.
('60', 30, 1, 8, 62612) The flesh should be saved from the filthy use it is turned to and must be made to yield fat, which will be valuable for manufacturing grease for factories.
('60', 30, 1, 9, 62768) The remains should finally be converted into manure or buried deep.
('60', 30, 1, 10, 62836) If volunteers make a point of remaining present throughout all these processes, the men will easily take to the new departure and will stop eating carrion.
('60', 30, 1, 11, 62992) There is nowhere any room for compulsion.
('60', 30, 1, 12, 63034) Where the hidecurers are not ready for the change, they must be left undisturbed.
('60', 30, 1, 13, 63116) They are no more bound to remove the dead cattle than the caste organizations are bound to get them removed by them.
('60', 30, 1, 14, 63233) It should be a matter of mutual adjustment.
('60', 30, 1, 15, 63277) But the beginning must be made by the volunteers supervising the processes, wherever, of course, the supervision is not resented.
('60', 30, 1, 16, 63407) The supervision need not be delayed until the volunteers have first mastered the processes.
('60', 30, 1, 17, 63499) Actual work will be a training in itself.
('60', 30, 1, 18, 63541) Municipalities and local bodies and States can immediately undertake the work of training volunteers in scientific skinning and hide curing.
('60', 30, 1, 19, 63682) This does need a little expense on buildings and experts.
('60', 30, 1, 20, 63740) They should really have a training school for this purpose and invite philanthropic experts and veterinary surgeons for co operation, suggestions and help.
('60', 30, 2, 21, 63896) Harijan, 18 3 1933
('60', 30, 3, 22, 63915) 38. TRUTH THE ONLY WAY 1
('60', 30, 4, 23, 63940) [March 12, 1933] 2
('60', 30, 5, 24, 63959) I have already summed up in an article in the last issue of Harijan the qualities regarded as indispensable in a servant of the Harijans.
('60', 30, 5, 25, 64097) 3 If this movement is essentially religious and has for its object the purification and protection of Hinduism, it can be carried on only by truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth.
('60', 30, 5, 26, 64288) Truth is the very foundation of religion.
('60', 30, 5, 27, 64330) If Truth is God, there can be no room for untruth in religion.
('60', 30, 5, 28, 64393) Let every Harijan Sevak inscribe this
('60', 30, 6, 29, 64431) 1 The article was first published in Harijan Sevak, 17 3 1933. 2 Gandhiji says he wrote it on this date.
('60', 30, 6, 30, 64536) 3 Vide “A True Servant”, 11 3 1933.
('60', 31, 0, 1, 64572) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 31, 1, 2, 64613) fundamental principle on the tablet of his heart.
('60', 31, 1, 3, 64663) I am being inundated with sanatanist literature.
('60', 31, 1, 4, 64712) New weeklies and leaflets are coming in daily.
('60', 31, 1, 5, 64759) Sanatanists have loosened their purse strings.
('60', 31, 1, 6, 64806) I like the awakening.
('60', 31, 1, 7, 64828) How I wish it was on the right lines!
('60', 31, 1, 8, 64866) The writings I see contain palpable falsehoods.
('60', 31, 1, 9, 64914) Their sole object is to stop the anti untouchability movement somehow or other.
('60', 31, 1, 10, 64994) How can one answer such propaganda?
('60', 31, 1, 11, 65030) Most certainly not by untruth.
('60', 31, 1, 12, 65061) Truth can be the only answer.
('60', 31, 1, 13, 65091) I have indeed had complaints against reformers from sanatanists to the effect that the former are resorting to untruth and rowdyism.
('60', 31, 1, 14, 65224) These complaints have been unsupported by evidence.
('60', 31, 1, 15, 65276) I have requested the correspondents to supply me with it.
('60', 31, 1, 16, 65334) Only in one case has an attempt been made to furnish evidence.
('60', 31, 1, 17, 65397) And I have forwarded the complaints to the proper quarters for investigation.
('60', 31, 1, 18, 65475) I do not wish to suggest that refusal to furnish me with evidence is proof positive that the reformers are all above reproach.
('60', 31, 1, 19, 65602) These lines are being written in order to warn them against any departure from truth and non violence.
('60', 31, 1, 20, 65705) My attempt is to know no distinction between the sanatanist and the reformer.
('60', 31, 1, 21, 65783) I ask for truthfulness from both.
('60', 31, 1, 22, 65817) But as the sanatanists refuse to regard me as one of their own—some even look upon me as their foe—I am afraid my appeal will have no weight with them.
('60', 31, 1, 23, 65969) I should be satisfied if the reformers will listen to my appeal.
('60', 31, 1, 24, 66034) For, their truth will overcome the opponents’ untruth, even as light overcomes darkness.
('60', 31, 1, 25, 66123) If, therefore, the Harijan Sevak will pursue every one of his activities with truth as the guiding principle, he is sure in the end to convert the sanatanists.
('60', 31, 2, 26, 66283) I shall certainly declare that no one can destroy the Hindu religion or any other religion by aggression.
('60', 31, 2, 27, 66389) This is a self evident truth.
('60', 31, 2, 28, 66419) That which can be destroyed by any external force is not religion.
('60', 31, 2, 29, 66486) It may well be a form of social behaviour.
('60', 31, 2, 30, 66529) Religion can be destroyed only by internal corruption.
('60', 31, 2, 31, 66584) Untouchability is one such corruption in the Hindu religion.
('60', 31, 2, 32, 66645) If that is not eradicated, Hindu religion is bound to be destroyed.
('60', 31, 2, 33, 66713) Untouchability is a monstrous untruth.
('60', 31, 2, 34, 66752) It can be overcome by contact.
('60', 31, 2, 35, 66783) Untouchability exists in our hearts.
('60', 31, 2, 36, 66820) It is a great sin to think, ‘This man belongs to the untouchable caste; so I will not touch him.’ This thought is filled with hatred, with pride, with the notion of superiority and inferiority.
('60', 31, 2, 37, 67014) All this is irreligion, it is untruth.
('60', 31, 2, 38, 67053) I know that untruth cannot be supported by truth, hatred cannot be supported by love, pride cannot be supported
('60', 31, 3, 39, 67165) 1 The paragraph that follows has been translated from Harijan Sevak, 17 3 1933.
('60', 32, 0, 1, 67245) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 33
('60', 32, 1, 2, 67288) by humility.
('60', 32, 1, 3, 67301) This is the reason why I see today the sanatanist newspapers full of hatred, pride and untruth.
('60', 32, 1, 4, 67397) The sanatanist will ask me, ‘Do you not expose your own truth, hatred and pride in saying so?’ Perhaps it is so.
('60', 32, 1, 5, 67510) I can only assert that to my knowledge I have no such thoughts.
('60', 32, 1, 6, 67574) When I see them I shall eschew them, then and there.
('60', 32, 1, 7, 67627) In order to perceive my own faults, I receive the critics with respect, and listen to them; what they write I read as much as I can.
('60', 32, 1, 8, 67760) The harder I tried, the more the faults I found in those critics.
('60', 32, 1, 9, 67826) I do not wish to write about this sad experience here.
('60', 32, 1, 10, 67881) But let the workers know that exaggeration is also a species of untruth.
('60', 32, 1, 11, 67954) I receive reports about opening of temples and wells to Harijans.
('60', 32, 1, 12, 68020) But sometimes it has been discovered that all the temples and wells referred to have not been opened and that the information supplied to me has been based on insufficient data.
('60', 32, 1, 13, 68198) The Dhulia Anti untouchability Committee has published a small pamphlet containing a list of temples and wells opened all over India.
('60', 32, 1, 14, 68332) It is an imposing list, but I am not inclined to accept it at its face value, not because the Committee has been careless in its compilation, but because it had no opportunity of testing the accuracy of the information supplied from all India sources.
('60', 32, 1, 15, 68584) Very often workers gain their information from newspapers, instead of being themselves suppliers of information to newspapers.
('60', 32, 1, 16, 68711) Statements received from Anti untouchability Committee cannot be accepted as conclusive evidence, if they are based upon untested reports published in the daily Press.
('60', 32, 1, 17, 68879) And then there is the great temptation to swell the list of temples and wells opened, for fear of my fast being precipitated.
('60', 32, 1, 18, 69005) It is a disheartening thought for me and it betrays a poor opinion of the great movement.
('60', 32, 1, 19, 69095) My fast was not designed to coerce people in any shape or form.
('60', 32, 1, 20, 69159) It was designed merely to make Hindus think and to spur them to action.
('60', 32, 1, 21, 69231) Truth is made of sterner stuff, and it must be held superior to any life or lives, be they ever so precious.
('60', 32, 1, 22, 69340) It must live even if a million lives had to be sacrificed.
('60', 32, 1, 23, 69399) In a big, religious movement like the drive against untouchability, which many believe to be an integral part of Hindu religion, nothing but unadulterated truth and unconquerable faith in the cause will avail.
('60', 32, 1, 24, 69609) The reformers hold untouchability to be itself the biggest blot on Hinduism, a great lie.
('60', 32, 1, 25, 69699) If it is, it can be defeated only by truth and gentleness.
('60', 32, 1, 26, 69758) Harijan Sevak, 17 3 1933 and Harijan, 18 3 1933

('60', 33, 5, 8, 70116) 40. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI March 12, 1933
('60', 33, 6, 9, 70161) NARANDAS, I got the mail you posted on the 9th.
('60', 33, 6, 10, 70209) I am dispatching this hoping that you will get it on Tuesday.
('60', 33, 6, 11, 70271) I had a postcard from Ramabehn.
('60', 33, 6, 12, 70303) She says that you have not called on her yet.
('60', 33, 6, 13, 70349) About helping her to learn English, you may discuss the matter further with me, but my understanding of the letter in which I advised you to go and see her is that the suggestion was not open to discussion.
('60', 33, 6, 14, 70556) Ramabehn had told me, and that is also what she indirectly suggests in her letter, that you would never take the initiative to call on her.
('60', 33, 6, 15, 70696) I had told her that that could not be so.
('60', 33, 6, 16, 70738) You should prove that I was right.
('60', 33, 6, 17, 70773) Is it true that Babla 1 escaped drowning in the Magan tank?
('60', 33, 6, 18, 70833) How and when did the accident occur?
('60', 33, 6, 19, 70870) I had received your wire about Parachure Shastri on Friday.
('60', 33, 6, 20, 70930) If all of you came to the decision independently, it is to be highly welcomed.
('60', 33, 6, 21, 71009) Kaka has conveyed it to Parachure Shastri.
('60', 33, 6, 22, 71052) He has gone to his place just now.
('60', 33, 6, 23, 71087) I will let you know what he decides.
('60', 33, 6, 24, 71124) I hope Lakshmi’s wedding went off well.
('60', 33, 6, 25, 71164) The bride and the bridegroom may come and see me if they wish.
('60', 33, 6, 26, 71227) I think Maruti does.
('60', 33, 6, 27, 71248) I hope you got the letters posted yesterday.
('60', 33, 6, 28, 71293) They contained one for Lakshmidas in which I wrote to him about Anandi.

('60', 34, 6, 17, 72368) GULAB, Normally it is not proper to wear a shirt and trousers and change over to half length sari and skirt whenever you feel like doing so.
('60', 34, 6, 18, 72509) I suppose by trousers you mean only shorts.
('60', 34, 6, 19, 72553) It will be better if you keep to one dress.
('60', 34, 6, 20, 72597) If your pronunciation has improved, you can try to memorize the Gita verses while working in the field.
('60', 34, 6, 21, 72701) You cannot keep a book with you unless your teacher permits.

('60', 35, 1, 2, 72975) 43. LETTER TO RAMABEHN JOSHI March 12, 1933
('60', 35, 2, 3, 73019) RAMA, I have your postcard.
('60', 35, 2, 4, 73047) Do not lose your peace of mind.
('60', 35, 2, 5, 73079) Narandas will certainly come and see you.
('60', 35, 2, 6, 73121) It is my duty to ask him to go and it is his duty to go.
('60', 35, 2, 7, 73178) Your duty is not to ask him to come and, if he wishes to come, to tell him that he need not do so.
('60', 35, 2, 8, 73277) This is how sweetness is preserved in social relations.
('60', 35, 2, 9, 73333) But now you may take that further step only after you have tested him.
('60', 35, 2, 10, 73404) Meanwhile, you should not worry.
('60', 35, 2, 11, 73437) I hope your arm is all right now.
('60', 35, 3, 12, 73471) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 5343
('60', 35, 4, 13, 73515) 44. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK March 12, 1933
('60', 35, 5, 14, 73561) PREMA, Your argument is worthy of an M.A. “If someone can hang himself upside down, why can I not play music?” Many other questions like this can be framed.
('60', 35, 5, 15, 73718) The only reply is that no reason can be given why you may not.
('60', 35, 5, 16, 73781) If one person can do one thing, why may another person not do something else?
('60', 35, 5, 17, 73859) But it is certainly possible that someone who hangs himself upside down may be able to give a valid reason even for such an action, while a person like me who then starts playing music may not be able to give a convincing reason for doing so.
('60', 35, 5, 18, 74102) But let that pass.
('60', 35, 5, 19, 74121) You should now put your proposal before the other inmates of the Ashram and, if a majority supports it, by all means go ahead and make the necessary preparations.
('60', 35, 5, 20, 74284) Being a prisoner, I myself will not be able to join that marriage procession.
('60', 35, 5, 21, 74362) And a prisoner has no vote either, so you need not consult me.
('60', 35, 5, 22, 74425) Q.E.D. I will patiently wait for Dhurandhar’s letter.
('60', 35, 5, 23, 74479) Whether you reply to my question or not, I will keep on inquiring about your health.
('60', 35, 5, 24, 74564) Tell me, therefore, is it all right?
('60', 35, 5, 25, 74601) Is the throat all right and can you speak?
('60', 35, 5, 26, 74644) How is the backache?
('60', 35, 5, 27, 74665) Is your weight increasing?
('60', 35, 5, 28, 74692) When the time comes for giving away the yarn which I am spinning with the slivers sent by you, I will certainly give it to you if you continue to deserve it even then.
('60', 35, 5, 29, 74860) I hope you will be satisfied with
('60', 36, 0, 1, 74894) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 37
('60', 36, 1, 2, 74937) this answer.
('60', 36, 1, 3, 74950) The count of the yarn will not exceed 75. There are fairly numerous rough particles in the slivers.
('60', 36, 1, 4, 75050) It is possible that even Keshu’s machine is not good enough for devkapas.
('60', 36, 1, 5, 75124) I hope you know that this variety of cotton cannot be carded with the ordinary bow.
('60', 36, 1, 6, 75208) I don’t know anything about Mahadev having been offended.
('60', 36, 1, 7, 75266) Nor did I know that he had written to anybody about the matter.
('60', 36, 1, 8, 75330) I knew something from Narandas’s letter.
('60', 36, 1, 9, 75371) I knew about disrespect only from your letter.
('60', 36, 1, 10, 75418) Mahadev has told me nothing.
('60', 36, 1, 11, 75447) Nor did I know, when I asked him to spin [with your slivers], that he found himself in a moral dilemma.
('60', 36, 1, 12, 75551) 1 In this matter your case seems to be perfectly correct.
('60', 36, 1, 13, 75609) I did not feel disrespect to anybody in your remark or your request.
('60', 36, 1, 14, 75678) I don’t know why Mahadev felt it.
('60', 36, 1, 15, 75712) I am observing silence just now, otherwise I would have asked him.
('60', 36, 1, 16, 75779) I did feel, however, that your request sprang from ignorant attachment.
('60', 36, 1, 17, 75851) Why should you have such attachment for me?
('60', 36, 1, 18, 75895) One should eschew attachment for a person who cannot belong to any one individual but daily strives to belong to all.
('60', 36, 1, 19, 76013) Such attachment can avail nothing.
('60', 36, 1, 20, 76048) But this is one thing.
('60', 36, 1, 21, 76071) To deduce from it a dislike for others is a different thing.
('60', 36, 1, 22, 76132) Sardar, I believe, was only joking, as is his wont.
('60', 36, 1, 23, 76184) And now see how I valued your love.
('60', 36, 1, 24, 76220) Surely you will agree that I should make what I believe to be the best use of the slivers sent by you.
('60', 36, 1, 25, 76323) Wouldn’t that be the best way of showing how I valued your love?
('60', 36, 1, 26, 76388) If a vaid, out of his great love for me, sends me gold bhasma 2, would it not be right to give it to my neighbour to whom it might be more useful than to me?
('60', 36, 1, 27, 76546) Or, if somebody sends me a carriage to drive and if my neighbour can drive it more safely than I can, would I not show better appreciation of the donor’s love by letting that neighbour drive it for me?
('60', 36, 1, 28, 76748) The same argument applies to slivers.
('60', 36, 1, 29, 76786) Among us here, Mahadev can make the best use of such fine slivers, and so I gave half the quantity to him.
('60', 36, 1, 30, 76893) This will test his skill and increase national wealth and I also will feel happier.
('60', 36, 1, 31, 76977) You should, therefore, change your nature which makes you wish that your gift should be used only by the person to whom it is given.
('60', 36, 1, 32, 77110) If you make a gift, you should do so unconditionally.
('60', 36, 1, 33, 77164) Sushila’s description of you was correct.
('60', 36, 1, 34, 77206) If Kisan was not likely to get in time the fruit which were brought for her, you would have served both Sushila and Kisan by eating it yourself.
('60', 36, 1, 35, 77351) It was foolish of you to have let them rot.
('60', 36, 1, 36, 77395) Q.E.D. again.
('60', 36, 1, 37, 77409) I am sorry I cannot reply to your last question.
('60', 36, 2, 38, 77458) 1 The addressee had inscribed on a gift parcel of slivers to Gandhiji: “To revered dear Mahatmaji”.
('60', 36, 2, 39, 77558) Mahadev Desai, therefore, had felt that it would not be proper for him to spin them.

('60', 44, 1, 2, 89786) 59. LETTER TO PRABHASHANKAR PATTANI March 13, 1933
('60', 44, 2, 3, 89837) SUJNA BHAISHRI, I got your letter.
('60', 44, 2, 4, 89872) I would be content to accept from you as much as you can give.
('60', 44, 2, 5, 89935) I must, therefore, make my request and leave the matter to your discretion.
('60', 44, 2, 6, 90011) In relation to you, I am in the same position as Ramabehn.
('60', 44, 2, 7, 90070) If she does not get something from you, will she complain about that to me?
('60', 44, 2, 8, 90146) You seem to believe that you are immortal and that, therefore, the people are safe.
('60', 44, 2, 9, 90230) But the truth is that in matters in which action by the Ruler is essential, he must act.
('60', 44, 2, 10, 90319) “Ruler” here may mean, if you wish, his Executive Council or the Assembly.
('60', 44, 2, 11, 90394) Responsibility must vest with some individual or body so that a tradition may be maintained.
('60', 44, 2, 12, 90487) When I analyse even your method, I discover the same thing, namely, that power is being exercised, though secretly.
('60', 44, 2, 13, 90603) You may deceive yourself and the people that things go on by themselves, but the truth is that nothing goes on by itself.
('60', 44, 2, 14, 90725) Hence in regard to such problems as removal of carrion, admission to schools, etc., about which something ought to be done and about which public opinion also is favourable, legislation is essential.
('60', 44, 2, 15, 90925) Where there are no laws, there can be no government but only anarchy or misrule.
('60', 44, 2, 16, 91006) Even Mussolini pretends to run a government.
('60', 44, 2, 17, 91051) Nobody should object to a declaration that the Durbar, that is, Bhavnagar State, does not recognize untouchability.
('60', 44, 2, 18, 91167) Sanatanists may, if they wish, continue to follow the practice and enforce it by social sanctions.
('60', 44, 2, 19, 91266) You follow many principles in your own family, but try and see if you can enforce them in your immediate circle in which you have influence.
('60', 44, 2, 20, 91407) You will not succeed.
('60', 44, 2, 21, 91429) You can declare, without hurting anybody, that for the Ruler all subjects are equal.
('60', 44, 2, 22, 91514) Having done that, don’t mind if no child from the so called untouchable communities can attend your schools.
('60', 44, 2, 23, 91623) I have written a note in the Gujarati Harijan about the problem of carcasses.
('60', 44, 2, 24, 91701) 1 Find some time and read it.
('60', 44, 2, 25, 91731) Some of what I have said there is addressed to you, though no particulars of name or place are mentioned.
('60', 44, 2, 26, 91837) Though both of us are old, we are greedy.
('60', 44, 2, 27, 91879) We have even the courage to do service.
('60', 44, 2, 28, 91919) We give away all the money we may have.
('60', 44, 2, 29, 91959) But you have to run a State, and your hair has become grey under the burden.
('60', 44, 2, 30, 92036) You should also cultivate the company of persons like me.
('60', 44, 2, 31, 92094) You have accepted a difficult Superficially it might seems that your path and mine are different.
('60', 44, 2, 32, 92192) Both of us have the same aim and pursue

('60', 45, 2, 11, 92927) 60. LETTER TO RANCHHODDAS PATWARI
('60', 45, 3, 12, 92961) March 13, 1933
('60', 45, 4, 13, 92976) RESPECTED BHAI, I have your letter.
('60', 45, 4, 14, 93012) I will not give up hope of you, nor should you give up hope of me.
('60', 45, 4, 15, 93079) Many have been able to get along together in this way.
('60', 45, 4, 16, 93134) It has also happened that some were not able to do so.
('60', 45, 4, 17, 93189) I shall not dismiss our case as belonging to the latter category.
('60', 45, 4, 18, 93255) It is in God’s hands.
('60', 45, 4, 19, 93277) However, I shall go on trying.
('60', 45, 4, 20, 93308) All reformers are not pure.
('60', 45, 4, 21, 93336) Nobody is pure.
('60', 45, 4, 22, 93352) But many struggle to be pure, many love dharma.
('60', 45, 4, 23, 93400) They believe that untouchability is really an inner matter and that it has no external sign.
('60', 45, 4, 24, 93493) We must all keep away from such untouchability.
('60', 45, 4, 25, 93541) No one is born an untouchable.
('60', 45, 4, 26, 93572) If there is anything in Hinduism which is not to be found in any other religion, which promotes dharma, it should be amenable to rational proof.
('60', 45, 4, 27, 93717) And its result should be manifest to the eye.
('60', 45, 4, 28, 93763) The theory of untouchability by birth neither appeals to reason nor has it any visible beneficial effect.
('60', 45, 4, 29, 93869) If you say that Antyajas should be helped except in the matter of admission to temples, why should you not regard it your dharma to give such help?
('60', 45, 4, 30, 94017) If you don’t wish to give such help through me, you may give it independently.
('60', 45, 4, 31, 94096) You also see the continual degradation of dharma.
('60', 45, 4, 32, 94146) But do you think it can be prevented by laying exclusive stress on external cleanliness?
('60', 45, 4, 33, 94235) I am not averse to such cleanliness.
('60', 45, 4, 34, 94272) I think I observe all rules of cleanliness which I know, but I don’t believe that their observance purifies me spiritually.
('60', 45, 4, 35, 94396) They help me to preserve physical cleanliness.
('60', 45, 4, 36, 94443) For preserving spiritual purity, it seems to me that what is necessary is observance of rules of internal cleanliness.
('60', 45, 4, 37, 94562) These we have forgotten altogether.
('60', 45, 4, 38, 94598) The result is that, though we have forsaken
('60', 46, 0, 1, 94642) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 47
('60', 46, 1, 2, 94685) dharma, lost our spiritual strength and remain absorbed in worldly pursuits, we believe that our dharma is safe and, if somebody like me comes forward to wipe out the blot of untouchability, a loud cry of dharma being in danger is raised and lies are spread against that person.
('60', 46, 1, 3, 94964) I do wish that people like you should not lend your support to such activities and that is why I plead with you.
('60', 46, 1, 4, 95077) On matters on which we differ, we should try to understand each other’s point of view and, in regard to other things about which we have no differences between us, we may work separately but with the same aim.
('60', 46, 1, 5, 95287) If all of us do this, the waste of energy that is taking place at present would stop.
('60', 46, 1, 6, 95373) Read this letter when your mind is free from other worries.
('60', 46, 1, 7, 95433) I am sure you will be able to get some time in Adhoi.
('60', 46, 1, 8, 95487) Pranams from MOHANDAS From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 20564

('60', 48, 6, 14, 98990) DEAR DR.
('60', 48, 6, 15, 98999) SHARMA, I have your letter 2 today and I reply at once before deciphering Amtussalaam’s.
('60', 48, 6, 16, 99088) What I would like you to do is to go over to the Ashram, see the patients who are still there and will be for some time, and see whether they can be treated there without being removed to a cooler climate.
('60', 48, 6, 17, 99294) After all, it is not quite so hot in Ahmedabad as one may think till April.
('60', 48, 6, 18, 99370) The nights are perfectly cool and I have not found even the summer to be trying.
('60', 48, 6, 19, 99451) I have not hesitated to take my own cure in the Ashram more than once, even though I was advised by some doctors to go to a hill station or at least to a seaside place.
('60', 48, 6, 20, 99620) But you shall judge for yourself, and then if you find it to be necessary I shall endeavour to select a cooler place.
('60', 48, 6, 21, 99738) Your going to the Ashram will serve a double purpose.
('60', 48, 6, 22, 99792) You will know the place and surroundings and you will have your first experience of it.
('60', 48, 6, 23, 99880) You will also be able to deal with cases of obstinate constipation which are common enough in the Ashram.
('60', 48, 6, 24, 99986) There are two patients there who are chronic asthmatics and who do not generally go to watering places
('60', 48, 7, 25, 100089) 1 The meteorologists were finally given permission to visit the jail during day time and they arrived on April 3. 2 The addressee, a naturopath, had decided to go to the Ashram for some time and had asked Gandhiji what his duties there would be.

('60', 49, 3, 10, 100941) 66. LETTER TO AMRITLAL V. THAKKAR
('60', 49, 4, 11, 100975) March 14, 1933
('60', 49, 5, 12, 100990) DEAR THAKKAR BAPA, I have been very slow in sending you the draft constitution 1. Now I have your telegram.
('60', 49, 5, 13, 101098) I was ready with it only last Sunday and then it awaited the dictating of this letter when your telegram was received.
('60', 49, 5, 14, 101217) You will see what labour has been put into it.
('60', 49, 5, 15, 101264) The draft as it comes to you is the 3rd draft prepared by Mahadev.
('60', 49, 5, 16, 101331) I was simply supervising and suggesting.
('60', 49, 5, 17, 101372) I think I told you that I read it first and found that it required a lot of re drafting and thinking out.
('60', 49, 5, 18, 101478) It was then handed to Shastri 2. Shastri went through it carefully and made suggestions.
('60', 49, 5, 19, 101567) Then Mahadev tackled it.
('60', 49, 5, 20, 101592) So, you may say that it is the result of the joint labours of three persons.
('60', 49, 5, 21, 101669) Before it is printed, it should be passed by the Committee of the Society.
('60', 49, 5, 22, 101744) I feel that Hariji 3 should apply his legal mind to it and, as a lawyer, make what amendments and additions he may think necessary before it is considered by the Committee.
('60', 49, 5, 23, 101917) If he cannot give it the necessary time, it should be put in the hands of some lawyer who is experienced in drafting constitutions for societies such as ours.
('60', 49, 5, 24, 102076) No labour now given to it will be a waste of time and effort if the Society is to grow into a big and efficient organization.
('60', 49, 5, 25, 102202) Constitution alone will not do it, I
('60', 49, 6, 26, 102239) 1 Vide “Draft Constitution of the Harijan Sevak Sangh”, 9 3 1933. 2 R. V. Shastri, editor of Harijan 3 Hridaya Nath Kunzru
('60', 50, 0, 1, 102362) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 51
('60', 50, 1, 2, 102405) know, it will be the workers who will perform the trick.
('60', 50, 1, 3, 102462) Nevertheless, without a good workable constitution we will not be able to bind together the different units composing the organization and its branches.
('60', 50, 1, 4, 102615) After you have the final draft for passing, if there is any time, I would like you to send me a copy of that draft, for, you should know that I have not examined the enclosed draft in all its details.
('60', 50, 1, 5, 102816) I am anxious to receive your impressions in detail of your Punjab tour, your experience of the Harijan leaders.
('60', 50, 1, 6, 102928) Swatmanandji 1 appears to me to be an able man.
('60', 50, 1, 7, 102976) He is a polished Hindi writer and seems to have original ideas.
('60', 50, 1, 8, 103040) He tells me that he met you.
('60', 50, 1, 9, 103069) He has sent me a copy of the representation that was submitted to you by his Society.
('60', 50, 1, 10, 103155) As you have seen from his report which I have sent you he has no faith in the chief caste Hindus working the different anti untouchability organizations.
('60', 50, 1, 11, 103309) We have to give him as much satisfaction as is possible, and if there is nothing whatsoever in his charges, we should be able to tell him so and support our statement with convincing evidence.
('60', 50, 1, 12, 103502) I know I have deprived you of the only secretary who was giving you the fullest satisfaction.
('60', 50, 1, 13, 103596) If you had pleaded your inability to part with Shastri, I should have managed somehow.
('60', 50, 1, 14, 103683) I have not the courage now to say, “You can have Shastri if you wish”.
('60', 50, 1, 15, 103754) At the same time I know that you must not remain without an efficient secretary.
('60', 50, 1, 16, 103835) Would you like me to make a search?
('60', 50, 1, 17, 103871) If you will, let me know your exact requirements and what you are prepared to pay.
('60', 50, 2, 18, 103954) Yours sincerely,

('60', 53, 6, 24, 109526) 2 It will examine the applications and recommend them to the Board.
('60', 53, 6, 25, 109594) The Board will, if it accepts the recommendations, grant the scholarships.
('60', 53, 6, 26, 109669) This Committee will also be invited to frame a scheme giving conditions under which scholarships should be given describing the qualifications of the candidates and it will be under these conditions that applications would be invited.
('60', 53, 6, 27, 109904) I would suggest the Committee keeping in touch with Mr. David in so far as he may be willing to assist the Committee with his informal guidance and advice.

('60', 55, 5, 14, 113162) MY DEAR DEVDHAR 2, I have your letter about Prof.
('60', 55, 5, 15, 113212) Purandare 3. The thing is this.
('60', 55, 5, 16, 113244) He had delivered some addresses in Poona.
('60', 55, 5, 17, 113286) He was brought to me by Haribhau.
('60', 55, 5, 18, 113320) Haribhau told me that his addresses were well received, and so in order to begin the propaganda and in order to help Purandare I suggested that his speeches should be published in book form.
('60', 55, 5, 19, 113511) He was quite agreeable.
('60', 55, 5, 20, 113535) He told me that his wants were very few and that he would gladly dedicate himself to the cause.
('60', 55, 5, 21, 113631) I asked him to tell me what he would require for his labour in collecting the speeches, perhaps even rewriting them, examining proofs, etc.
('60', 55, 5, 22, 113771) He would not name the sum although I pressed him hard.
('60', 55, 5, 23, 113826) But he told me that he would be entirely satisfied with whatever I named and got from the Central Board.
('60', 55, 5, 24, 113931) When the book was finished and the time came for payment I hesitated to name the sum.
('60', 55, 5, 25, 114017) I therefore referred the matter to Haribhau.
('60', 55, 5, 26, 114062) He suggested Rs. 125. I immediately accepted the amount and had the cheque prepared, when, lo and behold, Prof.
('60', 55, 5, 27, 114174) Purandare declined to accept the money and wanted “Rs. 1000, if not Rs. 3,000”.

('60', 60, 4, 7, 122996) NARANDAS, While waiting for the others to arrive for the morning prayer, I wrote out a letter to Mirabehn and one to Ba.
('60', 60, 4, 8, 123117) I made them brief and started this.

('60', 60, 4, 10, 123200) I have discussed these only briefly.
('60', 60, 4, 11, 123237) Where is the time?

('60', 60, 4, 13, 123307) You should invite Narahari to see you and try to understand his point of view.
('60', 60, 4, 14, 123386) I know his temperament very well.
('60', 60, 4, 15, 123420) He is one of the few sincere workers who have come together in the Ashram.
('60', 60, 4, 16, 123495) They should all learn to become one as milk with sugar.
('60', 60, 4, 17, 123551) If they cannot do this, the Ashram is bound to perish.
('60', 60, 4, 18, 123606) Naturally, it is the responsibility of the secretary to see that different parts of an organization work in harmony.
('60', 60, 4, 19, 123723) It is my duty to explain this clearly to you.
('60', 60, 4, 20, 123769) The secretary is the centre of an organization.
('60', 60, 4, 21, 123817) Those who do not feel the pull of his attraction are outsiders in that organization.
('60', 60, 4, 22, 123902) The secretary should either free them or give them a proper place in the organization and keep them in it.
('60', 60, 4, 23, 124009) You cannot regard Narahari as an outsider.
('60', 60, 4, 24, 124052) We look upon certain persons as the limbs of the body that is the Ashram.
('60', 60, 4, 25, 124126) We can never imagine the Ashram without them.
('60', 60, 4, 26, 124172) If we can imagine it without them, we can imagine it without ourselves too, which would mean the end of the Ashram.
('60', 60, 4, 27, 124288) I have only stated the principle.
('60', 60, 4, 28, 124322) You may draw from it what lesson you can.
('60', 60, 4, 29, 124364) Narahari should be regarded as an expert in the field of education.
('60', 60, 4, 30, 124432) In that field, therefore, we should subordinate our views to his.
('60', 60, 4, 31, 124498) If in conesquence we find that mistakes are being made, we should let them be made and draw the expert’s attention to them afterwards.
('60', 60, 4, 32, 124633) There is no other way, and there can be none.
('60', 60, 4, 33, 124679) If anybody tries to point out my mistake in my own field, I would not readily admit it.
('60', 60, 4, 34, 124767) I must, therefore, taste the bitterness of failure.
('60', 60, 4, 35, 124819) This holds true of all other fields.
('60', 60, 4, 36, 124856) In this, too, I have stated only the general principle.

('60', 61, 1, 2, 124953) All persons of the category of Maganbhai should have free access to the books.
