('60', 66, 10, 19, 134714) 90. LETTER TO NARAHARI D. PARIKH March 17, 1933
('60', 66, 11, 20, 134762) NARAHARI, Why did you tear up your letter to Mahadev?
('60', 66, 11, 21, 134816) Just think how much anger and violence there was in your action.
('60', 66, 11, 22, 134881) Narandas put the pieces together, reconstructed the whole letter and sent it here.
('60', 66, 11, 23, 134964) It was not right for you to tear up the letter, no matter how much at fault
('60', 67, 0, 1, 135040) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 67, 1, 2, 135081) Narandas was.
('60', 67, 1, 3, 135095) I have gone through your letter and also the brief reply Narandas has sent to Mahadev.
('60', 67, 1, 4, 135182) I have conveyed to Narandas in short the impression which was produced on me, and have suggested that he should show you that letter.
('60', 67, 1, 5, 135316) It is true that my trust in Narandas is as complete as you have heard it is.
('60', 67, 1, 6, 135393) That is my nature.
('60', 67, 1, 7, 135412) It is not that I have such trust in him alone.
('60', 67, 1, 8, 135459) I have similar trust in you, Panditji, Kaka and others whose names you yourself can supply.
('60', 67, 1, 9, 135551) I would never believe anything against any of them unless I had direct evidence.
('60', 67, 1, 10, 135632) Hence, there was— should have been—nothing surprising in what you heard.
('60', 67, 1, 11, 135705) Apart from it, this is what I believe regarding Narandas.
('60', 67, 1, 12, 135763) He has in him the qualities of efficiency, patience, power of discrimination, balance of mind, impartiality and firmness, of the highest order.
('60', 67, 1, 13, 135907) They have cast a spell on me.
('60', 67, 1, 14, 135937) I therefore wish that you and other co workers should appreciate his qualities and take full advantage of his services.
('60', 67, 1, 15, 136057) However, he cannot have these merits, nor can others see them in him, simply because I attribute them to him.
('60', 67, 1, 16, 136167) How can you help if you fail to see them?
('60', 67, 1, 17, 136209) And it is clear that if you fail to see them, you cannot avail yourself of his services even as much as you may wish.
('60', 67, 1, 18, 136327) So much about my faith in Narandas.
('60', 67, 1, 19, 136363) Apart from that, however, I liked your letter very much.
('60', 67, 1, 20, 136420) It is not necessary, and I have not the time, to analyse the letter in detail or point out your errors that it shows.
('60', 67, 1, 21, 136538) I think I have drawn from it the necessary lesson.
('60', 67, 1, 22, 136589) You will see this from the suggestions which I have made to Narandas.
('60', 67, 1, 23, 136659) What I expect you to do is that you should see Narandas, have a quiet discussion with him and persuade him to make the changes which seem necessary to you.
('60', 67, 1, 24, 136815) Do not press the points which Narandas finds unacceptable.
('60', 67, 1, 25, 136874) I don’t think that you wish, or believe it desirable, that the charge of the Ashram should be entrusted to somebody else.
('60', 67, 1, 26, 136996) Do tell me if that is what you wish or think.
('60', 67, 1, 27, 137042) But if that is not so, your duty is to persuade Narandas as much as you can.
('60', 67, 1, 28, 137119) You are responsible for the welfare of the Ashram quite as much as I or Narandas or others.
('60', 67, 1, 29, 137211) We are what we are, and it is we who will make the Ashram what it will be.
('60', 67, 1, 30, 137286) You cannot, therefore, regard yourself as an outsider and disclaim responsibility for it, since the bond among the inmates of the Ashram is an indissoluble one as that in a Hindu marriage.
('60', 67, 1, 31, 137475) The Gower Bill has not still been passed into a law; but even when it has, those who wish to adhere to the present form of indissoluble marriage will certainly do so.
('60', 67, 1, 32, 137642) The Gower Bill has for its subject matter forced marriages and ill matched pairs.

('60', 68, 6, 11, 138654) 92. NOTES
('60', 68, 7, 12, 138664) EVILS A RESULT
('60', 68, 8, 13, 138679) In the Telugu districts as well as the adjoining Tamil districts, Madigas and Malas, both of whom are at presents untouchables, kill cows and buffaloes for purposes of sacrifice to Matamma Mariyamma and Gangamma.
('60', 68, 8, 14, 138892) There is no doubt that a certain number of caste people also take vows before these goddesses in times of emergency and calamity, but the actual sacrifice is done by the so called outcastes.
('60', 68, 8, 15, 139083) The untouchables not only sacrifice animals in public but eat the beef.
('60', 68, 8, 16, 139155) They also eat carrion.
('60', 68, 8, 17, 139178) Caste Hindus do not, but they do freely eat pork.
('60', 68, 8, 18, 139228) I would request you, therefore, to advise the untouchables to give up this sacrifice and carrion eating.
('60', 68, 8, 19, 139333) The latter is responsible for their physical degeneration.
('60', 68, 8, 20, 139392) Could you not also send a message for us who are working in the cause of anti untouchability?
('60', 68, 8, 21, 139486) This is a condensed extract from a long letter from the Secretary of the Andhra Provincial Ryots’ Association.
('60', 68, 8, 22, 139597) There is no doubt that this habit of carrion eating, and especially beef eating, has a great deal to do with the prevalent prejudice, but in no other thing is the weakness of Hinduism, or rather of caste Hindus, betrayed so forcibly as in regarding a portion of fellow Hindus to be untouchable and neglecting them in the cruellest manner possible.
('60', 68, 8, 23, 139945) We have, therefore, only ourselves to thank that the untouchables are what they are.
('60', 68, 8, 24, 140030) But it is not yet too late to mend.
('60', 68, 8, 25, 140066) The Harijans should realize that
('60', 69, 0, 1, 140099) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 69, 1, 2, 140140) untouchability is dead and gone.
('60', 69, 1, 3, 140173) Its evil effect will persist for a long time to come.
('60', 69, 1, 4, 140227) The duration will be the measure of our joint neglect.
('60', 69, 1, 5, 140282) Greater by far is the responsibility of the caste Hindus.
('60', 69, 1, 6, 140340) If they will do their duty and work whole heartedly, they will certainly succeed in stopping these sacrifices and the habit of carrion eating.
('60', 69, 1, 7, 140483) Nothing but the spread of enlightenment is required to rid the community of evil superstition and evil habits.
('60', 69, 1, 8, 140594) But I cannot too often remind the reformers and caste Hindus in general that they will not purify Harijans of any single one of the evil habits, if they will make the reform the condition of the removal of untouchability.
('60', 69, 1, 9, 140816) Rather let us realize that the evils are a result, and not a cause, of untouchability, anyway most decidedly not at the present moment.
('60', 69, 1, 10, 140952) So far as carrion eating is concerned, the reader will find concrete suggestions which I have made in the Gujarati columns of Harijanbandhu and which have been translated for these columns.

('60', 70, 4, 12, 144075) 93. WHAT HARIJANS THINK
('60', 70, 5, 13, 144099) The reader must have read and digested what Thakkar Bapa, as he is endearingly called in Gujarat, especially by Harijans, said in the telegraphic account of his tour in the Punjab, published in the last issue of Harijan.
('60', 70, 5, 14, 144320) Harijan deputations that waited on him have sent me copies of the addresses they presented to him.
('60', 70, 5, 15, 144419) The one from the Ad Dharma Mandal of Jullundur City and Balmic Ad Dharma Mandal of Lahore City contains these observations:
('60', 70, 6, 16, 144543) The high class proud Hindus of the Punjab Province have degraded and lowered our position in the society to an unbreakable extent.
('60', 70, 6, 17, 144674) They think themselves to be polluted if we happen to touch them.
('60', 70, 6, 18, 144739) Our entry at the public places and getting water from the public wells and tanks is thought objection able.
('60', 70, 6, 19, 144847) Hindu washermen and barbers are not prepared to serve us in their respective occupations.
('60', 70, 6, 20, 144937) We are not allowed to dine at Hindu hotels.
('60', 70, 6, 21, 144981) We are not privileged to use bands, palanquins on the occasions of our marriage celebra tions.
('60', 70, 6, 22, 145076) We are forced to carry the palanquins of Hindu brides at their marriage.
('60', 70, 6, 23, 145149) If we happen to put on good clothes, they irritate them.
('60', 70, 6, 24, 145206) The depressed classes of the Punjab Province are faced by many troubles.
('60', 70, 6, 25, 145279) High class Hindus have pressed and degraded them from all sides.
('60', 70, 6, 26, 145344) Caste question has proved very troublesome.
('60', 70, 6, 27, 145388) Even the houses in which they live are not considered their property.
('60', 70, 6, 28, 145458) In the villages and towns their economic condition is very much
('60', 71, 0, 1, 145522) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 71, 1, 2, 145563) degraded, and for their uplift a vigorous campaign of propaganda is required.
('60', 71, 1, 3, 145641) If the condition is as bad as this in the advanced Punjab, what must it be in the other Provinces of India?
('60', 71, 1, 4, 145749) And as would be clear from Thakkar Bapa’s wire, law seems to have conspired with the caste Hindus in depriving the Harijans of even the right of owning agri cultural land.
('60', 71, 1, 5, 145921) Let us hope that the numerous uplift associations of the Punjab will make a united effort to remove at once some of the numerous disabilities enumerated above.
('60', 71, 1, 6, 146081) Harijan, 18 3 1933
('60', 71, 2, 7, 146100) 94. EVEN UNTO THESE LAST
('60', 71, 3, 8, 146125) For the heading of this article I have dared to steal from Ruskin a classical phrase stolen by him in his turn from the Bible.
('60', 71, 3, 9, 146252) I have added ‘even’ to the original and changed ‘this’ into ‘these’ to bring out the whole sense of what I want to say.
('60', 71, 3, 10, 146372) Among the Harijans the poor scavenger or the Bhangi seems to stand last in the list, though he is perhaps the most important and indispensable member of society, as indispensable to it as a mother is to her children in one respect.
('60', 71, 3, 11, 146604) The Bhangi attends to the sanitation of society as a mother to that of her children.
('60', 71, 3, 12, 146689) If the caste men had to do the scavenging for themselves, some of the methods that the Bhangi has to submit to for doing his work would have been swept away long ago.
('60', 71, 3, 13, 146856) I copy the following from a letter of the Anti untouchability Board of Muttra to its Municipal Board: 1
('60', 71, 4, 14, 146960) He must be a heartless fellow who has remained unmoved at the pathetic sight of a slender, aged and emaciated woman carrying, and being crushed under, the weight of a basket full of night soil over her head every morning from the city lanes to the trenching ground or the flushing pit.
('60', 71, 4, 15, 147246) The practice, though old, is inhuman, cruel and a relic of barbaric days.
('60', 71, 4, 16, 147320) It is most unhygienic.
('60', 71, 4, 17, 147343) The solution is simple.
('60', 71, 4, 18, 147367) Just purchase hand driven trolleys and let these speechless servants of yours use the trolley as a carrier rather than the head.
('60', 71, 4, 19, 147496) Another matter for your consideration.
('60', 71, 4, 20, 147535) Every privy should be provided with metal or earthen basins, so that the process of removal of night soil may be rendered less uncleanly.
('60', 71, 4, 21, 147673) Let not the reader laugh at the somewhat high flown language of the writer.
('60', 71, 4, 22, 147749) What he has said is God’s truth.
('60', 71, 4, 23, 147782) The Bhangis have hitherto done their work uncomplainingly, and therefore the caste men have not cared to know how these have served society for centuries.
('60', 71, 4, 24, 147937) If we had not regarded these servants of society as

('60', 72, 2, 15, 150042) Some earnest workers have simply to persist and the much needed reform can be inaugurated in every town and city.

('60', 73, 2, 5, 150919) 95. POSERS
('60', 73, 3, 6, 150930) An iconoclast schoolmaster asks the following three questions.
('60', 73, 4, 7, 150993) 1. Is it necessary for a Hindu, following the life of Shri Ramachandra, also to go and see his image in the temple?
('60', 73, 4, 8, 151109) Is darshan better than action?
('60', 73, 5, 9, 151140) 2. If we bow our head or join our hands before a living person, he replies in return, but the image does not.
('60', 73, 5, 10, 151250) Then what is the use of doing it?
('60', 73, 5, 11, 151284) What is the use of writing letters to one who never replies?
('60', 73, 6, 12, 151345) 3. The person, whose image a Hindu adores, might have committed some wrongs in his lifetime.
('60', 73, 6, 13, 151438) Will not the adorer be harmed by copying those wrongs, which he is likely to copy if he worships his image?
('60', 73, 6, 14, 151546) Questions like these have been asked and answered often enough before now.
('60', 73, 6, 15, 151621) But the temple entry question has revived them and they torment honest doubters like the correspondent, as if they had never been raised and answered before.
('60', 73, 6, 16, 151779) I must do the best I can, though I doubt if doubters like the correspondent will be satisfied.
('60', 73, 6, 17, 151874) It is not necessary for any Hindu to go to a temple to worship (the image of) Ramachandra.
('60', 73, 6, 18, 151965) But it is for him who cannot contemplate his Rama without looking at his image in a temple.
('60', 73, 6, 19, 152057) It may be unfortunate, but it is true that his Rama resides in that temple as nowhere else.
('60', 73, 6, 20, 152149) I would not disturb that simple faith.
('60', 73, 6, 21, 152188) The sub question in the first question is badly put.
('60', 73, 6, 22, 152241) There is no question of comparison between the darshan and the deed.
('60', 73, 6, 23, 152310) If there was, I would unhesitatingly say that the deed is better.
('60', 73, 6, 24, 152376) But the function of darshan is to enable the deed to be done, to steady and purify the soul.
('60', 73, 6, 25, 152469) Thus, darshan is not a substitute for right doing.
('60', 73, 6, 26, 152520) It is an encouragement for it.
('60', 73, 6, 27, 152551) In asking the second question, the schoolmaster has missed the whole point of temple worship.
('60', 73, 6, 28, 152645) When I bow to a living person and he returns it, it is a mutual exchange of courtesy and there is no particular merit about it.
('60', 73, 6, 29, 152773) It may be a sign of good breeding.
('60', 73, 6, 30, 152808) Temple going is for the purification of the soul.
('60', 73, 6, 31, 152858) The worshipper draws the best out of himself.
('60', 73, 6, 32, 152904) In greeting a living being, he may draw the best out of the person greeted, if the greeting is selfless.
('60', 73, 6, 33, 153009) A living being is more or less fallible like oneself.
('60', 73, 6, 34, 153063) But in the temple, one worships the living God, perfect beyond imagination.
('60', 73, 6, 35, 153139) Letters written to living persons often end in heartbreaking, even when they are answered, and
('60', 74, 0, 1, 153234) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 75
('60', 74, 1, 2, 153277) there is no guarantee of their being always answered.
('60', 74, 1, 3, 153331) Letters to God, who, according to the devotee’s imagination, resides in temples, require neither pen nor ink nor paper, not even speech.
('60', 74, 1, 4, 153468) Mere mute worship constitutes the letter which brings its own unfailing answer.
('60', 74, 1, 5, 153548) The whole function is a beautiful exercise of faith.
('60', 74, 1, 6, 153601) Here there is no waste of effort, no heart breaking, no danger of being misunderstood.
('60', 74, 1, 7, 153688) The writer must try to understand the simple philosophy lying behind the worship in temples or mosques or churches.
('60', 74, 1, 8, 153804) He will understand my meaning better if he will realize that I make no distinction between these different abodes of God.
('60', 74, 1, 9, 153926) They are what faith has made them.
('60', 74, 1, 10, 153961) They are an answer to man’s craving somehow to reach the Unseen.
('60', 74, 1, 11, 154026) The third question shows, perhaps, that the correspondent has not taken the trouble of understanding the Hindu theory of incarnations.
('60', 74, 1, 12, 154161) For the faithful Hindu, his incarnation is without blemish.
('60', 74, 1, 13, 154221) Krishna of the Hindu devotee is a perfect being.
('60', 74, 1, 14, 154270) He is unconcerned with the harsh judgment of the critics.
('60', 74, 1, 15, 154328) Millions of devotees of Krishna and Rama have had their lives transformed through their contemplation of God by these names.
('60', 74, 1, 16, 154453) How this phenomenon happens I do not know.
('60', 74, 1, 17, 154496) It is a mystery.
('60', 74, 1, 18, 154513) I have not attempted to prove A. Though my reason and heart long ago realized the highest attribute and name of God as Truth, I recognize Truth by the name of Rama.
('60', 74, 1, 19, 154678) In the darkest hour of my trial, that one name has saved me and is still saving me.
('60', 74, 1, 20, 154762) It may be the association of childhood, it may be the fascination that Tulsidas has wrought on me.
('60', 74, 1, 21, 154861) But the potent fact is there, and as I write these lines, my memory revives the scenes of my childhood when I used daily to visit the Ramji Mandir adjacent to my ancestral home.
('60', 74, 1, 22, 155039) My Rama then resided there.
('60', 74, 1, 23, 155067) He saved me from many fears and sins.
('60', 74, 1, 24, 155105) It was no superstition for me.
('60', 74, 1, 25, 155136) The custodian of the idol may have been a bad man.
('60', 74, 1, 26, 155187) I know nothing against him.
('60', 74, 1, 27, 155215) Misdeeds might have gone on in the temple.
('60', 74, 1, 28, 155258) Again I know nothing of them.
('60', 74, 1, 29, 155288) therefore, they would not affect one.
('60', 74, 1, 30, 155326) What was and is true of one is true of millions of Hindus.
('60', 74, 1, 31, 155385) I want my Harijan brother, if he wishes, to share this temple worship with the millions of his co religionists, the so called caste men.
('60', 74, 1, 32, 155522) It is the latter’s duty to throw open their temples their Harijan brethren.
('60', 74, 1, 33, 155598) Temple worship supplies the felt spiritual want of the human race.
('60', 74, 1, 34, 155665) It admits of reform.
('60', 74, 1, 35, 155686) But it will live as long as man lives.
('60', 74, 1, 36, 155725) Harijan, 18 3 1933
('60', 75, 0, 1, 155744) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 75, 1, 2, 155785) 96. THE DANGER OF IMITATION
('60', 75, 2, 3, 155813) I am a humble student of philosophy and so I thoroughly appreciate the movement for the removal of untouchability which has hindered the progress of a large portion of mankind.
('60', 75, 2, 4, 155990) I can also appreciate the way of penance by fast, but there is one difficulty in my way.
('60', 75, 2, 5, 156079) You know that the Bhagavad Gita has said, “What the great ones do, the others follow”, and if a great soul like you set the example of fasting, is there no danger of others blindly imitating you, and quoting your example in support?
('60', 75, 2, 6, 156312) Then again, you talk of the inner voice, and everybody will claim to speak in the name of the inner voice, and it will be held responsible for mixed marriages, mixed dinners, and consequent disruption of society.
('60', 75, 2, 7, 156525) And when such reckless indiscipline takes place in the name of the inner voice, how would you propose to raise the level of the ordinary men, especially of untouchables?
('60', 75, 2, 8, 156695) I must confess that I have considerably abridged the original which is fairly long.
('60', 75, 2, 9, 156779) But I am sure that the substance of the correspondent’s argument has not in any way been lost in the abridgment.
('60', 75, 2, 10, 156892) My answer is simple.
('60', 75, 2, 11, 156913) I accept the teaching of the Gita verse that the correspondent has quoted.
('60', 75, 2, 12, 156988) Surely, it was meant to warn leaders against conduct that might, if copied, result in harm to society.
('60', 75, 2, 13, 157091) It cannot possibly apply to conduct whose intelligent imitation can do no harm.
('60', 75, 2, 14, 157171) For if it did, it would mean an end to all progress and the setting of good examples.
('60', 75, 2, 15, 157257) There is no such thing in human affairs as insurance against all danger.
('60', 75, 2, 16, 157330) There is always danger of even the most irreproachable conduct being misinterpreted and misapplied, but the right thing has got to be, and has always been, done, in spite of the risk of misinterpretation and misapplication.
('60', 75, 2, 17, 157554) I hold my fast to have been wholly good and obligatory on me.
('60', 75, 2, 18, 157616) If the whole of mankind imitated the fast subject to all its conditions, no harm could result.
('60', 75, 2, 19, 157711) A fast that was calculated to affect a big movement for the better could not be given up because of the fear of some people abusing it.
('60', 75, 2, 20, 157847) Penitential fasting is admittedly a good institution.
('60', 75, 2, 21, 157901) And lastly, fasting is its own safeguard against abuse.
('60', 75, 2, 22, 157957) Not many people would be willing to fast, and much fewer still would be able to do so, even though they might be willing.
('60', 75, 2, 23, 158079) Much the same may be said about the inner voice.
('60', 75, 2, 24, 158128) Nobody has to my knowledge questioned the possibility of the inner voice speaking to some, and it is a gain to the world even if one person’s claim to speak under the authority of the inner voice can be really sustained.
('60', 75, 2, 25, 158349) Many may make the claim, but not all will be able to substantiate it.
('60', 75, 2, 26, 158419) But it cannot and ought not to be suppressed for the
('60', 76, 0, 1, 158472) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 77
('60', 76, 1, 2, 158515) sake of preventing false claimants.
('60', 76, 1, 3, 158551) There is no danger whatsoever if many people could truthfully represent the inner voice.
('60', 76, 1, 4, 158640) But, unfortunately, there is no remedy against hypocrisy.
('60', 76, 1, 5, 158698) Virtue must not be suppressed because many will feign it.
('60', 76, 1, 6, 158756) Men have always been found throughout the world claiming to speak for the inner voice.
('60', 76, 1, 7, 158843) But no harm has yet overtaken the world through their short lived activities.
('60', 76, 1, 8, 158921) Before one is able to listen to that voice, one has to go through a long and fairly severe course of training, and when it is the inner voice that speaks it is unmistakable.
('60', 76, 1, 9, 159095) The world cannot be successfully fooled for all time.
('60', 76, 1, 10, 159149) There is, therefore, no danger of anarchy setting in because a humble man like me will not be suppressed and will dare to claim the authority of the inner voice, when he believes that he has heard it.
('60', 76, 1, 11, 159350) Unbridled licence is undoubtedly in the air.
('60', 76, 1, 12, 159395) Everywhere one sees unrest, whether in the religious field or any other.
('60', 76, 1, 13, 159468) The spirit of independence is abroad.
('60', 76, 1, 14, 159506) Youth has always been found to be most impressionable and, therefore, it has naturally fallen a prey to this spirit; and in its haste to realize independence it has missed the central fact that independence can only come out of interdependence and that it is a fruit of long training in self restraint.
('60', 76, 1, 15, 159809) It has forgotten that independence is never synonymous with indulgence.
('60', 76, 1, 16, 159881) The blame for the wildnesses of youth lies, therefore, at the door of the spirit of the times.
('60', 76, 1, 17, 159976) It would be wrong to impute it to the assertion of sterling independence based upon a conscious practice of self restraint and an ever increasing effort implicitly to obey the will of God speaking within and then known as the inner voice.
('60', 76, 1, 18, 160215) It is now, perhaps, easy enough to answer the third question of the humble philosopher.
('60', 76, 1, 19, 160303) The only way to raise the level of Harijans is for the Harijan servants to raise their own level by prayer and penitential fasting and by so training their acoustic faculty as to listen to the inner voice.
('60', 76, 1, 20, 160509) Harijan, 18 3 1933

('60', 86, 1, 2, 177833) 112. A WORTHWHILE SCHEME
('60', 86, 2, 3, 177858) The scheme published by Shri Hiralal Shah regarding the cleanliness of Bhangis is worthy of consideration.
('60', 86, 2, 4, 177965) The aversion to the Bhangis is due to the kind of work they do.
('60', 86, 2, 5, 178029) Here it is beyond doubt that the entire fault is that of the so called high caste Hindus.
('60', 86, 2, 6, 178119) But I have not started writing this to blame anyone.
('60', 86, 2, 7, 178172) We have to consider what our duty is at present and Shri Hiralal’s scheme will help us in doing so.
('60', 86, 2, 8, 178272) The scheme is this: They should wear a special dress when they carry filth and after they have done the cleaning they should be encouraged to take a bath and change their clothes.
('60', 86, 2, 9, 178452) Right now they would do neither of their own accord.
('60', 86, 2, 10, 178505) The object may be achieved only by persuasion and by giving them requisite facilities.
('60', 86, 2, 11, 178592) Munici palities can take up this work on a large scale, but all the householders who utilize the Bhangis’ service can do so in a small way.
('60', 86, 2, 12, 178732) They should employ their own Bhangis, should suggest to them to bathe, should give them the facilities for bathing and should themselves provide them the separate dress.
('60', 86, 2, 13, 178902) One Bhangi family serves many houses.
('60', 86, 2, 14, 178940) One who is conscious of the value of cleanliness should find out the other employers of his Bhangi and should take their help in providing him with a dress; thus no one will find the expense too burdensome.
('60', 86, 2, 15, 179147) If this kind of work continues for some time the Bhangis will develop the habit of remaining clean and untouchability, in so far as it stems from dislike, will be eradicated.
('60', 86, 2, 16, 179322) No one should ignore this easily practicable suggestion by falling a prey to the age old folly that everyone’s work is no one’s work.
('60', 86, 2, 17, 179456) Whoever is in a position to do the work should make a beginning with it and draw other people behind him.
('60', 86, 2, 18, 179562) Along with this, there are two other reforms which can immediately be put into effect: the reform of latrines and in the mode of carrying filth.
('60', 86, 2, 19, 179707) The so called high caste people have kept the Bhangis at a distance, so that their latrines are like the abyss of hell, and the Bhangis are compelled to carry filth in a very odd and cruel way.
('60', 86, 2, 20, 179901) Improvements in latrines can be easily introduced.
('60', 86, 2, 21, 179952) The main requirement is dry earth.
('60', 86, 2, 22, 179987) The practice of carrying baskets of filth on the head should be done away with.
('60', 86, 2, 23, 180067) This movement has already begun in Mathura and Prayag.
('60', 86, 2, 24, 180122) 1 There the filth is carried in a hand cart instead of on the head.
('60', 86, 2, 25, 180190) It is possible that the cart cannot be taken everywhere.
('60', 86, 2, 26, 180247) In such cases, the filth can be carried in a bucket
('60', 86, 3, 27, 180299) 1 Vide “Even Unto These Last”, 18 3 1933.
('60', 87, 0, 1, 180341) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 87, 1, 2, 180382) hung on a rod.
('60', 87, 1, 3, 180397) Where the bucket is not heavy, it can be lifted by hand.
('60', 87, 1, 4, 180454) The practice of carrying the filth on the head is one which can be stopped immediately.

('60', 91, 2, 13, 191349) 115. VARNADHARMA
('60', 91, 3, 14, 191366) A Harijan worker puts me the above question 1. I am not understood because I do not believe in what we today regard as the varna system.
('60', 91, 3, 15, 191503) Varnashrama as we see it today implies restrictions as regards untouchability and intermarriage and inter dining among the varnas.
('60', 91, 3, 16, 191634) I regard today’s untouchability, in Akha’s language, as an extraneous growth fit to be rejected.
('60', 91, 3, 17, 191731) It is not the Shastras but only usage that supports the restriction on intermarriage and inter dining as part of the varnadharma.
('60', 91, 3, 18, 191861) As against this, the varnas have an intimate relation to one’s profession.
('60', 91, 3, 19, 191936) The pursuit of one’s calling is one’s dharma.
('60', 91, 3, 20, 191982) He who forsakes his, falls from his varna.
('60', 91, 3, 21, 192025) He himself is destroyed, his spirit decays.
('60', 91, 3, 22, 192069) That man causes confusion of varnas and thereby society is harmed and its organization breaks down.

('60', 96, 2, 8, 203068) You are not manufacturing enough yarn even to feed those two looms.
('60', 96, 2, 9, 203136) You should therefore go slowly but steadily and extend only when you have a nucleus of trained spinners and trained weavers having perfect control over their work and are able to produce what may be called marketable yarn and khadi.
('60', 96, 2, 10, 203369) If you do not do this, you will share the fate of several organizations that I know have started with a high purpose and a noble motive but for want of efficiency and application have died out.
('60', 96, 2, 11, 203563) This is an industry which requires just as much scientific skill, application and time as any other.
('60', 96, 2, 12, 203664) Indeed this requires a little more, but certainly not less.
('60', 96, 2, 13, 203724) I would therefore ask you to withdraw this public appeal and develop the work silently and unostentatiously, and when you have done that, you will find that you have money waiting for you for extension.

('60', 102, 6, 18, 216208) PREMA, Your suspicion is baseless.
('60', 102, 6, 19, 216243) As you frankly criticize other people and say about them what you feel, so did Mahadev.
('60', 102, 6, 20, 216331) I asked him.
('60', 102, 6, 21, 216344) He sensed disrespect for him in your repeatedly emphasizing “For Mahatmaji”!
('60', 102, 6, 22, 216421) He said what he felt.
('60', 102, 6, 23, 216443) You explained and the matter is over.
('60', 102, 6, 24, 216481) You should learn to endure criticism of you and overcome your sensitiveness.
('60', 102, 6, 25, 216558) Cultivate some sense of humour.
('60', 102, 6, 26, 216590) We should not weigh all the criticism against us with the weight which we use in weighing gold; for some of it, we should use the weights with which we weigh iron or stones.
('60', 102, 6, 27, 216764) And in doing so, we should take no account of half a maund this way or the other.
('60', 102, 6, 28, 216846) You don’t look delicate, but your heart is very sensitive.
('60', 102, 6, 29, 216905) Harden it now and make it less sensitive.
('60', 102, 6, 30, 216947) Instead of reasoning with you, I am now going to order you.
('60', 102, 6, 31, 217007) You may then disregard my order if you wish.
('60', 102, 6, 32, 217052) You are not permitted to disregard others’ orders, but you may disregard mine as often as you like.
('60', 102, 6, 33, 217152) Whether your conduct in doing so is rude or civil, whether your offence is criminal or civil, we shall decide in each case.

('60', 103, 1, 2, 217412) 125. LETTER TO PARIKSHITLAL L. MAJMUDAR March 19, 1933
('60', 103, 2, 3, 217467) BHAISHRI PARIKSHITLAL, I received your sincere letter.
('60', 103, 2, 4, 217522) It is from my own point of view that I find the figure you state to be frightening, but if I accept the other opposite standpoint it is the most reasonable.
('60', 103, 2, 5, 217679) Your duty is that of a soldier.
('60', 103, 2, 6, 217711) You should follow the standard laid down.
('60', 103, 2, 7, 217753) It is for Thakkar Bapa and your local or provincial (or whatever they call it) Committee to lay it down.
('60', 103, 2, 8, 217858) My function is only to point out the direction.
('60', 103, 2, 9, 217906) You may carry out as many of my suggestions as seem practicable in the circumstances.
('60', 103, 2, 10, 217992) There is every risk, and even probability, of the result being contrary to what was intended if my advice is followed mechanically.
('60', 103, 2, 11, 218124) Your first duty, therefore, is to weigh my suggestion in the light of your experience and, if it does not seem sound enough, to set it aside and forget all about it.
('60', 103, 2, 12, 218290) You may put it before your Committee if you find any worth in it.
('60', 103, 2, 13, 218356) If the Committee also approves of it, you should take it to Thakkar Bapa and carry it out only if he also approves of it.
('60', 103, 2, 14, 218478) I will not say more than this here.
('60', 103, 2, 15, 218514) I am now going to discuss my suggestions in the English and the Gujarati editions of the Harijan.
('60', 103, 2, 16, 218612) So you will be able to know about them.
('60', 103, 2, 17, 218652) I state here two rules for your consideration.
('60', 103, 2, 18, 218699) The money needed for propaganda work should be found from such work itself.
('60', 103, 2, 19, 218775) In other words, it should be self supporting.
('60', 103, 2, 20, 218821) 2. Constructive activity is the best propaganda.
('60', 103, 2, 21, 218870) Money invested in it will be fully rewarded.
('60', 103, 2, 22, 218915) BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 20629

('60', 109, 8, 14, 228637) It was arranged years ago.
('60', 109, 8, 15, 228664) We do not know to what varna the husband of the child belongs.
('60', 109, 8, 16, 228727) He was picked up as an orphan boy by one of the members of the Ashram and he has been brought up as his own child.
('60', 109, 8, 17, 228842) So far as varnashrama is concerned, I have expressed my views already in the pages of the Harijan and I have stated my belief that restriction on the intermarriage and inter dining is no part of varnadharma and was not in the palmy days of Hinduism.
('60', 109, 8, 18, 229092) 2 I have also expressed my opinion that at the present moment in India there is in reality but one varna possible, and that is of Shudra, in other words, that of service.
('60', 109, 8, 19, 229263) But you can learn my views more fully from the pages of the Harijan.

('60', 114, 5, 8, 235095) March 22, 1933
('60', 114, 6, 9, 235110) MY DEAR DIWAKAR, I have your letter.
('60', 114, 6, 10, 235147) No doubt the less demonstrative you are the better and more permanent your work will be.
('60', 114, 6, 11, 235236) Your last paragraph makes bad reading.
('60', 114, 6, 12, 235275) You say, “Sweeping of public roads has become irregular.” That’s wrong.
('60', 114, 6, 13, 235347) Having started the work you should have done it with scientific precision and regularity.
('60', 114, 6, 14, 235437) Your irregular scavenging will produce no effect on the public.
('60', 114, 6, 15, 235501) You saw with what trumpeting the work was inaugurated and I read with pleasure that you were thinking of constructing special carts or wheelbarrows for removing the refuse.
('60', 114, 6, 16, 235674) But this can be necessary only if you are doing your work thoroughly.
('60', 114, 6, 17, 235744) Your energy will be frittered away if you will jump from work to work without doing anything completely.
('60', 114, 6, 18, 235849) What will happen if after having half finished a table, a cabinet maker began a chair and so on?
('60', 114, 6, 19, 235946) Will you not call it all a waste of effort?
('60', 114, 6, 20, 235990) That is precisely what happens generally to philanthropic undertakings.
('60', 114, 6, 21, 236062) I would like you to guard yourself against that error.
('60', 114, 6, 22, 236117) If you will do the street cleaning then you must have a map and a programme according to the number of volunteers you have, and after you have begun a street, you may not leave it till its dwellers have taken up the cleaning themselves.
('60', 114, 6, 23, 236354) In order to impress them with the necessity of so doing, you will have to be gentle and patient with them, and your cleaning will have to be so thorough as to excite their pleasure and admiration, and when that happens you will see that the thing will work, but you will have to concentrate your attention wholly
('60', 114, 7, 24, 236667) 1 The names have been omitted.

('60', 118, 2, 3, 240203) March 22, 1933 THE SECRETARY THE JATHI NASHINI SABHA CANNANORE
('60', 118, 3, 4, 240266) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('60', 118, 3, 5, 240299) Though you can read your meaning in my writing, I must confess that I am too dense to read my meaning in your writing.
('60', 118, 3, 6, 240418) You are no doubt satisfied that I do not recognize any distinction between high and low.
('60', 118, 3, 7, 240507) Are you equally satisfied that everyone should pursue his ancestral occupation so as to conserve national energy, national talent, avoid unequal distribution of wealth and keen competition?
('60', 118, 3, 8, 240697) If you are, then you will alter the aims and objects of your Sabha, but if you are not prepared to alter the aims and objects in accordance with the idea presented, you might agree with me that your prosecution of your aims and objects is likely to create confusion and suspicion if you tack it on to untouchability.
('60', 118, 3, 9, 241014) Do you not observe that I do not tack on even reformed varnadharma to untouchability?
('60', 118, 3, 10, 241100) I have simply stated my position in order to avoid misunderstanding, and, what is more important still, the charge of suppressing my opinion in order to gain adherence for the cause of the abolition of untouchability.
('60', 118, 4, 11, 241318) Yours sincerely,

('60', 119, 5, 16, 243038) March 22, 1933
('60', 119, 6, 17, 243053) NARANDAS,
('60', 119, 7, 18, 243063) I got your big packet of mail.
('60', 119, 7, 19, 243094) It was a great thing indeed that the [Chamar] children gave up buffalo flesh.
('60', 119, 7, 20, 243172) But there may possibly have been violence behind this.
('60', 119, 7, 21, 243227) If they parted with it through fear, what happened was bad.
('60', 119, 7, 22, 243287) If they so wished they should have been given some compensation for giving it up since it was their food.
('60', 119, 7, 23, 243393) Hence you or some other responsible inmate of the Ashram should go and ask them.
('60', 119, 7, 24, 243474) It would be fine if they handed over the flesh of their own accord and could give up eating buffalo flesh for ever.
('60', 119, 7, 25, 243590) If they are not ready to do that, we should have patience with them.
('60', 119, 7, 26, 243659) You should find out from them or from Chamars who have connections with the Ashram the money value of a carcass.
('60', 119, 7, 27, 243772) Try and find out from them, if you can, what the hide, intestines, bones, etc., would fetch if sold separately and how they use these things.
('60', 120, 0, 1, 243914) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 121
('60', 120, 1, 2, 243958) If anybody else feels sick as Duncan did, you should immediately apply hot fomentation on the abdomen and give the person a piece of ice or lemon to suck.
('60', 120, 1, 3, 244113) He may also drink cold water one tea spoonful at a time.
('60', 120, 1, 4, 244170) Very often the vomiting stops with these measures.
('60', 120, 1, 5, 244221) If one had not eaten any poisonous food, there is no cause for alarm at all.
('60', 120, 1, 6, 244298) An enema also will stop vomiting.
('60', 120, 1, 7, 244332) You should tell this to all who live in the Ashram.
('60', 120, 1, 8, 244384) Impure attraction had sprung up between .
('60', 120, 1, 9, 244426) 1 and .
('60', 120, 1, 10, 244434) 2 They hid their love for quite a long time.

('60', 120, 1, 12, 244511) They used to meet secretly and also write to each other secretly.
('60', 120, 1, 13, 244577) I have still not been able to fathom what is in their hearts.
('60', 120, 1, 14, 244639) I do not know how far .
('60', 120, 1, 15, 244663) .’s passion has carried him.
('60', 120, 1, 16, 244692) Neither seems to have purified his or her heart of lust.
('60', 120, 1, 17, 244749) We have a rigid rule, to which no exception is condoned, that all young men and women who live in the Ashram as inmates should regard one another as brothers and sisters.
('60', 120, 1, 18, 244920) The love of these two had gone beyond that relationship.
('60', 120, 1, 19, 244977) The men and women living in the Ashram are forbidden to meet each other alone.
('60', 120, 1, 20, 245056) These two have violated that rule.
('60', 120, 1, 21, 245091) And they also tried, successfully, to deceive the whole Ashram, which means that they have violated our chief vow, that of truth.

('60', 126, 2, 3, 255229) March 23, 1933
('60', 126, 3, 4, 255244) TO THE HOME SECRETARY TO THE GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY
('60', 126, 4, 5, 255294) DEAR SIR, I have just had the Government’s reply to my letter of the 18th instant.
('60', 126, 4, 6, 255377) 1 I fear that the reply raises a vital issue which I thought the Government had decided once for all in 1922 2. The very principle that the Government have now communicated was departed from in that year.
('60', 126, 4, 7, 255582) Then too it was a question of fasting by the fellow prisoners.
('60', 126, 4, 8, 255645) Major Jones was then the Superintendent.
('60', 126, 4, 9, 255686) When the fasting became known to me, I sought an interview with the prisoners so that I could advise them.
('60', 126, 4, 10, 255793) Major Jones would not listen to my proposal.
('60', 126, 4, 11, 255838) I had to approach H.E. the then Governor, and I was permitted to see the prisoners with the happiest of results.
('60', 126, 4, 12, 255951) 3 Exactly the same question arose in 1930 when I was incarcerated for the second time.
('60', 126, 4, 13, 256038) 4 Major Martin was the Superintendent and he would not listen to my request to see a fasting prisoner.
('60', 126, 4, 14, 256141) There was correspondence with Government in which I suggested that I was humanitarian above everything else and that I could not exist without being able to make use of my influence as such, wherever it was possible to do so.
('60', 126, 4, 15, 256367) Here there was not the slightest intention of disturbing the prison discipline and at last my contention was allowed by Government and I was permitted to see prisoners every week, so as to understand their position, and wherever necessary offer helpful suggestions.
('60', 126, 4, 16, 256633) So far as I am aware Major Martin never had any occasion to deplore the Government’s decision to allow me the liberty.
('60', 126, 4, 17, 256752) That liberty has been continued during this incarceration, with restriction as to the number of prisoners I may see during any single fortnight.
('60', 126, 4, 18, 256897) And I am not aware of any inconvenience having been thereby caused to Major Bhandari.
('60', 126, 4, 19, 256983) The Superintendents under whom
('60', 126, 5, 20, 257014) 1 Vide”Letter to Home Secretary, Government of Bombay”, 18 3 1933. 2 This should be 1923. 3 Vide “Letter to F.C. Griffiths”, 17 7 1923 and “Jail Diary, 1923”.

('60', 130, 6, 9, 262708) 163. LETTER TO BOYD TUCKER
('60', 130, 7, 10, 262735) March 23, 1933
('60', 130, 8, 11, 262750) MY DEAR BOYD, You can never tire my patience, for I value the interest you are taking in everything I say or write or do.
('60', 130, 8, 12, 262872) I know also that you do not argue in any spirit of controversy.
('60', 130, 8, 13, 262936) I see your difficulty.
('60', 130, 8, 14, 262959) You take or seem to take only one view of things.
('60', 130, 8, 15, 263009) I have a profound faith in the Jain doctrine of Anekantvad.
('60', 130, 8, 16, 263069) It is the manysidedness as opposed to one sidedness.
('60', 130, 8, 17, 263122) To illustrate this celebrated doctrine we have a well known story of ‘the elephant and seven blind men’, all of whom described the same creature in seven different ways, and the poet ends by saying ‘they were all true and they were all false’, and we may add ‘God alone is true, no one and nothing else is or can be wholly true.’ Holding this view I can appreciate and defend your attitude, but I can also defend my own.
('60', 130, 8, 18, 263543) If the world will be influenced by my attitude on the question of temple entry, not in its own way but in my way, I have no fear about its moral safety.

('60', 131, 6, 21, 265006) Why should we fear the consequence of doing what is right?
('60', 131, 6, 22, 265065) Let other caste Hindus not go to that temple; at any rate you and Ramabehn, the Maharaja, Ranisaheba, etc., will go.

('60', 131, 6, 27, 265548) Even the sanatanists should not object to the Harijans being permitted to go to one of them.

('60', 135, 3, 4, 270792) MIRA, Your letter came in yesterday.
('60', 135, 3, 5, 270829) It is now 3.15 morning.
('60', 135, 3, 6, 270853) I am glad you are free from constipation.
('60', 135, 3, 7, 270895) You won’t feel the heat at all if you will continuously keep the wet cloth on the head.
('60', 135, 3, 8, 270983) It cools the whole system.
('60', 135, 3, 9, 271010) I do not know how they bring your milk.
('60', 135, 3, 10, 271050) If it is strained as soon as it is milked or if it is bottled immediately and well corked and wrapped in a wet cloth, it should keep for many hours and drunk cold and unfired.
('60', 135, 3, 11, 271226) I have given up fired milk altogether without any ill consequence.
('60', 135, 3, 12, 271293) I get all the vitamins and perhaps only one pound that I take gives me more strength than more of boiled milk will.
('60', 135, 3, 13, 271409) I am still on milk and paupau and oranges and dates.
('60', 135, 3, 14, 271462) Oranges I take only once.
('60', 135, 3, 15, 271488) This appears to be quite enough, perhaps more than enough.
('60', 135, 3, 16, 271547) But what I want to tell you is that if you can manage unfired milk you will suffer less from the heat.
('60', 135, 3, 17, 271650) The milk must be kept in as airtight a bottle as possible and the latter put in a wet cloth.
('60', 135, 3, 18, 271743) The wet cloth keeps it ice cold.
('60', 135, 3, 19, 271776) You may strain it through a cloth before you.
('60', 135, 3, 20, 271822) The cloth should be washed well immediately after use and so should the bottle.
('60', 135, 3, 21, 271902) If that is done, I should feel quite at ease even though you may take your milk unfired.
('60', 135, 3, 22, 271991) I think I have made my instructions quite clear.
('60', 135, 3, 23, 272040) If you do not like the change and are otherwise feeling quite well, you need not make the change.

('60', 143, 4, 16, 284975) 180. NOTES
('60', 143, 5, 17, 284986) WILL NOT TEMPLES BE DESERTED?
('60', 143, 6, 18, 285016) An M.A.,LL.B. enquires:
('60', 143, 7, 19, 285040) If temple entry is allowed to Harijans, it is highly likely that the caste Hindus and the priests will desert them.
('60', 143, 7, 20, 285156) In that event, of what avail would the right of temple entry be?
('60', 143, 7, 21, 285221) My only answer to this question should be that the corresp ondent evidently does not follow the movement but has simply condemned it, as his question implies and as I know from his long letter from which I have taken the question.
('60', 143, 7, 22, 285452) But such an answer will not be sufficient for the cause.
('60', 143, 7, 23, 285509) Let the correspondent and those who think like him understand that the contingency that they contemplate can never happen, because the movement is not designed to force entry into any single temple, whether by law or otherwise.
('60', 143, 7, 24, 285737) The assistance of the Legislature is being sought in order to make it possible to throw open temples where public opinion is ripe.
('60', 143, 7, 25, 285868) It is impossible today even where public opinion unanimously desires it.
('60', 143, 7, 26, 285941) When, therefore, caste Hindus, as also the priests, desire the entry of Harijans into particular temples side by side with them, there can be no question whatsoever of the temples being deserted.
('60', 143, 7, 27, 286137) When the temple entry of Harijans is permitted under
('60', 144, 0, 1, 286190) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 145
('60', 144, 1, 2, 286234) these voluntary conditions, the temples would be all the purer for their admission, as is the case with numerous private temples which have been opened and which have not been deserted either by the priests or the caste Hindus.
('60', 144, 2, 3, 286462) WOMEN WORKERS IN CUTTACK
('60', 144, 3, 4, 286487) Shrimati Rama Devi 1 of Cuttack sends me a letter in Hindi, giving an account of the work being done by the women of Cuttack amongst Harijans.
('60', 144, 3, 5, 286630) I give a translation of portions of the letter: Since October I have been working amongst Harijans, with seven other sisters.
('60', 144, 3, 6, 286756) We confine our attention to Cuttack only.
('60', 144, 3, 7, 286798) We are all volunteers, working under the direction of the Anti untou chability Board.
('60', 144, 3, 8, 286884) The only pecuniary assistance we receive is in the shape of books and medicine from the Municipality.
('60', 144, 3, 9, 286986) The stock of medicine is supplemented by local Kavirajs.
('60', 144, 3, 10, 287043) We have distributed ourselves in four bastis of Bhangis, allotting two workers to each.
('60', 144, 3, 11, 287131) We give instructions in the three R’s to the girls, teach them bhajans and read to them simple religious books.
('60', 144, 3, 12, 287243) We distribute medicines amongst the ailing inhabitants, clean their quarters, report their special difficulties to the Committee, and we put before the womenfolk the desirability of refraining from eating beef or carrion.
('60', 144, 3, 13, 287465) They were afraid of us when we first approached them.
('60', 144, 3, 14, 287519) They had no faith in what we said to them and would not even listen.
('60', 144, 3, 15, 287588) Slowly they shed their fear of us and now they do listen to us to some extent.
('60', 144, 3, 16, 287667) We hope to get other volunteers amongst the women of Cuttack.
('60', 144, 3, 17, 287729) Some girls have already begun work with us.
('60', 144, 3, 18, 287773) I congratulate these sisters of Cuttack on their devotion to the cause of the much desired reform.
('60', 144, 3, 19, 287872) Women are special custodians of all that is pure and religious in life.
('60', 144, 3, 20, 287944) Conservative by nature, if they are slow to shed superstitious habits, they are also slow to give up all that is pure and noble in life.
('60', 144, 3, 21, 288081) In this struggle for religious reform, therefore, the women of India may be expected to take a leading part.
('60', 144, 3, 22, 288190) I hope, therefore, that the example of the women of Cuttack will prove infectious and that the work begun by Shrimati Rama Devi and her companions will be continued in spite of the difficulties and disappointments that they might have to face.
('60', 144, 4, 23, 288434) 1 Rama Devi Choudhry.
('60', 144, 4, 24, 288456) Vide also “Letter to Rama Devi Choudhry”, 4 4 1933.

('60', 145, 1, 2, 288550) WHAT MORE CAN I DO?
('60', 145, 2, 3, 288570) A correspondent from the South writes:
('60', 145, 3, 4, 288609) I and my friend bought Khadi worth Rs. 20 and distributed it amongst Harijan brethren.
('60', 145, 3, 5, 288696) I presided at a meeting advocating removal of untouchability and I am proud to be able to say that my friends are taking steps in the direction.
('60', 145, 3, 6, 288841) What more can I do?
('60', 145, 3, 7, 288861) This is a curious question.
('60', 145, 3, 8, 288889) But I have not taken it literally.
('60', 145, 3, 9, 288924) The writer, I am sure, does not mean to convey that he is fully satisfied with what he has done.
('60', 145, 3, 10, 289021) But whether he is or not, in my opinion no one can afford, in this big campaign, to be satisfied with giving a little of his substance and occasionally presiding at meetings, assuming, of course, that he or she has much more time at their disposal.
('60', 145, 3, 11, 289270) When the spirit of reform seizes one, hundreds of things will press upon one’s attention.
('60', 145, 3, 12, 289360) It is not, however, for me to say what a particular person should do.
('60', 145, 3, 13, 289430) He must take up the whole programme of the Servants of Untouchables Society and do all those things which it may be possible for him to do, consistently with his other obligations.
('60', 145, 3, 14, 289611) The programme of the Society is merely illustrative, by no means exhaustive; therefore, it is open to anyone to supplement it, so as to meet with any peculiar circumstances that may be prevalent in his own locality.

('60', 146, 1, 2, 290258) THE MUCH MALIGNED BRAHMIN
('60', 146, 2, 3, 290284) A Bengali Professor 1 writes a long letter from which I take the following extracts:
('60', 146, 3, 4, 290369) You will be distressed to learn that the anti untouchability movement in certain parts of the country has degenerated into a vile and violent propa ganda against Brahminism and all that it stands for.
('60', 146, 3, 5, 290570) Misleading half truths and deliberate untruths are being assiduously circulated in order to lower the Brahmins as a class in the estimation of the general public.
('60', 146, 3, 6, 290733) Is the practice of untouchability confined exclusively to the Brahmins?
('60', 146, 3, 7, 290805) Are not the other caste Hindus equally guilty?
('60', 146, 3, 8, 290852) Even admitting that the Shastras were made by the Brahmins, where is the proof that the Shastras enjoin a rabid type of untouchability as is practised today in certain parts of India?
('60', 146, 4, 9, 291036) Is it not a fact that the Brahmins have made a very substantial contri bution towards the success of the present anti untouchability movement?
('60', 146, 4, 10, 291179) Is it not, again, true that the majority of those of our worthy M.L.A.s who have adopted an obstructionist attitude towards the Temple entry Bill happen to be other than Brahmins ?
('60', 146, 4, 11, 291360) Why, then, this tirade against the Brahmins, who perhaps realize more than anybody else the gravity of the situation created by the scourge of untouchability?
('60', 146, 4, 12, 291519) Except for the writings in the papers and periodicals repre senting the anti Brahmin movement which has been going on in the country for some years and which was inaugurated long before the campaign against untouchability was, I have not seen any attack, violent or otherwise, upon Brahminism.
('60', 146, 4, 13, 291813) Certainly the Servants of Untouchables Society has had nothing to do with any such attack, and the writer is quite right in saying that I would be distressed if I learnt that the anti untouchability movement had degenerated into a vile and violent propaganda against Brahminism.
('60', 146, 4, 14, 292092) I have, therefore, asked the correspondent to furnish me with the evidence that may be in his possession to prove the serious statement he has made.
('60', 146, 4, 15, 292241) The letter enables me, however, to reiterate my own opinion of Brahminism and Brahmins.
('60', 146, 4, 16, 292329) I believe Brahminism to be unadulterated wisdom leading one to the realization of Brahman, that is God.
('60', 146, 4, 17, 292433) If I did not hold that view, I should no longer call myself a Hindu.
('60', 146, 4, 18, 292502) Brahmins, however, like all the
('60', 146, 5, 19, 292534) 1 R. R. Chakravarti.
('60', 147, 0, 1, 292555) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 147, 1, 2, 292597) other members of the human family, are not all true representatives of Brahminism.
('60', 147, 1, 3, 292680) But I have to believe that, of all the classes in the world, the Brahmin will show the largest percentage of those who have given up their all in search of knowledge, that is Truth.
('60', 147, 1, 4, 292862) I know of no system other than Hinduism under which a class has been set apart from generation to generation for the exclusive pursuit of divine knowledge and consigned to voluntary poverty.
('60', 147, 1, 5, 293053) That Brahmins could not keep up the high standard that they had imposed upon themselves is no special fault of theirs.
('60', 147, 1, 6, 293172) Their imperfection merely proves that they were as fallible as the rest of mankind, and so corruption crept into the so called sacred books, and we have the spectacle of the most selfless rules governing Brahmins side by side with the selfish rules also made by them in order to help their breed.
('60', 147, 1, 7, 293469) But it was the Brahmins who rose against the corruptions and selfish interpolations into the sacred texts.
('60', 147, 1, 8, 293576) It was they who time and again strove to purge themselves and society of evil.
('60', 147, 1, 9, 293655) I confess that I have the highest reverence for Brahminism and a sneaking regard for Brahmins and that, in spite of what is to me the sorrowful spectacle of Brahmins so called making a frantic effort against the reform movement and lending their undoubted ability to the opposition, I am consoled, and let every unbiased Hindu be consoled, by the fact that the reform movement, too, is being led by those who are born Brahmins but who today take no pride in their birth.
('60', 147, 1, 10, 294126) If a census was taken of all the workers against untouchability, I think it will be found that the majority of workers who are devoted to the cause without any remuneration or with only just enough to keep body and soul together are Brahmins.
('60', 147, 1, 11, 294369) But I admit that Brahmins as a class have suffered degradation.
('60', 147, 1, 12, 294433) If they had not, if they had lived up to their profession, Hinduism would not be in the degraded state in which it is.
('60', 147, 1, 13, 294552) It would be a contradiction in terms to suggest that Hinduism is what it is in spite of the correct life of the Brahmins.
('60', 147, 1, 14, 294674) That could not be, because the Brahmins themselves have taught us to believe that they are the true custodians of the divine wisdom and that, where there is divine wisdom, there is no fear, there is no grinding pauperism, there is no high and low state, there is no greed, jealousy, war, plunder and the like.
('60', 147, 1, 15, 294984) Because Brahminism went down, it drew down with it all the other classes of Hindus, and I have not a shadow of doubt in my mind that, if Brahminism does not revive, Hinduism must perish, and for me the infallible test of the revival of Brahminism, that is, Hinduism, is the root and branch removal of untouchability.
('60', 147, 1, 16, 295301) The more I study the Hindu scriptures and the more I
('60', 148, 0, 1, 295354) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 149
('60', 148, 1, 2, 295398) discuss them with all kinds of Brahmins, the more I feel convinced that untouchability is the greatest blot upon Hinduism.
('60', 148, 1, 3, 295521) This conviction is amply supported by many learned Brahmins who have no axes to grind, who are devoted to the pursuit of truth and who receive nothing, not even thanks for their opinion.
('60', 148, 1, 4, 295708) But today Brahmins and Kshatriyas, Vaishyas and Shudras are mere labels.
('60', 148, 1, 5, 295781) There is utter confusion of varna as I understand it and as I have explained it in these columns, and I wish that all the Hindus will voluntarily call themselves Shudras.
('60', 148, 1, 6, 295952) That is the only way to demonstrate the truth of Brahminism and to revive varnadharma in its true state.
('60', 148, 1, 7, 296057) Because all Hindus may be classed as Shudras, wisdom and power and wealth will not disappear, but they will be all used for the service of not a sectional religion but the service of Truth and humanity.
('60', 148, 1, 8, 296260) Anyway, in battling against untouchability and in dedicating myself to that battle, I have no less an ambition than to see a complete regeneration of humanity.
('60', 148, 1, 9, 296420) It may be a mere dream, as unreal as the silver in the sea shell.
('60', 148, 1, 10, 296486) It is not so to me while the dream lasts, and in the words of Romain Rolland, ‘‘Victory lies not in realization of the goal but in a relentless pursuit after it.”
('60', 148, 2, 11, 296649) Harijan, 25 3 1933
('60', 148, 3, 12, 296668) 182. IDEAL HARIJAN TEACHER
('60', 148, 4, 13, 296695) The question is being asked as to what I expect of a teacher of Harijans.
('60', 148, 4, 14, 296769) I admit that my test is exacting, but it will be found also that it is none too exacting for a willing worker.
('60', 148, 4, 15, 296880) Moreover, my test is the only real test, if it is granted that this movement has a purely religious motive behind it.
('60', 148, 4, 16, 296998) I may also add that I tried the experiment with complete success, while it lasted, in Champaran years ago.
('60', 148, 4, 17, 297105) 1 It could not be continued, because my stay in Champaran proved to be brief, and the volunteers who had offered their services had undertaken merely to give a start, the idea being to raise local teachers of the type contemplated.
('60', 148, 4, 18, 297337) Let me briefly describe the teachers and the experiment.
('60', 148, 4, 19, 297394) The teachers were Avantikabai Gokhale, Anandibai Vaisham payan, Kasturbai Gandhi, Manibehn Parikh, Dharanidharbabu, Nara hari Parikh, Babasaheb Soman, Chhotelal Jain and Devdas Gandhi.
('60', 148, 5, 20, 297579) 1 Vide a “An Autobiography—Part V, Chapter XVII”.
('60', 149, 0, 1, 297629) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 149, 1, 2, 297671) These were all, of course, responsible men and women, some of them pleaders and graduates.
('60', 149, 1, 3, 297762) None of them were trained teachers.
('60', 149, 1, 4, 297798) The majority had no knowledge of Hindi except that they could, with more or less difficulty, make themselves understood.
('60', 149, 1, 5, 297919) Kasturbai Gandhi was illiterate but was in no way behindhand to other teachers.
('60', 149, 1, 6, 297999) These were spread out in four or five villages.
('60', 149, 1, 7, 298047) I forget the exact number for the moment.
('60', 149, 1, 8, 298089) They were to start with the children but finish with the men and women.
('60', 149, 1, 9, 298161) A knowledge of the three R’s was only one of the items.
('60', 149, 1, 10, 298217) They had to look after their health and their character.
('60', 149, 1, 11, 298274) They were not to use corporal punishment on any account whatsoever.
('60', 149, 1, 12, 298342) Work was to be like play.
('60', 149, 1, 13, 298368) The children—boys and girls— were on no account to be tired out.
('60', 149, 1, 14, 298433) The first business of the teacher was to examine the appearance of each boy and girl—their eyes, ears, teeth, hair, nails, etc., and clean them, wherever necessary, and teach the boys to keep themselves clean, to see to it that the children behaved properly towards one another and that they did not use foul language.
('60', 149, 1, 15, 298752) Let me say in parenthesis that the non Hindi teachers learnt their Hindi from the children.
('60', 149, 1, 16, 298844) They were otherwise so raw that the teachers could merely see that the children traced the alphabet correctly and count the numerals in proper sequence.
('60', 149, 1, 17, 298997) The central fact was to create round the school an atmosphere of culture.
('60', 149, 1, 18, 299071) The teachers were given no domestic servants.
('60', 149, 1, 19, 299117) They had to do their own cooking, washing, etc.
('60', 149, 1, 20, 299165) Where there were no buildings, they were to help building bamboo huts.
('60', 149, 1, 21, 299236) In every case, clean, open spaces and, in my opinion, the simple art of the rustic were insisted upon.
('60', 149, 1, 22, 299339) Paraffin tin shanties or dungheap surroundings were religiously shun ned.
('60', 149, 1, 23, 299413) In one instance we were able to secure the site of a temple.
('60', 149, 1, 24, 299474) In every case the school became the pride of the villagers and a centre of culture.
('60', 149, 1, 25, 299558) But it had also to radiate its direct influence upon the grownup men and women.
('60', 149, 1, 26, 299638) They received medical aid and therethrough also object lessons in cleanliness, etc.
('60', 149, 1, 27, 299722) The teachers’ living quarters, which were adjacent to the school, or where both house and school combined, were to be the dispensary of the village and contained stock of quinine, an opening medicine, and an ointment with dressings.
('60', 149, 1, 28, 299955) They were to confine their attention to constipation, malaria and simple ulcers.
('60', 149, 1, 29, 300036) The dispensaries were organized under the late lamented Dr. Dev of the Servants of India Society who personally
('60', 150, 0, 1, 300148) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 151
('60', 150, 1, 2, 300192) supervised this department of relief and attended to all serious cases.
('60', 150, 1, 3, 300264) He penetrated the homes of the villagers and transformed little Bhitiharva in a few weeks’ time from a dung and mud sodden village into a clean looking cluster of hamlets with the willing assistance of the villagers, and if I remember rightly, without the cost of a single pice.
('60', 150, 1, 4, 300543) Dr. Dev was not a mere overseer of works.
('60', 150, 1, 5, 300585) He was himself the leading labourer working with the spade and the shovel.
('60', 150, 1, 6, 300660) What Dr. Dev himself did in Bhitiharva the teachers did with more or less success in the other villages.
('60', 150, 1, 7, 300765) The village roads and wells were cleaned.
('60', 150, 1, 8, 300807) Inroads were made into the huts with the willing consent of the dwellers.
('60', 150, 1, 9, 300881) Their little yards were cleaned for them in the first instance.
('60', 150, 1, 10, 300945) The teachers had to become one with the villagers, share their troubles and sorrows and point to them the way to health and happiness in that malaria and superstition ridden, unknown part of India, once the land of Janak and Sita.
('60', 150, 1, 11, 301176) It was in remote Bhitiharva that Kasturbai made the discovery that several women had no wardrobe but the one ragged sari on their persons.
('60', 150, 1, 12, 301315) When one of the poor but dignified ladies was gently advised to bathe daily, she hotly replied,” Come into my room, see if I have a change of sari and then give me your advice.
('60', 150, 1, 13, 301492) You don’t expect a lady to bathe naked, do you?” There was nothing more to be said.
('60', 150, 1, 14, 301576) When I heard the tragic story, I could but drop a silent tear in shame and sorrow.
('60', 150, 1, 15, 301659) I need hardly carry the description any further.
('60', 150, 1, 16, 301708) The would be teacher of Harijans can easily fill in the details.
('60', 150, 1, 17, 301773) That was my very first experiment in village schools, as it was my first living experience of Indian villages.
('60', 150, 1, 18, 301884) Fifteen years have rolled by since.
('60', 150, 1, 19, 301920) My experience has widened considerably.
('60', 150, 1, 20, 301960) During these years I have seen hundreds of villages.
('60', 150, 1, 21, 302013) I fancy I understand their wants much better than I did in 1917. To my ideal school for Harijans, therefore, I would add handicrafts, and most certainly begin with spinning and other cotton processes.
('60', 150, 1, 22, 302214) I would add night schools for both the grown ups and the children.
('60', 150, 1, 23, 302281) I would entertain no high hopes of success.
('60', 150, 1, 24, 302325) I would not even attempt to carry things by storm.
('60', 150, 1, 25, 302376) I would, on the other hand, approach my work in due humility and infinite faith in my mission.
('60', 150, 1, 26, 302471) I would let the children and the parents dominate me before I dream of dominating them.
('60', 150, 1, 27, 302559) I would seek to qualify myself as their servant by right of love, in the fullest confidence that in the end I would dominate not them but their hearts.
('60', 150, 1, 28, 302711) I have already outlined this scheme before two co workers, one a High
('60', 151, 0, 1, 302781) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 151, 1, 2, 302823) Court pleader and the other a very well educated sister.
('60', 151, 1, 3, 302880) Each wanted to know how they could take up immediate service.
('60', 151, 1, 4, 302942) And I gave them each a fair half hour inviting them to be the ideal teacher.
('60', 151, 1, 5, 303019) I now present the invitation to every servant of Harijan who is in need of work.
('60', 151, 1, 6, 303100) I offer no pay.
('60', 151, 1, 7, 303116) But I undertake to find villages for those who cannot.
('60', 151, 1, 8, 303171) Everyone has to pay his or her own expenses and if he or she is too poor, he or she has to beg enough from his or her friends.
('60', 151, 1, 9, 303298) The teacher has to live like a Harijan.
('60', 151, 1, 10, 303338) Therefore, not much expense is needed.
('60', 151, 1, 11, 303377) The school building will be any verandah or open space that might be offered by the Harijans.
('60', 151, 1, 12, 303471) ‘‘Where there’s the will there’s the way.”
('60', 151, 2, 13, 303514) Harijan, 25 3 1933
('60', 151, 3, 14, 303533) 183. AUNDH STATE AND UNTOUCHABILITY
('60', 151, 4, 15, 303569) I had requested Pandit Satavlekar, the well known Vedic scholar of Aundh, to acquaint me with facts about the anti untouchability movement in the Auadh State, as I had seen reports about it in the Press.
('60', 151, 4, 16, 303773) His letter traces the progress of the movement during the last ten years and recounts the difficulties in the way of the reformer.
('60', 151, 4, 17, 303904) I give below a condensed rendering of his Hindi letters: There are 72 villages in the State.
('60', 151, 4, 18, 303997) The Chief is a Brahmin of advanced views and wants untouchability to go.
('60', 151, 4, 19, 304070) Ten years ago, he invited the so called untouchables in the State to fulfil the following three conditions, in order to enable him to declare them on a level with other Hindus and entitled to temple entry: 1. giving up of carrion, 2. giving up eating leavings of food, 3. daily bath.
('60', 151, 4, 20, 304354) These simple conditions were proclaimed in all the villages.
('60', 151, 4, 21, 304415) The response was not encouraging.
('60', 151, 4, 22, 304449) This was in effect the reply received from every one of the villages: (1) It is impossible for us to give up carrion as we get it free.
('60', 151, 4, 23, 304585) We can think of giving up carrion if we are given clean meat in lieu of it.
('60', 151, 4, 24, 304661) (2) We would fain give up leavings of food.
('60', 151, 4, 25, 304705) Give us clean food instead.
('60', 151, 4, 26, 304733) (3) There is not enough water for bathing and washing.
('60', 152, 0, 1, 304788) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 153
('60', 152, 1, 2, 304832) (4) We are indifferent as regards temple entry.
('60', 152, 1, 3, 304880) The matter was allowed to rest there.
('60', 152, 1, 4, 304918) Then came Sjt.
('60', 152, 1, 5, 304933) V. R. Shinde, the great abolitionist, who visited them in their homes and appealed to them to avail themselves of the Chief’s offer.
('60', 152, 1, 6, 305066) He also asked them to abolish untouchability amongst themselves.
('60', 152, 1, 7, 305131) This appeal, too, fell on deaf ears.
('60', 152, 1, 8, 305168) After this I started a village sanitation programme.
('60', 152, 1, 9, 305221) We went out every morning singing prabhat pheris and offering to clean the courtyards and surroundings of houses of which the tenants were indifferent.
('60', 152, 1, 10, 305373) The results were somewhat encouraging.
('60', 152, 1, 11, 305412) We offered soap and other washing facilities to those who were doing scavenging.
('60', 152, 1, 12, 305493) But they said it was too much to expect them to keep clean, when they had to earn their living from an unclean occupation.
('60', 152, 1, 13, 305616) This was followed up by propaganda in the shape of bhajans, kathas, and special fairs.
('60', 152, 1, 14, 305703) Classes were held to familiarize the Harijans with religious books.
('60', 152, 1, 15, 305771) Schools with two teachers—an untouchable and a touchable—were started to induce them to learn the three R’s.
('60', 152, 1, 16, 305880) No grown ups came forward, but youngsters did come and are still coming to these schools.
('60', 152, 1, 17, 305970) Here is an account of the present state of things: The State schools are open to all, and they are being availed of by Harijan children.
('60', 152, 1, 18, 306107) Harijans may visit temples after a bath, and they are doing so.
('60', 152, 1, 19, 306171) In October last, a Health Day was held, volunteers were posted in every Harijan quarter and the Chief was good enough to announce prizes to those whose houses and surroundings were found to pass the test of cleanliness.
('60', 152, 1, 20, 306391) One month’s intensive work before the Day was enough to do the trick.
('60', 152, 1, 21, 306461) Every street and every Harijan quarter was a model of cleanliness.
('60', 152, 1, 22, 306528) In fact, some Harijan houses in Aundh looked cleaner than Brahmin houses.
('60', 152, 1, 23, 306602) His Highness, with the Ranisaheba, made a point of visiting every quarter and in Aundh alone, 105 prizes were awarded, half of them being won by the Harijans.
('60', 152, 1, 24, 306761) The Rani saheba went into every Harijan house, made inquiries about their appointments and needs, and the Harijan women honoured her with marking with their own hands her forehead with the auspicious kumkum mark.
('60', 152, 1, 25, 306974) This led to a general awakening throughout the State.
('60', 152, 1, 26, 307028) On October 26th a meeting was held in the Bhawani temple for distri bution of prizes.
('60', 152, 1, 27, 307114) It was attended by numerous untouchables.
('60', 153, 0, 1, 307156) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 153, 1, 2, 307198) Harijans have free access to the palace, and the Ranisaheba and her daughters often attend Harijan weddings.
('60', 153, 1, 3, 307307) The Chief has allowed a Harijan Chamar to open his shop in a highcaste quarter.
('60', 153, 1, 4, 307387) On the auspicious Makarsankranti day—14th of January—the Ranisaheba invited Harijan women to the palace and distributed Sankranti gifts to them.
('60', 153, 1, 5, 307532) A Harijan kathakar gave a discourse in a famous temple and a number of caste Hindus attended it.
('60', 153, 1, 6, 307629) I may, therefore, say that, so far as the State is concerned, there is in Aundh State no recognition of untouchability.
('60', 153, 1, 7, 307749) But neither the caste Hindus nor the Harijans have reaped the full benefit of this.
('60', 153, 1, 8, 307833) I shall illustrate what I say.
('60', 153, 1, 9, 307864) The opponents of reform are more non Brahmins than Brahmins.
('60', 153, 1, 10, 307925) Temples visited by the Harijans are boycotted for the most part by non Brahmins.
('60', 153, 1, 11, 308006) In my own press there are six Harijan workers.
('60', 153, 1, 12, 308053) The Mahar among these regards himself as superior to the five Mangs.
('60', 153, 1, 13, 308122) When they sit down to feed in my house, they decline to sit in the same row.
('60', 153, 1, 14, 308199) In towns untouchability is going, but villages do still seem to be a difficult proposition.
('60', 153, 1, 15, 308291) In this connection, I must advert to carrion eating once again.
('60', 153, 1, 16, 308355) It has led to most unfortunate results.
('60', 153, 1, 17, 308395) It seems to stand like a dead wall between Harijans and caste Hindus and has often led to quarrels, and it may lead to bloody feuds.
('60', 153, 1, 18, 308528) The reason is that the Harijans do not scruple to poison cows and buffaloes and bullocks to the consternation of the poor agriculturist, who feel that association with these cow killers is unthinkable.
('60', 153, 1, 19, 308730) There were no fewer than 124 cases of cattle poisoning in the course of four months during the last year and special provision had to be made in the Law to prevent such crime.
('60', 153, 1, 20, 308906) I would request you to guide us with suggestions for future work.
('60', 153, 1, 21, 308972) This is an instructive and truthful account of the campaign against untouchability in the Aundh State.
('60', 153, 1, 22, 309075) Pandit Satavlekar is an old silent reformer of unremitting zeal.
('60', 153, 1, 23, 309140) He is a great Sanskrit scholar and has dedicated himself to the spread of the mission of the Vedas.
('60', 153, 1, 24, 309240) Aundh has a liberal minded Chief who, with the Ranisaheba, deserves congratulations for abolishing untouchability from his State.
('60', 153, 1, 25, 309370) Notwithstanding the existence of favourable circumstances, in Aundh, the progress of reform has been slow.
('60', 153, 1, 26, 309477) For progress is lame and taxes the reformer’s patience.
('60', 153, 1, 27, 309533) Pandit Satavlekar has asked for suggestions.
('60', 153, 1, 28, 309578) The work has been so thorough that I can only say, ‘Continue without
('60', 154, 0, 1, 309647) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 155
('60', 154, 1, 2, 309691) losing faith and success is a certainty.’ I must confess that I have no anger against the Harijans who poison cattle.
('60', 154, 1, 3, 309809) We are reaping as we have sown.
('60', 154, 1, 4, 309841) We dare not neglect a single limb of society without the whole of it suffering.
('60', 154, 1, 5, 309921) We have wholly misinterpreted the great law of karma and virtually consigned the Harijans to their own fate.
('60', 154, 1, 6, 310030) We have forced them to labour for us on utterly inadequate remuneration and never cared to know how they have lived and fared.
('60', 154, 1, 7, 310157) The wonder is that they are not much worse than they have been described.
('60', 154, 1, 8, 310231) I have suggested the only infallible method of weaning them from carrion eating.
('60', 154, 1, 9, 310312) All dead cattle should be declared State property and the cattle should be treated under the supervision of reliable officers, and proper remuneration should be given to the Harijans who may be willing to skin the carcasses and dispose of the several parts thereof as they may be directed.
('60', 154, 1, 10, 310602) Here there can be no quarrel, no cattle poisoning and no carrion eating.
('60', 154, 1, 11, 310675) All the proceeds from the disposal of the skin and other parts of carcasses should be earmarked for the benefit of Harijans, thus freeing the State from suspicion of exploitation.
('60', 154, 1, 12, 310855) For further guidance on this matter, I suggest a careful perusal of my article on “Disposal of Carcasses” 1 in last week’s Harijan.
('60', 154, 2, 13, 310987) Harijan, 25 3 1933
