('60', 156, 6, 8, 313299) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('60', 156, 6, 9, 313332) For me God and Truth are one, and of all the names by which we know God, Truth has always appeared to me the most appropriate name to know Him by, and for me selfless service is contemplation and meditation, whereas the so called meditation may be self indulgence.
('60', 156, 6, 10, 313597) For me God is formless and therefore my vision of Him does not consist of any form.
('60', 156, 6, 11, 313681) I think you will realize the Truth of what I am saying if you read the Bhagavad Gita carefully in the light of my remarks and live up to the interpretation I have tried to put before you.
('60', 156, 6, 12, 313869) You can hardly ever get pure, fresh olive oil in India.

('60', 156, 6, 14, 314010) I have never seen it.
('60', 156, 6, 15, 314032) The olive oil one generally gets at the chemists’.
('60', 156, 6, 16, 314083) It is often a year old, never less than six months, and I have ceased to believe that it can be a substitute for milk.

('60', 156, 6, 18, 314288) Fresh sweet oil that we can get abundantly in India is, medical men say, a good substitute for olive oil.

('60', 157, 2, 3, 314562) March 25, 1933
('60', 157, 3, 4, 314577) DEAR PROFESSOR, I thank you for your letter of the 14th instant.
('60', 157, 3, 5, 314642) I entirely agree with you that the proper thing is to abolish all distinction between touchables and untouchables and know them both by the generic name ‘Hindu’.
('60', 157, 3, 6, 314804) But so long as it is necessary to distinguish untouchables from touchables, surely it is better that they are known by an inoffensive name than by an offensive one.
('60', 157, 3, 7, 314969) An undutiful or unregenerate son might call his mother ‘father’s wife’, but a dutiful regenerate son would respectfully call her ‘mother’.
('60', 157, 3, 8, 315108) As to over emphasis on temple entry, I shall be entirely at one with you.
('60', 157, 3, 9, 315182) Temple entry, again, you will not mind agreeing, is necessary for the untouchable if he is to be an integral part of Hindu society and an equal partner with the caste Hindus.
('60', 157, 3, 10, 315357) As to your third question, whilst all non Hindu help would be welcome, surely penance has only to be done by those who have committed the sin.
('60', 157, 3, 11, 315500) Temple entry has got to be given by those who have robbed the Harijans of their sacred right, but I would certainly draw the line sharply at the natural religious boundary, but I should summarily put down any political differences or political exploitation.
('60', 157, 3, 12, 315758) For me this is purely a moral and religious question.
('60', 157, 4, 13, 315812) Yours sincerely, PROF.

('60', 161, 5, 21, 323095) UNTOUCHABILITY AMONG SWAMINARAYANS AND JAINS
('60', 161, 6, 22, 323140) A gentleman writes.
('60', 161, 7, 23, 323160) I did not know this.
('60', 161, 7, 24, 323181) I had always believed from my childhood that there was no untouchability at all among the Swaminarayans because the Gandhi family has had a very close relations with the follo wers of this sect for many years past.
('60', 161, 7, 25, 323396) But I have been able to read very little literature of that sect.
('60', 161, 7, 26, 323462) From the books on Jainism and my Jain friends, I have come to know that there should not be an inkling of untouchability among the Jains.
('60', 161, 7, 27, 323600) But the Jains also are very much influenced by untouchability.
('60', 161, 7, 28, 323663) The Poet Rajchandra often used to say that Jainism had spread mainly among the Vaniks, so the Jains who should have the highest courage were filled with cowardice and
('60', 161, 8, 29, 323830) 1 The names have been omitted 2 ibid 3 ibid 4 The letter is not translated here.
('60', 161, 8, 30, 323911) The correspondent had said that cobblers, generally considered untouchables, had been accepted by a Swaminarayan sect and allowed to enter its temples, and that among the Jains, there was an Antyaja saint known as Mahetaraj Muni, who was very popular in his time.
('60', 162, 0, 1, 324175) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 163
('60', 162, 1, 2, 324219) those who should have the best knowledge have become dry, and penance without knowledge had no power in it.
('60', 162, 1, 3, 324327) Having known the Jains very well, I bear testimony to the truth in this allegation and that has always made me unhappy.
('60', 162, 1, 4, 324447) The Jains have always regarded ahimsa as their exclusive virtue but its real form has been completely hidden.
('60', 162, 1, 5, 324557) Kindness towards living beings other than human beings has always assumed an acute form and the Jains do not hesitate to enforce that even by compulsion.
('60', 162, 1, 6, 324711) If ahimsa in its pure form were alive among the Jains, there would have been no trace of untouchability in their midst, every Jain would be an embodiment of love and thousands of men and women social workers would have come forth from amongst them.

('60', 165, 1, 2, 331803) 194. WOMEN’S DUTY
('60', 165, 2, 3, 331821) With the passage of time, I feel that women will have to make a very big contribution to the work of serving the Harijans.
('60', 165, 2, 4, 331944) The whole world knows that woman most truly protects religion because she is by instinct conservative.
('60', 165, 2, 5, 332047) If she sustains superstitions, she also observes vratas.
('60', 165, 2, 6, 332104) A religion cannot be safeguarded without tolerance and patience.
('60', 165, 2, 7, 332169) Woman is the embodiment of tolerance and patience.
('60', 165, 2, 8, 332220) Religion would not endure even a moment without faith.
('60', 165, 2, 9, 332275) A man’s faith cannot measure up to a woman’s.
('60', 165, 2, 10, 332321) Only linguists may know the true position, but in Sanskrit and in the languages derived from it, we find that many words indicative of virtue are feminine.
('60', 165, 2, 11, 332477) Shri 1, smriti 2, medha 3, dhriti 4, kshama 5, ahimsa, pavitrata 6, shanti 7, daya 8, namrata 9, are all feminine names.
('60', 165, 2, 12, 332598) And everywhere these qualities are met with in greater measure in women.
('60', 165, 2, 13, 332671) I do know of saints who dismiss the proposition by saying that one glimpses these virtues in a woman because she is often illiterate.
('60', 165, 2, 14, 332805) But the sum total of the experience of the whole world bears testimony to what I say.
('60', 165, 2, 15, 332891) The above mentioned virtues have no connection with knowledge of the alphabet but have a direct bearing on religion.
('60', 165, 2, 16, 333008) Moreover, religion would have perished long ago if it was thought that the educated alone could preserve it.
('60', 165, 2, 17, 333117) It is not many centuries since the art of printing was invented.
('60', 165, 2, 18, 333182) But religion has come down to us from time immemorial.
('60', 165, 2, 19, 333237) We have not heard of any religious preachers having been praised for their knowledge of the letters.
('60', 165, 2, 20, 333338) On the contrary their followers have proudly affirmed that if they had any literary knowledge, it was of little significance.
('60', 165, 2, 21, 333464) Whatever intelligence they had in them was only God given.
('60', 165, 2, 22, 333523) Their knowledge of the language was not bookish but was due to their penance and devotion to truth.
('60', 165, 2, 23, 333623) Whether all this is true or false, I have long held this belief and even if it is an illusion, so long as it is not removed it is to me not a falsehood but pure truth.
('60', 165, 2, 24, 333791) So for the religious activity of removing
('60', 165, 3, 25, 333833) 1 Beauty, grace, wealth 2 Remembrance 3 Intellect 4 Fortitude 5 Forbearance 6 Purity 7 Serenity 8 Compassion 9 Humility

('60', 166, 3, 19, 335647) 195. PROPAGANDA v.
('60', 166, 3, 20, 335666) CONSTRUCTION
('60', 166, 4, 21, 335679) The summary which I gave of a Harijan’s severe criticism of the Savarna Harijan Seva Sangh of his Province has produced good effect.
('60', 166, 4, 22, 335812) The workers have become vigilant.
('60', 166, 4, 23, 335846) But they are also baffled.
('60', 166, 4, 24, 335873) Does putting money into the pockets of Harijans mean constructive work or teaching a few children, digging a few wells and getting a few temples opened?
('60', 166, 4, 25, 336026) This is work for a century.
('60', 166, 4, 26, 336054) Propaganda means a countrywide effort to create among the people a feeling against untouchability through speeches, pamphlets, and social dinners, parties, etc.
('60', 166, 4, 27, 336215) (The reader should understand the difference between
('60', 166, 5, 28, 336268) 1 The letter is not translated here; for a summary of it, vide “Notes”, 25 3 1933.
('60', 167, 0, 1, 336351) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 167, 1, 2, 336393) social dinner and inter dining.
('60', 167, 1, 3, 336425) Social friendly dinners mean sitting together for meals at a social get together, each one eating from his own plate food which is acceptable to him.
('60', 167, 1, 4, 336575) While interdining means eating at each other’s home food prepared by the inviting party.
('60', 167, 1, 5, 336664) Brahmins and Vanias who believe in caste restrictions will participate in social dinners but may not associate with inter dining.) What a contrast between constructive work progressing at snail’s pace and propaganda work conducted at the speed of a hurricane!
('60', 167, 1, 6, 336924) This is what puzzles the workers.
('60', 167, 1, 7, 336958) Propaganda is of course essential.
('60', 167, 1, 8, 336993) But mere propaganda is likely to prove as short lived as a bubble.
('60', 167, 1, 9, 337060) Really speaking, the most effective propaganda lies in pure constructive work.
('60', 167, 1, 10, 337139) But since pure constructive work is a near impossibility, propaganda is necessary to supplement constructive work.
('60', 167, 1, 11, 337254) Pure constructive work means constructive activities by men and women workers of character who have perfect faith in the cause and who do their work in a missionary spirit.
('60', 167, 1, 12, 337427) We, however, are imperfect.
('60', 167, 1, 13, 337455) We may, therefore, sincerely do the best we can by way of constructive work and simultaneously carry on propaganda, too.
('60', 167, 1, 14, 337576) Here I wish to examine the question only from the financial point of view.
('60', 167, 1, 15, 337651) One thing should be self evident, namely, that we are bound to get a hundred per cent return on whatever money is put into the Harijans, pockets in the right manner.
('60', 167, 1, 16, 337817) Whereas the money spent on propaganda work will remain an uncertain investment till we actually see the result.
('60', 167, 1, 17, 337929) I would, therefore, advise all branches of the Sangh to utilize the contributions they have received for constructive activities.
('60', 167, 1, 18, 338059) We shall never have to repent for the money so spent.
('60', 167, 1, 19, 338113) If we get from among caste Hindus, teachers, masons, carpenters, etc., to work without remuneration or for nominal remuneration, our constructive work will progress so fast that we shall have very little need for propaganda.
('60', 167, 1, 20, 338338) In that case the entire money except what is paid as wages to the caste Hindu teachers and artisans will go to the Harijans.
('60', 167, 1, 21, 338463) I would regard the money thus spent on running a school or digging a well as reaching the pockets of Harijans.
('60', 167, 1, 22, 338574) Our ideal, of course, should be to see that the wages in connection with public wells or schools for Harijans should go into the pockets of Harijans.
('60', 167, 1, 23, 338724) But, till such time as we are able to reach this ideal, we should humbly content ourselves with the next best thing.
('60', 167, 1, 24, 338841) Every institution for Harijan welfare should maintain a separate account for such constructive work.
('60', 167, 1, 25, 338942) Propaganda work should be self supporting.
('60', 167, 1, 26, 338985) Pamphlets ought not to be distributed free of charge.
('60', 167, 1, 27, 339039) A public spirited printing press may print at nominal charge or free of charge, and the cost price of
('60', 168, 0, 1, 339141) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 169
('60', 168, 1, 2, 339185) each pamphlet may be borne by the people.
('60', 168, 1, 3, 339227) One who wishes to circulate the pamphlet among his acquaintances free of charge should pay for the copies himself or anyone from among the people whose interest has been aroused in the movement should pay for them.
('60', 168, 1, 4, 339442) Pamphlets received free are thrown into the waste paper basket.
('60', 168, 1, 5, 339506) Only a speculator would do such business.
('60', 168, 1, 6, 339548) But even he adds such expenses to the price of the things to be sold.
('60', 168, 1, 7, 339618) A religious body like the Harijan Seva Sangh simply cannot afford to indulge in such speculation.
('60', 168, 1, 8, 339716) From whom would it recover the expenses incurred?
('60', 168, 1, 9, 339766) What information about eradication of untouchability can we get from a report stating that one crore copies of pamphlets were distributed?
('60', 168, 1, 10, 339905) Who can say how many people cleansed themselves of the evil of untouchability after reading them?
('60', 168, 1, 11, 340003) Who can say, even, how many people read them?
('60', 168, 1, 12, 340049) If, however, the reader had paid one pie at least for a copy, we may assume that he must have read some portion of it.
('60', 168, 1, 13, 340168) Propaganda work carried on along these lines would not only be self supporting but, if it becomes popular, it would promote constructive work, too.
('60', 168, 1, 14, 340316) I cherish the ambition even today that, if the Harijan weeklies become popular, we may be able to save some money from their proceeds and utilize it for constructive work.
('60', 168, 1, 15, 340488) The reader may note that some of the work of these weeklies is done with the help of volunteers and that, whenever money is paid, it is paid at lower than market rates.
('60', 168, 1, 16, 340657) I mention this fact merely to point out that the Harijan weeklies are in the nature of propaganda work and that they are also self supporting.
('60', 168, 1, 17, 340800) Harijan is published in Bengali, Tamil, Gujarati and Hindi.
('60', 168, 1, 18, 340860) The Gujarati edition is on the point of becoming self supporting.
('60', 168, 1, 19, 340926) The Hindi has not become so.
('60', 168, 1, 20, 340955) The principle for pamphlets, books, etc., should be the same as for the Harijan weeklies.
('60', 168, 1, 21, 341045) And now about the expenses on the salaries and travelling allowances of the workers engaged in propaganda activities.
('60', 168, 1, 22, 341163) Most of such workers would be caste Hindus.
('60', 168, 1, 23, 341207) They, however, would never ask for any payment.
('60', 168, 1, 24, 341255) What effect can the speeches of paid workers have on the people?
('60', 168, 1, 25, 341320) Their travelling expenses should not have to be borne by the institution employing them but should be met by the people.
('60', 168, 1, 26, 341441) That is to say, the reception committees of the places which have invited them should bear the expenses.
('60', 168, 1, 27, 341546) The permanent body may arrange these things but should not bear their expenses.
('60', 168, 1, 28, 341626) And lastly about the office expenses, the salary of the accountant, the travelling expenses of the secretary, the rent for the building, etc.
('60', 168, 1, 29, 341768) This expenditure should not exceed ten per cent of the total budget.
('60', 168, 1, 30, 341837) Any institution whose administrative expenses total up to more than ten per cent should be looked upon as a self destroying and useless organization.
('60', 169, 0, 1, 341987) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 169, 1, 2, 342029) It is my firm opinion that the institution for serving Harijans which has been set up solely for the purification of religion and which exists for that one purpose cannot continue to function in any other way.
('60', 169, 1, 3, 342239) If I have been able to clarify my idea the reader should be convinced that (1) it includes a mighty organization; (2) there is great scope for widespread propaganda; (3) it is a test of the people’s faith and also conducive to its growth.
('60', 169, 1, 4, 342478) Finally, it is necessary to state that I am offering advice without being engaged in that field at the moment; so my views may be wrong.
('60', 169, 1, 5, 342615) If they do not appeal to the workers, intellect, they deserve to be discarded.
('60', 169, 1, 6, 342694) Even if they appear suitable, I do not have the right to get them accepted or put into practice, but the Harijan Sevak Sangh and its sub committees certainly have that right.
('60', 169, 1, 7, 342869) My duty is to give my opinion and to keep quiet.
('60', 169, 1, 8, 342918) The institutions concerned may give thought to this article and send their suggestions to Thakkar Bapa.
('60', 169, 1, 9, 343022) Then, on receiving his suggestions, all of them may act accordingly.

('60', 183, 1, 2, 367804) 216. INTERVIEW TO THE ASSOCIATED PRESS March 27, 1933 Now more than ever before redoubled efforts should be made to open all the private temples to the Harijans.
('60', 183, 2, 3, 367966) Asked if the failure of the Assembly to pass the motion for circulation of the Bill held up temple entry, Gandhiji replied in the negative and proceeded: It does not mean that the temple entry question would be held up, but it does mean that what is due to the Harijans in the light of the pledge given in September last has not been paid and, therefore, every effort should be made in order to redeem that pledge.
('60', 183, 2, 4, 368381) Meanwhile whatever other ways are open to educating public opinion and gaining access to temples for the Harijans should be tried and one thing that naturally suggests itself to me is the opening of all private temples to Harijans.
('60', 183, 2, 5, 368613) There is no custom in connection with the private temples which can be pleaded by the third party in order to prevent the entry of Harijans to them.
('60', 183, 2, 6, 368762) They should be thrown open to them and those who have none may even build new temples for the Hindus in general and these would be the model temples with model management and model priests so that they would be a true expression of Hinduism.
('60', 183, 2, 7, 369004) The Hindustan Times, 28 3 1933

('60', 185, 1, 2, 371736) 219. LETTER TO AMULYA KUMAR BASU March 28, 1933
('60', 185, 2, 3, 371784) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter.
('60', 185, 2, 4, 371826) You have no cause whatsoever for apologizing for doing what you conceive is your duty.
('60', 185, 2, 5, 371913) I give the others the same credit for honesty of purpose that I would claim for myself.
('60', 185, 2, 6, 372001) All therefore I would expect you to do is never to swerve from truth even in order to gain an end which you may consider to be desirable.
('60', 185, 2, 7, 372139) You will then receive congratulations from me for your fighting me, and who knows that you may not teach me to see the Light if I am enveloped in darkness.
('60', 185, 2, 8, 372295) It is therefore in a friendly spirit that I shall approach your paper 1, and if I find untruthfulness, unfairness or bitterness anywhere in it, I shall draw your attention, and I would like you to do the same thing towards me if you find in the Harijan any untruth, any exaggeration, any discourtesy towards those who think differently from me.
('60', 185, 2, 9, 372640) Rightly or wrongly, I regard untouchability as the greatest curse for Hindu religion.
('60', 185, 2, 10, 372726) I am therefore sparing no pains to get rid of that curse.
('60', 185, 2, 11, 372784) But if it is a blessing and if anybody can make me see it, I shall accept him as my deliverer, for, he would have saved me from an error which I have nursed practically for the past fifty years.
('60', 185, 2, 12, 372979) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('60', 185, 2, 13, 373001) AMULYA KUMAR BASU 5 AKSHAY KUMAR BASU LANE CALCUTTA

('60', 185, 4, 15, 373082) 220. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('60', 185, 5, 16, 373109) March 28, 1933
('60', 185, 6, 17, 373124) MY DEAR GHANSHYAMDASJI, I hope you received my letter 2 in Hindi which I wrote the day before yesterday, i.e., 26th.
('60', 185, 6, 18, 373241) I do think that we ought to find out a means of dealing with the basti problem in Calcutta as a whole, and not piecemeal.
('60', 185, 6, 19, 373363) When therefore you next go to Calcutta I suggest your having an informal meeting of the principal Municipal Councillors.
('60', 185, 6, 20, 373484) No matter what vested interests have grown up, they should be
('60', 185, 7, 21, 373546) 1 Sanatani, an English weekly 2 Vide “Letter to G. D. Birla”, 26 3 1933.
('60', 186, 0, 1, 373619) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 187
('60', 186, 1, 2, 373663) attacked and the problem dealt with.
('60', 186, 1, 3, 373700) From what you write to me, the cheapest method evidently seems to be to demolish these bastis.
('60', 186, 1, 4, 373795) The opposition to the introduction of a more humane method of carrying night soil seems to me to be perfectly useless.
('60', 186, 1, 5, 373914) Improved methods must in the beginning stages mean more expense, but undoubtedly less in the end.
('60', 186, 1, 6, 374012) The question behind all the difficulties that arise resolves itself, as a rule, into apathy on the part of those who profess their appreciation of the necessity for reform, but are not prepared to sacrifice anything for it.
('60', 186, 1, 7, 374236) You must therefore turn this apathy into active sympathy, and a way out will be quickly found.
('60', 186, 1, 8, 374331) As to the Hindi Harijan, I wrote to you the day before yesterday telling you that the only articles that were found worth reading were yours, except the first.
('60', 186, 1, 9, 374491) Your style is pleasing, simple, idiomatic.
('60', 186, 1, 10, 374534) Your method of dealing with the subject is plain, direct and easily understandable.
('60', 186, 1, 11, 374618) Of course the translation of my articles was faulty, but that difficulty will now be got over by sending translations ready made from here.
('60', 186, 1, 12, 374758) The Hindi will have to be polished there.

('60', 190, 1, 2, 380684) 226. LETTER TO N. March 28, 1933
('60', 190, 2, 3, 380717) MY DEAR N. , I have your letters of 23rd and 24th.
('60', 190, 2, 4, 380768) I expect that you left for the village on Sunday as you had intended.
('60', 190, 2, 5, 380838) May Truth take care of you there!
('60', 190, 2, 6, 380872) I know from personal experience how difficult it is to wash heavy khadi if you do not have plenty of water.
('60', 190, 2, 7, 380980) Generally washing comes before sewing, but if it is the same cloth that requires washing and sewing, the sewing undoubtedly precedes, because you thereby save time.
('60', 190, 2, 8, 381145) Washing will tear the cloth more at the point where it requires mending, therefore more time has to be given to sewing if it is done after the washing.
('60', 190, 2, 9, 381297) Your dress itself may require a little alteration when you have got rid of all the ornamental part of it and made it just so as to protect the body and satisfy the surrounding convention.
('60', 190, 2, 10, 381485) The quantity required is very small, the convention being the convention of the poorest.
('60', 190, 2, 11, 381574) I am glad you heard from Sir Todd Hunter.
('60', 190, 2, 12, 381616) I am not at all satisfied with R.’s letters.
('60', 190, 2, 13, 381661) There is still the old infatuation lurking, and as I read them, a disposition to justify the past.
('60', 190, 2, 14, 381760) I have written 1 to him gently drawing his attention to the inadequacy of his letters.
('60', 190, 2, 15, 381847) Durgadas’s letter I like still less.
('60', 190, 2, 16, 381884) The mode of address is unpardonable.
('60', 190, 2, 17, 381921) He can be no guide, friend and brother to you, who, although on his own showing he knew that you were a fallen woman, did not lift his little linger to save his sister.
('60', 190, 2, 18, 382090) There is no question of your resuming your correspondence.
('60', 190, 2, 19, 382149) Your correspon dence just now must be with God of Truth and yourself.
('60', 190, 2, 20, 382219) Nothing should come between you and Him.
('60', 190, 2, 21, 382260) I come in because I am witness to the promise that you have made to your Maker and because I want to be able to claim you as a permanent co worker in the service of the Harijans, in my opinion the most suppressed in the world, but neither I nor you can render that service unless that direct touch with Truth is completely established and the utmost purity attainable by a human being has become the exclusive passion.
('60', 190, 2, 22, 382679) You must beware of cold.
('60', 190, 2, 23, 382704) If you can procure whole wheat meal you ought not to take any rice at all.
('60', 190, 2, 24, 382779) You should learn how to make chapatis.
('60', 190, 2, 25, 382818) It is an incredibly simple performance.
('60', 190, 2, 26, 382858) Take 4 ounces of clean wheat meal, mix in water
('60', 190, 3, 27, 382906) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('60', 191, 0, 1, 382933) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 191, 1, 2, 382975) and knead it well, roll it on any smooth surface, wooden or stone, with a rolling pin—even a clean ruler will serve the purpose—and roll it slightly thinner than a cardboard piece and bake it on a flat iron disk, turning the sides while it is baked.
('60', 191, 1, 3, 383225) Out of 4 ounces you can make six of these chapatis, 6 inches in diameter.
('60', 191, 1, 4, 383299) These would be perfectly digestible.
('60', 191, 1, 5, 383336) I am sure that the lady of the house or hut where you are to stay knows all this simple cookery.

('60', 194, 3, 12, 388454) 234. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('60', 194, 4, 13, 388489) March 28, 1933
('60', 194, 5, 14, 388504) Two large sized telescopes 1 placed in the open yard occupied by Mr. Gandhi in the Yeravda Jail presented an unusual spectacle amidst the severe simplicity of the jail surroundings.
('60', 194, 5, 15, 388686) [Mr. Gandhi said:] They are for me.
('60', 194, 5, 16, 388722) Astronomy had always interested him, Mr. Gandhi stated, but after entering the jail this time, he was devoting himself to it with greater interest than ever before.
('60', 194, 5, 17, 388887) Mr. Gandhi proceeded: Now it has become a passion with me.
('60', 194, 5, 18, 388946) Every free minute I get I devote myself to it.
('60', 194, 5, 19, 388993) It is a wonderful subject, and more than anything else impresses upon me the mystery of God and the majesty of the universe.
('60', 194, 5, 20, 389118) To be lying on your back in the open air on a starry night and regarding universe after universe in the immeasurable expanse, you cannot help becoming a worshipper of God.
('60', 194, 5, 21, 389290) My mind leaps with joy as I do so.
('60', 194, 5, 22, 389325) Oh, it is marvellous !
('60', 194, 5, 23, 389348) It did not require a study of higher mathematics, Mr. Gandhi added, as his interest in astronomy was not professional.
('60', 194, 5, 24, 389467) He had been reading numerous books on the subject and with the aid of the apparatus before him, he would see more of those universes with his own eyes.
('60', 194, 5, 25, 389619) He could easily understand their use as their adjustments, though delicate, were simple.
('60', 194, 6, 26, 389708) The Hindu, 3 4 1933
('60', 194, 7, 27, 389728) 1 According to the report, these were lent to Gandhiji by Lady Premlila Thackersey of Poona.

('60', 197, 3, 9, 394771) 238. LETTER TO PANCHANAN TARKARATNA March 29, 1933
('60', 197, 4, 10, 394822) DEAR PANDITJI, I thank you for your letter which Motibabu has kindly translated for me.
('60', 197, 4, 11, 394910) On the one hand I see that you consider the matter of untouchability supersensuous and on the other you are applying mere mundane situations to the matter.
('60', 197, 4, 12, 395066) Personally, I do not regard untouchability as a supersensuous matter.
('60', 197, 4, 13, 395136) I regard nothing as supersensuous which is capable of being proved through the senses.
('60', 197, 4, 14, 395223) Thus, I would consider the question of the existence of God as supersensuous but not so the shape of the earth, and as our Shastras teach us, it would be a misuse of spiritual gifts to apply them for the discovery or for proving the properties of material objects.
('60', 197, 4, 15, 395488) Untouchability as described in the Shastras is a purely material thing.
('60', 197, 4, 16, 395560) There is nothing supersensuous in it.
('60', 197, 4, 17, 395598) Therefore if I apply the ordinary laws governing the examination of ordinary things I am doing no violence to the Shastras.
('60', 197, 4, 18, 395722) Thus examined, in spite of what may be said in the Shastras, hereditary untouchability has no basis, and if a Chandala, so described, did not disclose his birth, there is no test whereby he could
('60', 198, 0, 1, 395918) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 199
('60', 198, 1, 2, 395962) be distinguished from the rest.
('60', 198, 1, 3, 395994) What applies to him applies with much greater force to his progeny.
('60', 198, 1, 4, 396062) I am afraid that your analogy of the Red Indians, the Australian Indians and other such races has no application whatsoever to Indian conditions, and it is historically untrue to say that in India there has been no mixture of races.
('60', 198, 1, 5, 396295) On the contrary, there is incontestable proof that mixture of blood has been constantly going on in India since the known beginnings of time.
('60', 198, 1, 6, 396437) As to the pandits whose testimony I have cited, several who have upheld my interpretation I have not even had the pleasure of knowing.
('60', 198, 1, 7, 396572) They have accepted the same authority that you are quoting, only they have given a different interpretation to yours.
('60', 198, 1, 8, 396690) With due humility I claim that though I can make no pretension to Sanskrit learning, I know enough of Sanskrit and have read enough of the scriptures to be able to form my own judgment on conflicting interpretations being presented to me of the Shastras.
('60', 198, 1, 9, 396945) With reference to your son, my own recollection is distinct that he was to have come as your representative, not in order to have a religious disputation but to hold a discourse with me in order to present your viewpoint and in order that I could understand it, so that if it was at all possible we might find ourselves on the same platform.
('60', 198, 2, 10, 397287) Surely, that was an object wholly different from that of the pandits who came to engage in a set debate between rival schools of thoughts with judges to regulate the debate.
('60', 198, 2, 11, 397461) Your son coming as one of these disputants was not the same as his coming as your deputy without the conditions that governed the Pandits.
('60', 198, 2, 12, 397600) Of course there was nothing wrong about his being one of the pandits, but that could not be a fulfilment of your promise.
('60', 198, 2, 13, 397722) If he had the intention of engaging in a friendly and personal conversation with me after the debate, he could still do so.
('60', 198, 2, 14, 397846) I shall be pleased to meet him any time he comes and patiently listen to all he might have to say.
('60', 198, 2, 15, 397945) I can give you my assurance that I have not shut my ears to anything that might have still to be said on behalf of the part that upholds modern untouchability as an integral part of Hinduism.
('60', 198, 2, 16, 398137) Yours sincerely,
('60', 198, 3, 17, 398154) From a microfilm: S.N. 20744

('60', 203, 4, 7, 406052) PANNALAL, I have received both your letters.
('60', 203, 4, 8, 406097) You have been hasty in passing judgement on Narandas.
('60', 203, 4, 9, 406151) The decision about Mahavir 1 was not his; it was mine.
('60', 203, 4, 10, 406206) Considering his rudeness, the lies that he resorted to and his financial bungling, any other decision was impossible.
('60', 203, 4, 11, 406324) Behind the seemingly harsh decision, there is only pity.
('60', 203, 4, 12, 406381) Krishnamaiyadevi 2 did not know the truth.
('60', 203, 4, 13, 406424) Even then, after Narandas gave his opinion, Panditji, Totaramji and Chimanlal conducted an inquiry.
('60', 203, 4, 14, 406524) They gave their views separately and their conclusions were the same.
('60', 203, 4, 15, 406594) Only then were Mahavir and Krishnamaiyadevi asked to leave the Ashram.
('60', 203, 4, 16, 406665) I had not been inclined to have women [in the Ashram].
('60', 203, 4, 17, 406720) But Narandas showed courage.
('60', 203, 4, 18, 406749) I have very little to do even with the help that is to be given.
('60', 203, 4, 19, 406814) I had only suggested that they should be enabled to reach Darjeeling and provided with expenses for two months.
('60', 203, 4, 20, 406926) Narandas found this course difficult and found an easier way.
('60', 203, 4, 21, 406988) The Ashram was under no obligation to accommodate the Giri family.
('60', 203, 4, 22, 407055) In having them there, I had saddled Maganlal with a great burden, and had stretched the rules of the Ashram.
('60', 203, 4, 23, 407164) It was with great difficulty that we passed these many years.
('60', 203, 4, 24, 407226) I have no regrets about it.
('60', 203, 4, 25, 407254) But if I go on witnessing violations of the Ashram rules, there certainly will be reason for me to regret.
('60', 203, 4, 26, 407361) Now if Mahavir continues with his tales of woe, that will be one more reason why he should go.
('60', 203, 4, 27, 407456) He is not as innocent as you think.
('60', 203, 4, 28, 407492) Thinking him innocent I am not prepared to make him helpless.
('60', 203, 4, 29, 407554) If you have the time, go deeply into the matter and if you find you are mistaken correct the mistake.
('60', 203, 4, 30, 407656) If not, and if you think I am in the wrong, show me how.
('60', 203, 4, 31, 407713) Do not judge anyone in haste, certainly not your colleagues.
('60', 203, 4, 32, 407774) You have written to me that you heard many complaints against Narandas.

('60', 205, 4, 34, 411280) 247. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA

('60', 205, 6, 36, 411334) DEAR SATISBABU, I have your letter of 23rd instant.
('60', 205, 6, 37, 411386) I understand what you mean.
('60', 205, 6, 38, 411414) Of course I saw the sentences that followed your description of Bengal untouchability as a greater curse.

('60', 206, 0, 1, 411746) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 207
('60', 206, 1, 2, 411790) suppose you are not aware of the fact that if the Bengal description of untouchability was applied to Madras, then the untouchables would be perhaps 90% of the Hindu population, for every non Brahmin is practically an untouchable to a Brahmin in the Bengal sense of untouchability.
('60', 206, 1, 3, 412072) There are only two divisions in the south, Brahmins and non Brahmins.
('60', 206, 1, 4, 412142) Are you aware that if a non Brahmin looked at the food of a Brahmin, that food becomes polluted?
('60', 206, 1, 5, 412239) Hence my insistence upon stepping into the opponent’s shoes and examining his argument from his own standpoint.
('60', 206, 1, 6, 412351) I think that there is decidedly a meaning in the Bengal argument that untouchability in Bengal is of the mildest type and that real untouchability is confined to the Bhangis, Mehtars and the like, who are, after all, imported.
('60', 206, 1, 7, 412578) That we have to deal with every aspect of untouchability is quite true, but we shall only be able to deal with it when we are exquisitely balanced in our statements and that balance can only come if we will give even an exaggerated importance to the arguments of the opponents.
('60', 206, 1, 8, 412856) Ahimsa is a most exacting dame and it sits with the most sensitive scales noticing even an atom’s weight of himsa or want of charity.
('60', 206, 1, 9, 412990) We are on the safest ground.
('60', 206, 1, 10, 413019) We therefore need not be in a hurry to give them battle.
('60', 206, 1, 11, 413076) It will be time enough when they reach our border.

('60', 213, 9, 21, 424516) This is not always possible.
('60', 213, 9, 22, 424545) I gave much thought to it.
('60', 213, 9, 23, 424572) To make the paper self supporting, to refuse all advertisements, as the initiator of the movement to give my views as exhaustively as possible on the current happenings about Harijans, to combine all these things in one paper becomes almost an impossible task.
('60', 213, 9, 24, 424833) And then the reproduction of sanatanist views and those of the Ambedkar school was unnecessary for the vast majority of readers, because they knew all the sides of the question and they had been published in the daily Press.
('60', 213, 9, 25, 425058) It could then be of use only to the
('60', 213, 10, 26, 425094) 1 The newspaper report is dated March 31, 1933. 2 Vide “Notes”, sub title “Hard Facts, Not Words”.

('60', 214, 1, 2, 425237) foreign readers, of whom there are naturally but a select few.
('60', 214, 1, 3, 425300) Whether few or many they could not be neglected, and I knew that they were being well supplied with the literature outside what could be handled by the Harijan.
('60', 214, 1, 4, 425461) And this extra reading they had to do, whether through the Harijan or through the original sources, and I came to the conclusion that I must leave them to gather the different viewpoints through the original sources.
('60', 214, 1, 5, 425678) And because I have done so, it has been possible for me, even from almost the beginning, to make the Harijan self supporting.
('60', 214, 1, 6, 425804) I have certainly taken extraordinary precaution not to give any colouring to the views of the other sides, whenever it has been necessary for me to give them.
('60', 214, 1, 7, 425963) More than this I must not say.
('60', 214, 1, 8, 425994) Thus, though I am not able to give effect, as you would wish it, to this part of your letter, you know that everything you say must produce its invisible effect upon my mind, and therefore whatever you think is worth passing on to me you should do unhesitatingly.
('60', 214, 1, 9, 426258) The freer and fuller the criticism of friends and associates like you, the lighter and better will my work be, and such criticism will itself be an important part of our contribution to the Harijan cause.

('60', 220, 1, 2, 434057) 269. NOTES
('60', 220, 2, 3, 434068) MAJORITY V. MINORITY
('60', 220, 3, 4, 434089) A graduate from Madras sends the following quotation from Indian Home Rule:
('60', 220, 4, 5, 434165) It is a superstition and an ungodly thing to believe that an act of a majority binds a minority.
('60', 220, 4, 6, 434262) Many examples can be given in which acts of majorities will be found to have been wrong, and those of minorities to have been right.
('60', 220, 4, 7, 434395) All reforms owe their origin to the initiation of minorities in opposition to the majorities.
('60', 220, 4, 8, 434489) If among a band of robbers, a knowledge of robbery is obligatory, is a pious man to accept the obligation?
('60', 220, 4, 9, 434596) So long as the superstition that man should obey unjust laws exists, so long will their slavery exist.
('60', 220, 4, 10, 434699) And a passive resister alone can remove such a superstition.
('60', 220, 5, 11, 434760) and writes:
('60', 220, 6, 12, 434772) Kindly permit me to invite your attention to the above extract from your Indian Home Rule.
('60', 220, 6, 13, 434863) From this we see that you once held the opinion contained therein.
('60', 220, 6, 14, 434930) However, the above opinion of your own has been trampled under foot in connection with the temple entry question.
('60', 220, 6, 15, 435044) Are we to take that the present position differs from then position held by you then?
('60', 220, 6, 16, 435130) Apparently, the position taken up by you is inconsistent.
('60', 220, 6, 17, 435188) We hope to be enlightened on the subject.
('60', 220, 6, 18, 435230) It is unjust to a writer to quote against him passages from his writings without reference to the context.
('60', 220, 6, 19, 435337) Nor should I care to defend what may appear to be my inconsistencies.
('60', 220, 6, 20, 435407) I should leave the readers to judge for themselves.
('60', 220, 6, 21, 435459) In this instance the quotation appears to me to propound a great truth often overlooked.
('60', 220, 6, 22, 435548) Anyway I believe in every word of it.
('60', 220, 6, 23, 435586) The Temple entry Bills do not violate the rule.
('60', 220, 6, 24, 435634) They do not bind the minority to anything, they compel it to do nothing.
('60', 220, 6, 25, 435707) But if a majority may not compel a minority to its will, nor may the latter compel the former.
('60', 220, 6, 26, 435802) But the natural rule is that, where there is a dispute between a majority and a minority, the latter will, without admitting the rightness of the action of the former, let it have its way and, if it believes the majority in the wrong, refuse its co operation.
('60', 220, 6, 27, 436062) One of the Temple entry Bills does that and nothing more.
('60', 220, 6, 28, 436120) But I am myself so jealous of the rights and wishes of minorities if only
('60', 220, 7, 29, 436194) 1 Vide “Hind Swaraj”.
('60', 221, 0, 1, 436216) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 221, 1, 2, 436258) because I have been always, in the beginning at least, in a minority.
('60', 221, 1, 3, 436328) I have, therefore, proposed, as the reader should know, a solution whereby the minority will have its wishes also respected.
('60', 221, 1, 4, 436453) The other Bill takes away no rights of anybody.
('60', 221, 1, 5, 436501) It simply takes the question of untouchability from the purview of the civil law.
('60', 221, 1, 6, 436583) It does not interfere with the conscience or the religious observances of anybody.
('60', 221, 1, 7, 436666) In fact, the Bills are designed to protect all views and one merely provides what to do in the event of a difference of opinion.
('60', 221, 1, 8, 436795) Here I see no infringement of the rule enunciated in the quotation from Indian Home Rule.
('60', 221, 1, 9, 436885) It shows how a minority can protect itself.

('60', 222, 3, 7, 439008) 270. PROPAGANDA v.
('60', 222, 3, 8, 439027) CONSTRUCTION
('60', 222, 4, 9, 439040) The indictment 1 by a Harijan of Harijan uplift organizations that was published in these columns some time ago has given rise to interesting correspondence.
('60', 222, 4, 10, 439198) It is necessary in the light of that indictment and the correspondence to examine the pros and cons of propaganda and construction and to know exactly what is meant by the latter.
('60', 222, 4, 11, 439378) Propaganda in connection with the anti untouchability move ment has meant an energetic distribution of literature among the caste Hindus, spreading information about untouchability and holding meetings among them.
('60', 222, 4, 12, 439592) The Guruvayur referendum was essentially such propaganda.
('60', 222, 4, 13, 439650) It has also meant holding Harijan conferences and the like for the purpose of telling the Harijans what is being done by the caste Hindus and what is expected of Harijans in the way of internal reform, such as observance of the laws of sanitation and giving up carrion eating and other un Hindu practices.
('60', 222, 4, 14, 439956) Such propaganda is undoubtedly necessary.
('60', 222, 4, 15, 439998) We cannot have too much of it, if we can carry it on without creating bad blood and friction.
('60', 222, 4, 16, 440092) Whilst the sanatanists are organizing, themselves and imagining Hinduism to be in danger from the reformers’ activity, the latter have to be careful.
('60', 222, 4, 17, 440242) We do not want to rub the sanatanists up the wrong way.
('60', 222, 4, 18, 440298) Wherever, therefore, these are in a state of rage, the reformers would do well not to hold their meetings.
('60', 222, 4, 19, 440405) They are bound to contradict all falsehoods and exaggerations and themselves be scrupulously careful about what they say, write or do.
('60', 222, 4, 20, 440540) Falsehood will never help any cause, certainly not religion.
('60', 222, 4, 21, 440601) Such clean propaganda should be self supporting.
('60', 222, 4, 22, 440650) Insistence on making it self supporting will help to keep it pure and within bounds and make it most effective.
('60', 222, 4, 23, 440762) Leaflets and other literature must be paid for and may even leave a margin of profits to pay for the necessary
('60', 222, 5, 24, 440873) 1 Vide “As They see us”, 4 3 1933.
('60', 223, 0, 1, 440908) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 223, 1, 2, 440950) expenses of travelling, etc.
('60', 223, 1, 3, 440979) Let not the reader imagine that I am writing this without any experience.
('60', 223, 1, 4, 441053) On the contrary, what I am saying is based on an extensive experience gained before I became a ‘Mahatma’ and whilst I was little known in the surroundings in which God had placed me.
('60', 223, 1, 5, 441236) Economy of time and money (one and the same thing ) was an instinct with me.
('60', 223, 1, 6, 441313) One who has faith in his mission will find it easy enough to enforce this golden rule of truthful propaganda.
('60', 223, 2, 7, 441423) This does not mean that the reader pays for his leaflet in every case.
('60', 223, 2, 8, 441494) That would be an ideal state.
('60', 223, 2, 9, 441524) But it does mean that the central organization does not bear the cost.
('60', 223, 2, 10, 441595) The local agency requiring the leaflets should pay the central organization for them.
('60', 223, 2, 11, 441681) The local agency in its turn will see that it gets the cost repaid to it, partly by readers and partly by moneyed men interested in the distribution of leaflets.
('60', 223, 2, 12, 441843) In this way the cost of propaganda will be evenly distributed and not felt by anybody.
('60', 223, 2, 13, 441930) Such distribution would be a fair index to the strength and popularity of the propaganda.
('60', 223, 2, 14, 442020) The various editions of the Harijan are most certainly designed as propaganda.
('60', 223, 2, 15, 442099) They will have to be self supporting or they must stop.
('60', 223, 2, 16, 442155) The English.
('60', 223, 2, 17, 442168) and the Bengali editions have already become so.
('60', 223, 2, 18, 442217) The Gujarati is on a fair way to being so.
('60', 223, 2, 19, 442260) The Hindi edition is still struggling.
('60', 223, 2, 20, 442299) The Tamil edition is being published by Sjt.
('60', 223, 2, 21, 442344) Ganesan without any cost to the provincial organization.
('60', 223, 2, 22, 442401) The publication of these editions renders it easy for local organizations to carry on their propaganda without much or any cost.
('60', 223, 2, 23, 442530) They can have all interesting and instructive information published in the various editions of the Harijan, which is their organ.
('60', 223, 3, 24, 442660) There then remain the travelling charges of lecturers.
('60', 223, 3, 25, 442715) It goes without saying that they must be all volunteers.
('60', 223, 3, 26, 442772) If they are moneyed men, they often pay their own travelling expenses.
('60', 223, 3, 27, 442843) Where this cannot happen, these expenses must be found by the inviting agency.
('60', 223, 3, 28, 442922) And the general rule is for reception committees formed for the purpose to raise special subscriptions and defray the cost locally.
('60', 223, 3, 29, 443054) Thus the permanent organizations, whether central or local, merely procure lecturers, give guidance, lend the weight of their name and influence, but, as a rule, incur no expense.
('60', 223, 3, 30, 443234) Thus considered, the overhead charges include merely the cost of the organizing staff, rent, stationery and the travelling expenses of the Secretary.
('60', 223, 3, 31, 443384) The chief officials are often wholly honorary, or are volunteers drawing just enough for their maintenance and always
('60', 224, 0, 1, 443502) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 225
('60', 224, 1, 2, 443546) below their market price.
('60', 224, 1, 3, 443572) And if the general staff consists wholly, or so far as possible, of Harijans, there will be very little money going into the pockets of caste Hindus, certainly nothing like even ten percent of the collections of the organizations.
('60', 224, 1, 4, 443803) Thus, Lala Mohanlal of the Punjab Provincial Branch says:
('60', 224, 2, 5, 443861) Regarding the overhead charges, I have briefly to submit that, excepting the peon and the clerk, whose bill comes up to Rs. 50 p.m., no overhead charges of permanent or temporary nature have been incurred by the Punjab Board.
('60', 224, 2, 6, 444087) I am working as General Secretary of the body, but I am drawing my allowances from the Servants of the People Society of which I happen to be a life member.
('60', 224, 2, 7, 444244) I think this is the minimum staff required for running a provincial organization.
('60', 224, 2, 8, 444326) The bulk of the collections will, according to the scheme suggested above, be available for constructive work, such as conducting preparatory schools for Harijans, giving scholarships, opening wells, etc.
('60', 224, 2, 9, 444531) Here again, care has to be taken to see that most of the paid staff is composed of Harijans, or caste Hindu volunteers who have offered their services free or for less than their market price.
('60', 224, 2, 10, 444724) But it must be our aim to replace all paid caste Hindus by Harijans.
('60', 224, 2, 11, 444793) Then there is every chance of all but ten percent of the collections finding its way into Harijan pockets.
('60', 224, 2, 12, 444900) And who will deny that this will be the best and the most effective propaganda both for Harijans and caste Hindus?
('60', 224, 2, 13, 445015) The latter cannot but be touched by the silent, effective and dignified selfless work of caste Hindu volunteers and the consequent rise of the Harijans in the social scale.
('60', 224, 2, 14, 445188) And there is no reason why we should not have thousands of young men and women from among caste Hindus doing this noble service among those whom society has cruelly neglected for generations.
('60', 224, 2, 15, 445380) Have we got these missionaries?
('60', 224, 2, 16, 445412) I have already shown in these pages that we do not need highly educated persons.
('60', 224, 2, 17, 445493) We want men and women of grit, immovable faith and character that will resist temptation.
('60', 224, 3, 18, 445583) Harijan, 1 4 1933
('60', 225, 0, 1, 445601) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 225, 1, 2, 445643) 271. STUDENTS AND VACATION
('60', 225, 2, 3, 445670) The following is a condensed rendering of a Hindi letter received from a student in Dehra Dun: In the hostel belonging to our College, hitherto the Bhangis have taken the leavings of our dishes.
('60', 225, 2, 4, 445865) But since the awakening we have stopped this practice and we have been giving them clean chapatis and dal.
('60', 225, 2, 5, 445972) The Harijans are dissatisfied with this.
('60', 225, 2, 6, 446013) In the leavings they get some ghee and delicacies.
('60', 225, 2, 7, 446064) The students cannot afford to set apart all these things for Harijans.
('60', 225, 2, 8, 446135) Then there is this difficulty.
('60', 225, 2, 9, 446166) We may adhere to the new practice we have adopted, but the Harijans will continue to receive leavings of caste dinners, etc.
('60', 225, 2, 10, 446291) What is now to be done?
('60', 225, 2, 11, 446315) And at the same time that you answer this question, I would like you also to say how best we can use our vacation which will presently be upon us.
('60', 225, 2, 12, 446462) The difficulty that the correspondent has raised is real.
('60', 225, 2, 13, 446520) The Harijans have got so used to the leavings that they not only do not mind them but look forward to them.
('60', 225, 2, 14, 446628) Not to receive them they will regard as a positive deprivation.
('60', 225, 2, 15, 446692) But this tragic fact just shows the degradation both of Harijans and of caste Hindus.
('60', 225, 2, 16, 446778) The students need not worry about what happens in other places.
('60', 225, 2, 17, 446842) The first thing is for them to be in the right and I suggest to them that they should resolutely set apart for their sweepers a liberal amount of the food that is ordinarily cooked for them.
('60', 225, 2, 18, 447033) The Dehra Dun student has raised the question of cost.
('60', 225, 2, 19, 447088) I know something of the hostel life all over India.
('60', 225, 2, 20, 447140) It is my conviction that the general body of students spend far more on delicacies and luxuries than they should.
('60', 225, 2, 21, 447254) I know, too, that many students consider it undignified not to leave their plates with ample remains of the helpings they had.
('60', 225, 2, 22, 447381) I suggest to them that to have any leavings whatsoever on their plates is undignified and a sign of disregard of the poor people.
('60', 225, 2, 23, 447511) No one, least of all a student, has the right to take on his plate more than he could comfortably eat.
('60', 225, 2, 24, 447614) A student has no business to multiply the delicacies and luxuries.
('60', 225, 2, 25, 447681) The student life is meant for the cultivation of self restraint in everything and if they will follow the method of self restraint and adopt the clean habit of not having any leavings on their plates, they would find that they would effect a saving in their expenses, in spite of setting apart a
('60', 226, 0, 1, 447977) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 227
('60', 226, 1, 2, 448021) generous portion for their sweepers from the ordinary food that may be cooked for themselves.
('60', 226, 1, 3, 448115) And then, after having done that, I should expect them to treat the Harijans as if they were their own blood relations, speak to them kindly and tell them why it is necessary for them to give up the unclean habit of eating the leavings of other people’s plates and of making other reforms in their lives.
('60', 226, 1, 4, 448420) As to the use of the vacation by students, it they will approach the work with zeal, they can undou btedly do many things.
('60', 226, 1, 5, 448543) I enumerate a few of them.
('60', 226, 1, 6, 448570) 1. Conduct night and day schools with just a short course, well conceived, to last for the period of the vacation.
('60', 226, 1, 7, 448685) 2. Visit Harijan quarters and clean them, taking the assistance of Harijans if they would give it.
('60', 226, 1, 8, 448784) 3. Taking Harijan children for excursions, showing them sights near their villages and teaching them how to study nature, and generally interesting them in their surroundings, giving them by the way a working knowledge of geography and history.
('60', 226, 1, 9, 449029) 4. Reading to them simple stories from the Ramayana and the Mahabharata.
('60', 226, 1, 10, 449102) 5. Teaching them simple bhajans.
('60', 226, 1, 11, 449135) 6. Cleaning the Harijan boys of all the dirt that they would find about their persons and giving both the grown ups and the children simple lessons in hygiene.
('60', 226, 1, 12, 449295) 7. Taking a detailed census in selected areas of the condition of Harijans.
('60', 226, 1, 13, 449371) 8. Taking medical aid to the ailing Harijans.
('60', 226, 1, 14, 449417) This is but a sample of what is possible to do among the Harijans.
('60', 226, 1, 15, 449484) It is a list hurriedly made, but a thoughtful student will, I have no doubt, add many other items.
('60', 226, 1, 16, 449583) I have so far confined my attention to the service of Harijans, but there is a service no less necessary to be rendered to caste Hindus.
('60', 226, 1, 17, 449720) The students can often in the gentlest manner possible carry the mes sage of anti untouchability to them in spite of themselves.
('60', 226, 1, 18, 449849) There is so much ignorance which can be easily dispelled by a judicious distri bution of clean authentic literature.
('60', 226, 1, 19, 449966) The students can make a survey of those who are for abolishing untouchability and who are against and, whilst they are making this survey, they may take note of wells, scho ols, ponds and temples open to Harijans and of those closed to them.
('60', 227, 0, 1, 450208) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 227, 1, 2, 450250) If they will do all these things in a methodical and persistent manner, they will find the results to be startling.
('60', 227, 1, 3, 450366) Every student should keep a log book in which he should enter the details of his work, and at the end of the vacation a comprehensive but brief report of the results of their labours could be prepared and sent by them to the Servants of Untouchables Society of their Province.
('60', 227, 1, 4, 450643) Whether other students accept all or any of the suggestions made here, I shall expect my correspondent to give me a report of what he and his associates have done.
('60', 227, 2, 5, 450807) Harijan, 1 4 1933
('60', 227, 3, 6, 450825) 272. ‘THIS FIGHT IS NECESSARY’
('60', 227, 4, 7, 450856) The reader will appreciate the following instructive letter that Gurudev wrote on reading mine to Boyd Tucker on the place of temples, churches and mosques in religion in reply to his letter to me.
('60', 227, 5, 8, 451054) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('60', 227, 6, 9, 451070) It is needless to say that I do not at all relish the idea of divinity being enclosed in a brick and mortar temple for the special purpose of exploitation by a particular group of people.
('60', 227, 6, 10, 451258) I strongly believe that it is possible for the simple hearted people to realize the presence of God in the open air, in a surrounding free from all artificial obstruction.
('60', 227, 6, 11, 451430) We know a sect in Bengal, illiterate and not dominated by Brahminical tradition, who enjoy a perfect freedom of worship profoundly universal in character.
('60', 227, 6, 12, 451585) It was the prohibition for them to enter temples that has helped them in their purity of realization.
('60', 227, 7, 13, 451687) The traditional idea of Godhead and conventional forms of worship hardly lay emphasis upon the moral worth of religious practices; their essential value lies in the conformity to custom which creates in the minds of the worshippers an abstract sense of sanctity and sanction.
('60', 227, 7, 14, 451963) When we argue with them in the name of justice and humanity, it is contemptuously ignored, for, as I have said, the moral appeal of the cause has no meaning for them and you know that there are practices and legends connected with a number of our sectarian creeds and practices which are ignoble and irrational.
('60', 227, 8, 15, 452275) There is a tradition of religion connected with temple worship, and though such traditions can be morally wrong and harmful yet they cannot
('60', 227, 9, 16, 452415) 1 For the text of Gandhiji’s letter to Boyd Tucker, vide “Letter to Byod Tucker”, 4 3 1933. Vide also “Letter to Boyd Tucker”,23 3 1933.
('60', 228, 0, 1, 452552) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 229
('60', 228, 1, 2, 452596) merely be ignored.
('60', 228, 1, 3, 452615) There the question comes of changing them, of widening their range and character.
('60', 228, 1, 4, 452697) There can be differences of opinion with regard to the methods to be adopted.
('60', 228, 1, 5, 452775) From the point of view of the trustees of traditions, they are acting according to an inherent sense of propriety in preserving them as they are, in keeping the enjoyment of idol worship in temples for exclusive groups of people.
('60', 228, 1, 6, 453005) They not only deny the right of such worship to Christians and Mahomedans but to sections of their own community.
('60', 228, 1, 7, 453119) Particular temples and deities are their own property and they keep them locked up in an iron chest.
('60', 228, 1, 8, 453220) In this they are acting according to traditional religion which allows them such freedom, rather enjoins them to act in this manner.
('60', 228, 1, 9, 453353) A reformer, in dealing with such morally wrong traditions, cannot adopt coercion and yet, as in fighting with other wrong and harmful customs, he must exert moral force and constantly seek to rectify them.
('60', 228, 1, 10, 453559) This fight is necessary.
('60', 228, 1, 11, 453584) I do not think Tucker makes this point clear.
('60', 228, 2, 12, 453630) As to the Santiniketan prayer hall, it is open to all peoples of every faith.
('60', 228, 2, 13, 453708) Just as its doors do not shut out anybody, so there is nothing in the simple form of worship which excludes peoples of different religions.
('60', 228, 2, 14, 453848) Our religious service could as well take place under the trees, its truth and sacredness would not at all be affected but perhaps enhanced by such a natural environment.
('60', 228, 2, 15, 454018) Difficulties of climate and season intervene, otherwise I do not think separate buildings are really necessary for prayer and communion with the Divine.
('60', 228, 3, 16, 454171) I have sent a poem1 for the Harijan—translating it from one of my recent Bengali writings.
('60', 228, 3, 17, 454262) I do hope it is one in spirit with the ideals of the Harijan, which I read with much pleasure and interest.
('60', 228, 3, 18, 454370) There can be no more hopeful sign for India than the fact that her repressed humanity is waking up as a result of the great fast.
('60', 228, 4, 19, 454500) With loving regards,
('60', 228, 5, 20, 454521) Yours sincerely,
('60', 228, 6, 21, 454538) RABINDRANATH TAGORE Harijan, 1 4 1933
('60', 228, 7, 22, 454576) 1 “The Sacred Touch”; it was published in Harijan, 25 3 1933.

('60', 229, 1, 2, 454680) 273. KABULI ZULUM 1
('60', 229, 2, 3, 454700) The training in patient endurance of the Harijan has to be very generously supplemented by inviting Muslims of piety and influence to meet the Kabulis and point out to them that the taking of exorbitant rates of interest and the use of force for its recovery is contrary to law, morals and Islam and that, therefore, they should either [sic] be satisfied with the ordinary interest and recourse to law, if there is failure to pay.

('60', 230, 1, 2, 456377) 275. PROTECTIVE CLOTHING
('60', 230, 2, 3, 456402) The Home Office in England published for official use a carefully prepared pamphlet entitled Protective Clothing for Women and Girl Workers Employed in Factories and Workshops.
('60', 230, 2, 4, 456579) I am obliged for the pamphlet to Sjt.
('60', 230, 2, 5, 456617) Hiralal Shah’s industrious zeal.
('60', 230, 2, 6, 456650) It contains different patterns of protective clothing for a well classified list of employments, and it states that protective clothing has been found to be required for safeguarding the worker against accident or injury to health, or for securing her comfort and convenience in her work, or for protecting her ordinary clothing against damage caused by the materials, machinery, etc., used in the process in which she is employed, or resulting from the conditions under which the work has to be carried [on].
('60', 230, 2, 7, 457160) It goes on to state that in the great majority of cases the need for protective clothing arises from one or other of the following causes: 1. dusty or dirty processes, 2. working about machinery, 3. climbing ladders, etc., 4. use of acids or caustic liquids, 5. wet processes, 6. excessive heat, 7. exposure to weather, etc.
('60', 230, 2, 8, 457485) Then follows an instructive but brief description of every type of clothing recommended.
('60', 230, 2, 9, 457574) There are seven such types designed for 31 employments, coming under the headings I have already given.
('60', 230, 2, 10, 457678) The pamphlet is profusely illustrated.
('60', 230, 2, 11, 457717) I mention this only in order to show the care with which the lives of employees are regarded by the Government in England and to drive the truth home that such meticulous care is exercised in devising methods of not only protecting employees engaged in dirty or injurious trades but also of protecting the public.
('60', 230, 2, 12, 458031) How much more care is necessary in this climate for protecting the so called untouchables engaged in dusty or dirty processes and for protecting also the public from the contamination caused by the workers in such employment becoming living carriers of dust and dirt!
('60', 230, 2, 13, 458299) Their untouchability in no way protects society.
('60', 230, 2, 14, 458348) On the contrary, a false
('60', 231, 0, 1, 458373) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 231, 1, 2, 458415) sense of security aggravates the danger of contagion or infection and this aggravation is doubled by the fact that such employees, being neglected by society, become themselves so inured to insanitation that the surroundings in which they live become positive factories for disseminating dirt and disease.
('60', 231, 1, 3, 458721) Hence the necessity for adopting without delay the very simple reform advocated by Sjt.
('60', 231, 1, 4, 458809) Hiralal Shah.
('60', 231, 1, 5, 458823) If we did not take a crooked view of untouchability, we should go to the quarters where the untouchables reside; we would begin our study of their conditions by entering our sanitary closets with our eyes wide open.
('60', 231, 1, 6, 459039) Then society will not consider any cost too great for initiating and completing the reform, by ensuring the necessary measure of sanitation not only in the closets but also in the quarters inhabited by Harijans and by providing protective clothing and conveniences for washing and change.
('60', 231, 2, 7, 459328) Harijan, 1 4 1933

('60', 237, 3, 4, 468107) NARANDAS, .
('60', 237, 3, 5, 468119) .’s 1 affair is becoming a very painful one.
('60', 237, 3, 6, 468164) It has led to other revelations.
('60', 237, 3, 7, 468197) I still do not quite see my way, but I will draw your attention to one rule of the Ashram.
('60', 237, 3, 8, 468288) Nobody in the Ashram can accept a personal gift.
('60', 237, 3, 9, 468337) Anything received by any inmate belongs to the Ashram.
('60', 237, 3, 10, 468392) Nobody possesses anything that is his personal property.

('60', 243, 2, 3, 480103) April 2, 1933
('60', 243, 3, 4, 480117) NARANDAS,
('60', 243, 4, 5, 480127) The clock has just struck three and, after cleansing the teeth, I have sat down to write this letter.
('60', 243, 4, 6, 480229) You seem to feel a little defeated.
('60', 243, 4, 7, 480265) That will not do.
('60', 243, 4, 8, 480283) You must have observed that I tell everybody in my letters that they should do nothing mechanically unless they are convinced about it.
('60', 243, 4, 9, 480419) One should accept a thing either with one’s heart or with one’s reason.
('60', 243, 4, 10, 480491) One can accept a thing with the heart only if one has faith.
('60', 243, 4, 11, 480552) But in either case one feels satisfied and happy.
('60', 243, 4, 12, 480602) When reason does not understand a thing nor does the heart accept it, one feels discontented and slowly loses strength and energy.
('60', 243, 4, 13, 480733) Though such a person works day and night without rest, his work is not well done and he becomes weaker and weaker and falls ill.
('60', 243, 4, 14, 480862) This does not happen when one does work in which one has faith.
('60', 243, 4, 15, 480926) ‘What can I do?
('60', 243, 4, 16, 480942) I know that all this is not right, but I have to do it out of respect for my elders.’ This is not faith, but false civility.
('60', 243, 4, 17, 481067) According to our definition of truth, it is also a form of untruth.
('60', 243, 4, 18, 481135) This is the feeling which your letter [of the 31st] gives.
('60', 243, 4, 19, 481194) Don’t do anything because Narahari or I ask you to do it.
('60', 243, 4, 20, 481252) Do a thing only if you are convinced that it is right.
('60', 243, 4, 21, 481307) You are completely free to reject all suggestions of Narahari, for the final responsibility is yours.
('60', 243, 4, 22, 481409) Many of Narahari’s suggestions appeal to me, that is, they seem good on paper.

('60', 246, 8, 23, 486615) Stick to your stand, and don’t mind it if, in consequence, you fail in your aim.
('60', 246, 8, 24, 486696) I see no objection to a temple being built even if the funds are collected from the reformers.
('60', 246, 8, 25, 486791) If such a temple is built and is maintained properly on religious lines, it can become a great centre.
('60', 246, 8, 26, 486894) The site must be good and the men in charge of it should be persons of character.

('60', 247, 1, 2, 487299) 296. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('60', 247, 2, 3, 487331) April 2, 1933
('60', 247, 3, 4, 487345) PREMA, I wrote one letter 1 to you today morning.
('60', 247, 3, 5, 487395) You will probably get it before this.
('60', 247, 3, 6, 487433) What you write about .
('60', 247, 3, 7, 487456) 2 and .
('60', 247, 3, 8, 487464) 3 is a half truth.
('60', 247, 3, 9, 487483) Everybody makes mistakes.
('60', 247, 3, 10, 487509) We should not be upset if somebody makes one, but we are bound to feel unhappy when a person hides his mistake and it is brought to light in spite of him, and then he puts up an unworthy defence.
('60', 247, 3, 11, 487705) If we do not feel unhappy, we shall never find a way of preventing such incidents.
('60', 247, 3, 12, 487788) If we assume that such things will always happen and do nothing to prevent them, that will mean destruction of society.
('60', 247, 3, 13, 487908) We must, therefore, do what we can to prevent them.
('60', 247, 3, 14, 487960) We will do so only if we are shocked by such incidents.
('60', 247, 3, 15, 488016) We can say that one should not feel pain or get angry for things which don’t matter, and I think you also mean only that.
('60', 247, 3, 16, 488138) If you mean anything more, I am sure that you are wrong.
('60', 247, 3, 17, 488195) If some other word is suggested in place of “pain” or “shock”, I might accept it.
('60', 247, 3, 18, 488277) But your letter seems to spring from moha 4, I cannot explain how.
('60', 247, 3, 19, 488344) I cannot say whether the word moha is correct.
('60', 247, 3, 20, 488391) I will be satisfied if you understand what I mean.
('60', 247, 3, 21, 488442) I have already admitted the mistake which I made.
('60', 247, 3, 22, 488492) What I want you to show is simplicity of heart, tenderness, humility, patience, forbearance and generosity towards others.
('60', 247, 3, 23, 488615) You can show these things only if you come down from the sky to the earth.
('60', 247, 3, 24, 488690) When will you begin to feel that you are nothing?
('60', 247, 3, 25, 488740) Is it proper to bow down to Mother Earth every day and then kick her every day?
('60', 247, 3, 26, 488820) If our prayer to her is sincere, we should make ourselves mere particles of dust and learn to suffer the kicks of the world.
('60', 247, 3, 27, 488945) Mother Earth then will not feel our feet, as we shall have become ash, though still alive.
('60', 247, 3, 28, 489036) “Scatter the dust of separateness”, as the poet says.
('60', 247, 3, 29, 489090) I have still a stock of the slivers sent by you.
('60', 247, 3, 30, 489139) It was not your fault that they contain rough particles.
('60', 247, 3, 31, 489196) The fault was partly that of the carding bow and partly of the cotton.
('60', 247, 3, 32, 489267) If you had carded the cotton

('60', 249, 2, 3, 490991) April 2, 1933
('60', 249, 3, 4, 491005) SUJNA BHAISHRI, I have your letter.
('60', 249, 3, 5, 491041) I do not wish to issue an order, nor do I have any such right.
('60', 249, 3, 6, 491104) In the end I will always be satisfied with what you do, but I will continue to tell you what I want.
('60', 249, 3, 7, 491205) I attach herewith a [draft bill] approved by you.
('60', 249, 3, 8, 491255) 1 I shall publish nothing in your name without your desire or permission, and anything I might do would be not to compliment you but to serve the Harijan cause The suggestion is not for building a new temple and throwing it open, but for permitting the entry of Harijans to one of the four which already exist.
('60', 249, 3, 9, 491566) 2 I do wish that you should do this much if possible.
('60', 249, 3, 10, 491620) I am also of the view that it should be published in the Gazette that the Bhavnagar Ruler does not approve of discrimination against anybody in regard to schools, etc.
('60', 249, 3, 11, 491788) There is some such law in your State.
('60', 249, 3, 12, 491826) It will be enough if this principle is explicitly declared in it.
('60', 249, 3, 13, 491892) It can be enforced only to the extent that the people are ready to co operate.
('60', 249, 3, 14, 491971) I do not wish that you should force the people to do anything.
('60', 249, 3, 15, 492034) All that I want is that the State subjects should be informed of the policy of the Ruler, and that not orally but through a legal declaration.
('60', 249, 3, 16, 492177) In any case I do not wish to kill the goose that lays golden eggs.
('60', 249, 3, 17, 492244) For my part I want no eggs at all.
('60', 249, 3, 18, 492279) The milk of a milch goat would satisfy me and I would not complain even if the goat occasionally hit me with its horns.
('60', 249, 3, 19, 492399) Do take care of your health.

('60', 250, 8, 19, 493413) If you wish to have your body shining like gold and to devote yourself to service, you have to overcome that craving.

('60', 254, 1, 2, 497803) 308. LETTER TO BAJI KRISHNA RAO 1
('60', 254, 2, 3, 497837) April 3, 1933
('60', 254, 3, 4, 497851) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('60', 254, 3, 5, 497884) I was sorry to read your announcement, but I cannot help saying that your fast was an utterly uncalled for and an ignorant performance.
('60', 254, 3, 6, 498020) I hope it has left you none the worse for it bodily.
('60', 254, 3, 7, 498073) There can be no spiritual gain from such an ill conceived fast like yours.
('60', 254, 3, 8, 498148) Surely you had no data to enable you to come to the conclusion that the defeat suffered by Sjt.
('60', 254, 3, 9, 498244) Deorukhker was due to the sins of caste Hindus.
('60', 254, 3, 10, 498292) I do not know the cause of his defeat but I am quite sure that you could not know them either.
('60', 254, 3, 11, 498387) And why should you take it for granted that every Harijan candidate for election should succeed, whether he deserves or not?
('60', 254, 3, 12, 498512) It would be a terrible test for caste Hindus if you expected them in open elections invariably to elect a Harijan candidate when one offers himself for election.
('60', 254, 3, 13, 498674) What therefore in my opinion you need to do is to do real penance for the unjustified penance you have done and that penance consists in never again to do a single thing thoughtlessly.
('60', 254, 4, 14, 498859) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('60', 254, 4, 15, 498881) BAJI KRISHNA RAO 1ST CHETMI BAZAAR SECUNDERABAD, DECCAN
('60', 254, 5, 16, 498937) From a microfilm: S.N. 20819

('60', 254, 9, 26, 499316) There are many things for you to examine and see from
('60', 254, 10, 27, 499370) 1 The addressee, a social worker, in his letter of April 1, 1933 had informed Gandhiji of his intention to fast from April I to April 3 in order to do penance for the depressed classes leader Deorukhker’s defeat at an election.

('60', 255, 1, 2, 499640) the nature cure standpoint, and there is the common complaint about constipation which you would be able to deal with.
('60', 255, 1, 3, 499759) I am glad you have driven out Amtussalaam’s superstition that she is suffering from T. B. She has a very vivid imagination and she conjures up evil where there is none.
('60', 255, 1, 4, 499928) I want from your presence in the Ashram much more than mere treatment of a few patients.
('60', 255, 1, 5, 500017) A firm believer in nature cure myself, I would like to find in you a kindred spirit given up wholly to truthful research without any mental reservations.
('60', 255, 1, 6, 500171) And if I can get such a man with also a belief in the Ashram ideals, I could regard it as a great event.
('60', 255, 1, 7, 500276) I know you too are approaching the visit in that light.
('60', 255, 1, 8, 500332) You will therefore please make yourself thoroughly at home at the Ashram and study it in every detail.
('60', 255, 1, 9, 500435) It is my belief that a nature cure man should be able to vanquish the climate.
('60', 255, 1, 10, 500514) Millions of human beings ought to be able to live healthy life by understanding the laws of adaptability to the climate in which they find themselves.
('60', 255, 1, 11, 500665) They cannot have changes that rich men can afford and I cannot imagine nature to be so cruel as to be partial to the rich and indifferent to the poor.
('60', 255, 1, 12, 500816) On the contrary I believe in the Biblical saying that “it is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of Heaven”, and another Biblical verse says that “the Kingdom of Heaven is within you”.
('60', 255, 1, 13, 501061) Therefore I have always imagined that laws of nature are simple and understandable and capable of being followed easily by the millions.
('60', 255, 1, 14, 501198) I would ask you therefore to approach the Ashram with the set purpose of discovering the means of preserving or regaining health in the ordinary Indian climate.
('60', 255, 2, 15, 501359) Yours sincerely, BAPU

('60', 256, 5, 17, 502543) Y. M., April 3, 1933
('60', 256, 6, 18, 502564) MRIDULA, I have received your letter.
('60', 256, 6, 19, 502602) Have you received Sardar’s letter?

('60', 261, 3, 11, 509952) You cannot give me too many details of your life.
('60', 261, 3, 12, 510002) Truth peeps out through infinite details but it can be hidden from ourselves as well as from the spectators when a whole picture is presented.
('60', 261, 3, 13, 510145) That is to say, a generalization can be made to cover an untruth.
('60', 261, 3, 14, 510211) It will be true enough when I make a general statement.
('60', 261, 3, 15, 510267) ‘I’m all right’, but that general statement will cover the untruth, namely, the fact of the bad elbow.

('60', 261, 3, 17, 510484) There is a great passage in the most ancient and the simplest and I think the shortest of the Upanishads.

('60', 261, 3, 19, 510705) remove the lid for me so that I can see truth face to face.” 1 You now know what I mean by the golden lid.
