('60', 262, 1, 2, 511270) 321. LETTER TO P. N. RAJBHOJ April 4, 1933
('60', 262, 2, 3, 511313) MY DEAR RAJBHOJ, I hope you got my letter 1 sent to you as soon as I learnt that you had reached the Ashram.
('60', 262, 2, 4, 511422) I have now got your own letter.
('60', 262, 2, 5, 511454) In a few days’ time I expect you to write to me in Hindi, for there is not much difference between Marathi, Hindi and Gujarati.
('60', 262, 2, 6, 511582) They are all sister languages; a large part of the vocabulary is common to them and it is easy enough to detect a similarity in grammar.
('60', 262, 2, 7, 511719) You will resist the temptation to give.
('60', 262, 2, 8, 511759) I would ask you to be in no hurry.
('60', 262, 2, 9, 511794) You have gone to the Ashram for the purpose of taking, therefore quietly and persistently take in all that the Ashram has to give and when that has been done, begin giving by all means, and you will find that you are able to take much more than you had expected.
('60', 262, 2, 10, 512057) Do not combine giving and taking for the time being, rather believe that you cannot fail to be unconsciously giving while you are taking properly.
('60', 262, 2, 11, 512204) I am most anxious that for the time at least you should bury yourself in the Ashram, and when you have either assimilated enough of the Ashram atmosphere and attitude or rejected it as unassimilable or unsuitable, you should proceed to the next stage, and in all you do whilst you are in the Ashram, I would like you to be guided implicitly by Narandas.
('60', 262, 2, 12, 512558) That seems to me to be the best way of taking the most out of any institution.
('60', 262, 2, 13, 512637) I had seen the rough draft of your reply to Dr. Ambedkar’s statement.
('60', 262, 2, 14, 512707) There was not much in it and in no case could I have published it, seeing that Dr. Ambedkar’s statement was not published in the Harijan.
('60', 262, 2, 15, 512845) The draft was so roughly drawn that I did not know that you would want it back.
('60', 262, 2, 16, 512925) I think I destroyed it after having read it.
('60', 262, 2, 17, 512970) I am surprised at what you tell me about Sind, because there there are very staunch workers.
('60', 262, 2, 18, 513063) Jamshed Mehta is a host in himself.
('60', 262, 2, 19, 513099) Narayandas Bechar has given himself to the Harijan cause and there are several others.
('60', 262, 2, 20, 513186) The Harijans in Karachi are better housed and better looked after than elsewhere.
('60', 262, 2, 21, 513268) Of course there is room for improvement, but that would be so in every case.
('60', 262, 2, 22, 513345) However if you will send me concrete proposals I would gladly forward them to Jamshed Mehta.
('60', 262, 2, 23, 513438) I hope that you have completely thrown off the headache you had in the beginning.

('60', 263, 8, 23, 515212) NARANDAS, The packet of letters which I despatched this morning was a large one as usual.

('60', 264, 0, 1, 515464) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 265
('60', 264, 1, 2, 515508) I did not find Dhanvant Raka’s letter which you say was included.
('60', 264, 1, 3, 515574) I return Narahari’s letter with this.
('60', 264, 1, 4, 515612) This is my view regarding guests.
('60', 264, 1, 5, 515646) Even if every guest is given a copy of the rules to be observed by him, he should be given a seat by the side of a responsible inmate of the Ashram.
('60', 264, 1, 6, 515795) The latter should take away from him his dish for cleaning and also clean the spot where he is asked to sit.
('60', 264, 1, 7, 515904) These two things should be left to the guest only after he has himself started doing them.
('60', 264, 1, 8, 515995) About the food also, the neighbour should explain to him that the general menu of the Ashram contains no rice, but that it is included in the special menu and he can ask to be served according to either.
('60', 264, 1, 9, 516199) If there is only one solitary person who wants rice, he need not be asked.
('60', 264, 1, 10, 516274) As soon as a guest arrives, somebody should elicit from him his special requirements and as many of them should be provided as possible.
('60', 264, 1, 11, 516411) Potatoes and ratalu should not as a rule be served as vegetables.
('60', 264, 1, 12, 516477) I would have them served only in place of bread or rice.
('60', 264, 1, 13, 516534) They are mostly starch.
('60', 264, 1, 14, 516558) Vegetable means any green which contains no starch.
('60', 264, 1, 15, 516610) If people would agree, I would make it a rule to serve rice onl to persons who are ill.
('60', 264, 1, 16, 516698) The quantity of dal served should be very small.
('60', 264, 1, 17, 516747) Rice is not necessary at all.
('60', 264, 1, 18, 516777) Those who get milk need very little quantity of dal.
('60', 264, 1, 19, 516830) There is no doubt that our diet contains an excess of starch.
('60', 264, 1, 20, 516892) It is being proved day by day that the body needs very little starch.
('60', 264, 1, 21, 516962) But we cannot force this reform on unwilling people, and in any case we should watch the result.
('60', 264, 1, 22, 517059) We should not tolerate snacks being bought from the market.
('60', 264, 1, 23, 517119) But we need the fullest co operation of the families to put a stop to this practice.
('60', 264, 1, 24, 517204) If people went and saw for themselves how these things were prepared, they would never eat them again.
('60', 264, 1, 25, 517307) You should insist on the children sleeping for eight hours at night.
('60', 264, 1, 26, 517376) I believe that it is not proper to withhold a meal by way of punishment.
('60', 264, 1, 27, 517449) I myself, though, have been guilty of ordering such punishment.
('60', 264, 1, 28, 517513) I am also becoming more and more convinced that there should be no physical punishment either.
('60', 264, 1, 29, 517608) I have no doubt that the very fact that the need for punishment is felt bespeaks our imperfection.
('60', 264, 1, 30, 517707) We must learn how to teach without the use of any form of punishment, and we can do that only if we refrain from punishing even in extreme cases.

('60', 269, 12, 25, 525370) I have simply suggested its being put in an air tight bottle or an air tight vessel and wrapped in wet cloth under the belief that milk so kept remains for 12 hours or so without altering its quality, and if your reading confirms my belief, you should

('60', 270, 1, 3, 525929) You begin the milking early.
('60', 270, 1, 4, 525958) Some of the milk is not used till 10.30 or 11 o’clock.
('60', 270, 1, 5, 526013) If therefore it is taken in an unfired condition, it has got to be preserved against atmospheric changes.
('60', 270, 1, 6, 526119) And I think that the milkmen or milkmaids should be frequently watched and taught to wash the udders, etc., in a thorough manner.
('60', 270, 1, 7, 526249) My recollection of the Bangalore Dairy is that the animals were taken to a special open place for the purpose of milking.

('60', 270, 1, 9, 526388) I have a notion that Col.
('60', 270, 1, 10, 526414) Smith told me that it was better to take the animals to a free open space for milking.

('60', 270, 1, 12, 526570) But you know better.
('60', 270, 1, 13, 526591) I do not want to give you more work than is absolutely necessary.
('60', 270, 1, 14, 526657) I do want our dairy to be a first class model dairy of its kind.
('60', 270, 1, 15, 526722) We cannot go in for expensive methods, but we must go in for all the methods that would ensure, through methodical labour and meticulous care, cleanliness and purity of milk.
('60', 270, 1, 16, 526897) What is the lowest yield required from a cow to make her self supporting?
('60', 270, 1, 17, 526971) And what is the cost?
('60', 270, 1, 18, 526993) Now about homoeopathy.
('60', 270, 1, 19, 527016) I must confess that without any specific cause I have never been able to take kindly to it, though some of my friends have often recommended it to me.
('60', 270, 1, 20, 527167) I have noticed too that these friends themselves at critical moments have given up homoeopathy and gone to allopathy.
('60', 270, 1, 21, 527285) Though I should like to believe to the contrary I am driven to the conclusion that allopathy, although it has great limitations and much superstition about it, is still the most universal and justifiably the most popular system; Allopathy provides opening medicines, ointments for a variety of boils and eruptions, disinfectants for various situations and includes surgery of a most wonderful type.
('60', 270, 1, 22, 527684) It is an all inclusive system.
('60', 270, 1, 23, 527715) It can well include homoeopathy, biochemistry and the latest nature cures.
('60', 270, 1, 24, 527790) If therefore allopathy rids itself of the worship of mammon, which has overtaken most human activities, and could exclude vivisection and other practices which I call black, and liberally took advantage of the new methods discovered by lay people, it would become all satisfying and quite inexpensive.
('60', 270, 1, 25, 528092) Having said this, if you have an accurate knowledge of homoeopathy and can easily spare the time necessary for treatment, I do not mind your introducing it in the Ashram subject of course to consultation with Narandas and the other responsible people in the
('60', 271, 0, 1, 528350) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 271, 1, 2, 528392) Ashram.
('60', 271, 1, 3, 528400) I would love to think that we were independent of outside medical assistance or that it was only rarely that we have to trouble our medical friends.
('60', 271, 1, 4, 528549) My ideal is to find whatever alleviation we want in the Ashram itself.
('60', 271, 1, 5, 528620) It pains me when any of us have to go out for medical relief or treatment or to call in medical assistance.
('60', 271, 1, 6, 528728) We may never reach that perfect state, but the nearer the approach to it the better for us.

('60', 274, 1, 2, 533006) 337. LETTER TO SUMANGAL PRAKASH
('60', 274, 2, 3, 533038) April 5, 1933
('60', 274, 3, 4, 533052) SUMANGAL PRAKASH, I have you letter.
('60', 274, 3, 5, 533089) (1) One cannot give reasons for everything in this world.
('60', 274, 3, 6, 533147) Dharma does not lie in giving up a custom simply because no reason can be given for it.
('60', 274, 3, 7, 533235) On the contrary dharma consists in respecting the customs of the society of which one is part, provided these do not go against morality.
('60', 274, 3, 8, 533373) Therein lies truth and non violence.
('60', 274, 3, 9, 533410) To cause pain to anyone without reason is untruth and violence.
('60', 274, 3, 10, 533474) A person who gives up a practice because he cannot see any reason for its continuance is unwise and wilful.
('60', 274, 3, 11, 533582) (2) In regard to inter dining and inter marriage there is not contradiction between my earlier writings and present writings.
('60', 274, 3, 12, 533708) When I wrote those articles I had Lakshmi with me and I was planning to have her married outside the Dhed community.
('60', 274, 3, 13, 533825) 1 I still hold that in inter dining and inter marriage some restrictions are necessary.
('60', 274, 3, 14, 533913) I do not think that varnashrama comes in here.
('60', 274, 3, 15, 533960) There is no loss of dharma in marrying a suitable partner outside one’s varna.
('60', 274, 3, 16, 534039) I may say that my views are now much clearer than before.
('60', 274, 3, 17, 534097) But I hesitate to revise the views I have held for a long time.
('60', 274, 3, 18, 534161) My present views supplement the views I have expressed earlier.
('60', 274, 3, 19, 534225) However, if it appears that there is conflict between the two you should accept what I say now and reject what I have said before.
('60', 274, 3, 20, 534356) (3) I should not answer this question.
('60', 274, 3, 21, 534395) I am also not competent to answer it.
('60', 274, 3, 22, 534433) Everyone should be able to find the meaning of the vow he has taken.
('60', 274, 3, 23, 534502) The meaning that I may give to your vow should be considered false, while the meaning you give it should be taken as valid.
('60', 274, 3, 24, 534626) When one does not have confidence in oneself one may accept a witness’s interpretation.
('60', 274, 3, 25, 534714) Here the witness is not in a position to givean interpretation.
('60', 274, 3, 26, 534778) Therefore you should either interpret the vow yourself or ask other co workers.
('60', 274, 3, 27, 534858) (4) That is because the address of the journal is changes.
('60', 274, 4, 28, 534917) Blessings from BAPU
('60', 274, 5, 29, 534937) 1 Vide “Letter to Ramachandra”, 31 3 1933.

('60', 275, 1, 2, 535022) [PS.] I have left out the question about smallpox.
('60', 275, 1, 3, 535073) Whether the patient is a child or an adult, I know only one treatment: apply a wet pack to the stomach.
('60', 275, 1, 4, 535177) Dissolve some permanganate of potash 1 in cold water, enough to make the water rose pink.
('60', 275, 1, 5, 535267) Dip a sheet, large or small, in the water and wring it.
('60', 275, 1, 6, 535323) Then spread a rug on a cot and cover the rug with this wet sheet.
('60', 275, 1, 7, 535389) Then wrap the whole round the patient right up to the neck.
('60', 275, 1, 8, 535449) Keep him in this position for as long as he can bear it.
('60', 275, 1, 9, 535506) If the patient does not get a motion in the natural course, give him an enema.
('60', 275, 1, 10, 535585) For diet only fruit juice.
('60', 275, 1, 11, 535612) If the tongue is clear and the patient feels hungry, milk also may be given.
('60', 275, 1, 12, 535689) Give him a much water as he can drink.

('60', 282, 1, 2, 547519) 346. LETTER TO N.
('60', 282, 2, 3, 547537) April 6, 1933
('60', 282, 3, 4, 547551) MY DEAR N.,
('60', 282, 4, 5, 547563) I have your letters of 31st March and 2nd April together.
('60', 282, 4, 6, 547621) You were quite right in accepting Sreenivas Rao’s gifts and asking him to send you whole wheatmeal and dried fruit.
('60', 282, 4, 7, 547737) It is a great handicap that you can get no fresh leafy vegetables.
('60', 282, 4, 8, 547804) But you know that leafy vegetables are grown in no time.
('60', 282, 4, 9, 547861) I had an English friend living with me in South Africa who grew sufficient cresses in a fortnight’s time.
('60', 282, 4, 10, 547967) You should get some seeds, have just a little plot of land, fence it in, dig it well superficially and beat up the earth well.
('60', 282, 4, 11, 548094) You can use the manure that the animals around you may give, and sow lettuce seeds, tomatoes and any of the leaves that grow easily there.
('60', 282, 4, 12, 548233) You should make some explorations also in and about Chital drug.
('60', 282, 4, 13, 548298) I cannot imagine all that place being without leafy vegetables known as bhaji.
('60', 282, 4, 14, 548377) I would ask you not to abstain from milk and butter at least just now.
('60', 282, 4, 15, 548448) You may take only a little quantity if you like, but I am afraid that you will become weak in due course if you do not take these two things, for you are not having enough fresh fruit nor wheatmeal.
('60', 282, 4, 16, 548647) You need not write anything to Durgadas 1 about your statement, but write it out yourself from memory and let me have it.
('60', 282, 5, 17, 548769) I understand what you say about pulses for S. As he is very active according to the description you gave me here, perhaps there is no harm if he is given a moderate quantity.
('60', 282, 5, 18, 548944) I shall send you the book on village sanitation.
('60', 282, 5, 19, 548993) I am writing to the Ashram, but let me give you the substance of Poore’s method.
('60', 282, 5, 20, 549074) The theory is that 18 inches of the surface of earth is all filled with germs which do the work of scavenging for all the creatures that reside on it.
('60', 282, 5, 21, 549225) These germs can work on all the filth that the creatures deposit on the surface of the earth from day to day.
('60', 282, 5, 22, 549335) Poore having known this and having understood the most economical use that the Chinese make of human excreta developed his method and said that
('60', 282, 6, 23, 549479) 1 Then an editor of the Associated Press of India 2 The addressee had prepared a statement about herself and sent it to the Associated Press of India for publication.
('60', 282, 6, 24, 549646) It was, however, not published.
('60', 283, 0, 1, 549678) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 283, 1, 2, 549720) all the excreta, both liquid and solid, should be buried not more than 12 or at the outside 18 inches below the surface of the earth.
('60', 283, 1, 3, 549854) He therefore does not suggest movable latrines nor the ordinary deeppit latrines.
('60', 283, 1, 4, 549936) He suggests receiving the excreta in buckets, each person covering the excreta with earth, which is ready in the closet, so that the closet remains clean and sweet smelling all the time.
('60', 283, 1, 5, 550123) These buckets are emptied in the squares, dug up and kept ready, not many yards away from the latrine itself, and then the earth, which is heaped up on the edge of the square, is taken up and the excreta covered with it.
('60', 283, 1, 6, 550344) No more excreta should be heaped upon the deposit just made.
('60', 283, 1, 7, 550405) Ample earth is thrown on each deposit so that dogs and other animals may not dig out the thing.
('60', 283, 1, 8, 550501) Inside of a fortnight all that excreta is worked upon by the germs and turned into fine manure and the ground is ready for cultivation.
('60', 283, 1, 9, 550637) We have followed this plan most successfully at the Ashram for 17 years, that is, since its inception.
('60', 283, 1, 10, 550740) The whole of the performance takes no time and there is no smell emitted out of these squares.
('60', 283, 1, 11, 550835) I hope you will have no difficulty in following what I have said.
('60', 283, 1, 12, 550901) This is the cheapest method of dealing with human and other excreta.
('60', 283, 1, 13, 550970) All the kitchen refuse is also dealt with in the same manner, only this cannot be mixed up with the excreta, because the work of the germs done upon vegetable rubbish is different from the work done upon the excreta.
('60', 283, 1, 14, 551187) But the process is the same in all other respects.
('60', 283, 1, 15, 551238) We have found in the Ashram, by observation, that wherever we have made use of this excellent manure, our crops have been much richer in quantity and quality.
('60', 283, 1, 16, 551397) If you have any difficulty in following this, please ask.
('60', 283, 1, 17, 551455) Of course you are quite right in asking the Municipality to give you all the assistance you need.
('60', 283, 1, 18, 551553) If they give it, well and good; if they do not, you won’t worry or fidget.
('60', 283, 1, 19, 551628) For the time being, you have your work cut out for you amongst the Harijans, and what is more, in mending yourself.
('60', 283, 1, 20, 551744) Now about the dress.
('60', 283, 1, 21, 551765) You need three articles only—a loose vest somewhat after men’s shirt with short sleeves reaching up to the elbow only, skirt reaching 2 or 3 inches above the ankles, and a kuchh like mine but not so long and smaller in size.
('60', 283, 1, 22, 551990) If you want to go to the trouble of sewing, you can have something after the style of men’s shorts.
('60', 283, 1, 23, 552090) This makes the simplest dress.
('60', 283, 1, 24, 552121) The bawis, that is, the female mendicants, wear something like this.
('60', 283, 1, 25, 552190) Your saris can be turned into
('60', 284, 0, 1, 552220) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 285
('60', 284, 1, 2, 552264) vests or shirts.
('60', 284, 1, 3, 552281) The skirts you have should serve the purpose, and very probably you have something answering knickers or shorts.
('60', 284, 2, 4, 552394) Yours sincerely, [PS.] As to your addressing me Bapu, you are wrong.
('60', 284, 2, 5, 552463) You will address me as such when you have confidence in yourself that you will inspire me with trust in you and will never deceive me.
('60', 284, 2, 6, 552598) I am trying to trust you by signing myself Bapu.

('60', 289, 4, 10, 560342) 356. THE LAW AND THE HEART
('60', 289, 5, 11, 560369) A sanatanist who believes in temple entry by Harijans but who does not think that legislation to this effect will serve any purpose, in one of his letters writes.
('60', 289, 6, 12, 560532) The extract quoted above is couched in beautiful language but the writer has not attempted to understand facts relating to legislation.
('60', 289, 6, 13, 560668) There is no doubt that untouchability is a mental attitude.
('60', 289, 6, 14, 560728) It cannot be abolished by legislation.
('60', 289, 6, 15, 560767) Law can touch the body, but not the mind.
('60', 289, 6, 16, 560809) The mind can be touched only by love and persuasion.
('60', 289, 6, 17, 560862) For the spreading of dharma any other means cannot be effective, nor should they be resorted to.
('60', 289, 7, 18, 560959) 1 For extracts from addressee’s letter answering these questions, vide Appen dix.
('60', 289, 7, 19, 561041) 2 Vide “Disposal of Carcasses”, 12 3 1933. 3 The letter is not translated here.
('60', 289, 7, 20, 561121) The correspondent had questioned the desirability of legislation enabling Harijans to enter temples, on the ground that this might lead to friction.
('60', 289, 7, 21, 561270) He had advocated educating public opinion for the purpose.
('60', 290, 0, 1, 561329) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 291
('60', 290, 1, 2, 561373) The correspondent is afraid of strife.
('60', 290, 1, 3, 561412) This fear too in my opinion is unfounded.
('60', 290, 1, 4, 561454) No one wants to have the temples opened by force.
('60', 290, 1, 5, 561504) Temples will be opened only where public opinion has been prepared in favour of opening the temples to the Harijans and nowhere else.
('60', 290, 1, 6, 561638) If that is so, then why the legislation?
('60', 290, 1, 7, 561679) As conditions are today, even if the Hindu temple goers, priests and custodians of a temple desire that Harijans should be allowed inside the temple for darshan, the law prevents them from doing so.
('60', 290, 1, 8, 561878) There is no doubt about this; it is a self evident fact.
('60', 290, 1, 9, 561935) Legislation is needed to have this obstructive legislation revoked.
('60', 290, 1, 10, 562003) It is clear enough that only legislation can remove legislative restriction.
('60', 290, 1, 11, 562080) Yes, in the new legislation that is being talked about there should be no compulsion.
('60', 290, 1, 12, 562166) One compulsive legislation should not be replaced by another compulsive legislation.
('60', 290, 1, 13, 562251) As far as I understand, no question of compulsion arises in either of the two bills.
('60', 290, 1, 14, 562336) The idea in both is to remove legal interference only.
('60', 290, 1, 15, 562391) But, today, the orthodox are so adamant that they are not prepared to listen to anyone.
('60', 290, 1, 16, 562479) They write lies, they slander, abuse, and even resort to violence.
('60', 290, 1, 17, 562546) Under such conditions what are the reformers to do?
('60', 290, 1, 18, 562598) If the reformers wish to safeguard dharma, their first duty is patiently to put up with the high handedness of the orthodox, answer hatred with love, and lies with truth.
('60', 290, 1, 19, 562769) Let them bear abuses and violence.
('60', 290, 1, 20, 562804) Let them continue to do their duty.
('60', 290, 1, 21, 562840) Let them continue their efforts to have the obstructive law repealed.
('60', 290, 1, 22, 562910) Let them make attempts to have private temples opened to Harijans, and themselves keep away from temples which are barred to Harijans.
('60', 290, 1, 23, 563045) The reformers should also endeavour to remove any other difficulties that the Harijans may be facing.
('60', 290, 1, 24, 563147) I have spoken and written several times that for me abolition of untouchability is a penance.
('60', 290, 1, 25, 563241) Religious impurity cannot be removed without self purification.
('60', 290, 1, 26, 563305) Untouchability is the greatest impurity in Hindu religion.
('60', 290, 1, 27, 563364) Even if thousands of Hindus were to fast in order to remove it I should not consider it a great thing.
('60', 290, 1, 28, 563467) Perhaps, even such a great offering may not be sufficient for that great yajna.
('60', 290, 1, 29, 563547) In order to find Lord Shiva what a great deal of fasting Parvati had to do!
('60', 290, 1, 30, 563623) Every time man was faced with a spiritual crisis he invoked God through fasting and penance and only then was he able to overcome the crisis.
('60', 290, 1, 31, 563765) Tulsidas has written: By the strength of tapasya God created the universe,
('60', 291, 0, 1, 563840) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 291, 1, 2, 563882) By the strength of tapasya Vishnu protects all creation, By the strength of tapasya Shambhu destroys, By the strength of tapasya Shesha carries the burden of the earth.
('60', 291, 1, 3, 564051) All creation rests on the strength of tapasya.
('60', 291, 1, 4, 564098) Understand this, and go forth to do tapasya.
('60', 291, 2, 5, 564143) [From Hindi]
('60', 291, 3, 6, 564156) Harijan Sevak, 7 4 1933
('60', 291, 4, 7, 564180) 357. THREE CONUNDRUMS
('60', 291, 5, 8, 564202) A teacher asks:
('60', 291, 6, 9, 564218) 1. According to the system of varnashrama, in which varna would the Bhangis and Chamars be placed?
('60', 291, 7, 10, 564317) 2. May one following one trade marry among those following another trade?
('60', 291, 8, 11, 564391) 3. Since untouchability must be eradicated why should we not also inter dine with the untouchables?
('60', 291, 8, 12, 564491) Strictly speaking all these questions have been answered in Harijan Sevak in one way or another.
('60', 291, 8, 13, 564588) I shall nevertheless answer them here in the hope further to elucidate the matter.
('60', 291, 8, 14, 564671) In my view the system of varnashrama does not today exist any more.
('60', 291, 8, 15, 564739) All the varnas have given up their respective functions.
('60', 291, 8, 16, 564796) The Shastras say, and reason agrees, that when all the attributes of the varnas vanish the varnas themselves vanish.
('60', 291, 8, 17, 564913) The varnas have today given up their dharma and so there has come about a confusion of varnas.
('60', 291, 8, 18, 565008) If there is any varna that still survives it is the Shudra varna.
('60', 291, 8, 19, 565074) It is under this varna that all of us, “touchables” and untouchables, ought to be classed.
('60', 291, 8, 20, 565165) If this is not desired, people may choose for themselves what varna they like.
('60', 291, 8, 21, 565244) The point is that varnashrama as an institution does not exist any more.
('60', 291, 8, 22, 565317) Dharma is not a matter of choosing; it is not a matter of rights, only of duty.
('60', 291, 8, 23, 565397) In dharma there is no one high and no one low.
('60', 291, 8, 24, 565444) The second question concerns intermarriage.
('60', 291, 8, 25, 565488) I have repeatedly said that marriage is not a matter necessarily connected with the varna divisions.
('60', 291, 8, 26, 565589) It is a personal matter.
('60', 291, 8, 27, 565614) As a rule, however, people like to enter into matrimonial alliances with their neighbours or with people who are like them.
('60', 291, 8, 28, 565738) The practice therefore of people marrying among people belonging to the same occupations as themselves will continue.
('60', 292, 0, 1, 565856) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 293
('60', 292, 1, 2, 565900) The third question is one concerning inter dining.
('60', 292, 1, 3, 565951) Removal of untouchability as it has today been defined does not include within its scope inter dining, and rightly so.
('60', 292, 1, 4, 566070) Eating and drinking are personal matters.
('60', 292, 1, 5, 566112) One will eat and drink where it pleases one to.
('60', 292, 1, 6, 566160) Certain norms will nevertheless remain.
('60', 292, 1, 7, 566200) Everyone will not be eating everywhere indiscriminately.
('60', 292, 1, 8, 566257) While no hard and fast rules can be laid down it must however be said that no considerations of high and low should apply here.
('60', 292, 1, 9, 566385) Unfortunately in Hinduism today the only things that remain are these considerations of high and low, touchability and untouchability.
('60', 292, 1, 10, 566520) Everyone treats others as lower than themselves and refuse to touch food or water offered by them.
('60', 292, 1, 11, 566619) I see nothing of dharma in this.
('60', 292, 1, 12, 566652) On the contrary in this way we only make ourselves the laughing stock of the world.
('60', 292, 2, 13, 566736) [From Hindi]
('60', 292, 3, 14, 566749) Harijan Sevak, 7 4 1933
('60', 292, 4, 15, 566773) 358. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('60', 292, 5, 16, 566802) April 7, 1933
('60', 292, 6, 17, 566816) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have your letters and enclosures, also copy of an article of yours in an old number of The Modern Review.
('60', 292, 7, 18, 566941) I understand and even appreciate the moral repulsion against ‘fasting unto death’.
('60', 292, 7, 19, 567024) I have perhaps some repulsion, if not the same repulsion, against fasting unto death myself, but I remain unmoved.
('60', 292, 7, 20, 567139) There are many other things I have done and am still doing against my will, because I count my will as nothing before God’s will when I see it clearly before me.
('60', 292, 7, 21, 567301) I will make myself as certain as it is humanly possible to be that the will that appears to me to be God’s is really His, and not the Devil’s.
('60', 292, 7, 22, 567444) But when I am clear about it, I rejoice in obeying that will, rather than mine, although I may have no human companion to endorse it.
('60', 292, 7, 23, 567578) That this kind of fasting has a definite place in Hinduism, and properly so, I have not a shadow of a doubt, but it is a privilege that comes only to a few, and when it comes in obedience to a call from above, it has a mighty force, only fasting unto death is a corrupt expression.
('60', 292, 7, 24, 567860) Where I used it first, it had its definite meaning.
('60', 292, 8, 25, 567912) 1 The article bearing the caption, “Racial Segregation and Untouchability”, appeared in the March issue of The Modern Review.
('60', 293, 0, 1, 568038) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 293, 1, 2, 568080) Now it is being used torn from its context and looks certainly barbarous.
('60', 293, 1, 3, 568154) But it is there, and its real meaning is unmistakable, and you can almost say that it is not so much a ‘fasting unto death’ as it is a ‘fasting unto a new life’.
('60', 293, 1, 4, 568316) All the same, I value your letter and the information you give me about the English attitude.
('60', 293, 1, 5, 568410) I do want English sympathy in this big struggle.
('60', 293, 1, 6, 568459) I do want also to be understood.

('60', 293, 1, 9, 568640) Kirby Page’s article which you have sent I shall see as soon as I get time, and if there is anything worth saying, I shall reduce it to writing.
('60', 293, 1, 10, 568785) I hope that your brother’s septic teeth were extracted and that he had benefited by the extraction.
('60', 293, 1, 11, 568885) You know all about Verrier’s change of mind.
('60', 293, 1, 12, 568930) He had changed it before your blessings were received, and you know the reason also for the change.
('60', 293, 1, 13, 569030) Whilst I was prepared to bless the marriage, I cannot help saying that I blessed the change still more.

('60', 294, 1, 2, 569839) 359. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('60', 294, 2, 3, 569866) April 7, 1933
('60', 294, 3, 4, 569880) MY DEAR GHANSHYAMDAS, I have your letter of 28th March.
('60', 294, 3, 5, 569936) I do not mind those who have, under a mistaken notion, gone away from the Hindu fold, returning when they like.
('60', 294, 3, 6, 570048) But what I cannot understand is the occasion for any expense whatsoever in connection with their return.
('60', 294, 3, 7, 570153) For, if they have left the Hindu fold under a mistaken notion, as soon as they discover their mistake, it is itself a sufficient prayashchitta, and no further ceremony is necessary.
('60', 294, 3, 8, 570335) So much on the merits.
('60', 294, 3, 9, 570358) Assuming that there must be some expense which the returning Doms 1 cannot be expected to pay, why should not the S.U.S. 2 bear the expense or contribute its quota?
('60', 294, 3, 10, 570523) I should give my answer in the negative, because I feel that the S.U.S. has its very defined sphere, namely, service of the Hindu Harijans.
('60', 294, 3, 11, 570663) It has no connection with those who are today not Hindus.
('60', 294, 3, 12, 570721) Its sphere begins after the return of the prodigals.
('60', 294, 3, 13, 570774) The latter is the function of a separate organization altogether.
('60', 294, 3, 14, 570840) Here therefore there is no question of fear, but it is a question of confining ourselves to the original purpose.
('60', 294, 3, 15, 570954) However limited it may be, the return of the Doms is a kind of shuddhi, and the difference between the extreme shuddhi and this modified shuddhi is a difference in degree only.
('60', 294, 3, 16, 571131) And once the Society takes up this modified form, it would be most difficult for it [not] to lend its assistance to the various other shades.
('60', 294, 3, 17, 571273) However desirable therefore the return of the Doms to Hinduism may be, I am quite clear that its encouragement by the Society is outside the scope laid down at its very foundation.
('60', 294, 3, 18, 571454) As to the advertisement of the Titagarh Mills, I am quite clear that we may not entertain their advertisement in any shape or form, and if it is a matter of getting cheap paper, it can be had from many other mills without the slightest difficulty.
('60', 294, 3, 19, 571702) We are getting the paper for the English edition at less than market price.
('60', 294, 3, 20, 571778) It was possible to have a still more reduced quotation, but I thought it would not be proper to ask for further accommodation.

('60', 295, 4, 8, 572458) 360. LETTER TO DR.
('60', 295, 4, 9, 572477) G. V. DESHMUKH
('60', 295, 5, 10, 572492) April 7, 1933
('60', 295, 6, 11, 572506) DEAR DR.
('60', 295, 6, 12, 572515) DESHMUKH, I am very grateful to you for your most exhaustive and learned reply to my query.
('60', 295, 6, 13, 572607) I liked it so much that although the editing of the ensuing number of the Harijan was finished, I made room for your letter.
('60', 295, 6, 14, 572732) Of course you may hand the correspondence for publication in the local Press.
('60', 295, 6, 15, 572810) There is a domestic matter on which I want your advice.
('60', 295, 6, 16, 572866) As you know, Sardar Vallabhbhai has some trouble about his nose.
('60', 295, 6, 17, 572931) It has worried him all these many months, but just now the irritation has gone almost beyond endurance, as it seems to us onlookers.
('60', 295, 6, 18, 573064) As you know it is not his habit to complain, but we, his companions, know what it all means to him.
('60', 295, 6, 19, 573164) The prison medical men have undoubtedly done whatever they were capable of doing.
('60', 295, 6, 20, 573246) But their remedies have brought no relief.
('60', 295, 6, 21, 573289) I notice that he has, constantly to clean his nose, and there is always some discharge coming out.
('60', 295, 6, 22, 573388) He uses a big towel for the purpose and in 24 hours it is fairly dirty all over.
('60', 295, 6, 23, 573469) By a big towel I mean a bathing towel that is used in middle class Hindu households.
('60', 295, 6, 24, 573554) It has appeared to me that if he cleaned his nose with warm water 3 or 4 times a day he will not have so much discharge and will not have the trouble he has in cleaning the nose.

('60', 298, 9, 23, 578391) 365. NOTES
('60', 298, 10, 24, 578402) “HARIJAN SEVAK”
('60', 298, 11, 25, 578418) The readers know that there is a Hindi edition of the Harijan called the Harijan Sevak, which is published in Delhi by the Hindustan Times Press.
('60', 298, 11, 26, 578564) It has not yet become self supporting, whereas the English has.
('60', 298, 11, 27, 578628) If any of the editions has to show a loss, I should personally prefer that it were English, for real propaganda against untouchability has to be carried on amongst the masses and, therefore, the message has to be delivered to them.
('60', 298, 11, 28, 578860) Hence the necessity for publishing correct infor 
('60', 299, 0, 1, 578910) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 299, 1, 2, 578952) mation in the various Indian languages, and as Hindi is admittedly the most largely understood and spoken language, one would like to see a large circulation of the Hindi Sevak.
('60', 299, 1, 3, 579130) It is steadily improving and, being more or less the same in substance as the English edition, it naturally contains most of the things to be found in the English edition, besides things of special interest to the Hindi reader.
('60', 299, 1, 4, 579358) At the present moment about 1,000 copies are sold.
('60', 299, 1, 5, 579409) At least 2,500 copies should be sold in order to make it self supporting.
('60', 299, 1, 6, 579483) I hope that the various organizations in the Hindi speaking areas will see to an increased circulation of the Hindi edition.
('60', 299, 1, 7, 579608) The workers should report their need of the kind of literature wanted in their districts.
('60', 299, 2, 8, 579698) TWO CORRECTIONS
('60', 299, 3, 9, 579714) The newly published Sanatani has a well deserved laugh at the expense of Harijan by telling its readers that the opening of two temples in Ratnagiri reported in the issue of 25th February was repeated in that of 4th March.
('60', 299, 3, 10, 579937) This was an obvious mistake for discovering which I offer the Sanatani my congratulations.
('60', 299, 3, 11, 580028) Its inference, however, that, if temples continue to open as in Ratnagiri, there should be no need for Temple entry Bills is hardly justified, inasmuch as these were private temples.
('60', 299, 3, 12, 580211) And even if the trustees of a stray public temple were to run the risk of a prosecution and open the temple under their charge, the trustees of other public temples cannot be expected to do so.
('60', 299, 3, 13, 580405) The other correction to be made is on behalf of Shrimati Rama Devi of Cuttack, who says that in the general description of her activity 1 she did not mean that she herself did the actual teaching but that the girls who accompanied her did it.
('60', 299, 4, 14, 580648) BHOR STATE AND UNTOUCHABILITY
('60', 299, 5, 15, 580678) One read in the papers that the Chief of Bhor had abolished untouchability in his State, so far as the law was concerned.
('60', 299, 5, 16, 580800) I have now got the text of the proclamation dated 1st November 1932. It is as comprehensive as it can be and advises the subjects of the State for the sake of their own religious advancement to do away with untouchability as it is observed today.
('60', 299, 5, 17, 581047) Those who have supplied me with a copy of the proclamation have also given me a bulky report of the reformers’ activity in the
('60', 299, 6, 18, 581174) 1 Vide “Notes”, 25 3 1933.
('60', 300, 0, 1, 581201) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 301
('60', 300, 1, 2, 581245) Sudhagad Taluka of the Bhor State and they mention their hopes and their difficulties about their work.
('60', 300, 1, 3, 581349) The workers are few, and the tremendous activity that has covered the whole of India in connection with untouchability woke up the orthodox party also in Bhor State, and so the reformers experienced unexpected opposition, so much so that the Harijans were themselves frightened to take advantage of the services that the few reformers were prepared and able to offer.
('60', 300, 1, 4, 581717) I need not take up the space of Harijan and the time of the reader by recounting the difficulties and describing the successes that the reformers had.
('60', 300, 1, 5, 581868) The reading of their report has left the impression on my mind that reformers need not expect thorough success, unless they are themselves willing to suffer boycott, complete ostracism, and, maybe, even loss of their social position and their belongings.
('60', 300, 1, 6, 582123) Easy chair and substantial religious reform go ill together.
('60', 300, 1, 7, 582184) The orthodox party, sincerely believing that their religion is in peril, may be expected to fight every inch of the ground and to give no quarter to the reformers.
('60', 300, 1, 8, 582348) They have been taught to believe that to relegate a large portion of mankind to perpetual untouchability and all it means is a just retribution.
('60', 300, 1, 9, 582493) They will not hesitate to believe that those who seek to free untouchables from their shackles would deserve the same retribution and, from their own point of view, they may not be blamed.
('60', 300, 1, 10, 582682) The reformer, therefore, who has a religious conviction about the necessity of reform is expected to brave all the consequences of his activity, and if a sufficient number is found all over India, the result is a certainty in spite of the opposition of orthodoxy.
('60', 300, 1, 11, 582946) For I believe that truth and time are on the side of reformers, and where these are ensured, it matters little whether reformers are few or many.
('60', 300, 1, 12, 583092) As Thoreau has said so well, “All reform all the world over always began with one person taking it up.”
('60', 300, 2, 13, 583196) Harijan, 8 4 1933
('60', 300, 3, 14, 583214) 366. HARIJANS AND TEMPLE ENTRY
('60', 300, 4, 15, 583245) The other day a deputation of Harijans led by Rao Bahadur M. C. Rajah waited on H. E. the Viceroy with reference to the Temple entry Bills.
('60', 300, 4, 16, 583385) The following extract from their representation will be read with interest:
('60', 300, 5, 17, 583461) The opening of temples to our people along with other Hindu castes is a matter of the greatest importance for our social emancipation.
('60', 300, 5, 18, 583596) We quite
('60', 301, 0, 1, 583605) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 301, 1, 2, 583647) realize that we cannot hope for a permanent emancipation and betterment unless our status in the Hindu religion is improved.
('60', 301, 1, 3, 583772) We, therefore, hope Your Excellency’s Government will assist the passage into Law of the Temple entry and Anti untouchability Bills.
('60', 301, 2, 4, 583905) The courts in India are now assisting the enforcement of the supers tition of untouchability.
('60', 301, 2, 5, 583999) British Law has not left the superstition to its own resources, but has placed the machinery of the courts and the State at the disposal of the caste Hindus in the maintenance of those superstitious prac tices.
('60', 301, 2, 6, 584210) Even if the Government cannot interfere in the religious practices of the Hindus, it should at least refrain from assisting in the enforcement of such practices, when they are opposed to humanity and public welfare as in the case of the treatment accorded to us.
('60', 301, 2, 7, 584473) The Bill for the abolition of untouchability, sought to be introduced in the Assembly, puts an end to this anomaly and does not interfere with the religion of any person or community.
('60', 301, 3, 8, 584657) The Temple entry Bill, for which we seek Your Excellency’s support, is drafted so as to provide a legal machinery for peaceful and gradual evolution of reform with the consent of the people concerned.
('60', 301, 3, 9, 584858) Each locality will be enabled to work out a suitable compromise for solving the question of our status.
('60', 301, 3, 10, 584962) We beg Your Excellency to help in the achievement of a peaceful solution of this question that so fundamentally affects the dignity and the daily life of a community of forty six million souls who cling to the ancient Hindu religion, to which they belong, and who wish to find an honourable place in it without causing turmoil or disturbance.
('60', 301, 3, 11, 585305) In the face of the above, it is a cruel suggestion to make that the Harijans do not want temple entry.
('60', 301, 3, 12, 585408) There is undoubtedly a difference of opinion as to the emphasis laid on temple entry as compared to the economic and political uplift.
('60', 301, 3, 13, 585543) But not even Dr. Ambedkar opposes temple entry.
('60', 301, 3, 14, 585591) He will be the first man to bring it up against the caste Hindus, and rightly, if there was no movement for temple entry.
('60', 301, 3, 15, 585713) The fact is temple entry is not a substitute for any other uplift.
('60', 301, 3, 16, 585780) It is an indispensable test that religious untouchability has been abolished and that the Harijan is no longer the pariah of Hindu society.
('60', 301, 3, 17, 585920) It is not impossible to conceive that untouchables may all become econo mically and politically superior to the caste Hindus and may yet be treated as untouchable by caste Hindus, no matter how poor and even degraded they themselves may be.
('60', 301, 3, 18, 586161) There are many individual Harijans who are economically well off and are members of legislative and municipal bodies, but to the orthodox caste Hindu, they are just as untouchable as they ever were, so long as they have no right of
('60', 302, 0, 1, 586393) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 303
('60', 302, 1, 2, 586437) temple entry, as the caste Hindus have.
('60', 302, 1, 3, 586477) Temple entry prohibition and the consequent segregation that it carries with it constitute the distinguishing bar sinister of perpetual degradation.
('60', 302, 1, 4, 586626) When that is lifted, and only then, will religious untouchability be said to have been abolished.
('60', 302, 1, 5, 586724) The question, therefore, is not how many Harijans want temple entry or, having got the privilege, will exercise it.
('60', 302, 1, 6, 586840) Caste Hindus have to recognize that right if they will purify Hinduism and render justice to over forty millions of fellow Hindus.
('60', 302, 1, 7, 586971) The reformers may not, therefore, slacken their effort.
('60', 302, 1, 8, 587027) The fact that the Bills have been hung up is no cause for despondency or going to sleep.
('60', 302, 1, 9, 587116) The passage of the Bills, since they are private, will mean a mere register of the Hindu will, if they are passed by a clear Hindu majority and if they have the backing of Hindu opinion outside.
('60', 302, 1, 10, 587311) They would be of no importance to me if they were forced upon Hindus by a superior power.
('60', 302, 1, 11, 587401) I am interested in them because they are necessary to remove a legal hindrance in the way of reform.
('60', 302, 1, 12, 587502) Whether orthodoxy represents the majority or the minority of one, it is able to stop the onward march of reform.

('60', 302, 1, 14, 587676) They have no further or other use.
('60', 302, 1, 15, 587711) That points to the necessity for legislation and the education of public opinion in the matter of Temple entry Bills, if the public temples are ever to be opened.
('60', 302, 1, 16, 587874) The pace will be accelerated if private temples, of which there are many, are opened and if temples for general worship are built where public opinion demands it.
('60', 302, 1, 17, 588037) As a result of the recent brief tour of Shrimati Vijayalakshmi Pandit in Kathiawar, she told me that there was a movement in Rajkot for the building of a general temple for the use of all Hindus—Harijans, reformers and the orthodox, if the last will join.
('60', 302, 1, 18, 588293) 1 The temple is proposed to be built after the ancient pattern, so as to combine a school dharmashala, a place of congregation and worship.
('60', 302, 1, 19, 588433) I do hope that those who have the scheme in hand will persevere with it and bring it to fruition.
('60', 302, 1, 20, 588531) There need not be much money required for it.
('60', 302, 1, 21, 588577) It can be built in sections as the huge temples of the South could only have been.
('60', 302, 1, 22, 588660) A beginning can be made at once by securing a good open site and the services of a devout honest pujari.
('60', 302, 1, 23, 588765) Mere brick and mortar is of no use, if the pujari in charge is corrupt.
('60', 302, 1, 24, 588837) But I am digressing; my purpose for the moment is to drive
('60', 302, 2, 25, 588896) 1 Vide “A Model Temple”, 29 4 1933 and 30 4 1933.

('60', 304, 1, 2, 590471) 368. WHAT IT MEANS
('60', 304, 2, 3, 590490) I gave the other day an extract 1 from the experiences of a new teacher of Harijans.
('60', 304, 2, 4, 590575) Here is a free and condensed translation of extracts from a recent letter of his: Within the few days that I have been teaching these child ren, I see that I have to give them object lessons in every thing.
('60', 304, 2, 5, 590782) Cleanliness is the most difficult thing.
('60', 304, 2, 6, 590823) For the past fortnight, therefore, I take the children regularly for bathing.
('60', 304, 2, 7, 590901) I get them to wash their clothes with a bit of soap.
('60', 304, 2, 8, 590954) Of the little children I wash the clothes myself.
('60', 304, 2, 9, 591004) I supply them with brush sticks and get them to use them every day.
('60', 304, 2, 10, 591072) I pare their nails and attend to every other detail.
('60', 304, 2, 11, 591125) The result is that cleanliness occupies a larger place in my mind just now than giving them a knowledge of the three R’s.
('60', 304, 2, 12, 591247) Their parents appreciate this personal attention that is being given to their children.
('60', 304, 2, 13, 591335) Now they, too, come to my nightly gatherings.
('60', 304, 2, 14, 591381) I give them stories from the Ramayana, Jatakmala and adaptations from Tolstoy, and I propose to add Nanabhai’s sketches of the heroes of the Mahabharata.
('60', 304, 2, 15, 591535) In the morning I have an attendance of about ten children.
('60', 304, 2, 16, 591594) There is a double attendance in the evening.
('60', 304, 2, 17, 591639) Generally I take pleasure in this work, but events happen that confound me.
('60', 304, 2, 18, 591715) Sometimes drunkards appear on the scene.
('60', 304, 2, 19, 591756) Sometimes there is a proper fight between husband and wife, and sometimes I have to be an unwilling listener to choice abuse.
('60', 304, 2, 20, 591882) Boys try my temper at times.
('60', 304, 2, 21, 591911) Once one of them went beyond limits in his pranks and I had to take him by the hand and put him out.
('60', 304, 2, 22, 592012) But I have faith in God and I am hoping that this will be my life work.
('60', 304, 2, 23, 592084) I know that it is most taxing and if I did not hold on to my faith in God, I should have a recurring fit of disappointments.
('60', 304, 2, 24, 592209) You have drawn my attention to weaning them from the habit of taking leavings of food from their employers.
('60', 304, 2, 25, 592317) But I shall be patient.
('60', 304, 2, 26, 592341) When I have gained their confidence, I shall broach the subject to them.
('60', 304, 2, 27, 592414) I would love to learn how to skin carcasses and tan the hides.
('60', 304, 2, 28, 592477) This is necessary if I am to deal with the habit of
('60', 304, 3, 29, 592529) 1 Vide “Notes”, 26 3 1933.
('60', 305, 0, 1, 592556) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 305, 1, 2, 592598) carrion eating.
('60', 305, 1, 3, 592614) Many of them add to it the drink habit and it is the commonest thing for both men and women to indulge in tobacco.
('60', 305, 1, 4, 592729) The more I come in touch with them, the more I am baffled by the insanitation amongst many of them.
('60', 305, 1, 5, 592829) There is a stench coming from their bodies and their clothes, especially when they have eaten carrion.
('60', 305, 1, 6, 592932) Add to this the foul smell coming from the dung heaps.
('60', 305, 1, 7, 592987) In order to minimize the effect of these smells, I generally sit under the open sky.
('60', 305, 1, 8, 593072) This is followed by a heart rending description of the dirty habits of two boys.
('60', 305, 1, 9, 593153) Such experiences need not dishearten any teacher.
('60', 305, 1, 10, 593203) Let us remember that this is a direct result of the criminal neglect of caste men and of compulsory segregation of the most useful members of society, and all that in the name of religion.
('60', 305, 1, 11, 593392) If we are to reduce our death rate and to bring under control the diseases that are rampant among us, we will have to have hundreds like this teacher, who would work amongst Harijans with real love and unquenchable faith.
('60', 305, 1, 12, 593614) We have to feel towards these children as if they were our very own.
('60', 305, 1, 13, 593683) What do parents do when they have their children suffering from terrible confluent smallpox or still more dreadful diseases, filling their rooms with stench and dirt?
('60', 305, 1, 14, 593850) They do not mind staking their everything in order to see their children cured.
('60', 305, 1, 15, 593930) We shall have to bestow the same love on these Harijan children.
('60', 305, 1, 16, 593995) We shall have to have the same patience with them even as we have for our own.
('60', 305, 1, 17, 594074) Whatever may be said to the contrary, I shall proclaim from the housetops that, unless we remove the scourge of untouchability from our hearts, Hinduism is doomed.
('60', 305, 1, 18, 594238) The Shastras do not warrant the neglect of a single human being in the way in which we have neglected over 40 millions, and if we would repent of our sins, I would like to have an army of voluntary workers, drawn from the so called higher classes, offering to teach and take care of Harijan children.
('60', 305, 2, 19, 594539) Harijan, 8 4 1933

('60', 308, 7, 15, 598883) April 8, 1933
('60', 308, 8, 16, 598897) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter.
('60', 308, 8, 17, 598939) 1 Is it not a universal experience that things that were at one time pure have become impure through the march of time?
('60', 308, 8, 18, 599059) Both the Mahabharata and the Ramayana containample evidence that at one time varnadharma was followed in the sense I have described.
('60', 308, 8, 19, 599192) I never knew that it was the impression of almost all the Hindus that the caste system was the same as the varnashrama.
('60', 308, 8, 20, 599312) No Hindu to my knowledge has claimed that there are innumerable varnas, but every child knows that there are numberless castes.
('60', 308, 8, 21, 599440) Is it not also a fact that there are many castes claimed to belong to the same varna?
('60', 308, 9, 22, 599526) 1 In this the addressee had contended that no varnadharma could be practised without doing away with the caste system,
('60', 309, 0, 1, 599645) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 309, 1, 2, 599687) as I can see, the origin of caste is wholly different from the origin of varna, and except up to a certain point the function also of caste differs from that of varna.
('60', 309, 1, 3, 599855) I do claim that in ideal varna there can be no inequality what soever.
('60', 309, 1, 4, 599926) There would be a variety, but not inequality.
('60', 309, 2, 5, 599972) Yours sincerely,

('60', 314, 4, 13, 609355) 379. SIGNIFICANCE OF THE VARNA SYSTEM
('60', 314, 5, 14, 609393) A student after reading my article 2 on the system of the varnas writes.
('60', 314, 6, 15, 609466) Yes, I believe in the hereditary division into varnas.
('60', 314, 6, 16, 609521) Had it not been so, the varna system would have had no meaning at all and serve no purpose.
('60', 314, 6, 17, 609613) It would be mere jargon.
('60', 314, 6, 18, 609638) The system of varnas is no man made scheme.
('60', 314, 6, 19, 609682) It emanates from the law of Nature or God.
('60', 314, 6, 20, 609725) It rests with man whether or not to abide by the law.
('60', 314, 6, 21, 609779) Hence, man’s individuality does not suffer in any way.
('60', 314, 6, 22, 609834) Fire says you will burn yourself if you touch it.
('60', 314, 6, 23, 609884) If we do not pay heed to what fire says and hold it in our hand just to assert individual freedom, we are bound to get burnt.
('60', 314, 6, 24, 610010) The same applies to the law of varnas.
('60', 314, 6, 25, 610049) The sages, at the end of their penances, realized that a class structure was essential for social progress and so brought about this division.
('60', 314, 6, 26, 610192) It is left to us whether or not to accept it.
('60', 314, 6, 27, 610238) No one is going to take us to task if we refuse to do it.
('60', 314, 6, 28, 610296) But who can then stop Nature’s punishment?
('60', 314, 6, 29, 610339) Why indeed call it punishment?
('60', 314, 6, 30, 610370) Who can prevent what may be the
('60', 314, 7, 31, 610402) 1Addressee’s grand daughter 2Vide “Varnadharma”, 19 3 1933. 3 The letter is not reproduced here.
('60', 314, 7, 32, 610499) The correspondent had asked whether Gandhiji believed that varna was determined by birth, which belief would be contrary to the doctrine of individual freedom.
('60', 315, 0, 1, 610659) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 315, 1, 2, 610701) natural consequence of not abiding by the laws of the varna system?
('60', 315, 1, 3, 610769) So, the division into varnas can do no harm to individuality.
('60', 315, 1, 4, 610831) But why should varnas be by birth?
('60', 315, 1, 5, 610866) It is not something I have produced out of my pocket.
('60', 315, 1, 6, 610920) Birth is at the very root of the varna system.
('60', 315, 1, 7, 610967) The very name Brahmin is suggestive of the qualities expected of a Brahmin and one would prepare his progeny for them.
('60', 315, 1, 8, 611086) The same is true of a Shudra.
('60', 315, 1, 9, 611116) He will cultivate in his children the qualities expected of a Shudra.
('60', 315, 1, 10, 611186) This is not to imply that a Shudra is not entitled to knowledge.
('60', 315, 1, 11, 611251) The system of the varnas is necessarily related to livelihood.
('60', 315, 1, 12, 611314) A person shall earn his livelihood only by pursuing the occupation of the varna in which he is born.
('60', 315, 1, 13, 611415) There is no objection to one varna acquiring the knowledge of all the other varnas.
('60', 315, 1, 14, 611499) For individual progress and protection of freedom, all people should have the qualities generally found in all the four varnas.
('60', 315, 1, 15, 611627) But each man must especially develop the qualities of his own varna.
('60', 315, 1, 16, 611696) The varna system emphasizes the curbing of material greed so that it can leave greater scope for spiritual development Material objects and material happiness are transitory.
('60', 315, 1, 17, 611871) If man gets himself entangled in acquiring that alone, makes it the sole aim of his life, he will not be able to think about his soul.
('60', 315, 1, 18, 612006) This does not in any way dampen human endeavour.
('60', 315, 1, 19, 612055) When man does not have to go in search of means of livelihood, when means of livelihood are ready for him, all his efforts would be directed towards the spiritual quest.
('60', 315, 1, 20, 612225) It is my firm conviction that by hitting upon the varnas the Hindus have made a great spiritual discovery, and have provided means for spiritual development.
('60', 315, 1, 21, 612383) In course of time we forgot this fact and the varna system became disorganized.
('60', 315, 1, 22, 612463) It reduced itself to touchability and untouchability and to restrictions on inter dining and intermarriage.
('60', 315, 1, 23, 612571) This resulted in its fall, viz., the confusion of the varnas.
('60', 315, 1, 24, 612633) People lost themselves in encroaching upon the vocations of the other varnas.
('60', 315, 1, 25, 612711) The Brahmin gave himself to greed and abandoned his duty as a Brahmin.
('60', 315, 1, 26, 612782) If the sea catches fire, who shall put out that fire?
('60', 315, 1, 27, 612836) If the salt loses its savour, wherewith shall it be salted?

('60', 316, 1, 2, 613026) 380. OBEDIENCE TO PARENTS
('60', 316, 2, 3, 613052) It is one’s duty to obey one’s parents.
('60', 316, 2, 4, 613092) They are one’s teachers.
('60', 316, 2, 5, 613117) They are God.
('60', 316, 2, 6, 613131) Shravana achieved his salvation by regarding his parents as God.
('60', 316, 2, 7, 613196) While obeying his father’s orders, Rama gave up his kingdom.
('60', 316, 2, 8, 613257) Now you say that untouchability is adharma, that Hinduism will perish if that blot is not washed off.
('60', 316, 2, 9, 613359) To many of us what you say sounds true.
('60', 316, 2, 10, 613399) But our parents do not accept it.
('60', 316, 2, 11, 613433) As one of my friends undertook to do service to Harijans, his mother left her home and could be located only after midnight.
('60', 316, 2, 12, 613558) She has returned home, but a great difficulty faces my friend.
('60', 316, 2, 13, 613621) What should this friend do now?
('60', 316, 2, 14, 613653) This must be the case with many young people.
('60', 316, 2, 15, 613699) This is a summary of a letter.
('60', 316, 2, 16, 613730) This is a real difficulty.
('60', 316, 2, 17, 613757) I believe in devotion to parents.
('60', 316, 2, 18, 613791) While my parents were alive, I conducted myself regarding Shravana as an ideal.
('60', 316, 2, 19, 613871) I believe that whatever I have achieved is due to my devotion to my parents and the fruit of their blessings.
('60', 316, 2, 20, 613981) Despite that, I think we can imagine circumstances in which disobe dience to the orders of parents becomes one’s clear duty.
('60', 316, 2, 21, 614106) Where the parents have been given the place of a teacher and of God, they have been thought of as perfect beings, so that to their offspring they are perfect.
('60', 316, 2, 22, 614265) The children do not even entertain a doubt that what their parents say may be full of ignorance or error.
('60', 316, 2, 23, 614371) They certainly are partial to their parents, because they desire their welfare.
('60', 316, 2, 24, 614451) Where there exists a pure environment and the children have complete faith in their parents, the latter’s well being consists in carrying out their parents’ orders.
('60', 316, 2, 25, 614616) But when the children have a doubt, what is to be done?
('60', 316, 2, 26, 614672) The parents say, ‘Drink liquor, eat carrion, offer bribes, secure that job by telling lies, one can speak an untruth in business, marry a nine year old girl, there is sin in touching an untouchable,’ etc., etc.
('60', 316, 2, 27, 614883) What should children do when such a situation arises?
('60', 316, 2, 28, 614937) I think that the answer is provided in asking the question itself.
('60', 316, 2, 29, 615004) When parents issue an order which appears to the children to be clearly an adharma, it is their dharma to disobey it.
('60', 316, 2, 30, 615122) But where there is the slightest room for doubt as to what is right and what is wrong, it is one’s dharma to do one’s parents’ bidding.
('60', 316, 2, 31, 615258) One cannot compare any other man’s word with that of one’s parents.
('60', 316, 2, 32, 615326) In such circumstances, one has to follow one’s parents’ word only.
('60', 316, 2, 33, 615393) Only he may disobey his parents who feels it incompatible with his dharma to obey them.
('60', 317, 0, 1, 615481) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 317, 1, 2, 615523) But who can claim such religious prompting?
('60', 317, 1, 3, 615567) An impudent, licentious or selfish son may get such an urge.
('60', 317, 1, 4, 615628) But he does not thereby acquire the right to disobey his parents.
('60', 317, 1, 5, 615694) Only a son who has restraint, thoughtfulness, renunciation, forbearance, etc., who has known what it is to obey orders, who has clearly experienced religious awakening, may alone have the obligation to act contrary to his parents’ orders.
('60', 317, 1, 6, 615933) Moreover, in an age of licentiousness and indepen dence when many sons belittle their parents, it is difficult to say who disobeys his parents’ command regarding it his dharma to do so.
('60', 317, 1, 7, 616119) But because of that we cannot observe their dharma.
('60', 317, 1, 8, 616171) I believe he who observes the conditions which I have pointed out will not commit a mistake.
('60', 317, 1, 9, 616264) Again, those young men and women, who act contrary to their parents’ wishes cannot claim the facilities of their parental homes and their parents’ money.
('60', 317, 1, 10, 616418) They should be ready to give up home and wealth without hesitation and anger.
('60', 317, 1, 11, 616496) Very often such conduct pro duces a good effect.
('60', 317, 1, 12, 616545) The parents’ opposition calms down.
('60', 317, 1, 13, 616581) Where the parents are licentious and the son is restrained, one very often sees a change brought about in the parents.
('60', 317, 1, 14, 616700) One cannot say this in regard to untouchability.
('60', 317, 1, 15, 616749) Here both can be restrained.
('60', 317, 1, 16, 616778) Both can regard their own conduct as dharma.
('60', 317, 1, 17, 616823) Such honest differences may even endure.
('60', 317, 1, 18, 616864) Here one can only expect that both will conduct themselves by tolera ting mutual differences.
('60', 317, 1, 19, 616958) Parents should not expect their grown up sons or daughters always to obey them.
('60', 317, 1, 20, 617038) And where the parents remain obdurate or threaten to kill themselves and so on, the youths who clearly know their dharma should thoughtfully observe it.

('60', 318, 1, 2, 617275) 381. NEW USAGES OF TERMS 1
('60', 318, 2, 3, 617302) [April 9, 1933]
('60', 318, 3, 4, 617318) From the point of view of the correspondent 2 there is some truth in what he says, from my point of view there is none.
('60', 318, 3, 5, 617438) I have given words a wider meaning, no doubt, but I have not rejected the popular meaning.
('60', 318, 3, 6, 617529) The correspondent gives up the popular meaning, and tries to accept mine.
('60', 318, 3, 7, 617603) This attempt itself is misguided.
('60', 318, 3, 8, 617637) If we give up the popular meaning, what meaning can we expand?
('60', 318, 3, 9, 617700) I have faith also in stone and other images.
('60', 318, 3, 10, 617745) The fact is that language can never comp letely express human thoughts.
('60', 318, 3, 11, 617817) So, the meanings of words continue to expand.
('60', 318, 3, 12, 617863) It is impossible, it is unnecessary, to coin new words for every sense.
('60', 318, 3, 13, 617935) When the same word is used to convey opposite ideas, there is a definite danger of ambiguity and absurdity.
('60', 318, 3, 14, 618043) There is no such danger here as I have only expanded the popular meaning.
('60', 318, 3, 15, 618117) In fact, it is not an expansion but a clarification of the meaning.
('60', 318, 3, 16, 618185) The popular meaning tells us that the stone is God.
('60', 318, 3, 17, 618237) But the correct idea is not that the stone is God but that God pervades the stone.
('60', 318, 3, 18, 618320) People might say that if there is God in the stone, why should we not regard the stone as God?
('60', 318, 3, 19, 618415) The body is not the soul, but the soul dwells in the body.
('60', 318, 3, 20, 618474) Yet millions say and believe that the body itself is the soul.
('60', 318, 3, 21, 618537) It is of course true from their point of view, or rather, there is an element of truth even in what they think.
('60', 318, 3, 22, 618649) It means that the popular meaning does not deserve to be abandoned altogether.
('60', 318, 3, 23, 618728) As a concept grows wider, the meaning of the term would go on expanding too.
('60', 318, 3, 24, 618805) What I am doing is nothing new.
('60', 318, 3, 25, 618837) My ideas themselves may strike one as something new.
('60', 318, 3, 26, 618890) This is inevitable because that is my sadhana 3. One has to think in the search for Truth.
('60', 318, 3, 27, 618981) The narrow meaning does not satisfy.
('60', 318, 3, 28, 619018) With contemplation the same meanings of the same words are found satisfying.
('60', 318, 3, 29, 619095) It is said that the Vedas are but an expansion of Om.
('60', 318, 3, 30, 619149) Tulsidas says that Rama himself is Om, Rama himself is the Vedas.
('60', 318, 3, 31, 619215) Rama includes everything.
('60', 318, 3, 32, 619241) He alone is, all else is illusion.
('60', 318, 3, 33, 619276) But the Rama of the people is only a son of Dasharatha.
('60', 318, 3, 34, 619332) Tulsidas says: “My Rama may be Dasharatha’s
('60', 318, 4, 35, 619376) 1 The Gujarati translation of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 9 4 1933. 2 The correspondent had stated that Gandhiji had used terms like ‘idolworship’ and ‘temples’ in a new sense and wanted these new meanings to be explained so as to avoid possible misunderstanding.
('60', 318, 4, 36, 619644) 3 Spiritual striving
('60', 319, 0, 1, 619665) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 319, 1, 2, 619707) son but He is also much more: He is Sachchidananda Purnabrahma.” There is no contradiction in this at all.
('60', 319, 1, 3, 619814) It is the broadening of an idea, expansion of a meaning.
('60', 319, 1, 4, 619871) Tulsidas meditated and in his meditation had a vision of the flawless, formless, all pervading Rama.
('60', 319, 1, 5, 619972) This has not led to any absurdity.
('60', 319, 1, 6, 620007) On the contrary, we have a better understanding of the significance of the avatars.
('60', 319, 1, 7, 620091) It has brought peace to our mind and heart.
('60', 319, 1, 8, 620135) And we also realize how Rama has come to be known as more than Dasharatha’s son.
('60', 319, 1, 9, 620216) Similarly, let us proceed from the stone to the atom and we have endless images.
('60', 319, 1, 10, 620297) And we see God hidden even in the atom.
('60', 319, 1, 11, 620337) Hence, the whole world is given to image worship.
('60', 319, 1, 12, 620387) The place in which the image of Jagannatha is installed is a Jagannatha temple.
('60', 319, 1, 13, 620467) And the place where a few persons sit together and pray to God is also a temple.
('60', 319, 1, 14, 620548) So a tem ple is an integral part not only of Hindu dharma but of religion as such—one may call it a church or a mosque, a gurudwara or an upa shraya 1. As long as the body and the soul are related, temple and God will always stay together.
('60', 319, 1, 15, 620788) The body is a fountain of filth as well as an abode of God.
('60', 319, 1, 16, 620848) Similarly, a temple can also become a den of vice, and it is already an abode of God.

('60', 324, 1, 18, 630845) One should do only what one spontaneously can, and if anyone cannot observe the Ashram rules or does not wish to do so, it would be better for them to leave.
('60', 324, 1, 19, 631003) All of us are imperfect, but if, knowing imperfec tions, we constantly strive to follow the Ashram ideals and do not hide our shortcomings, we are fit to live in the Ashram.
('60', 324, 1, 20, 631177) We should, how ever, leave if we do not wish to follow those ideals or have no faith in them.
('60', 324, 1, 21, 631271) If you circulate the foregoing among all friends there, it will suffice.
('60', 324, 1, 22, 631344) If you wish to suggest any changes in what I have written, you may do so.
('60', 324, 2, 23, 631418) BAPU [PS.] Chhaganlal does not worry about Rama at all.
('60', 324, 2, 24, 631474) He is sure that you will do whatever is necessary.

('60', 326, 6, 9, 633061) 390. LETTER TO SHAMAL R. RAVAL
('60', 326, 7, 10, 633092) April 9, 1933
('60', 326, 8, 11, 633106) SHAMAL, I welcome your question.
('60', 326, 8, 12, 633139) Of course I would never say that people should give up eating carrion and eat the flesh of slaughtered animals instead.
('60', 326, 8, 13, 633259) However, I do say that carrion has a very bad effect on the person eating it.
('60', 326, 8, 14, 633337) It is considered bad all over the world.
('60', 326, 8, 15, 633378) Yes, I do say that a person who cannot give up eating flesh may eat the flesh of a slaughtered animal.
('60', 326, 8, 16, 633481) Of course it cannot be that a person accustomed to eating flesh will eat only carrion.
('60', 326, 8, 17, 633568) It is certainly not that those who eat carrion do so because they think it to be against dharma to kill an animal for food.
('60', 326, 8, 18, 633692) It is sheer superstition to believe that carrion is especially good for health.
('60', 326, 9, 19, 633772) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 3146. Also C.W. 2882. Courtesy: Shamal R. Raval

('60', 335, 6, 12, 646182) 406. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA
('60', 335, 7, 13, 646221) April 11, 1933
('60', 335, 8, 14, 646236) DEAR SATISBABU, There is no doubt about it that untouchability works nowhere so cruelly as in the South.
('60', 335, 8, 15, 646341) That in the South all the non Brahmins are not classed as untouchables has a historical reason.
('60', 335, 8, 16, 646437) But in its working it is the same, whether you call them untouchables or not; and hence it is that you find in Madras alone non Brahmin constituencies.
('60', 335, 8, 17, 646589) Therefore in Madras you have reservation of seats for non Brahmins and untouchables instead of merely untouchables, and the feeling between Brahmins and non Brahmins runs much higher and keener than between touchables and untouchables.
('60', 335, 8, 18, 646825) In Bengal no doubt things are bad enough and need to be mended.
('60', 335, 8, 19, 646889) The untouchables in Bengal
('60', 335, 9, 20, 646916) 1 Dr. Suresh Chandra Banerjee 2 The addressee who was at one time in charge of the khadi work at Abhoy Ashram, Comilla, had requested Gandhiji to give copies of his statements to the Free Press of India also as he did to the Associated Press of India.
('60', 336, 0, 1, 647168) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 337
('60', 336, 1, 2, 647212) would feel the irritation just as much as the untouchables in Madras, for they know nothing worse.
('60', 336, 1, 3, 647311) But when we begin to set up comparisons we have to admit that the Madras pattern is infinitely worse than the Bengal one, and if you went to Madras and studied the question you will immediately say, ‘Bad as things are with us in Bengal, they are infinitely worse in Madras.’ Therefore I want you to work away against untouchability in Bengal as unremittingly as you have begun, but at the same time avoid comparison with the other Provinces and be more than fair in your judgment of the sanatanists.
('60', 336, 2, 4, 647811) Yours sincerely,

('60', 337, 2, 3, 649236) April 11, 1933
('60', 337, 3, 4, 649251) MIRA, Your long letter came yesterday.
('60', 337, 3, 5, 649290) Your argument appeals to me.
('60', 337, 3, 6, 649319) Women themselves have resisted the argument that you have advanced.
('60', 337, 3, 7, 649387) I have believed it always that man is the aggressor.
('60', 337, 3, 8, 649440) He is more sensual than woman.
('60', 337, 3, 9, 649471) I have therefore no difficulty in following your argument.
('60', 337, 3, 10, 649530) But the corollary you draw defies experience.
('60', 337, 3, 11, 649576) It has been happy where it has worked.
('60', 337, 3, 12, 649615) But they are rare cases and will always be so—nor is it unfortunate.
('60', 337, 3, 13, 649684) The usual condition is marriage and procreation.
('60', 337, 3, 14, 649733) That means breach of brahmacharya as we know it.
('60', 337, 3, 15, 649782) That does not mean that we should not aim at it.
('60', 337, 3, 16, 649831) We must aim at it even though there may be only one case of perfect brahmacharya out of the experiment.
('60', 337, 3, 17, 649935) Many attempt, only a few will attain salvation.
('60', 337, 3, 18, 649983) Therefore generally we shall have to be satisfied with married people growing to brahmacharya and a few only being life brahmacharis.
('60', 337, 3, 19, 650117) If I am right, the Ashram will have to be what it is, always rising higher after every failure.
('60', 337, 3, 20, 650213) 1 and .
('60', 337, 3, 21, 650221) are infinitely better for having lived in the Ashram nor is the Ashram any the worse for their having lived in it.
('60', 337, 3, 22, 650336) They would easily have been much better if I had been less imperfect and more wise and for that matter the other elders.
('60', 337, 3, 23, 650457) But I was their foot rule, so imperfect and untrue.
('60', 337, 3, 24, 650509) Yet I do not consider myself an unsafe guide because I am not consciously untruthful and always attempt to discover and throw away my imperfections.
('60', 337, 3, 25, 650658) All I say is that failures there must be so long as we have not in our midst a perfect man or woman.
('60', 337, 3, 26, 650759) But we need not lose hope nor become unnerved on discovering instances like .
('60', 337, 3, 27, 650837) .’s; they are attempts of the system to throw off impurities.
('60', 337, 3, 28, 650899) I rejoice at the discovery, while I deplore .
('60', 337, 3, 29, 650945) .’s error, even as I would rejoice at the discovery of a disease in my own body, though I may deplore it.
('60', 337, 3, 30, 651051) Further than this I cannot carry this tremendous problem—‘one step enough for me, I do not ask to see the distant scene’.
('60', 337, 3, 31, 651173) We know the fundamental truth we want to reach, we know also the way.
('60', 337, 3, 32, 651243) The details we do not know, we shall never know them all, because we are but very humble instruments among millions of such moving consciously or unconsciously towards the divine event.
('60', 337, 3, 33, 651429) We shall reach the Absolute Truth, if we will faithfully
('60', 337, 4, 34, 651486) 1 This and the subsequent names in the letter have been omitted.
('60', 338, 0, 1, 651551) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 339
('60', 338, 1, 2, 651595) and steadfastly work out the relative truth as each one of us knows it.
('60', 338, 1, 3, 651667) Ba wants her letter separately because of the separate delivery.
('60', 338, 1, 4, 651732) According to the date of the delivery of my letter to her, the fortnight is not yet complete.
('60', 338, 1, 5, 651826) I do not understand this intricate working of the jail regulations.
('60', 338, 1, 6, 651894) It differs in every jail evidently.
('60', 338, 1, 7, 651930) But that ought not to cause any worry.
('60', 338, 1, 8, 651969) The philosophy of prison life is that the body belongs to the keeper, i.
('60', 338, 1, 9, 652042) e., the State.
('60', 338, 1, 10, 652057) Therefore generally speaking it may be said that a prisoner is foolish who worries about exterior wants the supply of which depends wholly upon the keeper’s will.
('60', 338, 1, 11, 652220) Thus everything given to a prisoner is a concession which may be withdrawn at the will of the State.
('60', 338, 1, 12, 652321) Domestic letters fall under that category.
('60', 338, 1, 13, 652364) We may thankfully receive and write them so long as they are allowed but we may not foam or fret or curse, if we are not allowed to do so.
('60', 338, 1, 14, 652503) Regularity of delivery we may prize but irregularity ought not to unhinge us.
('60', 338, 1, 15, 652581) Those who are prisoners for conscience’ sake should at least grasp this very simple but not generally understood truth.
('60', 338, 1, 16, 652701) If you can explain it to Ba, you should do so.
('60', 338, 1, 17, 652748) I shall see about the delivery of Hindi Harijan.
('60', 338, 1, 18, 652797) My weight is steady at 104. Love from us all.

('60', 338, 2, 21, 652981) I therefore return it for you to keep.
