('60', 343, 1, 2, 658814) I am thankful for the correction that it was not in 1922 but in 1923 that I was permitted to see two fellow convicts in the Yeravda prison who were fasting.
('60', 343, 1, 3, 658971) I am sorry for the decision of the Government on the issue raised by me.
('60', 343, 1, 4, 659044) Technically the Government are right in their reply.
('60', 343, 1, 5, 659097) Naturally every concession lapses with the end of the prisoner’s incarceration.
('60', 343, 1, 6, 659177) The limits of the current concessions I have not questioned, though I did not like them in so far as the inquiry about the treatment or conduct of other prisoners was concerned.
('60', 343, 1, 7, 659355) Happily there was no occasion for definitely raising the point.
('60', 343, 1, 8, 659419) My endeavour has been to avoid, as far as possible, occasion of conflict with authority.
('60', 343, 1, 9, 659508) I have been content to live, as becomes a prisoner, a hand to mouth existence in the hope that with the march of time my conduct would inspire the Government with confidence in my desire to tender and promote prison discipline to the best of my ability and thus make my way smooth for humanitarian work that was possible for me even as a prisoner to do.
('60', 343, 1, 10, 659862) And I may be pardoned for referring to a policy once established by the Government and pleading for its continuity.
('60', 343, 1, 11, 659978) But the Government would on the contrary seem to repent of past concessions and to want to curtail them.
('60', 343, 1, 12, 660083) For the communication under reply says, “Government are unable to extend this concession so as to cover direct communications between him and prisoners in jails other than Yeravda.” Does this mean that I am not now to exchange communications which I have hitherto carried on with prisoners in jails other than Yeravda, and that in cases such as Seth Poonamchand’s I am not to be permitted to offer friendlyintervention?
('60', 343, 1, 13, 660503) I can only hope that the Government do not mean to curtail or restrict the concession already granted to me.
('60', 343, 1, 14, 660612) I request an early reply as even the concession granted in the matter of Seth Poonamchand has not, in my opinion, been properly given effect to.
('60', 343, 2, 15, 660757) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('60', 358, 2, 3, 688612) April 13, 1933
('60', 358, 3, 4, 688627) MY DEAR MARGARETE, Your letter of 20th March is disturbing.
('60', 358, 3, 5, 688687) Everything done in a hurry generally proves unsatisfactory when it is not positively harmful.
('60', 358, 3, 6, 688781) All haste must be deprecated.
('60', 358, 3, 7, 688811) From the highest standpoint, and that is the only one I am sure which you want to apply to yourself, your coming will be justified only when you are ready for the Ashram life.
('60', 358, 3, 8, 688987) That clearly you are not.
('60', 358, 3, 9, 689013) Your immediate duty is to be by your mother’s side.
('60', 358, 3, 10, 689065) You cannot risk bringing her to India.
('60', 358, 3, 11, 689104) If you are thrown out of employment and have to be in search of one, you have to courageously stand by your people and suffer the hardships that they will have to suffer, and if you have imbibed the fundamentals of the Ashram life, you might even render inestimable help to them.
('60', 358, 3, 12, 689384) All your letters to 24 people in India, therefore, to get you a job should not have been written.
('60', 358, 3, 13, 689482) You do not want a job in India, but you want to give your free service, the whole of yourself, to India.
('60', 358, 3, 14, 689587) You cannot do two contrary things at the same time.
('60', 358, 3, 15, 689639) I wish therefore you would give up the idea of the job, remain there by your mother’s side and live the Ashram life there, so that if God wills it, He will send you some day to the Ashram.

('60', 369, 1, 2, 706803) 449. LETTER TO HARIBHAU PHATAK 1
('60', 369, 2, 3, 706836) April 14, 1933
('60', 369, 3, 4, 706851) MY DEAR HARIBHAU PHATAK, My claim to be a servant of Harijan, of Daridranarayana, has yet to be established, and I freely admit that my food is undoubtedly one of the obstacles to the successful establishment of my claim.
('60', 369, 3, 5, 707073) But you should know that I do not spend anything on my food.
('60', 369, 3, 6, 707134) Here it is the costly Government assisted by spendthrift friends who supply me with my food, but the fact that somebody else spends a lot of money over my food is no defence, nor perhaps is it any defence that the goat’s milk and the fruit that I take are a medical need for the body.
('60', 369, 3, 7, 707419) I know that there are thousands, if not millions, whose bodies too would be pronounced to be in medical need of the kind of food that I am taking.
('60', 369, 3, 8, 707566) But they have no doctors who would issue such certificates to them, and if they happen to get such a doctor, neither this Government nor our millionaires would supply them with the food that I receive.
('60', 369, 3, 9, 707768) I am an out and out believer in the doctrine of swadeshi, but I flatter myself with the belief that my swadeshi is not a narrow doctrine.
('60', 369, 3, 10, 707906) I will take from the whole world what I cannot and do not produce in India profitably in terms of the millions.
('60', 369, 3, 11, 708018) Therefore I do not hesitate to take from Arabia its health giving dates or from Afghanistan its equally health giving raisins.
('60', 369, 3, 12, 708145) These are only a few examples of the foreign articles that I use.
('60', 369, 3, 13, 708211) But my claim to be a votary of swadeshi is well established because I would take the coarsest hand spun manufactured by Harijans in preference to the finest cloth manufactured in Indian mills.
('60', 369, 3, 14, 708404) Yes, poor Pyarelal, knowing my weakness for everything Indian, thought that he had found out dates in his paradise, the Punjab, and he did find them.
('60', 369, 3, 15, 708554) These were expensive enough for those who sent them, but I had to pay nothing for them.
('60', 369, 3, 16, 708642) I took them whilst they lasted at the expense of Arabia, but the latter won the day, because the Punjab dates were available only during the season which lasts only two or three months.
('60', 369, 3, 17, 708828) So, on the whole, Arabia will remain the victor with me
('60', 369, 4, 18, 708884) 1 The addressee in a letter dated April 13 had expressed his agitation over hearing sarcastic remarks from friends regarding gandhiji’s diet, its cost and its indigenous quality.
('60', 369, 4, 19, 709063) He wanted gandhiji’s assurance on this matter in order in answer such attacks.
('60', 370, 0, 1, 709142) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 371
('60', 370, 1, 2, 709186) because I do not propose to deny myself the dates which my body needs and by taking which I deprive no date grower in India.
('60', 370, 1, 3, 709311) I cannot give you the name of the agents because Pyarelal could not get the names, for he interested a friend of his in procuring the Punjab dates.
('60', 370, 1, 4, 709459) I am glad that the Poona Municipality has passed Sjt.

('60', 374, 6, 22, 716572) 456. NOT MERELY BY BIRTH
('60', 374, 7, 23, 716597) The following three verses from Madame Wadia’s instructive address delivered the other day will bear reproduction in these pages, though they have been often quoted and published:
('60', 374, 8, 24, 716777) Listen to these words of Yudhishthira in the “Vanaparva” of the Mahabharata: “Truth, charity, forgiveness, good conduct, gentleness, austerity and mercy, where these are seen, O King of the Serpents, there is a Brahmin.
('60', 374, 8, 25, 716997) If these marks exist in a Shudra and are not in a Dvija, the Shudra is not a Shudra, nor the Brahmin a Brahmin.”
('60', 374, 9, 26, 717110) And in the Vishnu Bhagavata we read:
('60', 374, 10, 27, 717147) “What is said as to the marks of conduct indicative of a man’s caste, if those marks are found in another, designate him by the caste of his marks (i.e., not of his body and birth).”
('60', 374, 11, 28, 717330) But some of you would prefer Manusmriti.
('60', 374, 11, 29, 717371) Well, here you are.
('60', 374, 11, 30, 717391) “As a wooden elephant, as a leathern deer, such is an unlearned Brahmin; these three bear only names.
('60', 374, 11, 31, 717493) The Brahmin, who, not having studied the Vedas, labours elsewhere, becomes a Shudra in that very life together with his descendants.”
('60', 375, 0, 1, 717627) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 375, 1, 2, 717669) These and numerous other verses from the Shastras unm istakably show that mere birth counts for nothing.
('60', 375, 1, 3, 717774) A person must show corresponding works and character to establish his claim by birth.
('60', 375, 1, 4, 717860) Such verses also enforce the argument that (a) a person loses varna by failing to exhibit its peculiar characteristics, (b) inter varna marriage or inter dining, whatever virtue the restrictions on them may have, does not affect a person’s varna, at least not so much as the failing to live up to one’s varna, (c) birth, while it gives a start and enables the parents to determine the training and occupation of their children, does not perpetuate the varna of one’s birth, if it is not fulfilled by works.
('60', 375, 2, 5, 718367) Harijan, 15 4 1933
('60', 375, 3, 6, 718386) 457. SECOND HARIJAN DAY
('60', 375, 4, 7, 718410) The first Harijan Day was observed on 18th December last.
('60', 375, 4, 8, 718468) Amritlal Thakkar has been most anxious for the fixing of another Harijan Day, but I have been putting it off because of my want of faith.
('60', 375, 4, 9, 718606) Thakkar Bapa was satisfied with the work done on 18th December.
('60', 375, 4, 10, 718670) I was not.
('60', 375, 4, 11, 718681) The fixing of a special day can only be warranted by extraordinary effort.
('60', 375, 4, 12, 718756) In a sacred cause like the Harijan cause, a special day should be one of greater dedication, prayer and intensive work.
('60', 375, 4, 13, 718876) Consultation with Thakkar Bapa has infected me with his hope.
('60', 375, 4, 14, 718938) The last Sunday of this month has been chosen as the day of observance.
('60', 375, 4, 15, 719010) I should divide the day somewhat after this style: 1. I should begin the day from 5 a.m.
('60', 375, 4, 16, 719099) with prayer and set apart for the cause some money or cloth or grain according to my means.
('60', 375, 4, 17, 719191) The poorest can do this by denying themselves a meal or meals or a portion thereof without feeling the slightest deprivation.
('60', 375, 4, 18, 719317) Preferably donations in kind should be converted into cash.
('60', 375, 4, 19, 719377) Where this is not possible, they should be given to the most deserving and needy Harijans.
('60', 375, 4, 20, 719468) 2. The work of the family Bhangi, if there is any, should be wholly done by the family or at least shared with him.
('60', 375, 4, 21, 719584) This will enableone to understand the nature of the service that the Bhangi performs and may also lead to an improved method of performing such services.
('60', 375, 4, 22, 719738) Not many persons have any consideration for the
('60', 376, 0, 1, 719786) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 377
('60', 376, 1, 2, 719830) ‘knight of the broom’ at the time of using the sanitary conveniences.
('60', 376, 1, 3, 719900) If we had no untouchability in us and if we even occasionally shared the work with the Bhangis, we would have a different method of working the home sanitary system.
('60', 376, 1, 4, 720066) 3. Having done these two things, we are ready for the corporate effort for the day, which should open with house to house collection of donations in cash or kind.
('60', 376, 1, 5, 720229) This work should be finished by a given hour.
('60', 376, 1, 6, 720275) The donations should be handed to the local committee, which will in its turn hand the collection to the superior committee till it reaches the headquarters of the Province.
('60', 376, 1, 7, 720449) Collectors should take with them a judicious selection of literature including leaflets, pamphlets, books and even copies of Harijan, English or vernacular edition as may be required.
('60', 376, 1, 8, 720633) The literature should be sold or given away as the exigency of the moment may require.
('60', 376, 1, 9, 720720) But each committee should bear the cost of the literature ordered by it.
('60', 376, 1, 10, 720793) If extra copies of the Harijan are required, previous advice should be given to the publishers so as to enable them to print extra copies.
('60', 376, 1, 11, 720932) 4. Harijan quarters should be visited in each place and they should be cleaned wherever necessary.
('60', 376, 1, 12, 721031) Meetings of Harijans should be held and their wants noted.
('60', 376, 1, 13, 721090) They should be advised as to the part they have to play in the removal of untouchability.
('60', 376, 1, 14, 721180) Dr. Deshmukh’s authoritative opinion should be used in support of the plea for the giving up of carrion eating.
('60', 376, 1, 15, 721292) Children can arrange meetings and excursions for Harijan children.
('60', 376, 1, 16, 721359) Possibilities of an inauguration of improved methods of sanitation should be explored and wherever possible, the scheme of Sjt.
('60', 376, 1, 17, 721487) Hiralal Shah should be given effect to.
('60', 376, 1, 18, 721527) It is neither difficult nor expensive if the people will shoulder the burden willingly.
('60', 376, 1, 19, 721615) In the end it means a visible addition to the health and wealth of the community.
('60', 376, 1, 20, 721697) 5. The day should be wound up by a general meeting of both savarnas and Harijans to pass resolutions, pledging the meeting to the removal of untouchability and emphasizing the desirability of permissive legislation regarding temple entry.
('60', 376, 1, 21, 721936) 6. Where public opinion is favourable, public wells and private temples should be opened to Harijans.
('60', 376, 1, 22, 722038) An accurate report of the work done should be sent to the Central Committee and, if possible, a copy to me to avoid delay in publication.

('60', 377, 1, 2, 722294) 458. THINKING ALOUD
('60', 377, 2, 3, 722314) Both C. F. Andrews and I have the habit of thinking aloud.
('60', 377, 2, 4, 722373) Here is a sample from one of his letters:
('60', 377, 3, 5, 722415) I have enclosed .
('60', 377, 3, 6, 722433) ’s 1 letter because I hardly think you realize how very strong here is the moral repulsion against ‘fasting unto death’.
('60', 377, 3, 7, 722554) I confess, as a Christian I share it and it is only with the greatest difficulty that I find myself able to justify it under any circumstances.
('60', 377, 3, 8, 722698) I was convinced at the time last year when in desperation the way seemed open for nothing else and only this one door seemed unclosed.
('60', 377, 3, 9, 722833) But even then it was an agony to me.
('60', 377, 3, 10, 722870) I know also that I must bow to God’s will even when it comes in very strange forms.
('60', 377, 3, 11, 722954) Also I know that it has had its place in the past in Hindu religion and I have to try to understand exactly what it means to a Hindu.
('60', 377, 3, 12, 723088) All this I am trying very hard to think out.
('60', 377, 3, 13, 723133) But it has not come out all clear yet.
('60', 377, 4, 14, 723172) I felt that it would be good to tell you all this at a time when there is no immediate prospect of such a thing happening.
('60', 377, 4, 15, 723295) Meanwhile, I am trying to think out the whole matter.
('60', 377, 4, 16, 723349) I have again and again defended over here your last fast and pointed to its results and to the fact that such a tender conscience as Gurudev’s could see in it only what was great and noble.
('60', 377, 4, 17, 723539) But in the great effort that you yourself are making (and we are interpreting to the very best of our power) to convert the hearts of Englishmen, whom you love and respect, to side with you and not against you in freeing your country, the following is true:
('60', 377, 5, 18, 723797) 1. It is easy to get their sympathy with the removal of untouchability.
('60', 377, 5, 19, 723869) Their hearts are truly touched.
('60', 377, 5, 20, 723901) 2. It is not easy to get sympathy with the idea of committing suicide by fasting unto death.
('60', 377, 5, 21, 723994) The horror and repulsion are too great, and the mere threat of such a thing benumbs instead of awakening the conscience.
('60', 377, 6, 22, 724115) I know you would love me to tell you all this just now, if I have not
('60', 377, 7, 23, 724185) told it to you already, because while it is not an immediate issue, I can write
('60', 377, 8, 24, 724265) calmly.
('60', 377, 8, 25, 724273) I publish this letter because it deserves a public reply.
('60', 377, 8, 26, 724331) I do want every ounce of real sympathy from every part of the world in the very difficult and anxious work of the purification of Hinduism, which, as I have claimed, is in a way purification of the whole human family.
('60', 377, 8, 27, 724549) I know the English repulsion to fasting for religious ends and especially ‘fasting unto death’.
('60', 377, 8, 28, 724645) I should like to own also that even the
('60', 377, 9, 29, 724685) 1 The name is omitted in the source.

('60', 378, 1, 2, 724766) fast which Deenabandhu Andrews reconciled himself to, though very reluctantly, has had untoward results in India, as I have discovered to my sorrow.
('60', 378, 1, 3, 724915) Hindus had become delirious and done acts which, when they became sober, they undid.
('60', 378, 1, 4, 725000) They opened temples and wells to Harijans freely during the fast.
('60', 378, 1, 5, 725066) Some of these were closed soon after the end of the fast.
('60', 378, 1, 6, 725124) A very large number of educated caste Hindus in Bengal do sincerely feel that, in the midst of the excitement caused by the fast, a grave injustice was done to Bengal in the allotment of seats to Harijans.
('60', 378, 1, 7, 725330) I know, too, that in some other Provinces the Yeravda Pact was assented to under the pressure of the fast.
('60', 378, 1, 8, 725437) All this was bad.
('60', 378, 1, 9, 725455) I certainly had not anticipated it all when I embarked on the fast.
('60', 378, 1, 10, 725523) But I do not repent of it.
('60', 378, 1, 11, 725550) In the first place, the fast was not of my doing.
('60', 378, 1, 12, 725600) Secondly, though the respective acts were done under the pressure of the fast, they were not in themselves evil.
('60', 378, 1, 13, 725713) Were they evil, I should move heaven and earth to undo the evil.
('60', 378, 1, 14, 725778) But my purpose just now is to examine, not the effects of the fast, but the fast itself as a necessary part of the Divine scheme.
('60', 378, 1, 15, 725908) If it is a part of it, it ought not to need elaborate explanations each time it is undertaken.
('60', 378, 1, 16, 726003) Although the sanatanists swear at me for the fast, and Hindu co workers may deplore it, they know that fasting is an integral part of even the present day Hinduism.
('60', 378, 1, 17, 726168) They cannot long affect to be horrified at it.
('60', 378, 1, 18, 726215) Hindu religious literature is replete with instances of fasting, and thousands of Hindus fast even today on the slightest pretext.
('60', 378, 1, 19, 726346) It is the one thing that does the least harm.
('60', 378, 1, 20, 726392) There is no doubt that, like everything that is good, fasts are abused.
('60', 378, 1, 21, 726464) That is inevitable.
('60', 378, 1, 22, 726484) One cannot forbear to do good because sometimes evil is done under its cover.
('60', 378, 1, 23, 726562) My real difficulty is with my Christian Protestant friends, of whom I have so many and whose friendship I value beyond measure.
('60', 378, 1, 24, 726690) Let me confess to them that, though from my very first contact with them I have known their dislike for fasts, I have never been able to understand it.
('60', 378, 1, 25, 726842) Mortification of the flesh has been held all the world over as a condition of spiritual progress.
('60', 378, 1, 26, 726940) There is no prayer without fasting, taking fasting in its widest sense.
('60', 378, 1, 27, 727012) A complete fast is a complete and literal denial of self.
('60', 378, 1, 28, 727070) It is the truest prayer.
('60', 378, 1, 29, 727095) “Take my life and let it be, always only all for Thee” is not, should be, a mere lip or figurative expression.
('60', 378, 1, 30, 727206) It has to be a wreckless and joyous giving without the least reservation.

('60', 379, 1, 2, 727374) beginning, the least part of the surrender.
('60', 379, 1, 3, 727418) Whilst I was putting together my thoughts for this article, a pamphlet written by Christians came into my hands wherein was a chapter on the necessity of example rather than precept.
('60', 379, 1, 4, 727601) In this occurs a quotation from the 3rd chapter of Jonah.
('60', 379, 1, 5, 727659) The Prophet had foretold that Nineveh, the great city, was to be destroyed on the fortieth day of his entering it.
('60', 379, 2, 6, 727774) So the people of Nineveh believed God, and proclaimed a fast, and put on sackcloth, from the greatest of them even to the least of them.
('60', 379, 2, 7, 727911) For word came unto the king of Nineveh, and he arose from his throne, and he laid his robe from him, and covered him with sackcloth, and sat in ashes.
('60', 379, 2, 8, 728062) And he caused it to be proclaimed and published through Nineveh by the decree of the king and his nobles, saying, ‘Let neither man nor beast, herd nor flock, taste anything: let them not feed, nor drink water: but let man and beast be covered with sackcloth, and cry mightily unto God: yea, let them turn everyone from his evil way, and from the violence that is in their hands.
('60', 379, 2, 9, 728441) Who can tell if God will turn and repent, and turn away from his fierce anger, that we perish not?’ And God saw their works, that they turned from their evil way; and God repented of the evil, that He had said that He would do unto them; and He did it not.
('60', 379, 2, 10, 728698) Thus this was a ‘fast unto death’.
('60', 379, 2, 11, 728733) But every fast unto death is not suicide.
('60', 379, 2, 12, 728775) This fast of the king and the people of Nineveh was a great and humble prayer to God for deliverance.
('60', 379, 2, 13, 728877) It was to be either deliverance or death.
('60', 379, 2, 14, 728919) Even so was my fast, if I may compare it to the Biblical fast.

('60', 380, 1, 2, 729686) 459. AN IMPATIENT WORKER
('60', 380, 2, 3, 729711) An earnest but impatient worker has been trying to have temples and public places thrown open to Harijans.
('60', 380, 2, 4, 729818) He had some success but nothing to be proud of.
('60', 380, 2, 5, 729866) In his impatience, therefore, he writes:
('60', 380, 3, 6, 729907) It is no use waiting for these orthodox men to make a beginning.
('60', 380, 3, 7, 729972) They will never move unless compelled to do so.
('60', 380, 3, 8, 730020) Drastic steps are required to wipe of untouchability.
('60', 380, 3, 9, 730074) I therefore beg you to kindly favour me with your opinion if satyagraha at the entrance of the temples by workers and Harijans preventing orthodox persons from entering the temples will be an effective method.
('60', 380, 3, 10, 730284) Appeals and entreaties have produced no effect, and to lose more time on these will, in my humble opinion, be sheer waste of valuable time.
('60', 380, 3, 11, 730424) Such blocking the way will be sheer compulsion.
('60', 380, 3, 12, 730472) And there should be no compulsion in religion or in matters of any reform.
('60', 380, 3, 13, 730547) The movement for the removal of untouchability is one of self purification.
('60', 380, 3, 14, 730623) No man can be purified against his will.
('60', 380, 3, 15, 730664) Therefore, there can be no force directly or indirectly used against the orthodox.
('60', 380, 3, 16, 730747) It should be remembered that many of us were like the orthodox people before our recognition of the necessity of the removal of untouchability.
('60', 380, 3, 17, 730891) We would not then have liked anybody to block our way to the temples, because we in those days believed, no doubt wrongly as we now think, that Harijans should not be allowed to enter temples.
('60', 380, 3, 18, 731084) Even so may we not block the way of the orthodox to the temples.
('60', 380, 3, 19, 731149) I should also remind correspondents that the word ‘satyagraha’ is often most loosely used and is made to cover veiled violence.
('60', 380, 3, 20, 731277) But as the author of the word I may be allowed to say that it excludes every form of violence, direct or indirect, veiled or unveiled, and whether in though, word or deed.
('60', 380, 3, 21, 731449) It is breach of satyagraha to wish ill to an opponent or to say a harsh word to him or of him with the intention of harming him.
('60', 380, 3, 22, 731578) And often the evil thought or the evil word may, in terms of satyagraha, be more dangerous than actual violence used in the heat of the moment and perhaps repented and forgotten the next moment.
('60', 380, 3, 23, 731773) Satyagraha is gentle, it never wounds.
('60', 380, 3, 24, 731812) It is never fussy, never impatient, never vociferous.
('60', 380, 3, 25, 731866) It is the direct opposite of compulsion.
('60', 380, 3, 26, 731907) It was conceived as a complete substitute for violence.
('60', 380, 3, 27, 731963) Nevertheless, I fully agree with the correspondent that ‘most drastic steps are required to wipe off untouchability’.
('60', 380, 3, 28, 732081) But these steps have to be taken against ourselves.
('60', 380, 3, 29, 732133) The orthodox people sincerely believe that untouchability, as they practise it, is enjoined by the
('60', 381, 0, 1, 732232) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 381, 1, 2, 732274) Shastras and that great evil will befall them and Hinduism if it was removed.
('60', 381, 1, 3, 732352) How is one to cope with this belief ?
('60', 381, 1, 4, 732390) It is clear that they will never change their belief by being compelled to admit Harijans to their temples.
('60', 381, 1, 5, 732498) What is required is not so much the entry of Harijans to the temples as the conversion of the orthodox to the belief that it is wrong to prevent Harijans from entering the temples.
('60', 381, 1, 6, 732679) This conversion can only be brought about by an appeal to their hearts, i.e., by evoking the best that is in them.
('60', 381, 1, 7, 732794) Such an appeal can be made by the appellants’ prayers, fasting other suffering in their own persons, in other words, by their ever increasing purity.
('60', 381, 1, 8, 732944) It has never yet been known to fail.
('60', 381, 1, 9, 732981) For it is its own end.
('60', 381, 1, 10, 733004) The reformer must have consciousness of the truth of his cause.
('60', 381, 1, 11, 733068) He will not then be impatient with the opponent, he will be impatient with himself.
('60', 381, 1, 12, 733152) He must be prepared even to fast unto death.
('60', 381, 1, 13, 733197) Not everyone has the right or the capacity to do so.
('60', 381, 1, 14, 733250) God is most exacting.
('60', 381, 1, 15, 733272) He exacts humility from His votaries.
('60', 381, 1, 16, 733310) Even fasts may take the form of coercion.
('60', 381, 1, 17, 733352) But there is nothing in the world that in human hands does not lend itself to abuse.
('60', 381, 1, 18, 733437) The human being is a mixture of good and evil, Jekyll and Hyde.
('60', 381, 1, 19, 733501) But there is the least likelihood of abuse when it is a matter of self suffering.

('60', 382, 1, 2, 734446) 461. LETTER TO V. S. R. SASTRI
('60', 382, 2, 3, 734477) April 15, 1933
('60', 382, 3, 4, 734492) DEAR FRIEND, I went through your letter very carefully as soon as I got it.
('60', 382, 3, 5, 734568) You should accept my assurance that I want to be convinced.
('60', 382, 3, 6, 734628) I have no axe to grind on this earth except to find Truth.
('60', 382, 3, 7, 734687) You insist upon your own interpretation, or call it the orthodox interpretation, and you swear by it.
('60', 382, 3, 8, 734789) That is quite natural.
('60', 382, 3, 9, 734812) Others whose learning I do not doubt for one moment swear by their own interpretation.
('60', 382, 3, 10, 734899) You are doing them an injustice when you say that they do so to please me.
('60', 382, 3, 11, 734974) I can only tell you what I do know and what I alone can know, and that is this: They are independent men.
('60', 382, 3, 12, 735080) They are scholars known to fame.
('60', 382, 3, 13, 735113) They have a character to keep.
('60', 382, 3, 14, 735144) And many of them were accepted as authority on Shastras before I returned to India from my long exile.
('60', 382, 3, 15, 735247) It is between these two interpretations that I have to make my choice, guided by such knowledge as I have of the Shastras, both in the original and in translations.
('60', 382, 3, 16, 735412) You suggest a meeting of the Pandits representing different schools of thought.
('60', 382, 3, 17, 735492) Perhaps you do not know that I had such a meeting.
('60', 382, 3, 18, 735543) I listened to their arguments with the greatest patience and with the utmost respect.
('60', 382, 3, 19, 735629) I approached my task without any bias.
('60', 382, 3, 20, 735668) I resist untouchability because I regard it as a great lie.
('60', 382, 3, 21, 735728) If somebody convinced me that it was a great truth, I would repent of my folly and swear by untouchability.
('60', 382, 3, 22, 735836) Beyond this I cannot argue.
('60', 382, 3, 23, 735864) But before closing I must answer one pointed question that you have put to me.
('60', 382, 3, 24, 735943) It is only in God that everything melts into one and there is neither virtue nor vice, neither good nor evil, neither sin nor merit, neither happiness nor unhappiness, and if you will, neither truth nor untruth.
('60', 382, 3, 25, 736155) That is indefinable.
('60', 382, 3, 26, 736176) But so long as I am in a body I must continue to experience the duality.
('60', 382, 3, 27, 736249) The obliteration of duality can only exist in my imagination as an intellectual grasp.
('60', 382, 3, 28, 736336) And if any person were to put forth an opposite claim, I should have no right to question his claim, and I would gladly admit the inferiority of my position.
('60', 382, 3, 29, 736494) The inferiority would not worry me because it would be in accordance with the Truth as I see it.
('60', 382, 4, 30, 736591) Yours sincerely,
('60', 382, 5, 31, 736608) From a microfilm: S.N. 20948

('60', 400, 8, 15, 771953) 478. LETTER TO KRISHNA CHANDRA MUKHERJI
('60', 400, 9, 16, 771993) April 18, 1933
('60', 400, 10, 17, 772008) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('60', 400, 10, 18, 772041) The problem you have raised is not new, and because we are surrounded by death and destruction on all sides we have the positive word “himsa”, and yet every religion that is known to mankind insists upon life as the law, but conduct prescribed has been designated by a negative word, that is, “ahimsa” or non violence.
('60', 400, 10, 19, 772360) That can only exist for a bodied life as an ideal to be reached, not to be realized in action in physical existence.
('60', 400, 10, 20, 772477) Nevertheless if we recognize the law of ahimsa we would always shape our conduct so as to approach it as near as possible and therefore we would resort to as little violence as it is humanly possible, whereas if himsa was the law of our being, we would naturally do as much destruction as we could and rejoice in it.
('60', 400, 10, 21, 772794) But we do not find many people rejoicing in doing violence, whereas we do find many people apologizing for what violence they did.
('60', 400, 10, 22, 772925) To say that there is double law
('60', 400, 11, 23, 772957) 1 The addressee had asked for a message for the opening ceremony of the “Navajivan Library and Reading Room” and amalgamation of “Navajivan Pustakalaya” with it for the special benefit of Harijans.
('60', 401, 0, 1, 773155) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 401, 1, 2, 773197) working, namely, violence and non violence, would be to argue that two contrary laws can co exist.
('60', 401, 1, 3, 773296) This is hardly the right thing.
('60', 401, 2, 4, 773328) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('60', 401, 2, 5, 773350) KRISHNA CHANDRA MUKHERJI
('60', 401, 3, 6, 773375) MAGURA P. O. ( JESSORE)

('60', 404, 1, 2, 777898) 483. LETTER TO MOTILAL ROY
('60', 404, 2, 3, 777925) April 18, 1933
('60', 404, 3, 4, 777940) DEAR MOTIBABU, I have your letter and I am glad you have written to me so exhaustively.
('60', 404, 3, 5, 778028) In thinking of temple entry, we must not think of what the Harijans want, but what is due by us to them and what was promised so solemnly at the Bombay meeting 1 under the Presidentship of Malaviyaji.
('60', 404, 3, 6, 778229) Temple entry was there promised and that promise has to be fulfilled at the sacrifice of life itself.
('60', 404, 3, 7, 778331) Remember the words of the Mahabharata, “Truth in one scale and all the other sacrifices in the opposite scale: the scale holding Truth will outweigh the other scale.” Breach of promise to the Harijans and to God is unthinkable.
('60', 404, 3, 8, 778559) We may be as patient as possible with the sanatanists, but those who have any regard for that solemn promise must ceaseless]y pursue temple entry.
('60', 404, 3, 9, 778706) I do not therefore need to examine the other part of your argument about temple entry.
('60', 404, 3, 10, 778793) Of course education has to be an active programme.
('60', 404, 3, 11, 778844) Education in the widest sense of the term is wanted, not merely for the Harijans but also for the savarna Hindus.
('60', 404, 3, 12, 778958) What we are today suffering from is not so much the want of education as too much of mis education.
('60', 404, 3, 13, 779058) Irreligion and hypocrisy has been taught us in the place of religion and honesty, superstition in the place of true knowledge, intolerance in the place of charity, incontinence in the place of chastity, distortion of the Shastras in the place of a true and simple interpretation thereof woven round the central truth.
('60', 404, 3, 14, 779376) I note what you say about the activities of the Sangh, and I hope that your efforts will be crowned with full success.
('60', 404, 3, 15, 779495) If you will keep the central fact of hand spinning intact, you will not yield to the temptation of taking the fine yarn from the indigenous mills.
('60', 404, 3, 16, 779642) I do not know whether you have traced the history of Harijans being driven from weaving to scavenging simply because the natural cord between hand spun and hand woven has been broken.
('60', 404, 3, 17, 779826) If you will have fine cloth, you should teach the men and women how to spin fine yarn.
('60', 404, 3, 18, 779913) Out of good slivers I spin 70 counts.
('60', 404, 3, 19, 779951) Mahadev has gone as much as 110 counts.
('60', 404, 3, 20, 779991) This is finer than the finest spun by any mill in India, and
('60', 404, 4, 21, 780052) 1 Held on September 25, 1932. For the text of the resolution.
('60', 405, 0, 1, 780114) 406 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 405, 1, 2, 780156) you will be surprised to learn that a Harijan weaver at the Ashram has woven Mahadev’s 40 counts.
('60', 405, 1, 3, 780254) Finer than 40 we began to spin only during this incarceration, but I have no doubt that when our stock of fine yarn can be given for spinning, the same weaver will be able to handle it.
('60', 405, 1, 4, 780440) We must face the difficulty, cost what it may, in this movement of regeneration.

('60', 409, 1, 2, 785575) 490. LETTER TO P. N. SANKARANARAYANA IYER
('60', 409, 2, 3, 785617) April 19, 1933
('60', 409, 3, 4, 785632) MY DEAR SANKARANARAYANA, You will please forgive me for not attending to your pamphlet before this.
('60', 409, 3, 5, 785732) I was helpless.
('60', 409, 3, 6, 785748) As soon as I had a few moments to spare I took up your pamphlet.
('60', 409, 3, 7, 785813) You have asked me to offer remarks, suggestions, guidance and to give you my blessings.
('60', 409, 3, 8, 785901) Blessings you have if you deserve them.
('60', 409, 3, 9, 785941) Whether you do or not I cannot judge, because I have no personal knowledge of your activity.
('60', 409, 3, 10, 786034) But I can certainly see your earnestness in your report.
('60', 409, 4, 11, 786091) I have gone through all the passages that you have specially marked.
('60', 409, 4, 12, 786160) It is difficult for me to offer useful criticism.
('60', 409, 4, 13, 786210) Your hit at the turmoil of the temple entry movement and at the great national leaders betrays somewhere irritation, impatience and ignorance of facts.
('60', 409, 4, 14, 786362) If you had simply said that the Harijans that have come under your notice do not care for temple entry, that would have been quite a fair statement to make; but to belittle a great religious movement without even studying it was not right.
('60', 409, 4, 15, 786602) Just see what it is.
('60', 409, 4, 16, 786623) In September last, representative Hindus in a public meeting entered into a solemn pledge that among other things temples should be thrown open to Harijans.
('60', 409, 4, 17, 786780) From that moment it became their duty to strain every nerve to secure the opening of Hindu temples to Harijans.
('60', 409, 4, 18, 786892) It is irrelevant whether Harijans want to make use of these temples or not, just as it would be irrelevant to the question of opening public schools, public wells and giving them all the other rights hitherto denied to them whether they want or do not want these rights.
('60', 409, 4, 19, 787163) It is the simple duty of the suppressors to remove the weight of suppression from the heads of the suppressed.
('60', 409, 4, 20, 787274) The suppressed may have become so stunted that in spite of the lifting of the weight they might not even appreciate the fact that it was lifted.
('60', 409, 4, 21, 787419) But that would be no excuse for the suppressors to continue the suppression.
('60', 409, 4, 22, 787496) If you admit the justice of the argument you should have no hesitation in owning your mistake.
('60', 409, 4, 23, 787591) More than this I think I need not say.
('60', 409, 4, 24, 787630) Every little thing done for the sake of Harijans cannot but be welcome to me, and I think that the field of service is so vast that
('60', 409, 5, 25, 787762) 1 His activities were mentioned in Harijan, 29 4 1933.
('60', 410, 0, 1, 787817) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 411
('60', 410, 1, 2, 787861) workers can well afford to do that service without criticizing or belittling the efforts of others except of course where the other effort is mischievous, immoral or selfish.

('60', 416, 3, 4, 798145) NARANDAS, I got your big packet.
('60', 416, 3, 5, 798178) It is really big this time.
('60', 416, 3, 6, 798206) Nobody should copy my bad habits.
('60', 416, 3, 7, 798240) I can even give reasons to excuse them.
('60', 416, 3, 8, 798280) All the same everybody should know that they are bad habits and avoid them.
('60', 416, 3, 9, 798356) 1. Nobody should read a book or a newspaper while eating.
('60', 416, 3, 10, 798414) The best thing is to have in one serving as much as one wants and to eat the meal in complete silence.
('60', 416, 3, 11, 798517) If one cannot do this, one may talk to one’s neighbour in whispers.
('60', 416, 3, 12, 798585) It is a bad habit to do two things simultaneously.
('60', 416, 3, 13, 798636) 2. Nobody should do any other work while spinning, should neither dictate letters nor teach as I do.
('60', 416, 3, 14, 798737) 3. It is a bad habit to read in the lavatory.
('60', 416, 3, 15, 798783) 4. It is unbearable to clean the teeth in the lavatory.
('60', 416, 3, 16, 798839) The habit is unhygienic and dirty.
('60', 416, 3, 17, 798874) I have never been guilty of this bad habit.
('60', 416, 3, 18, 798918) But I do the first three things.
('60', 416, 3, 19, 798951) However, a person’s bad habits should not be copied.
('60', 416, 3, 20, 799004) I never defend these habits as good.
('60', 416, 3, 21, 799041) Moreover, I live in complete privacy.
('60', 416, 3, 22, 799079) I have a separate room for lavatory and can keep books in that room.
('60', 416, 3, 23, 799148) I may die any time, and cannot overcome the temptation to do as much work as I can while I live.
('60', 416, 3, 24, 799245) I am not eager to overcome it either.
('60', 416, 3, 25, 799283) I have these and many other reasons or excuses.
('60', 416, 3, 26, 799331) But nobody else should use them to defend his bad habits.
('60', 416, 3, 27, 799389) Show this to all the inmates.

('60', 428, 8, 17, 817971) BHAISHRI FULCHAND, At last I got a letter from you after waiting for one for a long time.
('60', 428, 8, 18, 818061) All of us were wondering why there was no letter and were, therefore, very much pleased when we got it.
('60', 428, 8, 19, 818165) I cannot understand what happened to my letter.
('60', 428, 8, 20, 818213) My atitude in the matter is that we should write what we wish to, and not worry whether or not the letter reaches the addressee.
('60', 428, 8, 21, 818342) Our life goes on from day to day.
('60', 428, 8, 22, 818376) We often think about your enlarged family there, but feel sure that, since you are quite a few veterans there, things are going on without friction.
('60', 428, 8, 23, 818525) If an accident occurs to a railway train, a good many people will die.

('60', 428, 8, 27, 818817) But we rarely find this from reading history.

('60', 429, 1, 17, 820548) And now the replies to the questions asked by Mohanlal, the school teacher from Bavla: 1. By abhyasa 1 the Gita means regular reading of something which is worth pondering over, though one may not feel interested in it.
('60', 429, 1, 18, 820768) Such regular study enables one to maintain the current of one’s thoughts in the right direction.
('60', 429, 1, 19, 820865) The Lord has coupled vairagya 2 with abhyasa.
('60', 429, 1, 20, 820911) But the two things are practically the same.
('60', 429, 1, 21, 820956) Fixing one’s mind in abhyasa necessarily means withdrawing it from other things, and that is vairagya.
('60', 429, 1, 22, 821059) 2. Prasad may be described as serene contentment.
('60', 429, 1, 23, 821109) We feel contented when we get the things of the world which we desire, but such contentment is useless and springs from the satisfaction of the senses.
('60', 429, 1, 24, 821261) Since the goods of the world are short lived, the contentment which they bring is also short lived.
('60', 429, 1, 25, 821361) The goods of spiritual life are eternal possessions, and so the contentment produced by them is also
('60', 429, 2, 26, 821462) 1 Practice 2 Renunciation
('60', 430, 0, 1, 821488) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 431
('60', 430, 1, 2, 821532) abiding.
('60', 430, 1, 3, 821541) It is an experience beyond the grasp of the senses, an experience of the mind and the heart.
('60', 430, 1, 4, 821634) One can, therefore, feel true contentment only when one becomes indifferent to the happiness of the senses.
('60', 430, 1, 5, 821742) This is the contentment that the Gita talks about.
('60', 430, 1, 6, 821793) Regards from us all to everybody there.

('60', 430, 10, 17, 822121) 518. HOW DOES THE STREAM OF BHAKTI FLOW?
('60', 430, 11, 18, 822162) [April 21, 1933] 2
('60', 430, 12, 19, 822181) A lover of the Bhagavata dharma writes: 3
('60', 430, 13, 20, 822223) The stream of bhakti does not flow from the pen.
('60', 430, 13, 21, 822272) It is not a matter pertaining to the intellect.
('60', 430, 13, 22, 822320) That stream can only flow from the cavern of the heart; and when it does flow, no power will be able to stop its current.
('60', 430, 13, 23, 822442) Who can stop the current of the Ganga?
('60', 430, 13, 24, 822481) I am indeed trying for such bhakti but the effort cannot succeed through any verbal grandeur.
('60', 430, 13, 25, 822575) The only way to it is karmayoga.
('60', 430, 14, 26, 822608) 1 This cable was drafted on a telegram received on April 20, 1933 from Dr. Purushottam Patel in reply to Gandhiji’s to him dated April 19, 1933; Vide “Telegram to Purushottam Patel”, 19 4 1933. 2 Vide “Letter to Viyogi Hari”, 21 4 1933. 3 The letter is not translated here.
('60', 430, 14, 27, 822882) The correspondent had requested Gandhiji to write one article on bhakti in each Harijan issue so that people would not indulge in unnecessary discussions but follow the path of pure bhakti.
('60', 430, 14, 28, 823072) It was his firm belief that only Gandhiji could do this in an age of atheism.
('60', 431, 0, 1, 823150) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 431, 1, 2, 823192) total indifference towards the result is necessary for that yoga.
('60', 431, 1, 3, 823258) Karmayoga is but another name for action which is wholly devoid of any desire for results.
('60', 431, 1, 4, 823349) Hence, I do not see the need to write any article specially in order to make the stream of devotion flow.
('60', 431, 1, 5, 823455) If every word of the Harijan—whether it is in English, Hindi or Gujarati—is an echo of the devotion which is within, it will automatically make an impression.
('60', 431, 1, 6, 823614) I have grasped the intention of the lover of the Bhagavata dharma.
('60', 431, 1, 7, 823681) If there is devotion within me, and, to the extent that it is there, that devotion will not fail to touch others.
('60', 431, 1, 8, 823795) This is because I believe that a change of heart can be brought about through the Bhagavata dharma alone.
('60', 431, 1, 9, 823901) That dharma is contagious.
('60', 431, 1, 10, 823928) Once it is revealed, it does not leave anyone untouched.
('60', 431, 1, 11, 823985) When it is truly revealed in any of us, the Harijans and the sanatanists will automatically become aware of it.
('60', 431, 1, 12, 824097) This at least I can say for myself that all my actions—writing, speaking, walking—are undertaken with the object of generating devotion within me.
('60', 431, 1, 13, 824244) It is my confirmed belief that if Hinduism is to be saved, there is no other way to do so.
('60', 431, 1, 14, 824335) Religion has never been, and can never be, saved through hooliganism or hypocrisy, through rhetoric or beautiful articles.
('60', 431, 1, 15, 824458) Religion can be saved only through the purification and penance professing it.
('60', 431, 1, 16, 824537) And, the author of the Bhagavata has clearly stated that in this age the path of bhakti alone can be pursued of those without difficulty; perhaps it is the sole path.
('60', 431, 1, 17, 824704) The question may then arise why I write or speak.
('60', 431, 1, 18, 824754) The answer is contained in what I have stated above regarding my actions.
('60', 431, 1, 19, 824828) That activity itself shows that even if there has been any flowering of the Bhagavata dharma in me, it can in no way be said to have attained perfection; and my activity in that direction is for that very development.
('60', 431, 1, 20, 825046) And, if that is really so, others will catch a glimpse of devotion in one or the other of these activities.
('60', 431, 1, 21, 825154) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 30 4 1933
('60', 432, 0, 1, 825195) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 433
('60', 432, 1, 2, 825239) 519. FIVE QUESTIONS ON VARNADHARMA
('60', 432, 2, 3, 825274) A gentleman has sent me the following questions:
('60', 432, 3, 4, 825323) 1. What work should the Brahmin, the Kshatriya, the Vaishya and the Shudra do to earn their livelihood?
('60', 432, 4, 5, 825427) 2. In what way should the four varnas serve?
('60', 432, 5, 6, 825472) 3. Can work for livelihood be the same as work for service?
('60', 432, 5, 7, 825532) Or are the two different?
('60', 432, 6, 8, 825558) 4. You have written that “in order to revive varnashrama it is necessary that all should voluntarily become Shudras”.
('60', 432, 6, 9, 825676) If the other three varnas (the Brahmin, the Kshatriya, the Vaishya) embrace the Shudra varna, will they not be guilty of the sin of giving up their dharma and adopting another?
('60', 432, 7, 10, 825853) 5. You have written, “A small varna aspiring to Brahmajnana fortunately exists today through which sanatana dharma will again shine in its purity and show the world the path to happiness.” What is that varna?
('60', 432, 7, 11, 826062) I seek to prevent no one from asking questions.
('60', 432, 7, 12, 826110) But I must say that if my writings were read carefully many questions that are asked would be answered of themselves.
('60', 432, 7, 13, 826228) An article in which questions raised in it are not answered is considered useless.
('60', 432, 7, 14, 826311) Articles treating of moral questions should not be read only once.
('60', 432, 7, 15, 826378) If such an article is read over and over again with concentration, then the questions included in them solve themselves easily.
('60', 432, 7, 16, 826506) I should therefore request the correspondent to reread my article on varnashrama.
('60', 432, 7, 17, 826588) He will then find that what I am going to say here is already contained in it.
('60', 432, 7, 18, 826667) I address this suggestion to the readers in general.
('60', 432, 7, 19, 826720) Let not the correspondent think that it applies only to him.
('60', 432, 7, 20, 826781) The habit of reading is increasing in us, but the habit of pondering is diminishing and therefore we have become somewhat helpless.
('60', 432, 7, 21, 826913) On everything we want to know another’s opinion.
('60', 432, 7, 22, 826962) We have lost the power of original thinking which comes from constant pondering.
('60', 432, 7, 23, 827043) It is truly pitiable that things have come to such a pass.
('60', 432, 7, 24, 827102) Once a principle is understood we should have the capacity to understand its corrolaries.
('60', 432, 7, 25, 827192) With just a little practice this power can be developed.
('60', 432, 7, 26, 827249) I shall now answer the questions: 1. The Brahmin will impart to society knowledge of the Brahman.
('60', 432, 7, 27, 827347) The Kshatriya will protect the country.
('60', 432, 7, 28, 827387) The Vaishya will earn wealth through trade and commerce.
('60', 432, 7, 29, 827444) The Shudra will do service.
('60', 433, 0, 1, 827472) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 433, 1, 2, 827514) All these will earn their livelihood each by doing the work of his own varna.
('60', 433, 1, 3, 827592) That will be enough.
('60', 433, 1, 4, 827613) 2. Varna, strictly speaking, is a duty not a right.
('60', 433, 1, 5, 827665) Hence the existence of varna can only be for service, not for self.
('60', 433, 1, 6, 827733) For this reason there is no one high and no one low.
('60', 433, 1, 7, 827786) A man who considers himself above others, is worse than a fool despite all his wisdom.
('60', 433, 1, 8, 827873) Because of his arrogance or superiority he falls from varna.
('60', 433, 1, 9, 827934) Here, it is also necessary to understand that there is nothing in varnashrama to prevent a Shudra from acquiring learning or defending his country; yes, the Shudra may not barter his knowledge or take to defending his country for purposes of livelihood.
('60', 433, 1, 10, 828188) It is also not enjoined that the Brahmin or the Kshatriya may not do menial work.
('60', 433, 1, 11, 828270) But they must not earn their livelihood from such work.
('60', 433, 1, 12, 828326) If this simple dharma were scrupulously followed, all the disorders that face society today, all the jealousies and rivalries that are rampant, all this craze to amass wealth, all the falsehood that is prevalent, all this production of weapons of war would vanish.
('60', 433, 1, 13, 828591) Whether the whole world follows this principle or not, whether all Hindus do so or not, even if some follow this, the world will gain by so much.
('60', 433, 1, 14, 828737) My faith that the salvation of the world lies in following varnadharma grows stronger each day.
('60', 433, 1, 15, 828833) The true meaning of varnadharma is service.
('60', 433, 1, 16, 828877) Whatever is done should be done in the spirit of service.
('60', 433, 1, 17, 828935) Where is bargaining in service?
('60', 433, 1, 18, 828967) Now comes the question of manual labour.
('60', 433, 1, 19, 829008) As far as I understand the Gita, it mentions many kinds of yajnas.
('60', 433, 1, 20, 829075) One of them is manual labour.
('60', 433, 1, 21, 829105) It is the duty of all the castes to do manual labour as yajna for the preservation of the world.
('60', 433, 1, 22, 829202) No one can escape this yajna.
('60', 433, 1, 23, 829232) Without body labour the journey of life itself is impossible.
('60', 433, 1, 24, 829294) He who does not perform this yajna of labour is truly a thief.
('60', 433, 1, 25, 829357) To say that manual labour is meant for Shudras only shows ignorance of dharma.
('60', 433, 1, 26, 829436) Work of service does not necessarily mean manual work.
('60', 433, 1, 27, 829491) He who washes his own dishes is doing manual work but not work of service.
('60', 433, 1, 28, 829566) A watchman who earns his livelihood by standing at the gate does no manual work; but he certainly does work of service.
('60', 433, 1, 29, 829686) 3. There is no need now to answer this question.
('60', 433, 1, 30, 829735) 4. In asking this question, my correspondent has perhaps forgotten that in my opinion varnadharma today is all but destroyed.
('60', 433, 1, 31, 829861) Brahmins, Kshatriyas and Vaishyas have long since given up their varna duties and arrogated rights.
('60', 433, 1, 32, 829961) The sin has been committed.
('60', 433, 1, 33, 829989) Now the Brahmins, Kshatriyas and Vaishyas, who have fallen from
('60', 434, 0, 1, 830053) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 435
('60', 434, 1, 2, 830097) varnadharma can by voluntarily embracing Shudradharma absolve themselves of the sin.
('60', 434, 1, 3, 830182) They never had any right to treat the Shudras as low born.
('60', 434, 1, 4, 830241) 5. Those who follow the Bhagavata dharma and, for love of God, barely earning their livelihood, always serve their fellow beings, impart divine knowledge to the world.
('60', 434, 1, 5, 830409) There is no doubt about this.
('60', 434, 1, 6, 830439) There are among them men of learning as well as without learning.
('60', 434, 1, 7, 830505) They do not make a show of their work.
('60', 434, 1, 8, 830544) I do not know them all by their names.
('60', 434, 1, 9, 830583) But I know that there are such people even though their number is very small.
('60', 434, 1, 10, 830661) [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 21 4 1933

('60', 444, 4, 5, 847199) 536. TELEGRAM TO B. R. AMBEDKAR
('60', 444, 5, 6, 847231) [On or before April 22, 1933] 1
('60', 444, 6, 7, 847263) COME SUNDAY BETWEEN NINE TEN.
('60', 444, 8, 8, 847293) From a photostat: S.N. 20993
('60', 444, 9, 9, 847322) 537. REMEMBER 30TH APRIL 3
('60', 444, 10, 10, 847349) Those who would organize a proper concentrated programme for 30th instant, the day fixed as Harijan Day, would do well to take time by the forelock and make all preparations in a methodical manner.
('60', 444, 10, 11, 847547) Every Committee is free to add to or subtract from the items I have suggested.
('60', 444, 10, 12, 847626) I hope it is clearly understood that, where no other work is at all possible, there will be at least substantial collections made.
('60', 444, 10, 13, 847757) I know that collectors often despise copper collections.
('60', 444, 10, 14, 847814) Let me remind them of the English proverb: “Take care of your pennies, and the pounds will take care of themselves.” And let me give a tit bit from my own experience as an expert collector.
('60', 444, 10, 15, 848004) Among the masses I remember having collected not pice, i.e., quarteranna pieces, but pies, in Orissa, and when the collections were counted, the total was a respectable amount.
('60', 444, 10, 16, 848181) We are a country of many millions and, therefore, in my opinion, the copper pies of the millions have, when put together, an infinitely greater value than the rupees of a few thousand middle class men or a few lakhs from half a dozen millionaires.
('60', 444, 10, 17, 848429) If the collectors
('60', 444, 11, 18, 848447) 1 This telegram was in reply to Ambedkar’s letter of April 19, 1933 and they met on Sunday, April 23, 1933. ('60', 445, 0, 1, 848789) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 445, 1, 2, 848831) will have faith in themselves, in their cause and in the masses, they will go from door to door and collect whatever coppers are given.
('60', 445, 1, 3, 848967) A pie given with a full heart will be to me a token that the giver wants untouchability to go and that he or she has contributed his or her mite towards the movement.
('60', 445, 1, 4, 849134) If the Committees will make a faithful report of the results of their collections and show not only how much they have collected but also from how many people, it will give one a fair index of the strength of the movement.
('60', 445, 1, 5, 849357) Needless to say, the work must be done quietly and as gently as possible, and when it is done without fuss by door to door visits, there need be no opposition from any quarter.
('60', 445, 1, 6, 849534) Where householders are unwilling to give anything, there should be no argument with them, no ill will shown towards them.
('60', 445, 1, 7, 849656) The donations must be free will offerings.
('60', 445, 1, 8, 849699) One thing I would suggest to the medical fraternity.
('60', 445, 1, 9, 849752) I have just had a report from the schoolmaster whose doings I am noting in these columns from time to time, showing the need Harijans have of medical assistance.
('60', 445, 1, 10, 849914) In the case I have in mind, a physician, immediately a case of pneumonia was reported to him, went free of charge to the Harijan quarters and not only gave relief in this particular case, but, much to the delight of the Harijans, examined the other cases and offered to go freely whenever his assistance was needed.
('60', 445, 1, 11, 850230) It will be a striking demonstration if the medical men in every part of India met together and appointed visitors from among themselves to go to the Harijan quarters, speak to the inmates on the necessity of observing the laws of hygiene and sanitation and offer medical relief wherever it was required.
('60', 445, 1, 12, 850534) Naturally, this work to be done on an ambitious scale can only be done without expectation of any fees.
('60', 445, 1, 13, 850638) No organization can undertake the task of rewarding the services that the medical men might render to Harijans; whereas, if the medical men took this burden upon themselves, there are so many now in India that by a judicious distribution of work no pressure will be felt by any single physician.
('60', 445, 1, 14, 850934) The third thing that occurs to me is for the women workers all over the country to combine in order to do away with the inhuman practice of giving to Harijans the leavings of food.
('60', 445, 1, 15, 851115) I have a letter 1
('60', 445, 2, 16, 851133) from a Harijan in Karachi who asks in piteous terms that the women might at least shoulder the burden of having this reform accomplished at once.
('60', 445, 2, 17, 851279) He says that they think nothing of giving to Harijans food
('60', 445, 3, 18, 851338) 1 Vide “Complaint against Women”, 23 4 1933.
('60', 446, 0, 1, 851383) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 447
('60', 446, 1, 2, 851427) that is rotten and unfit for human consumption, food that is stinking, that is dirty beyond description, and this too, lest they might be polluted, they throw from their balconies or from their verandahs into the laps of debased Harijans; and he adds in agony, “The pity of it is that the Harijans would feel it a deprivation if these leavings were not given to them.” It would certainly be a grand thing if earnest women all over banded themselves together and made it a point of seeing their sisters and weaning them from the practice.
('60', 446, 1, 3, 851965) I have every hope that in this mission of mercy and humanity even the sanatanists will co operate; but whether they do or not, the duty before the women who realize the abomination of the practice is to bestir themselves and quicken the conscience of their sisters who do not even perhaps know that they are offending humanity by making themselves responsible for the degradation of those who are, after all, their own kith and kin.
('60', 446, 1, 4, 852398) And in this connection, I would invite the attention of workers to the concrete suggestions I made the other day in answer to a Dehra Dun student.
('60', 446, 2, 5, 852545) Harijan, 22 4 1933
('60', 446, 3, 6, 852564) 538. WHAT IT MEANS TO BE A HARIJAN
('60', 446, 4, 7, 852599) Elsewhere 2 the reader will find how the Harijans fare in the city of Allahabad in the north, known to the millions of Hindus as Prayag, one of the most noted among the places of Hindu pilgrimage and situated at the confluence of the Ganges and the Jumna.
('60', 446, 4, 8, 852855) Let him turn also to the extreme south.
('60', 446, 4, 9, 852895) There he will find a cluster of villages inhabited by the land owning ryots known as Nattars and their landless ‘semi slaves’, the Harijans.
('60', 446, 4, 10, 853036) There was a conflict between these two during May, June and July last year.
('60', 446, 4, 11, 853112) There was also a resolution in the Madras Council, carried by 44 votes against 22, recommending to the Government the appointment of a committee to inquire into and report on the alleged atrocities committed by the Nattars on the Harijans.
('60', 446, 4, 12, 853352) Nothing is said as yet to have been done by the Government on the recommendation.
('60', 446, 4, 13, 853434) Amritlal Thakkar has, however, sent me a fairly full report.
('60', 446, 5, 14, 853495) 1 Vide “Students and Vacation”, 1 4 1933. 2 Vide the following item.
('60', 447, 0, 1, 853564) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 447, 1, 2, 853606) The subject is still topical, inasmuch as the trouble is by no means over and may burst forth any moment.
('60', 447, 1, 3, 853712) The two sections are living, as it were, in a state of armed neutrality.
('60', 447, 1, 4, 853785) The inquiry was conducted by Sjt.
('60', 447, 1, 5, 853819) A. Rangaswami Iyengar, Advocate, and President of the District Harijan Committee, Sjt.
('60', 447, 1, 6, 853906) Lakshmiratan Bharati, Advocate, and Secretary of the District Committee, Sjt.
('60', 447, 1, 7, 853984) V. E. Eapen, Advocate, and Sjt.
('60', 447, 1, 8, 854016) Ramachandran, the Secretary of the Tamilnad Board, S.U.S. They visited Devakottah, Pavanakottah, Paramakkudi, Eluvankottah and Chittanur.
('60', 447, 1, 9, 854154) The trouble began during the temple festival at Eluvankottah.
('60', 447, 1, 10, 854216) The Harijans “till recently had to work for the Nattars on conditions prescribed by the latter”.
('60', 447, 2, 11, 854313) During the trouble the Nattars raided the village (Pavanakottah) and looted the Harijan houses.
('60', 447, 2, 12, 854409) They tied some of the Harijans, who wanted to resist, to a tree....
('60', 447, 2, 13, 854477) The little schoolhouse in the Harijan quarter was burnt down.
('60', 447, 2, 14, 854539) The little granaries made of cow dung and hay in front of most Harijan houses were broken to bits and the grain looted.
('60', 447, 2, 15, 854659) These granaries look more like huge jars than like rooms.
('60', 447, 2, 16, 854717) We saw the ruins of a schoolhouse and the grain jars.
('60', 447, 2, 17, 854771) The report proceeds:
('60', 447, 3, 18, 854792) The Harijans themselves include two divisions—Pallas and Pariahs.
('60', 447, 3, 19, 854858) The Pallas ran away at the first sign of trouble to Devakottah, leaving their women and children in the village, who were considerably harassed by the raiders.
('60', 447, 3, 20, 855018) Quite a number of these Pallas were Christians even before.
('60', 447, 3, 21, 855078) The Pariahs met with more trouble.
('60', 447, 3, 22, 855113) The Christian pastor who did the conversion now pays a weekly visit for prayer meetings and general propaganda.
('60', 447, 3, 23, 855225) He has also consented to give them a new school of their own.
('60', 447, 3, 24, 855287) The Pallas returned to their homes earlier and the Pariahs a little later.
('60', 447, 4, 25, 855362) Four families consisting of 14 members embraced Christianity 3 months ago.
('60', 447, 4, 26, 855437) It is expected more families will follow suit.
('60', 447, 4, 27, 855484) As far as we could ascertain, there is no trouble between the converts and the Harijans.
('60', 447, 4, 28, 855573) In answer to our questions, one of the converted men said that they had become Christians because the missionaries promised them protection and care.
('60', 447, 4, 29, 855723) The Harijans told the Committee:
('60', 447, 5, 30, 855756) The Nattars want us to observe exactly old customs and manners.
('60', 447, 5, 31, 855820) They do not like our men to wear shirts or upper clothes as we like, or our women to put on frocks and saris.
('60', 447, 5, 32, 855930) The old custom was that our clothes should not go below the knee and any upper cloth should be tied round the loins only.
('60', 447, 5, 33, 856052) The women were not allowed to cover their bodies above the waist, except with their hands.
('60', 447, 5, 34, 856143) In the old times, in religious processions, we had to go doing a
('60', 448, 0, 1, 856208) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 449
('60', 448, 1, 2, 856252) particular dance.
('60', 448, 1, 3, 856270) Even today, the Harijans on meeting a Nattar has to say “sevakam” meaning “at your service”.
('60', 448, 1, 4, 856363) They do not allow us to work where we like or for whom we like.
('60', 448, 1, 5, 856427) We have to work for them for what wages they give and wherever they order.
('60', 448, 1, 6, 856502) They do not like us to use brass vessels and are angry when our women put on ornaments.
('60', 448, 1, 7, 856590) Only two weeks ago, in a near village, Paramakkudi, a woman who went with a frock was spat upon by a Nattar and asked not to be arrogant in the Nattar street.
('60', 448, 1, 8, 856749) A Nattar Headman stated as follows:
('60', 448, 2, 9, 856785) We have no quarrel with the Harijans.
('60', 448, 2, 10, 856823) Only we do not want him to go against old customs and conventions.
('60', 448, 2, 11, 856890) He now refuses to work for us.
('60', 448, 2, 12, 856921) He asks for high wages.
('60', 448, 2, 13, 856945) We don’t much mind his putting on shirt or his women having ornaments or frocks in his own village.
('60', 448, 2, 14, 857045) We only object to his parading them in our village and during the temple festival, when there are large crowds of all kinds of people.
('60', 448, 2, 15, 857180) If their men and women dress as the rest of us, how can we differentiate them among the festival crowds?
('60', 448, 2, 16, 857285) This results in a general mix up and consequent pollution.
('60', 448, 2, 17, 857344) We have no objection to their dress, as they want it, but our difficulty is: how are we to distinguish them in a crowd?
('60', 448, 2, 18, 857464) We don’t object to their going to schools, but if they come to a common school, they must sit separate.
('60', 448, 2, 19, 857568) We know very well that they cannot remain exactly where they were in old times.
('60', 448, 2, 20, 857648) But we are bound to resist arrogance and revolt.
('60', 448, 2, 21, 857697) The agony need not be protracted.
('60', 448, 2, 22, 857731) Instances elsewhere of resentment of and assault on Harijans dressing well or Harijan brides and bridegrooms carried in palanquins in their marriage procession have come to light.
('60', 448, 2, 23, 857911) 1 It is up to sanatanists to join hands with reformers and put an end to the arrogation of superiority by one caste over another in the name of religion.
('60', 448, 2, 24, 858065) The reader will be glad to know that the Committee do not propose to be satisfied with the mere investigation they have made, important as it is.
('60', 448, 2, 25, 858211) They have followed it up by a visit to the sub collector, who has promised protection, should there be trouble, which is said to be impending in a village called Uruvatti during a coming festival.
('60', 448, 2, 26, 858408) The members are also seeking the assistance of influential Nattars and other well known men living in the neighbourhood in bringing about honourable peace between the Nattars and the Harijans.
('60', 448, 2, 27, 858601) They feel, too, that “nothing but education will finally solve the difficulty”.
('60', 448, 2, 28, 858681) They have, therefore, proposed that a string of schools
('60', 448, 3, 29, 858737) 1 Vide “What Harijans Think”, 18 3 1933.

('60', 449, 2, 5, 858995) 539. IMMEDIATE DUTY
('60', 449, 3, 6, 859015) The Allahabad branch of the Servants of Untouchables Society (U.P. Provincial Board) had appointed a committee consisting of Sjts.
('60', 449, 3, 7, 859146) P. N. Sapru, Bisheshwar Prasad and Ramnath Dar to report upon the condition of the Harijans of that city and to recommend measures for its amelioration.
('60', 449, 3, 8, 859299) The Committee has presented an elaborate report covering fifty eight pages of typed matter, excluding appendices.
('60', 449, 3, 9, 859413) The Committee is to be congratulated on its production.
('60', 449, 3, 10, 859469) One misses in the report the number of the Harijan population.
('60', 449, 3, 11, 859532) The city excluding the cantonment has a population of only 1,73,895. I do not propose to deal with the whole of this important document.
('60', 449, 3, 12, 859669) Those who would study it should procure a copy from the Allahabad Office.
('60', 449, 3, 13, 859743) The Mehtars and the Doms are by far the most ill treated and uncared for?
('60', 449, 3, 14, 859817) not only by the savarna Hindus but also by all the citizens represented by the cosmopolitan municipality.
('60', 449, 3, 15, 859923) This is what the Committee says about their condition:
('60', 449, 4, 16, 859978) The very approach to depressed class quarters has a most depressing effect upon one’s mind.
('60', 449, 4, 17, 860070) Some of the quarters in which they live, particularly those in the heart of the city, are literally unfit for human habitation.
('60', 449, 4, 18, 860198) The houses are dark, dreary and damp.
('60', 449, 4, 19, 860236) They do not look like places of human habitation.
('60', 449, 4, 20, 860286) Their houses generally consist of one room of 5 square yards, in which a whole family of four to six has to live.
('60', 449, 4, 21, 860400) There is no light and air in these houses, no verandah or open space in front and no arrangement for latrine, kitchen or bath.
('60', 449, 4, 22, 860527) The lanes in front of these houses are extremely narrow, kutcha, muddy, without any drain or light.
('60', 449, 4, 23, 860627) The whole atmosphere of these localities is foul; there are hardly any arrangements for sanitation; and the sights one sees there are disgusting and loathsome.
('60', 449, 4, 24, 860787) Not much can be expected of human beings who have to live not more than seven feet from scandalously dirty public lavatories.
('60', 449, 4, 25, 860913) We have found taps attached to these lavatories for the domestic and bathing purposes of the sweepers living in the vicinity.
('60', 449, 4, 26, 861039) One is filled with shame and horror at the discovery that there are places (in the twentieth century) in a city, which claims to be the capital of a
('60', 450, 0, 1, 861188) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 451
('60', 450, 1, 2, 861232) big Province and which has a developed public life, where large groups of men, women and children lead a paralysed existence in the midst of all this filth and dirt.
('60', 450, 1, 3, 861398) Who can belittle the importance of physical surroundings upon man’s character?
('60', 450, 1, 4, 861477) Little wonder, then, that the “untouchable” is now lost to all sense of the clean and the beautiful in life.
('60', 450, 1, 5, 861586) The tyranny of society sits tight upon him; he has little initiative and less independence left.
('60', 450, 1, 6, 861683) It is hard to write with restraint about the conditions in which the Mehtar is compelled to live, and we would request earnestly all those who are interested in social welfare work to verify for themselves the accuracy of our statements by visits to, say, the Phul Talab, Bhainsa Godown or the Kali Mai ka Than in Allahabad.
('60', 450, 1, 7, 862008) Of Kali Mai ka Than the report says:
('60', 450, 2, 8, 862045) According to Municipal estimates, 1192 men and 1220 women visit these latrines daily.
('60', 450, 2, 9, 862131) There is no light in these latrines, with the result that men have to ease themselves in the evening in the open space outside.
('60', 450, 2, 10, 862259) The inmates of the houses facing the latrine use the space between the latrines and their houses as their courtyard and playground for their children.
('60', 450, 2, 11, 862410) There is no wall round the latrine, with the result that the lower part of the person using them can be seen from the houses of sweepers.
('60', 450, 2, 12, 862548) There are separate blocks for men and women in this latrine, but the wall dividing the blocks is low and a man who stands on the khuddi can see the women on the other side.
('60', 450, 2, 13, 862721) There is only one tap and that, too, near the latrine and quite close to a cesspool.
('60', 450, 2, 14, 862806) The water supply is irregular and wholly inadequate.
('60', 450, 2, 15, 862859) The tap is used both for cleaning the latrines and bathing and domestic purposes.
('60', 450, 2, 16, 862941) The cesspools attached to the latrines often overflow with urine and are in a most insanitary condition.
('60', 450, 2, 17, 863046) Sweepers have to go down into the cesspools barefooted for the purpose of cleaning them thoroughly.
('60', 450, 2, 18, 863146) Both the land lying about the locality and the main lane are kutcha and get muddy in the rainy season.
('60', 450, 2, 19, 863249) There is no platform for transferring night soil from the public and private latrines into the night soil carts.
('60', 450, 2, 20, 863362) Sweepers have to mount the cart with heavy loads of dirt in order to place the night soil into the carts.
('60', 450, 2, 21, 863468) Most of the receptacles in the latrines are in a damaged condition.
('60', 450, 2, 22, 863536) Being also small, they get filled up soon and filth overflows them and passes along with urine and water into the cesspools.
('60', 450, 3, 23, 863661) The number of night soil carts is four only.
('60', 450, 3, 24, 863706) We have seen sweepers
('60', 450, 4, 25, 863728) throwing the contents of their tokras containing human excreta on the ground
('60', 450, 5, 26, 863805) on account of the carts being too full.
('60', 450, 5, 27, 863845) We claim that the facts stated above
('60', 450, 6, 28, 863882) cannot be challenged.
('60', 450, 6, 29, 863904) In my estimation, everything else in the report pales into in significance compared to this.
('60', 450, 6, 30, 863997) That the other cities, if there was the same investigation as at Allahabad, are likely to show the same woeful
('60', 451, 0, 1, 864108) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 451, 1, 2, 864150) state of things or that the latter has gone on for years would be no excuse for continuing the condition revealed by the report.
('60', 451, 1, 3, 864279) When a snake is discovered in a house, one does not delay its removal because it is also discovered that it had been there for years.
('60', 451, 1, 4, 864413) The plague spot of Allahabad is worse than the imagined snake in the imagined house.
('60', 451, 1, 5, 864498) I hope that the members of the committee and the Allahabad Branch of the Society will not rest nor give rest to the Municipality of Allahabad, till the disgraceful condition is radically altered and these most useful members of society are decently housed in a decent spot.
('60', 451, 1, 6, 864772) I know a case in which fifteen hundred inhabitants of a plague spot were removed within twenty four hours of the outbreak of plague in their midst and housed in tents till permanent quarters were found elsewhere.
('60', 451, 1, 7, 864985) 1 This case demands no less summary measures.
('60', 451, 1, 8, 865031) And if Allahabad leads the way, I have little doubt that the other cities will follow.
