('60', 451, 3, 10, 865137) 540. A HARIJAN SEVAK’S DIFFICULTY
('60', 451, 4, 11, 865171) A Harijan sevak writes: You know that the anti untouchability worker has to suffer at the hands of the orthodox priests.
('60', 451, 4, 12, 865292) They refuse to officiate at religious ceremonies at the homes of such workers.
('60', 451, 4, 13, 865371) You have stated 2 in the Harijan No.
('60', 451, 4, 14, 865408) 4 that the reformers should learn to dispense with the outward form.
('60', 451, 4, 15, 865477) Will you not dispense with the priest altogether?
('60', 451, 4, 16, 865527) The latter works only for money.
('60', 451, 4, 17, 865560) Many priests to my knowledge do not even pronounce the mantras accurately; still fewer know their meaning.
('60', 451, 4, 18, 865667) They trade on the gullibility of the public.
('60', 451, 4, 19, 865712) What merit can such officiating carry with it?
('60', 451, 4, 20, 865759) Such humbug is more rampant at places of pilgrimage than elsewhere.
('60', 451, 4, 21, 865827) I am myself a Brahmin.
('60', 451, 4, 22, 865850) The upanayanam ceremony was performed upon me when I was 13 years old.
('60', 451, 4, 23, 865921) At the end of the ceremony, the priest said I was a Shudra up to the time that I was without the sacred thread, but that, having put on the sacred thread, I became a Brahmin.
('60', 451, 4, 24, 866096) I had to repeat this formula before my parents when I went to make obeisance to
('60', 451, 5, 25, 866176) 1 Vide “An Autobiography—Part IV, Chapter XVII”, Location in Flames.
('60', 451, 5, 26, 866245) 2 Vide “What should Harijans Do?”, 5 3 1933.
('60', 452, 0, 1, 866290) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 453
('60', 452, 1, 2, 866334) Here the idea given to me was that after having taken the sacred thread I had risen to a higher status.
('60', 452, 1, 3, 866438) How do you reconcile this with your claim that there is no high and low status in Hinduism?
('60', 452, 1, 4, 866530) I want to tell you another thing.
('60', 452, 1, 5, 866564) When I was at school, our class had a debate on untouchability.
('60', 452, 1, 6, 866628) An orthodox teacher presided on the occasion.
('60', 452, 1, 7, 866674) I remember his having said something like this: Our womenfolk become untouchable every month and are treated like any other untouchable.
('60', 452, 1, 8, 866811) Then, why should we not observe such untouchability regarding those who are called untouchables?
('60', 452, 1, 9, 866908) I have considerably abridged what is a long letter from this correspondent.
('60', 452, 1, 10, 866984) What he says about the ignorance of many priests and the show that they make of learning is unfortunately only too true.
('60', 452, 1, 11, 867105) The remedy for it is a general levelling up of the character of the people and the spread of the right stamp of education, including a workable knowledge of Sanskrit.
('60', 452, 1, 12, 867272) I believe in the great power which Vivekananda used to ascribe to Sanskrit.
('60', 452, 1, 13, 867348) We are unnecessarily frightened by the difficulty of learning Sanskrit.
('60', 452, 1, 14, 867420) For a persevering student it is no more difficult than any of the other languages.
('60', 452, 1, 15, 867503) I do not mean that we can easily gain a knowledge of Sanskrit that would enable us to understand the intricacies of ancient texts, but I do suggest that to gain a workable knowledge of Sanskrit, to acquire the correct pronunciation, so as to be able to know whether the priest is performing his task correctly or whether a pandit is misleading us, is not a difficult task, certainly not one tenth as difficult as it is to acquire an equivalent knowledge of English.
('60', 452, 1, 16, 867969) And then it must not be forgotten that such a knowledge of Sanskrit gives one a master key to the knowledge of the majority of Indian languages, not excluding the Southern group.
('60', 452, 1, 17, 868148) But I must not stray away from my subject.
('60', 452, 1, 18, 868191) Till this happy day arrives, we have to do the best we can with the tools at our disposal.
('60', 452, 1, 19, 868282) And if we cannot get a trustworthy Brahmin priest to officiate, the Bhagavata and the later saints have supplied us with an incredibly simple solution.
('60', 452, 1, 20, 868434) At every ceremony, whether it is in connection with marriage, birth or death or any other religious function, the uttering of the sacred name from the heart is enough to ensure the presence and benediction of God at the ceremony.
('60', 452, 1, 21, 868664) The fact is that God is there all the time, only we do not realize it.
('60', 452, 1, 22, 868735) The recitation of the sacred
('60', 453, 0, 1, 868764) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('60', 453, 1, 2, 868806) name, hallowed by the practice of an unbroken line of saints, wakes us from our ignorance and works as infallibly as an electric spark, and immediately makes the presence of God felt in our midst.
('60', 453, 1, 3, 869003) I say this only for those who have faith.
('60', 453, 1, 4, 869045) Those who have none should dismiss it from their minds altogether.
('60', 453, 1, 5, 869112) For them, even the presence of the orthodox priest is a mere mechanical act, an ignorant obedience to custom.
('60', 453, 1, 6, 869222) They derive no advantage, no merit from the act.
('60', 453, 1, 7, 869271) An honest orthodox priest has a place in the Hindu family.
('60', 453, 1, 8, 869330) He is fast losing it by his own folly.
('60', 453, 1, 9, 869369) He may be safe if he sheds his laziness, his ignorance, and, what is worse, his dishonesty.
('60', 453, 1, 10, 869461) The present movement is indirectly intended to effect that reform.

('60', 453, 1, 12, 869672) Who can make the real beginning, if not he who calls himself a Brahmin?
('60', 453, 1, 13, 869744) As for the upanayanam ceremony, though I have discarded it myself, it has, there is no doubt, a deep meaning.
('60', 453, 1, 14, 869854) The sacred thread is a sign of new birth, a regeneration.
('60', 453, 1, 15, 869912) Before the adoption of the thread, there is but one birth, that is the physical.
('60', 453, 1, 16, 869993) The adoption of the thread is a sign of the second birth, that is the spiritual.
('60', 453, 1, 17, 870074) It is a sign of initiation—of a new life of dedication to God.
('60', 453, 1, 18, 870137) It is, therefore, a higher life in the sense of greater responsibility in relation to oneself, but it gives one no greater status in relation to his neighbour.
('60', 453, 1, 19, 870297) Indeed, at the time of initiation, there ought to be a definite realization that from that date one becomes a servant of the poorest and the lowliest.
('60', 453, 1, 20, 870448) And to my mind, the thought that all are Shudras till the ceremony of initiation and dedication is a beautiful and ennobling thought.
('60', 453, 1, 21, 870582) Unfortunately, these rites which were intended to emphasize human duties have been abused for the sake of exploitation and usurpation.
('60', 453, 1, 22, 870717) As to the comparison of the untouchability of the womenfolk with the untouchability that we observe today in respect of nearly 40 million human beings, it is a violence done to truth.
('60', 453, 1, 23, 870901) The temporary untouchability of the womenfolk attaches to a temporary condition of the body.
('60', 453, 1, 24, 870994) The untouchability of the untouchable millions is a hallmark of suppressed humanity and it attaches to birth, irrespective of a change in their condition.
('60', 453, 1, 25, 871149) The one has in its reasonable form a rational basis for it, the other is wholly irrational and based upon an ignorant and selfish interpretation of the Shastras.

('60', 454, 1, 2, 871374) 541. A FRIEND’S WARNING 1
('60', 454, 2, 3, 871400) When you embarked on the great struggle for the liberation of the suppressed classes, I was exhilarated for the time being, but my difficulty began soon after.
('60', 454, 2, 4, 871560) All these days I was debating whether to write you or not, but now the thing haunts me during my sleep and disturbs my meals.
('60', 454, 2, 5, 871686) Hence this letter.
('60', 454, 3, 6, 871705) Years ago my friends and I began work for the untouchables in the hope that they and we and all would forget the very name ‘untouchable’.
('60', 454, 3, 7, 871843) We dreamt that we would do away with separate schools, separate wells, separate sports and the like.
('60', 454, 3, 8, 871944) When, therefore, you began your crusade, I was elated with hope that untouchability would be banished from India and that untouchables would be absorbed in the Hindu mass.
('60', 454, 4, 9, 872116) But I am stunned by what you and others are doing now.
('60', 454, 4, 10, 872171) It is bound to widen the gulf—separate schools, separate scholarships, everything separate for Harijans—and you seem to delight in these things.
('60', 454, 4, 11, 872316) They pain me.
('60', 454, 4, 12, 872330) The 5 crores of Harijans will now become 10 crores.
('60', 454, 4, 13, 872382) Some so called sadhus or sannyasis will become their high priests and there will come into being a new sect in a century or two hence.
('60', 454, 4, 14, 872517) You will be regarded as the founder of that sect.
('60', 454, 4, 15, 872567) Statues will be erected in your memory and it will be said of you that you had separated the Harijans from the Hindus.
('60', 454, 4, 16, 872686) From the way things are going, it would look as if you were making them feel that they were a class apart.
('60', 454, 4, 17, 872793) For they fancy that they gain by being separated from the rest of the Hindus.
('60', 454, 4, 18, 872871) You have made the path of Dr. Ambedkar and Rao Bahadur Srinivasan easy and you have strengthened their hands.
('60', 454, 4, 19, 872981) They will not be absorbed in Hinduism, but there will be cries of “Long live untouchables”, “Long live Harijans”.
('60', 454, 4, 20, 873095) I have not said all these things thoughtlessly, but what I see happening around me pains me.
('60', 454, 4, 21, 873188) You have been trapped and if you do not courageously come out of it, you will harm the very cause for which you were prepared to lay down your life.

('60', 459, 3, 4, 880686) MY DEAR C. R., Your letter of 11th April was received by me only yesterday.
('60', 459, 3, 5, 880762) Unfortunate, but there it is.
('60', 459, 3, 6, 880792) There is a delicacy about writing on the fate of the Bills.
('60', 459, 3, 7, 880852) 1 I would be prepared to write to the Viceroy and also to the Secretary of State, if you think it worth while, but I do not feel inclined to write about them publicly.
('60', 459, 3, 8, 881020) It is hardly a dignified spectacle, a prisoner publicly criticizing a Government holding him under its custody.
('60', 459, 3, 9, 881132) You will observe that I have scrupulously steered clear of any public criticism of the Government and I think that I should retain that detachment.
('60', 459, 3, 10, 881280) I would love to put Narasimhan under Dinshaw Mehta’s care, but I know that you do not believe, as much as I do, if at all, in nature cure.
('60', 459, 3, 11, 881419) Kaka is taking that cure at Sinhagad at present and Sinhagad is a very fine secluded sanatorium.
('60', 459, 3, 12, 881516) It is only a few miles from Poona.
('60', 459, 3, 13, 881551) If you will not send him to Sinhagad you should send him to the Mysore sanatorium.
('60', 459, 3, 14, 881634) Papa was bound to improve on your reaching there.
('60', 459, 3, 15, 881684) I have made my suggestion about her also.

('60', 464, 1, 2, 888262) 555. ANSWERS TO CORRESPONDENTS 1
('60', 464, 2, 3, 888295) MORE ABOUT TEMPLE ENTRY 2
('60', 464, 3, 4, 888321) There is no doubt whatever that anyone who has no faith in image worship is not entitled to participate in the movement for temple entry.
('60', 464, 3, 5, 888459) No purpose would be served by allowing Harijans a right to have darshan 3 from the spots you have indicated in the maps.
('60', 464, 3, 6, 888580) only those restrictions should be applied to Harijans as are applied to the other Hindus.
('60', 464, 3, 7, 888670) If the public has any objection to it, it would be better not to permit Harijans to enter the temples just now.
('60', 464, 3, 8, 888782) If the trustees are keen on performing shuddhi 4 of the images, they are entitled to do so.
('60', 464, 3, 9, 888874) Before Harijans enter a temple they should of course be instructed about the general restrictions.
('60', 464, 3, 10, 888973) In brief, I am clearly of the view that in the matter of temple entry coercion has no place at all.
('60', 464, 3, 11, 889073) It is improper to force entry of Harijans into a temple where a majority of the worshippers are opposed to it.
('60', 464, 3, 12, 889184) If the worshippers approve of it, Harijans may certainly visit it.
('60', 464, 3, 13, 889251) In any case, only those Harijans who abide by the rules applied to the general public are entitled to temple entry.
('60', 464, 4, 14, 889367) TRUE MAJORITY 5
('60', 464, 5, 15, 889383) I had recognized the difficulty about the majority at the very time the Bill was placed before me.
('60', 464, 5, 16, 889482) I had told Rajaji that 51 per cent would not be proper.
('60', 464, 5, 17, 889538) I had even suggested an amendment to it, for, I am clearly of the view that the great reform we are trying to bring about cannot become universal so long as there is no clear majority.
('60', 464, 5, 18, 889723) And all of you would have noticed that for that very reason I have tried to accommodate the sentiments of even a lone opponent.

('60', 466, 2, 3, 892703) HARIJANS DON’T CARE 1
('60', 466, 3, 4, 892725) The question is not what they demand.
('60', 466, 3, 5, 892763) The point is what we owe to them and what we have promised them in the open convention 2of the Hindu world in Bombay held under the presidentship of Malaviyaji.
('60', 466, 3, 6, 892924) We have made a promise to admit Harijans into temples and Hindus have pledged to lay down their lives to that end, if necessary.
('60', 466, 3, 7, 893053) Do you remember the statement in Mahabharata?” “Placetruth in one scale and a thousand yajnas in the other.
('60', 466, 3, 8, 893161) The scale of truth will always be lower.” It is unbearable that we should break our promises to the Harijans and to God.

('60', 466, 3, 11, 893442) You say that things would sort themselves out once we educate the Harijans.

('60', 466, 3, 13, 893580) Not that there is no education today.
('60', 466, 3, 14, 893618) But the great misfortune is that it is wrong education that is being given.
('60', 466, 3, 15, 893694) The wrong education has given us wrong lessons.
('60', 466, 3, 16, 893742) It teaches us that adharma is dharma, that sanctimoniousness is religion, that superstition is knowledge, that intolerance is kindness, that indulgence is restraint.
('60', 466, 3, 17, 893908) And that the interpretation of the Shastras consists not in understanding their simple and straightforward meaning but in arbitrarily forcing on them a far fetched and perverse meaning.
('60', 466, 3, 18, 894094) First of all this wrong education will have to be wiped out.

('60', 467, 3, 10, 895425) 556. WARNING TO ME
('60', 467, 4, 11, 895444) I do not wish to give the name of the author of this 1. But everybody knows him.
('60', 467, 4, 12, 895525) He is one of the sincere servants of the country and has rendered exceptional service to the cause of Harijans.
('60', 467, 4, 13, 895637) I, therefore, wish that everybody should read this letter carefully.
('60', 467, 4, 14, 895706) I read it twice over, and pondered over it.
('60', 467, 4, 15, 895750) The correspondent’s warning is justified, and timely.
('60', 467, 4, 16, 895804) The fear he has expressed may even prove true.
('60', 467, 4, 17, 895851) If that happens, I will not repent.
('60', 467, 4, 18, 895887) It will not be the first time that “Man proposes, God disposes” will have been proved true.
('60', 467, 4, 19, 895979) God, though He ordains everything, takes responsibility for nothing; otherwise I would throw all responsibility on Him and disclaim any for myself.

('60', 470, 3, 7, 902562) 558. COMPLAINT AGAINST WOMEN
('60', 470, 4, 8, 902591) I give below the gist of what a Harijan from Karachi has written to me, retaining his broken language as far as possible: The sense of pollution through touch is much stronger among women.
('60', 470, 4, 9, 902780) More so against the Dhed Harijans.
('60', 470, 4, 10, 902815) They throw down to them stale, dirty, rotten left over food.
('60', 470, 4, 11, 902876) The women believe that only stale and rotten food should be given to the Bhangis.
('60', 470, 4, 12, 902958) They are convinced that this is proper.
('60', 470, 4, 13, 902998) The Bhangi men and women as a matter of course believe that they are getting their morning meal in return for their scavenging work.
('60', 470, 4, 14, 903131) If they Hindu society stops giving rotten food to the Bhangi and the other communities, I can humbly say that pollution will disappear from the women.
('60', 470, 4, 15, 903282) Youwill have to plead further with women to shed the superstitious notion of pollution through touch.
('60', 470, 4, 16, 903384) I have given the above as the substance of along letter.
('60', 470, 4, 17, 903441) Untouchability will not be eradicated merely by women giving good food to the Harijan brethren instead of left overs, but if they did that, certainly it would be said that they women had some compassion in their hearts.
('60', 470, 4, 18, 903661) The complaint against women is a genuine one.
('60', 470, 4, 19, 903707) If they wish, they can forthwith effect this reform.
('60', 470, 4, 20, 903760) This does not involve a question of money but only a change of heart.
('60', 470, 4, 21, 903830) The woman in whose heart God dwells can readily accept a harijan as a fellow being.

('60', 470, 5, 24, 904022) By controlling their palate, the women can give a clean share of food to the Harijans without adding to the expense by a single pie.

('60', 475, 3, 4, 912982) DEAR RUDRAMUNI, I thank you for you letter.
('60', 475, 3, 5, 913026) It is because you belong to the priesthood of the Harijan community that I have flet so sore about you.

('60', 475, 3, 12, 913894) Surely, it was a matter for you to welcome when a sister who had but till yesterday been leading an unclean life suddenly resolves to throw off all uncleanliness and adopt a life of renunciation, apart from the economic and the hygienic necessity of removing the hair.
('60', 475, 3, 13, 914163) Do you not understand, as a Hindu, that as a sannyasini, which according to our notion she had become, she cannot keep hair or any ornamentation that would tempt base human nature?
('60', 475, 3, 14, 914344) Lastly, you have not told me that the ticket for her to come to Poona was kindly paid for by a Parsi gentleman.
('60', 475, 3, 15, 914456) Please let me have his full name and address.

('60', 475, 3, 17, 914573) I have no right to do so.
('60', 475, 3, 18, 914599) I have not known you except through N. But because I consider you to be one of my own and because I feel for you I have written this in the hope that it may serve as a warning for the future.

('60', 480, 5, 9, 922359) April 23, 1933
('60', 480, 6, 10, 922374) Dr. Ambedkar 3 having received several communications from Harijan friends as to the desirability of altering the panel system in the Poona Pact 4 came to sound my views about the proposal.
('60', 480, 6, 11, 922564) The substitute suggested is that only those Harijan candidates should be declared elected who succeed in getting a fixed minimum of the votes of Harijans from among the joint electorates.
('60', 480, 6, 12, 922752) Not having ever applied my mind to this formula, I was unable to give him any answer.
('60', 480, 6, 13, 922838) I simply told him that he should first see the different Harijan Associations and others interested, and then let me know their views.
('60', 480, 6, 14, 922973) He asked me, however, to consider the proposal independently, and write to him at London my opinion which I shall try to do.
('60', 480, 7, 15, 923098) Asked why Dr. Ambedkar wanted a change, Mr. Gandhi replied that Dr. Ambedkar stated that so far as he was concerned he was quite satisfied with the panel system, and he would not go back on the Poona Pact.
('60', 480, 7, 16, 923304) But pressure was being brought to bear upon him for securing the above change.

('60', 481, 2, 3, 924149) Will you be prepared to accept the alteration if the others also agree?

('60', 481, 2, 5, 924259) I have not yet considered it.

('60', 481, 2, 8, 924557) My con firmed opinion is that whatever is in the real interest of the Harijans must necessarily be in the interest of the caste Hindus.

('60', 488, 3, 4, 935985) MARY, I was wondering what had happened to you not having heard from you after your departure from the Ashram.
('60', 488, 3, 5, 936096) I was therefore delighted to have your letter.

('60', 488, 3, 7, 936189) The fact is that she postponed her rest too long.
('60', 488, 3, 8, 936239) I hope however that she is now benefiting by the relaxation.
('60', 488, 3, 9, 936300) For it is not so much the bracing air as the relaxation of mind and body that she needs.

('60', 488, 3, 11, 936636) She may take salad vegetables but she does not need them.
('60', 488, 3, 12, 936694) If she carries out these very simple instructions to the letter she will find that she will derive the greatest benefit from the change.

('60', 488, 3, 17, 937210) She will find this to be a complete, effective substitute for milk or coffee or cocoa.

('60', 492, 3, 4, 941794) JAMNA, I very much liked the letter you wrote to me.
('60', 492, 3, 5, 941847) Whenever we see a wrong being done, one may caution and restrain the husband, the father and even the king.
('60', 492, 3, 6, 941955) If the person does not listen to one immediately, one may repeat the caution again and again.
('60', 492, 3, 7, 942049) But this is for the future.
('60', 492, 3, 8, 942077) I do not believe that girls who are kept under strict restraint do not feel passion.
('60', 492, 3, 9, 942162) On the contrary they lose all self control and when the parents learn the fact they too cover it up.
('60', 492, 3, 10, 942263) We should try to discover the middle way.
('60', 492, 3, 11, 942305) We should give freedom to boys and girls and also teach them self restraint.
('60', 492, 3, 12, 942382) Do uncovered heads arouse passion where it is not the custom to cover the head?
('60', 492, 3, 13, 942462) What do you think happens in the Madras Presidency where the girls wear their hair loose?
('60', 492, 3, 14, 942552) The seat of the passions is not outside oneself, but inside—in one’s eyes.
('60', 492, 3, 15, 942627) The impure eye will see impurity everywhere.
('60', 492, 3, 16, 942672) Nevertheless, it is the duty of the senior women to sit together and think about the problem of the girls and draw up instructions for them, which should then be put before the girls and even before the men.
('60', 492, 3, 17, 942880) I have stated above my own point of view so that all of you may think about the problem.

('60', 493, 4, 7, 943905) 590. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('60', 493, 5, 8, 943936) April 26, 1933
('60', 493, 6, 9, 943951) NARANDAS, You must have received the letter 1 which I wrote to you yesterday.
('60', 493, 6, 10, 944029) I forgot to enclose in it a newspaper cutting to be shown to Dr. Sharma.
('60', 493, 6, 11, 944102) I send it with this letter.
('60', 493, 6, 12, 944130) These days I have to write with the left hand and so could not write yesterday all that I wished to.
('60', 493, 6, 13, 944231) I hope to do so today.
('60', 493, 6, 14, 944254) I felt that it would be better if Chhaganlal replied to your comments on his criticisms of you, and so pressed him to do that.
('60', 493, 6, 15, 944381) Accordingly, he has given me his reply.
('60', 493, 6, 16, 944421) After careful thinking I felt that I ought to send it to you, and am doing so.
('60', 493, 6, 17, 944500) I don’t think it proves the necessity of your reforming your method of work in any respect, but I do see in his note his honesty of purpose.
('60', 493, 6, 18, 944641) I have never felt any malice in him.
('60', 493, 6, 19, 944678) But he is suspicious by nature and cannot easily put a straightforward interpretation on things.
('60', 493, 6, 20, 944775) He does not readily see the virtues of the other party, and magnifies the defects.
('60', 493, 6, 21, 944858) This gives an impression to other people that he lacks generosity of heart.
('60', 493, 6, 22, 944934) He does not wish to be ungenerous nor is he ungenerous by nature.
('60', 493, 6, 23, 945000) But people who do not understand him can easily see ungenerosity in him.
('60', 493, 6, 24, 945073) If I have succeeded in convincing you of this, the anger and intolerance which are present in your reply would not be there.
('60', 493, 6, 25, 945198) Your charge that some inmates of the Ashram realized the necessity of better educational facilities for children after they themselves had children, is unworthy of you.
('60', 493, 6, 26, 945367) And it is not true, either.
('60', 493, 6, 27, 945395) It is utterly wrong to believe that Narahari, Chhaganlal and others who subscribe to this criticism are as selfish as that.
('60', 493, 6, 28, 945519) They also are loyal inmates of the Ashram and are good men.
('60', 493, 6, 29, 945579) They a]so care for the good of the Ashram as much as we do.
('60', 493, 6, 30, 945639) They may be—they are—less efficient, but you ought not to be conscious in the slightest degree of
('60', 493, 7, 31, 945737) 1 Vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 25 4 1933.
('60', 494, 0, 1, 945784) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 495
('60', 494, 1, 2, 945828) your greater efficiency or be proud of it.
('60', 494, 1, 3, 945871) Even a mention of somebody else’s inefficiency is an indirect form of self praise.
('60', 494, 1, 4, 945954) I want you to avoid even that, And suppose that children are born to inmates of the Ashram and some new ideas occur to the parents when the children grow up a little, we should not detect in that their selfishness as parents.
('60', 494, 1, 5, 946180) This thing is part of human nature and criticism of it is not just.
('60', 494, 1, 6, 946248) All that we should expect from people is this.
('60', 494, 1, 7, 946295) one should desire for others, children what one desires for one’s own and should make no distinction between one’s children and other’s children under one’s charge.
('60', 494, 1, 8, 946460) We may say that in the measure that this attitude is absent in the Ashram we are imperfect.
('60', 494, 1, 9, 946552) However, no inmate of the Ashram should say that the shortcomings are those of others and not his.
('60', 494, 1, 10, 946651) It is as difficult to know one’s shortcomings fully as it is to attain self realization.
('60', 494, 1, 11, 946740) And I believe that for a person who can see his shortcomings fully and who ceaselessly strives to overcome them to the best of his ability, self realization is no difficult task.
('60', 494, 1, 12, 946919) I, therefore, certainly desire that, if you fed that it was improper for you to make such a statement and that it cannot be proved, you should withdraw it and apologize to your co workers.
('60', 494, 1, 13, 947108) However, I don’t want you to withdraw it only to please me if you yourself are not convinced of its impropriety.
('60', 494, 1, 14, 947221) If you sincerely believe that the reason why people make this criticism against you is that they have children now, let your charge remain till in course of time you learn from experience that it is not true.
('60', 494, 1, 15, 947430) In the Ashram nobody should be asked to apologize merely for the sake of form.
('60', 494, 1, 16, 947509) Such apology would benefit no one.
('60', 494, 1, 17, 947544) For us apology can have only one meaning; namely, that it is sincere admission of one’s error.
('60', 494, 1, 18, 947639) All of us must tolerate the charges which our co workers make against us.
('60', 494, 1, 19, 947713) I don’t ask those who make charges against you to apologize to you, because they sincerely believe what they say.
('60', 494, 1, 20, 947827) I can advise them to apologize only when I can change their belief.
('60', 494, 1, 21, 947895) The same rule applies to you.
('60', 494, 1, 22, 947925) Chhaganlal’s second objection is against your criticism of him for occasionally requiring food to be sent to his room.
('60', 494, 1, 23, 948044) Maybe when he had a guest he found it necessary to ask for a thali for him in his room.
('60', 494, 1, 24, 948132) I see nothing wrong in that.
('60', 494, 1, 25, 948161) If a guest turna up unexpectedly, what else can a person who does not cook in his own house do ?
('60', 494, 1, 26, 948258) And if a guest has turned up just at mealtime, I can understand that one might not like to bring him to the common kitchen, for it might be possible to talk to him only during the meal.
('60', 494, 1, 27, 948444) I do not know whether or not Chhaganlal had these legitimate reasons, but I do not expect
('60', 495, 0, 1, 948534) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 496
('60', 495, 1, 2, 948576) criticism for such things from you.
('60', 495, 1, 3, 948612) Need there be any limit to generosity ?
('60', 495, 1, 4, 948652) Our ideal examples of generosity are king Bali, Yudhishthira and others like them.
('60', 495, 1, 5, 948735) The former lost his whole kingdom through his generosity and Yudhishthira stopped the blood from flowing out of his wound in order to save king Virat from Arjuna’s wrath and, before the latter arrived, got it all cleaned by Draupadi and waited as if nothing had happened.
('60', 495, 1, 6, 949007) our aspiration is that we should be able to do easily in this age all that they could do in ancient times.
('60', 495, 1, 7, 949114) I did not read any complaint on your part in your references to Purushottam 1 and Kanu 2, but saw in them only an acknowledgment that things could not be otherwise in the Ashram.
('60', 495, 1, 8, 949293) Mahadev, on the other hand, supports Chhaganlal’s interpretation and says that you nurse a grievance about Purushottam and Kanu having remained without a knowledge of history, geography, etc.
('60', 495, 1, 9, 949485) Whether it is that or whether it is an acknowledgment on your part of what is inevitable in the Ashram, your own interpretation should be accepted as the only right one.
('60', 495, 1, 10, 949655) Let me, therefore, know what the truth is.
('60', 495, 1, 11, 949698) My own view is that we should not regret any boy having not learnt what passes today as history and geography.
('60', 495, 1, 12, 949809) on the contrary, I believe that the boys could, not have acquired anywhere else what they have in the Ashram.
('60', 495, 1, 13, 949919) Moreover, they have learnt history and geography, too, of the kind to which we attach value.
('60', 495, 1, 14, 950012) I do feel unhappy, but not by way of complaint against anybody.
('60', 495, 1, 15, 950076) I feel unhappy about the interpretation of the Ashram itself.
('60', 495, 1, 16, 950138) I know that we have not been able to give the children all that we were eager to give them.
('60', 495, 1, 17, 950230) Isn’t that my own shortcoming?
('60', 495, 1, 18, 950261) That people do not regard it as such is another matter.
('60', 495, 1, 19, 950317) But when we try to draw up a balance sheet and examine the credit and the debit columns, a shortcoming must be recognized as a shortcoming.
('60', 495, 1, 20, 950457) The Ashram has grown according to the capacities of the persons whom I could attract and the ideas which I could implement.
('60', 495, 1, 21, 950581) I can enumerate no end of shortcomings to be found in the Ashram.
('60', 495, 1, 22, 950647) And still I love it, for it is chiefly my handiwork.
('60', 495, 1, 23, 950700) If I had greater ability and the circumstances had been more favourable, the Ashram would be a more attractive place and there would have been no ground for the criticism which it deserves in some respects.
('60', 495, 1, 24, 950907) My purpose, however, in stating all this is to persuade you not to see the shortcomings of others
('60', 495, 2, 25, 951005) 1 Sons of the addressee 2 ibid
('60', 496, 0, 1, 951036) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 497
('60', 496, 1, 2, 951080) and not to criticize people who might criticize you, only to point out the error in their criticism and accept whatever is acceptable in it and act upon it.
('60', 496, 1, 3, 951237) This will save you from many problems.
('60', 496, 1, 4, 951276) And now a few words about Chhaganlal’s note.

('60', 499, 4, 10, 958347) 593. THE YERAVDA PACT
('60', 499, 5, 11, 958369) [April 27, 1933] 2
('60', 499, 6, 12, 958388) Though an agitation has been going on in Bengal for some time for securing a revision of the Yeravda Pact, I have not felt called upon to take part in the discussion, if only not to embarrass the Bengal friends.
('60', 499, 6, 13, 958600) The Pact is safe so long as even one party interested in it opposes any change.
('60', 499, 6, 14, 958680) At the same time, any opposition for the sake of it would be foolish, if it could be demonstrated that a particular change was necessary.
('60', 499, 6, 15, 958818) I do not pretend to understand the local situation in Bengal.
('60', 499, 6, 16, 958880) Therefore, I felt that it would be presumptuous on my part to take part in the Bengal controversy, till it became absolutely necessary for me to do so and till all the material required for forming a judgment upon it was before me.
('60', 499, 6, 17, 959112) But I assured the Harijan friends who referred to me for my opinion that I would not do anything without consultation with them and that I had till now seen nothing to alter my view.
('60', 499, 6, 18, 959295) Generally I have a]ways held the opinion that, when the principle of reservation is accepted, not imposed, the party in whose interest the reservation is accepted should determine the quantum.
('60', 499, 6, 19, 959488) In the case of Harijans, I have felt further that they could not have too many seats reserved for them, especially if the criterion were not mere untouchability but backwardness.
('60', 499, 6, 20, 959667) Indeed, if I could have my way, I would throw open the list of untouchable voters to all backward
('60', 499, 7, 21, 959765) 1 The letter was completed by Vallabhbhai Patel.
('60', 499, 7, 22, 959814) 2 From The Bombay Chronicle, 23 5 1933; vide also “Letter to B. R. Ambedkar”, 27 4 1933.
('60', 500, 0, 1, 959903) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 501
('60', 500, 1, 2, 959947) classes under one generic name and permit every Hindu who chose to come under that list.
('60', 500, 1, 3, 960036) That would at once correct the atmosphere, and untouchability will be banished at least from politics.
('60', 500, 1, 4, 960139) To this perhaps the sanatanists, too, would have no objection.
('60', 500, 1, 5, 960202) They have never, so far as I am aware, demurred to the representation of Harijans in the legislatures and they can have no objection to anyone classifying himself as a Harijan.
('60', 500, 1, 6, 960379) But all this is merely by way of introduction to what I want to say.
('60', 500, 1, 7, 960448) Dr. Ambedkar’s sudden visit to me has rendered it necessary for me to discuss the Pact.
('60', 500, 1, 8, 960536) At the pressure and invitation of his friends, he suggested 1 that the panel system provided in the Yeravda Pact should be altered to a single election by the joint electorate providing that the Harijan candidate should secure a fixed minimum of Harijan votes.
('60', 500, 1, 9, 960797) I was not prepared to give any opinion during the Doctor’s visit.
('60', 500, 1, 10, 960863) I had not applied my mind to the question at all.
('60', 500, 1, 11, 960913) Moreover, I suggested that he should first secure the opinion of different schools of thought among Harijans and of caste Hindus interested in the question and then ask me for my opinion.
('60', 500, 1, 12, 961101) He said he would do that, but he made me promise that I should consider his proposal independently and give my opinion on it.
('60', 500, 1, 13, 961227) The matter being too important for a private discussion, I propose to fulfil my promise by publicly stating my opinion.
('60', 500, 1, 14, 961347) The new proposal seems to me to be in no way to the advantage of Harijans.
('60', 500, 1, 15, 961422) The only objection to the panel system I have heard is that it is costly.
('60', 500, 1, 16, 961496) This presupposes that there would be a contest almost in every case for coming into the panel.
('60', 500, 1, 17, 961591) It would have been so if the panel was confined to only two, instead of four, candidates.
('60', 500, 1, 18, 961681) Selection of four candidates for contesting each seat would make it unnecessary in most cases to have the primary election.
('60', 500, 1, 19, 961805) Except where Harijan parties are many and are sharply divided, there cannot be more than four candidates for one seat.
('60', 500, 1, 20, 961924) Indeed, for some time to come it will be difficult even to have candidates enough to fill all the reserved seats and, in the majority of cases, there will be no contests whatsoever.
('60', 500, 1, 21, 962106) It would be up to Harijan associations not to have bitter rivalries at the very threshold of their political career and it will be the duty of caste Hindus not to foment divisions in the Harijan ranks.
('60', 500, 1, 22, 962308) I am hoping that the interests of Harijans and other Hindus will never clash.
('60', 500, 1, 23, 962386) But should they do so, the panel system amply provides for the selection in the
('60', 500, 2, 24, 962466) 1 Vide “Interview to Associated Press of India”, 23 4 1933.
('60', 501, 0, 1, 962526) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 502
('60', 501, 1, 2, 962568) first instance of the right kind of the Harijan candidate—right, I mean, from the purely Harijan point of view.
('60', 501, 1, 3, 962680) And yet so long as there is no bitter strife among Harijans themselves, there never need be any primary election, or, for that matter, even a joint final election.
('60', 501, 1, 4, 962844) But the alternative seems to be fraught with grave danger.
('60', 501, 1, 5, 962903) As the very first choice will be general, unscrupulous political parties will put their own Harijan candidates and create divisions among the Harijan ranks with the greatest ease and demoralize the candidates and the Harijan electorate.
('60', 501, 1, 6, 963140) So far as I can see and so long as the system of reservation prevails, the panel system is the best adopted for securing the selection only of those candidates who in the Harijan opinion are best fitted to serve their special interests.
('60', 501, 1, 7, 963377) Whereas I can see nothing but seeds of strife and bitterness in the alternative proposal.
('60', 501, 1, 8, 963467) Though I have written decisively, I am open to reason.
('60', 501, 1, 9, 963522) The argument of expense makes no appeal to me.
('60', 501, 1, 10, 963569) I hope I have shown that, if anything, the panel system is calculated to avoid all needless expense.
('60', 501, 1, 11, 963670) I was amazed, however, to see an interview in the Press in which Dr. Ambedkar is reported to have said his proposal made no alteration whatsoever in the substance of the Pact.
('60', 501, 1, 12, 963846) I venture to dicer from this view.
('60', 501, 1, 13, 963881) Whereas the panel system gives an opportunity to the caste Hindus to have some say in the election of Harijan candidates, Dr. Ambedkar’s alternative may well deprive the caste Hindus of any say whatsoever in the election of Harijan candidates and thus create an effectual bar between caste Hindus and Harijan Hindus.
('60', 501, 1, 14, 964198) It was just to prevent that calamity that I put forth all the force that I could command, and looking back upon the past, I do not regret having done so.
('60', 501, 1, 15, 964352) I put my difficulty very mildly before Dr. Ambedkar at the Sunday interview.
('60', 501, 1, 16, 964429) As I think over the difficulty, it appears to me to be insurmountable, and it is this: The candidate who gets the minimum of Harijan votes provided under the alternative need never have a single vote from the caste voters, for any Harijan candidate getting just the number of Harijan votes required under the proposal will defeat his rival even though he may otherwise top the whole of the list of candidates, Harijan and non Harijan, if he gets just one vote less than the minimum required from the Harijans.
('60', 501, 1, 17, 964939) This would ,amount to an utter negation of the Yeravda Pact.
('60', 501, 1, 18, 965000) It is open to Dr. Ambedkar, as it is to the Bengal friends and any other person, to say that the Yeravda Pact was arrived at under the coercion of the fast.
('60', 501, 1, 19, 965157) I have no sense of shame about it.
('60', 501, 1, 20, 965192) If they accepted the Pact in order to save my life, surely, they had their
('60', 502, 0, 1, 965267) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 503
('60', 502, 1, 2, 965311) consideration, and it comes with ill grace from them now to repudiate a completed bargain.
('60', 502, 1, 3, 965402) The use they can make of their mistake, if such it was, is never to repeat it and not to swerve from the path of duty for fear of sacrificing the life of a person, however dear that life may be.
('60', 502, 1, 4, 965597) I had staked my life not to coerce anybody to do what to them appeared to be wrong.
('60', 502, 1, 5, 965681) I had staked it for achieving a purpose which I thought was altogether noble.
('60', 502, 1, 6, 965759) The way to approach the question, therefore, is not to bring in the fast in the controversy but in cold blood to show to the public that the Pact is inherently bad, either on moral or public grounds.
('60', 502, 1, 7, 965959) It will be time enough to seriously examine the question of reopening the Pact when such a case is satisfactorily made out in the first instance.

('60', 503, 0, 1, 966864) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 504
('60', 503, 1, 2, 966906) You may pursue the conduct of the Ashram as much as you like.
('60', 503, 1, 3, 966968) It won’t tire me.
('60', 503, 1, 4, 966986) It will assist me.
('60', 503, 1, 5, 967005) It will enable you to understand my viewpoint better.
('60', 503, 1, 6, 967059) You must not accuse yourself of want of faith in me or my wisdom because you do not see a point of mine at once or because having seen it you cannot agree with me.
('60', 503, 1, 7, 967223) I am not a perfect being.
('60', 503, 1, 8, 967249) Why should you see eye to eye with me in my errors?
('60', 503, 1, 9, 967301) That would be blind faith.
('60', 503, 1, 10, 967328) Your faith in me should enable you to detect my true error much quicker than a fault finder.
('60', 503, 1, 11, 967421) What I would like your faith to do is that when you cannot convince me of my error you should think that it is likely that I see more clearly than you do in matters where I have thought and experienced more.
('60', 503, 1, 12, 967629) That would give you peace of mind.
('60', 503, 1, 13, 967664) Therefore you should not paralyse your thought by suppressing your doubts and torturing yourself that you do not agree with my view in particular things.
('60', 503, 1, 14, 967818) You should therefore pursue the discussion of the Ashram till you have the clearest possible grasp of all my ideas about it.
('60', 503, 1, 15, 967943) You need not have argued about the man being the worse sinner of the two.
('60', 503, 1, 16, 968017) I have always held that view against most, if not all, of my male friends who have expressed their opinion on the point.
('60', 503, 1, 17, 968138) of course I agree with you also that man’s superiority, if it is that, over the brute creation, consists in his capacity for observing brahmacharya.
('60', 503, 1, 18, 968287) It must therefore be an Ashram ideal to be attained immediately if that were possible.
('60', 503, 1, 19, 968374) There is therefore complete agreement.
('60', 503, 1, 20, 968413) between us so far as the fundamental thing is concerned.
('60', 503, 1, 21, 968470) The difficulty or the difference comes in when we begin to devise ways and means of encompassing the ideal.
('60', 503, 1, 22, 968578) I am becoming more and more confirmed in the view that it must go on as it is now doing, with ample liberty to the manager to regulate fresh admissions.
('60', 503, 1, 23, 968731) Our life should become daily simpler and not more complex.
('60', 503, 1, 24, 968790) We should be progressively more self restrained.
('60', 503, 1, 25, 968839) But we should remain a composite family that we now are.
('60', 503, 1, 26, 968896) The present composition is not the hindrance.
('60', 503, 1, 27, 968942) The hindrance is that we have so few real complete brahmacharis.
('60', 503, 1, 28, 969007) All were broken vessels, all had their own individual passions to conquer.
('60', 503, 1, 29, 969082) But I hold that most of them were and are sincere strivers.
('60', 503, 1, 30, 969142) Therefore we are blind leaders of the blind and ever stumbling.
('60', 503, 1, 31, 969206) When some of us have, by constant striving, become at least matriculates in the effort, we shall certainly do better.
('60', 503, 1, 32, 969324) Therefore the problem resolves itself into each one
('60', 504, 0, 1, 969376) VOL. 60 : 10 MARCH, 1933 26 APRIL, 1933 505
('60', 504, 1, 2, 969420) of us striving to the utmost to approach the ideal.
('60', 504, 1, 3, 969472) Remember my definition of brahmacharya.
('60', 504, 1, 4, 969512) It means not suppression of one or more senses but complete mastery over them all.
('60', 504, 1, 5, 969595) The two states are fundamentally different.
('60', 504, 1, 6, 969639) I can suppress all my senses today but it may take aeons to conquer them.
('60', 504, 1, 7, 969713) Conquest means using them as my willing slaves.
('60', 504, 1, 8, 969761) I can prick the ear drum and suppress the sense of hearing by a simple, painless operation.
('60', 504, 1, 9, 969853) This is worthless.
('60', 504, 1, 10, 969872) I must train the ear so that it refuses to hear gossip, lewd talk, blasphemy, but it.
('60', 504, 1, 11, 969958) is open to the celestial music, it will hear the most distant cry for succour from thousands of miles.
('60', 504, 1, 12, 970061) Saint Ramdas is said to have done so.
('60', 504, 1, 13, 970099) Then how [to] use the organs of generation?
('60', 504, 1, 14, 970143) By transmuting the most creative energy that we possess from creating counterparts of our flesh into creating constructive work for the whole of life, i.e., for the soul.
('60', 504, 1, 15, 970314) We have to rein in the animal passion and change it into celestial passion.
('60', 504, 1, 16, 970390) Read here Chapter II, Verse 64, of the Gita.
('60', 504, 1, 17, 970435) The burden of the Divine Song is not “fly from the battle but face it without attachment”.
('60', 504, 1, 18, 970526) Therefore you and I and every one of us have to stand unmoved in the midst of all kinds of men and women.
('60', 504, 1, 19, 970632) There is no physical seclusion except temporarily for some.

('60', 514, 1, 2, 986834) APPENDIX
('60', 514, 2, 3, 986843) EXTRACTS FROM DR.
('60', 514, 2, 4, 986861) G. V. DESHMUKH’S LETTER TO GANDHIJI1
('60', 514, 3, 5, 986898) Between carrion of an healthy animal and slaughtered meat there is no chemical or physiological difference.
('60', 514, 4, 6, 987006) In the slaughter of animals, the animal bleeds and nearly all the blood being drained away, the slaughtered meat contains less blood.
('60', 514, 4, 7, 987140) In the case of carrion, all the blood remains in the tissues of the animal and consequently the meat contains more blood.
('60', 514, 5, 8, 987262) Decomposition sets in in every dead animal, whether killed or dead naturally.
('60', 514, 5, 9, 987340) This decomposition is liable to set in earlier in moist tissues and tissues containing more blood.
('60', 514, 5, 10, 987439) Carrion, therefore, is liable to decompose earlier than slaughtered meat .
('60', 514, 6, 11, 987514) You might possibly think that meat, when it starts decomposing, is universally rejected by human beings as food.
('60', 514, 6, 12, 987627) It is not only the depressed classes of our country who partake of decomposing meat, but this practice is not uncommon in other parts of the world.
('60', 514, 6, 13, 987775) Gypsies in Europe have been known to be fond of this practice; they go to the extent of even disinterring the dead carcasses of buried animals for food purposes.
('60', 514, 6, 14, 987937) Decomposing fish is estimated to be an article of diet of more than three hundred millions of human beings in the world.
('60', 514, 7, 15, 988058) DISEASED MEAT: But all this is in the case of healthy animals.
('60', 514, 7, 16, 988121) This cannot hold good in the case of diseased animals.
('60', 514, 7, 17, 988176) Many epidemics of meat poisoning have occurred in the West which have been proved to be due to eating of meat from diseased animals, and the diseases in animals which lead to poisoning are not the prominent diseases in cattle which kill them, such as Anthrax and Glanders, but common, pus producing diseases which do not attract so much attention in life.
('60', 514, 7, 18, 988532) Hence the necessity of meat inspection in all civilized countries.
('60', 514, 7, 19, 988599) In Indian villages where this practice of eating carcasses is more common, it will be seen how dangerous this practice is likely to be, on account of animals dying of diseases to which no importance is attached but which are particularly dangerous to human beings.
('60', 514, 8, 20, 988864) The meat of poisoned cattle is not poisonous to eat.
('60', 514, 8, 21, 988917) Poison is used by the Red Indians of America, also the Akas Tribe near Brahmaputra, in hunting for food with poisoned arrows, but the meat of this poisoned animal is eaten by them without any detriment to health.
('60', 514, 9, 22, 989130) Probably the poison used in India is strychnine (kuchala) for killing cattle, but the meat of the dead animal is not poisonous to eat.
('60', 514, 9, 23, 989265) Experiments have been carried on animals, such as dogs, by feeding them on poisoned meat of the animals killed by vegetable poison such as strychnine, escerine, pilocarpine, veratrine and

('60', 515, 1, 2, 989550) mineral poisons such as arsenic and antimony; and meat in all these cases has proved to be harmless.
('60', 515, 1, 3, 989651) The explanation is that, although the poison is strong enough to kill the animal, the poison is further oxidised into a harmless product and the meat, therefore, remains harmless.
('60', 515, 1, 4, 989831) In the case of mineral poisons and caustics, very little is absorbed into the system of animals and the meat, therefore, contains very little of the mineral poison.
('60', 515, 1, 5, 989996) Meat of poisoned animals, therefore, is harmless for eating purposes.
